title: Jazzmania and Tin Palace Offer AvantGarde Chicago Ensembles
description: There is no evidence of collusion, but Jazzminia, 14 East 23d Street, and the Tin Palace, Second Street and the Bowery, have been turning Sunday afternoons into prime time for jazz listening. Each location presents a regular avantgarde concert series on Sundays, Jazzmania at 1 P.M. and the Tin Palace at 3 P.M., and yesterday both concerts featured groups from the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians in Chicago.

title: Analysts Predicting Little Change In Partisan Makeup of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Three incumbent Senators appear to be running well behind in their races for reelection, and several others could easily lose their seats in Tuesday's election.

title: Last 1976 TransAtlantic Crossing by the QE2 Lists 1,400 Passengers
description: On the midtown pier overshadowed by the great black hull of the Queen Elizabeth 2, a large, ruddyfaced Briton in a big chef's hat is standing, paring knife in hand, to sample the fresh fruits and vegetables coming aboard.

title: Carter Says Ford Has a Long Record Without Distinction
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 31In his final campaign appearance in Texas, Jimmy Carter characterized President Ford today as a man with an undistinguished record in Congress unbroken by his tenure in the White House.

title: Todd is Off to Winning Start As Jets Turn Back Bills, 1914
description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., Oct. 31Shaky at the start, the closely watched new Jets quarterback, Richard Todd, recovered his poise to avoid major mistakes today, and his teammates on defense and offense helped steer the club to a 1914 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

title: Jenkins, Rudd Ride to Tie As Capital Show Closes
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 31Rooney Jenkins rode Number One Spy and Terry Rudd piloted Mr. Demenor to a tie for the international open jumper class tonight as the Washington International horse show ended a nineday run at the Capital Centre.

title: The New York Times/Frank C. Dougherty
description: ed in talk of escape by the disgruntled prisoners and attempts by authorities to remedy the situation. The county has even appealed to the U.S. Army to accept some the inmates, at least temporarily, at Fort Dix stockade.

title: Mondale Campaigns in New York In Drive to Win Key Eastern States
description: Senator Walter F. Mondale swept into New York City last night, continuing his downtothewire effort to shore up narrow Democratic margins in some key states and possibly tip the balance in others by enhancing the crucial turnout of his party's voters east of the Mississippi tomorrow.

title: JOHN BROWN'S GRAVE AND OLYMPICS CLASH
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.John Brown's body, which has been amouldering in the grave here since 1859, has become a most unlikely obstacle to the construction of a new ski jump for the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: Suspicious Fire Damages Barn At Reformatory in Connecticut
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 31 (AP)A generalalarm fire of suspicious origin caused extensive damage today to storage barn at the Long Lane Correctional School, authorities said.

title: Two Brooklyn Youths Are Killed With Another in an Upstate Crash
description: CORTLAND, N.Y., Oct. 31 (UPI)Three young persons were killed and three others injured, two of them critically, do a twocar crash here early today, the state police said.

title: Undecided Voters Could Hold Key
description: If the race between Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter is as close as the polls show, then the election may well rest in the hands of a small group of voters who are older, earn less money and are less educated than the average voter, and who are much more likely than most to feel the President is just a figurehead leader.

title: Van Buren's Hometown Trying to Make His Name a Familiar One
description: KINDERHOOK, N. Y.Mount Vernon had its Washington, Monticello its Jefferson. Lindenwald has only Martin Van Buren.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP)The Soviet Union has denied a visa to an American political scientist who was to have analyzed the Presidential election for Soviet officials and journalists, sources at the United States Embassy said today.

title: Prince of Homburg A Weighty, Epic Play
description: The Prince of Homburg was Heinrich von Kleist's last play completed in 1811, the year the author committed suicide. Although the play gradually has come to he accepted as a classic, the production at the Chelsea Theater Center, which opened last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is the professional American premiere. That it should take 165 years for the work to be produced here is astonishing, and it is characteristic of Chelsea's daring that it should he the first to attempt it.

title: Deaths
description: ABRA0MSHarry, on Oct. 29, 1976, aoored husband of Martha, belovou broiner of Bertha Mayer and the late idc, loving uncle and brotherlinlaw. Services Mon., Nov. 1, 11:45 A.M., rite Riverside, 76th St. & Amsierdarn Ave. Interment at Old Mount Carmel Cemetery.

title: N.H.L. Standings
description: Detroit 6, Rangers 5. Buffalo 4, Boston 1. Philadelphia 9, Minnesota 1. Chicago 5, Washington 4.

title: Joyce Fern Seltzer Married To Martin Oestreich on L.I.
description: Joyce Fern Seltzer, ciaugnter or Pell. and Mrs. David Seltzer of Valley Stream, L. I., was married yesterday to Martin R. Oestreich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Oestreich of Lawrence, L. The ceremony was performed in thb Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., 1:)1.,; TTarnirl T Sanerstein.

A Jehovah's Witness Says His Require Solutions Beyond Men
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 31 (UPI)Jehovah's Witnesses were told that only God's government can truly solve the momentous problems facing mankind as they closed their semiannual convention today.

description: In a year of tight campaign financing, conservationists have been a substantial source of help to office seekers.

title: The Nuclear Issues
description: Of all the issues the next President will face, none are more critical than those in the nuclear field, civilian and military, for they can mean life or death for the nationand for all civilization. The policies Jimmy Carter and President Ford promise in this area diverge sharply at a number of points.

title: Life at Home Disenchanting To Young Nigerian Exiles
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 31Bayo, a 22yearold Nigerian who has been studying physics at the University of Wisconsin for four years, came home recently for a month's vacation. After one week, he decided to return to the United States.

title: A Bangladesh Pakistan Link
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 31 (Reuters) The capitals of Bangladesh and Pakstain were linked by satellite telecommunication for the first time last night. Rear Adm. Mosharraf Hossnin Khan, chief of the Bangladesh Navy and one of three deputy chief martial law administrators in charge of communications, spoke on the telephone to Pakistan's Communications Minister, Mumtaz All Bhutto, to open the link.

title: QE 2 Begins Her Final TransAtlantic Crossing of 1976
description: On the midtown pier overshadowed by the great black hull of the Queen Elizabeth 2, a large, ruddyfaced Briton in a big chef's hat is standing, paring knife in hand, to sample the fresh fruits and vegetables coming aboard.

title: Betty Ford Meets Few Cheers In Orchard Street Campaigning
description: Betty Ford, campaigning yesterday on the Lower East Side, received a generally cordial but unenthirsiastic reception. There was not much cheering, but she encountered some booing during a busy walking tour of Orchard Street.

title: MEMORIAL CONTRIBUTIONS

title: U.S. THINKS BRITAIN MUST EXPAND ROLE IN RHODESIAN PLAN
description: GENEVA, Oct. 31The United States is convinced that Britain must play a pivotal role in the transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia or face an escalation of the guerrilla war there, according to wellplaced diplomatic sources.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Nicklaus Wins Aussie Open by 4
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 31 (AP)Jack Nicklaus, blazing away from the field with a fourunderpar 32 on the front nine today, scored a fourstroke victory in the $160,000 Australian open golf tournament.

title: DETROIT WAGES WAR ON SEX BUSINESSES
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31Citizens of this city have recently started a concerted campaign to break the commercial sex industry here and chase it out of town.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: When we expounded recently on our technique for outwitting those airline chefs (traveling economy, we carried aboard a firstclass snack pack that included among other things smoked salmon and smoked sturgeon), the column elicited interesting replies from a few readers who described their own techniques in similar dealings.

title: PolishAmericans Bolster President At Buffalo Church
description: President Ford went to a Roman Catholic mass at St. Stanislaus Church in Buffalo yesterday and began the last Sunday of the Presidential campaign with two happy surprises.

title: Bomb Wrecks Car in Canal Zone; Owner Sued to Bar Panama Deal
description: CCOROZAL, Canal Zone, Oct. 31 (AP) A bomb explosion early today wrecked the car of a United States Canal Zone policeman who had filed a civil suit to halt negotiations on a new canal treaty, officials said. No one was iniured.

title: FOURTH GERMAN SINGER IN MET'S MEISTERSINGER
description: At the season's premiere of Wagner's Die Meistersinger last month, the Metropolitan introduced three impressive German singers: Gerd Brenneis (Walther), Dieter Weller (Beckmesser) and Peter Meven (Pogner). Now there are four, with the Saturday night debut of Frieder Stricker as the apprentice David.

title: Canada in Tennis Sweep
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 31Canada won two singles matches today to complete a 50 sweep of the CommonwealthCarribbean in the firstround of North American Davis Cup play Canada will meet Mexico next weekend in the second round.

title: New Floor Trader Ends A Tradition at Big Board
description: On her first day as a broker on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange last Thursdaythereby becoming the first woman member in the history of the Big Board to spend all of her working time thereAlice Jarcho took a hard fall.

title: Jersey Mariner, Missing 17 Days, Sighted 500 Miles Off Puerto Rico
description: A missing 23yearold Hillsdale, N. J., sailor who set out a month ago to circumnavigate the world alone in a 31foot sloop was sighted by a Coast Guard search plane 500 miles east of Puerto Rico yesterday, adrift but apparently unhurt.

title: List of the Candidates in New York City and Suburbs in Elections Tomorrow
description: Following is a list of the candidates in the New York metropolitan area in tomorrow's election. Asterisk(4) denotes incumbent. Party abbreviations are R., Republican; D., Democrat; C., Conservative; Lib., Liberal; Com., Communist; Socialist Workers; Lab., Labor; F. L., Free Liberterians; Ind., Independence; W., Workers.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Jet Lag and Talk of Ford's Mo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The biorhythm was all wrong on Election Day for someone born July 17, 1913. it said so on the card printed by a 25cent vending machine in the lobby of a Philadelphia hotel where the Ford campaign rested the other night. The card forecast terrifically good health and impressive endurance, but it showed no romance, minimal friendship, mediocre creativity and, most ominous of all, it suggested that leisure plans were in order on Nov. 2 for Gerald R. Ford.

title: Havana Stens Un Airliner Security After Bombing Fatal to 73 and Seeks to Place the Blame on the C.I.A
description: HAVANA, Oct. 31Flying to Havana aboard a Cuban airliner can be a strain.

title: 2 KILLED AND 10 HURT BY UPSTATE GUNMAN
description: MECHANICVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 31Madeline Ryan had just turned on her television set to warm it up for the Mary Tyler Moore show when she heard a gunshot out front.

title: Radio
description: 910 A.M. WNCNFM. Orchestras of the World iymphony No. 1, J.C.F. Bach; Piano Concerto in B minor, Hummel.

title: Books of The Times
description: Naturally it is painful in the extreme to have to contemplate once again the horrors of the holocaust and the six million. Even when fresh details evoke fresh tears, one is only reminded of the impotence of weeping. Still, in New Lives: Survivors of the Holocaust Living in America, it is absolutely necessary for Dorothy Rabinowitz to offer up new or forgotten snapshots of the horror  liberated inmates of Belsen screaming in fear when British doctors tried to approach them with needles and solutions for intravenous feedings; Gen. George S. Patton Jr. moving away from an inspection party to vomit at the sights in a labor camp at Ohrdruf, near Gotha.

title: Statewide E.R. A. Faces Key Test In Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31Equalrights advocates and opponents are looking to a vote on a state referendum here on Tuesday for a clue to the fate of the proposed amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: Returning to Her Home in Quincy. Ruth Gordon Reminisces at
description: QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 31In September 1914 at the age of 17, Ruth Gordon Jones left her home in the Wollaston section of Quincy, and, holding a oneway ticket, she took the Fall River Line boattrain to New York City to become an actress. Last night, on her 80th birthday, Ruth Gordon returned homeas a star of stage and screen, a bestselling author (her latest book, an autobiography, My Side, was published last week), playwright and screen writer  in collaboration with her husband, Garson Kanin. Quincy turned out to welcome her.

title: Irish Imbroglio
description: The Presidency of Ireland is principally a ceremonial post; its occupant has no more political power than Britain's Queen. But one of his functions could be a vital safeguard in a democratic system before signing into law a bill passed by Parliament, he can ask the Supreme Court to rule on its constitutionality.

title: Lois Bewley Depicts Idea of Solitude in Dance
description: Lois Bewleys solo dance concert at Kaufmann Concert Hall Saturday night brought in a full house. A former member of several major ballet companies, Miss Bewley had many friends in the audience, although she was alone onstage.

title: Judge Voids Pennsylvania Law On Signatures for Nominations
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (UPI)  A Federal judge has held unconstitutional a portion of the state election law that he says sets unfair standards for the gathering of signatures by candidates who want to run in statewide primaries.

title: DETROIT TO GET FUNDS FOR RAPID TRANSIT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31Federal transportation officials, in what one of them termed a major new departure in policy, have commtted $600 million for a rapid transit system in southeastern Michigan to be used as a rallying point for urban revitalization.

title: West Germany's 2 Worlds: Sober North, Carefree South
description: MUNICH, West Germany  Georg HagnSternecker, a 72yearold Bavarian farmer, does not feel out of place wearing a pair of embroidered Lederhosen and a green Alpine hat in the elegant streets of Munich. Why not? he says. Munich is Bavaria too, isn't it?

title: Halloween Campus FreeforAll
description: CHAMPAIGN, 111., Oct. 31 (UPI)  A Halloween celebration resulted in a wild freeforall involving more than 1,000 persons early today, many of them University of Illinois students jubilant after football homecoming victory. Before the fighting was over, between six and 18 persons had suffered minor injuries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dr. Walter Judd, the former Representative from Minnesota, once wrote: People often say that, in a democracy, decisions are made by a majority of the people of course, that is not true. Decisions are made by a majority of those who make themselves heard and who votea very different thing.

title: Polish Delegation to Visit Russia
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (UPI)Poland will send a government and Communist party delegation to the Soviet Union during the first half of November, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: FOUR LATVIANS REPORTED PUNISHED IN FISH STRIKE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP)Four Latvian dock workers have been sent to labor camps following a strike at the port of Riga to protest meat shortages according to dissidents here.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: ManMade Fiber Prices Weaken For U.S. and Foreign Producers
description: A lag in retail sales curing the summer months and early fall has weakened prices in the manmade fiber producing industry. Polyester filament yarn has been most seriously affected, but weakness is also evident in polyester staple fiber and in nylon.

title: U.S. Will Give F16 Nuclear Capability in Move to Reassure Allies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Defense Department has decided to give the new F16 fighter a nuclear capability, partly to reassure the European allies that the United States will have a continuing ability to wage a limited nuclear war in Europe.

title: Events Today
description: DON'T STEP ON MY OLIVE BRANCH, sa tirical Israeli musical. Book by Chaim Jacov music and lyrics by Ron Eliran; cirected and choreographed by Jonathan Aarmon; at the Play house Theater, 259 West 48th Street, 6:45.

title: Carter's Church Upholds Its Policy by Refusing to Admit Four Blacks
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 31The Plains Baptist Church, where Jimmy Carter is a deacon, locked its doors and refused to hold services today rather than admit four blacks in violation of a resolution passed in 1965 barring Negroes and civil rights agitators.

title: Paul Newman Captures National Amateur Race
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., Oct. 31 (AP)Paul Newman won a national championship today with a twolength victory over Lee Mueller as the Sports Car Club of America's amateur national championships ended.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carter Rally on Eiffel Tower
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP)Pierre Salinger and other Democrats held an 11hour rally for Jimmy Carter at the Eiffel Towel this weekend. It was ton late to get out the vote for the Democratic Presidential nominee, so the 300 Americans, ranging from bluejeaned students to visiting businessmen made it a fundraiser. They paid $7 each to attend the party at a firstlevel restaurant in the 1,000foot high landmark.

title: AIDE UNDER INQUIRY TO RECEIVE PENSION
description: Ira Duchan, who resigned two weeks ago as New York City's Real Estate Commissioner and is now the subject of three investigations, is scheduled to start receiving an irrevocable city pension in two weeks. One city actuary estimated that Mr. Duchan would be eligible for a maximum pension of $25,000 a year.

title: Charles Crocker, a Secretary To the Vanderbilts, Dies at 101
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 31Charles Edward Crocker, for many years secretary to the Vanderbilt family in New York and Newport died at a local nursing home Saturday. He was 101 years old.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: FIRST56,500, cl., 3YO and uo, 1 ??m.

title: Lauda to Stay as Driver For Ferrari Next Year
description: MODENA, Italy, Oct. 31 (AP)Niki Lauda, the former world driving champion, will stay with the Ferrari organization next season, the company said today after a meeting between Lauda and company officials. The Austrian driver lost this year's world championship in Formula One auto racing to James Hunt of Britain after Lauda withdrew from the final race in the season at Japan because of bad weather conditions.

title: Della Femina Agency Lands Two Accounts
description: Last week was a good one for Della Femina, Travisano & Partnerstwo new accounts to announce. And how different they are.

title: Governor for Bank of Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 (Reuters)Arnon Gafny, formerly director general of the Finance Ministry, was sworn in today as governor of the Bank of Israel. Mr. Gafny's nomination followed the withdrawal by the Government of its own nominee, Asher Yadlin, director of the Trades Union Sick Fund.

title: Irving Shapiro, 60, Dies; Served as a Mediator For State of New York
description: Irving R. Shapiro, a labor arbiter and mediator who served for many years with the New York State Board of Mediation, died yesterday in Albany Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived at 338 South Manning Boulevard. Albany.

title: Centrists in Egypt Win Heavily In the First Round of Elections
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31 (AP)Egyptian voters have given the centrist political faction led by Prime Minister Mamdouh Salem 90 of 12 parliamentary seats decided in the first round of elections, according to results announced today.

title: Donald Trump, Real Estate Promoter, Builds Image as He Buys Buildings
description: He is tall, lean and blond, with dazzling white teeth, and he looks ever so much like Robert Redford. He rides around town in a chauffeured silver Cadillac with his initials, DJT, on the plates. He dates slinky fashion models, belongs to the most elegant clubs and, at only 30 years of age, estimates that he is worth more than $200 million.

title: Barclay's Bank of Britain Placed On Arab Boycott Office Blacklist
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31 (UPI)The Arab Boycott of Israel Office has placed the Britishowned Barclay's Bank on its blacklist for violating Boycott regulations, according to the Sauid Press Agency.

title: In Memoriam
description: FARRINGTONAnna. HAPPY Birthay In Heaven, Mom, with Dad and sisters Jewel and Geraldine, SON, PARNELL.

title: Jungle Habitat Plans to Close Zoo in Jersey.
description: Jungle Habitat", the Warner Brothers $10 million drivethrough zoo in West Milford, N.J., which opened in 1972, says it will not reopen next spring.

title: Bridge:
description: The good player ho wishes to polish his defensive skills should certainly acquire How Good is Your Defense, recently published here by Hart it is collection of 110 defensive problems, perhaps the best selection ever in this difficult area, compiled by Aksel J. Nielsen of Denmark and presented by Victor Mollo of England. This 256page paperback is available from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025. at a special price of $3.50.

title: The Bedford Sports Swap Retains Its Proper Tone
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., Oct. 31At first it seemed as though this year's Sport Swap might turn out to be a bit less tony than last year's, which featured a child's whitewater kayak, but then a Gordon setter walked in, one of four pedigreed hunting dogs for sale, and everybody smiled.

title: Going Home to History at 80, Ruth Gordon Recalls Her Side
description: QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 31In September 1914 at the age of 17, Ruth Gordon Jones left her home in the Wollaston section of Quincy, and, holding a oneway ticket, she took the Fall River Line boattrain to New York City to become an actress. Last night, on her 80th birthday, Ruth Gordon returned homeas a star of stage and screen, a bestselling author (her latest book, an autobiography, My Side, was published last week), playwright and screen writer  in collaboration with her husband, Garson Kanin. Quincy turned out to welcome her.

title: News Summary
description: Britain must play a pivotal role, in Washington's view, in a transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia or guerrilla warfare there will accelerate, diplomatic sources in Geneva said. Behindthescenes talks at the Geneva conference on Rhodesia center on a Briton's serving as an interim governor or as chairman of the proposed council of state, part of a twotier temporary regime. (Page 1, Column 1.]

title: HARLEM CENTER AIDS DISTURBED CHILDREN
description: In 1946, when Dr. Mamie Phipps Clark and Dr. Kenneth B. Clark founded the Northside Center for Child Development, some psychologists felt that psychoanalytic theory was the key to the problems of families with emotionally disturbed children.

title: Rail Clerk's Leader Seeks Bargaining Plan
description: The new president of the 275,000member Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks is Fred J. Kroll, a 40yearold Philadelphian, who started his labor career as an accounting clerk on the old Pennsylvania Railroad after graduating from parochial school in 1953. Mr. Kroll, a vice president, was moved up by the union's executive board after C. L. Dennis retired because of illness two and a half years before the expiration of his term.

title: Wings Beat Rangers, 65, On Late Goal
description: The New York Rangers scored enough goals to win many a hockey game last night but couldn't compensate for their defensive shortcomings and lost, 65, to Detroit on a Red Wing goal with 20 seconds to play.

title: Dibbs Defeats Fillol in 4 Sets In Paris Final
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (UPI)Eddie Dibbs defeated Jaime Fillol of Chile in threehour match today to win the $50,000 Paris Grand Prix tennis tournament. The scores were 57, 64, 64, 76. before 3,000 fans.

title: Carter Chances In Jersey Linked To Organization
description: On the eve of the election in New Jersey, leaders of both parties believe that President Ford is the more popular candidate and that if Jimmy Carter is to win it will depend on how well the urban Democratic organizations do their jobs.

title: Children Led to Safety In Skating Rink Fire
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 31 (AP)About 300 children attending a Halloween party were led to safety when a fastmoving fire burned down a roller skating rink in nearby Celoron this afternoon.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Time For a Change
description: SAN FRANCISCOOct. 31At the end, Jimmy Carter has become what he might have been all along the underdog or so it seems, reading the polls that show Gerald Ford drawing just about even.

title: Cowboys Outclass Redskins by 20 7
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Mention Cowboys and Redskins to a football fan and his immediate association could be a battle full of gore and drama with either Billy Kilmer or Roger Staubach leading some kind of late uprising. But such histrionics did not come to pass today because the Dallas team, the methodical Cowboys was too much far Washington. The Cowboys won the game, 20.7 and it was a bland affair, one in which neither Staubach or Kilmer was around at the end.

title: Ragtime Program With 7 on the Piano Hits Its Stride Well
description: GRTF.ENVALE, L. I., Oct. 31 A Ragtime Spectacular bringing together what Dave Jasen, a ragtime specialist who tcaches at the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University, described as the greatest gathering of ragtime stylists in the world right now, filled the Post Center's Dome Auditorium with a lot of lively and rarely heard piano music yesterday evening.

title: CHILE REFUSES TO REVERSE DECISION ON ANDEAN PACT
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 (UPI)Chile has refused to reconsider its withdrawal from the Andean Pact, a regional economic market of six South American nations.

title: Police in India Continue to Make Political Arrests, But Many Critics Are Believed to Have Been Freed
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 31Piloo Mody and Samar Guha two antiGovernment members of Parliament, were sitting in the opposition organization's office the other day discussing something that they have in common. They were both released from jail in recent weeks after more than a year as political prisoners.

title: G.O.P. EXPECTS TO WIN CONNECTICUT RACES
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 31Even behind the brave campaign rhetoric, the Republicans expect to do well in the elections in Connecticut on Tuesday, almost certainly winning another term in the United States Senate for Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and hanging on to the two of the six Connecticut seats in the United States House of Representatives that the Repubslicans now hold.

title: BICENTENNIAL DAY IN KEARNY: Members of the Lyndhurst fire department and one of their clowns cavorting as the Bicentennial Parade passed City Hall
description: The New York Times

title: Boston Music Festival a Mixed Affair
description: BOSTON For anyone prepared to listen, an ancient lesson in esthetics was offered here over the weekend at the World Music Days festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music: more is sometimes less, and bigger is not necessarily better.

title: Concert: ACharleston Premiere
description: The Chamber Music Society of New York started its eighth season yesterday afternoon in Tully Hall, and honored the occasion with a new work composed for it. The work was Stanley Silverman's Charleston Concerto, and those who may have had any idea in advance about the famous dance step of the 1920's were disabused when a harpsichord was wheeled on stage.

title: Labor: Unionists Reserve Efforts For a Final Big Drive for Carter
description: Organized labor has distributed more than 80 million pieces of literature aimed at getting Jimmy Carter into the White House. Its political apparatus has outspent every other interest group. But labor's supreme effort is being reserved for these final hours of the most comprehensive drive in its history to get unionists and their families to the polls.

title: Philadelphian, in Costume, Killed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP)A 19yearold man dressed in a Halloween costume was shot and killed early today during an argument outside a club in the city's Kensington section, the police said. Russell Gillespie was found outside the Bubble Club at 1:30 A.M. with a gunshot wound on the left side of his chest. The police arrested Edward Powers, 32, a bartender at the club, and charged him with murder and possession and a dealy weapon.

title: Triple Crown Eludes Keystone Ore
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 31Just when it seemed Keystone Ore was going to become the first horse since 1970 to win all three legs of pacing's triple crown, clinch 3yearold honors and take a giant step toward gaining the horseoftheyear award, along came Windshield Wiper with a late rush last night to thwart one goal and check the impetus toward the other two.

title: WARCRIMES TRIALS STIR GERMAN YOUTH
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Oct. 31 (AP)The war crimes trial of former New Yorker Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan and other defendants revealed to be former Nazi concentration camp guards has produced a flood of questions from German teenagers.

title: Tom Kinder Named U.S. Trust Chairman
description: The United States Trust Company announced yesterday that Torn Killefer would assume the post of chairman of the large commercial and investment banking organization today, replacing Charles W. Buek, who has reached the mandatory retirement age of 65.

title: ABCTV Drops Plan to Lengthen Evening News Show to an Hour
description: ABCTV announced yesterday that it was, no longer planning to expand the Evening News with Harry Reasoner and Barbara Walters from half an hour to 45 minutes or an hour. The announcement came within days of a similar statement by NBC.

title: Ballet: Joffrey Does Balanchine
description: Robert Jaffrey has never hesitated to ask choreographers of genius to provide his company with special ballets. Why ask anyone less? it is a formula that has worked well for the Joffrey Ballet, which presented its first Tchaikovsky Pas ce Deux Saturday evening. Denise Jackson was partnered sensitively by Kevin McKenzie in George Balanchine's luscious showpiece.

title: New York Is FundRaising Capital For Politicians During Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Last December, Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, voted against legislation to provide $2.3 billion in Federal loans to New York City. Last month, Mr. Hartke, candidate for reelection, went to New York City to hold a fundraising cocktail nartv and left with $8,000.

title: TenFour at House And Lots of Goodies
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) As three costumed youngsters pursued the ageold custom of seeking goodies from door to door Halloween night, they used modern communications to keep in contact with their father and mother.

title: Lynn Ann Schaefer Wed Tn Thomas G. Anderson
description: Lynn Ann Schaefer and Thomas Ciardiner Anderson were married yesterday afternoon in the United Church of Rol.vayton, Conn. The Rev. Donald W. Emig performed the Protestant cereThe parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Eugene Schaefer of Englewood, N. J., and Quogue, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. William Gardiner Anderson of Noank, Conn.

title: Meadowlands

title: U.S. THINKS BRITAIN MUST EXPAND ROLE IN RHODESIAN PLAN
description: GENEVA, Oct. 31The United States is convinced that Britain must play a pivotal role in the transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia or face an escalation of the guerrilla war there, according to wellplaced diplomatic sources.

description: Bill Arnsparger was a winner yesterday.

title: Severin Takes Senior Golf
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 31 (UPI)Paul Sevefin of Richmond defeated James Tingley of Glen Cove, L.I., 2 and 1, and took North and South senior men's golf title today.

title: MISS LEAR AND STEW ART OFFER ITALIAN SONG BOOK
description: Hugo Wolf's Italian Songbook was the composer's last major collection of lieder before insanity put an end to his creativity in 1897. These extraordinary songs, 46 altogether, are so concentrated, the musical gestures so subtly distilled, that their essence often eludes singers as well as audiences. As a result, complete performances have always been infrequent.

title: Raiders Top Broncos, 196, Widen A. F. C. West Lead
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 31The Oakland Raiders, alternately lucky and awesome, took another stride toward a fifth straight division title in the National Football League by beating the Denver Broncos today, 196.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Coast Guard said a helicopter survey it was conducting had found large concentrations of oil along the Arthur Kill, which divides New Jersey from Staten Island, with heavy iridescence covering much of Raritan Bay. The 250,000 gallon spill occurred when a Liberian tanker, the Richard C. Sauer, hit a rock and ran aground Friday. Wind conditions, which have held most of the oil concentrated to the shoreline, had stopped, and the current was spreading most of the oil in a thin film over the bay, a spokesman said. Cleanup contractors have 60 men and 16 to 18 vacuum trucks on the scene, The cleanup was expected to take a week for the water and several weeks for some beaches in Staten Island.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at. Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 10 (cable), 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, WGBB, 8 P.M.)

title: Market Place
description: An announcement by the American Motors Corporation last week indicating that it lost money heavily in the 1976 fiscal year has aroused fresh concern in Wall Street that the No. 4 auto maker may not survive.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)Cigarette smuggling has become a booming business that is costing states and cities millions of dollars in lost tax revenues, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration said today.

title: 3 Die in California Fire
description: MOORPARK, Calif., Oct. 31 (UPI) Three persons, including a 1yearold boy were killed in an early morning fire today that was started by a smoldering cigarette and destroyed a singlestory residence. The victims were identified as Arthur Deery, 38 years old, Patricia Wallace, 23, and their son, Arthur.

title: Israel Again Devalues Its Pound
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 (UPI)Israel devalued the pound today for the 13th time since a system of creeping devaluations was introduced last June. The 1.9 percent devaluation raised the dollar exchange rate from 8.40 pounds to about 8.61. Creeping devaluations allow officials to adjust the Israeli pound to group of major currencies including the United States dollar.

title: 3 GOVERNOR RACES COULD ASSIST FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Is a Presidential election year, gubernatorial contests rarely attract much national attention This year there are only 14 such contests, and, with one exception, they involve middlesized or small states of modest political impact.

title: ISRAEL SAYS ARABS SEEK TO JOIN ARMY
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Scores of Christian Arab citizens of Israel have recently volunteered to serve in the Israeli defense forces, apparently in appreciation of Israel's military assistance to the Lebanese Christians in their civil war.

title: P.B.A. CHIEF BIDS UNION AGREE TO NEW CONTRACT
description: Douglas B. Weaving, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, yesterday urged the members of his union to approve a compromise contract agreement with the city, while Philip Caruso a P.B.A. delegate and a rival for the union's presidency, called for its defeat.

title: BRONFMAN ABDUCTION STILL RAISES QUERIES
description: The Bronfman kidnapping trial in White Plains will resume this morning for the 13th day of testimony with virtually none of the major issues in the alleged abduction joined and with defense lawyers continuing to attack the credibility of a long procession of prosecution witnesses.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The ?????/ Bureau of Investigation has announced too arress in Trenton of a 21yearold man and the recovery of a babyalerledly kidnapped from her mother in Texas on Oct. 23. The F.B.I. said Denn's Body Neace had been charged with kidnapping Bobbie Sue Hill, 18 rnonths old, from her mother, Susan Hill, in Fort Worth. The agency said Mr. Neace had been living with Susan Hill there and claimed he was the father of the infant. The mother has denied this, the F.B.I. said. Mr. Neace has been living in the last week at a Salvation Army mission in Trenton, the F.B.I. said, while the baby has been living with his mother, Elizabeth Saranzcak, at 684 Centre Street.

title: RIGOLETTO COMES BACK TO CITY OPERA REPERTORY
description: Verdi's Rigoletto returned to the City Opera's repertory yesterday afternoon, the occasion marking the conducting debut of Michael Chaffy, as well as company firsts for Faye Robinson as Gilda and Pablo Elvira in the title role.

title: Rutherford Wins, Gains in Standing
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP),Johnny Rutherford outdueled Gordon Johncock on the 92d lap today and roar rd to his first victory since winning the Indianapolis 500 with yictery, in the championshipcar portion of the world series of auto racing at Texas World Speedway.

title: Giants Suffer And Shutout In Succession
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 31What a Difference McVay Makes.

title: Auto Prices and Profits
description: The Council on Wage and Price Stability has served notice on United States automobile manufacturers that it sees no basis for any further increase in prices on 1977 cars. Two months ago, when American steel producers rescinded the 4.5 per cent price increase that was to have taken effect Oct. 1, the auto companies did not reduce the 5.8 to 5.9 percent increase they had announced on 1977 models.

title: Buckley and Moynihan in Final Debate
description: Senator James L. Buckley and his DemocraticLiberal opponent, Daniel P. Moynihan, made their final joint appearance of the campaign yesterday in what turned out to be a debate on issues and an exchange of pleasantries with barbs.

title: Venezuela's Auto Makers Face $50 Million Loss This Year
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela's automobile industry, which lost $28 million last year, will be in the red for nearly $50 million by the end of 1976, executives here predict.

title: Wintz Leads By a Stroke In Pensacola
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP)Gary Wintz scrambled out of the pack with a fourunderpar 67 and established a surprise onestroke lead today in the raindelayed third round of the $125,000 Pensacola pan golf tournament.

title: Crabiel Foresees an 85% Turnout At Polls, Despite Apparent Apathy
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31A turnout of about 3.2 million voters, or 65 percent of the record 3.8 million registration in New Jersey, is predicted for Tuesday's general election by J. Edward Crabiel, the Secretary of State.

title: Florida Town Offers Discount To Entice More People to Vote
description: OCOEE, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP)The City Council of this Central Florida town, which stopped taxing its elderly citizens last year, has taken another innovative actionthis one designed to get out the vote Tuesday.

title: Rebel French Bishop Again Defies the Pope
description: GENEVA, Oct. 31Bishop Marcel Lefebvre, the rebel French prelate, today again affirmed his refusal to obey Pope Paul VI, ordaining 13 deacons and an assistant deacon.

title: A Hitler Painting Brings $3,330
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Oct. 31 (UPI) A watercolor the Hitler painted in 1916 has been sold for $3,330 at an auction here at which a silverware set owned by Hermann Goering brought $2,510. Tho Hitler painting City at a River was bought by an are collector. A Spokesman for the Count Klenau auction house said the demand for relics of the Nazi past was very good.

title: Democratic Organizations in New Jersey Called Key to Carter's Chances There
description: On the eve of the election in New Jersey, leaders of both parties believe that President Ford is the more popular candidate and that if Jimmy Carter is to win it will depend on how well the urban Democratic organizations do their jobs.

title: GLOOM IS SPREADING AS PROBLEMS GROW IN WORLD ECONOMY
description: PARIS, Oct. 31In the business and financial centers of Europe an air of gloom is spreading over prospects for the world economy and its capacity to tackle the mounting problems of debt management, sluggish growth and rising unemployment.

title: Buckley and Moynihan in Final Debate
description: Senator James L., Buckley and his DemocraticLiberal opponent, Daniel P. Moynihan, made their final joint appearance of the campaign yesterday in what turned out to be a debate on issues and an exchange of pleasantries with barbs.

title: Accused Sniper A Black Sheep, Neighbors Say
description: MECHANICVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 31Residents of this workingclass, residential town portrayed Kenyon W. Pruyn today as the black sheep of one of the town's oldest and, at one time, most prosperous families. He was in custody on charges of having killed two persons and injured 10 others with gunfire from his apartment last night.

title: PolishAmericans Bolster President At Buffalo Church
description: President Ford went to a Roman Catholic mass at St. Stanislaus Church in Buffalo yesterday and began the last Sunday of the Presidential campaign with two happy surprises.

title: Academic Foundation Chief
description: His new job is bringing Aaron Wildaysky back home to New York City again. I've lived away for almost 26 years, and that's been too long, he said yesterday. It's time for me to come home. The 46yearold Dr. Wildaysky, who is currently dean of the Graduate School of Public Policy at the University of California at News Berkeley, expects, however, to he away from New York for just a bit longer. That is because he is not scheduled to start on his new job as president of the Russell Sage Foundation until Sept. 1 next year.

title: State Planning to Restrict Building in Pine Barrens To Preserve Area'sW ater
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Oct. 31New Jersey's Deputy Environmental Commissioner, Rocco Ricci, has proposed preserving the water resources of the Pine Barrens by making it tough to speculate in land in that wilderness region.

title: A PIECE OF FRANCE IS DYING IN CANADA
description: ST. BONIFACE, ManitobaAlthough formally incorporated into the larger city of Winnipeg five years ago, this middleclass community has struggled hard to preserve its separate identity as an outpost of French culture in the hostile linguistic environment of the wheatgrowing prairie country.

title: Politicians Look To New Yorkers In Fund Drives
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Last December, Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, voted against legislation to provide $2.3 billion in Federal loans to New York City. Last month, Mr. Hartke, a candidate for reelection, went to New York City to hold a fundraising cocktail party and left with $8,000.

title: News Summary
description: Britain must play a pivotal role, in Washington's view, in a transition to black majority rule in Rhodesia or guerrilla warfare there will accelerate, diplomatic sources in Geneva said. Behindthescenes talks at the Geneva conference on Rhodesia center on a Briton's serving as an interim governor or as chairman of the proposed council of state, part of a twotier temporary re7, gime. title: 50State Survey of Probable Electoral Balloting Indicates Final Efforts Could Be Crucial
description: President Ford has scored gains in enough states to give himself close to an even chance of upsetting Jimmy Carter in tomorrow's Presidential election, according to a comprehensive, 50state electoral vote survey by The New York Times.

description: MIAMI, Oct. 31Two women vying for a seat on the State Public Commission have enlivened somewhat the otherwise listless political campaign in Florida.

description: The people passing by the chanting group of Hare Krishna religious devotees had never seemed threatening to Merylee Kreshower, one of the chanters, as she danced and celebrated the name of God within the strangely joyous, saffronrobed sidewalk throng. But now the people, by way of their elected representative, the Queens District Attorney, have taken sides and charged that Merylee has been brainwashed by her religious leaders, a victim, of mind control at the age of 24 years.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 (UPI)Arson specialists are trying to determine the cause of a suspicious weekend fire in which two elderly persons died and 14 others were injured.

title: College Football
description: because Bell is in a battle with Tony Dorsett of Pittsburgh for the Heisman Trophy as the outstanding collegiate football player in the nation.

title: Arab Force Awaited As Lebanon Rivals Fail to Hold Parley
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31A meeting of military commanders of rival factions in Lebanon failed to materialize today as rightwing Christian leaders clearly indicated that an Arab peace plan for Lebanon could not he fulfilled before an Arab deterrent force arrived here.

title: Few Cornorations Have Experienced Right to Convey Political Opinions to Shareholders and Executives
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A handful of icorporations, prodded by the President Ford Committee, have exercised their legal right to campaign among their stockholders and executives on behalf of the Republican ticket this fall.

title: COAST GUARD FINDS MISSING MARINER
description: A missing 23yearold Hillsdale, N. J., sailor who set out a month ago to circumnavigate the world alone in a 31foot sloop was sighted by a Coast Guard search plane 500 miles east of Puerto Rico yesterday, adrift but apparently unhurt.

title: Less Costly Reform
description: WASHINGTON  For two generations, American liberals have associated reform with big Federal programs. But that era is quietly ending, and Jimmy Carter could be an appropriate symbol.

title: Treasury Sale Lacking Appeal For Individuals
description: The Treasury is selling $6 billion of new notes and bonds later this week, but the Government securities that once attracted individual investors have lost much of their lure.

title: Unrest Replaces The Revolution For Portuguese
description: LISBON, Oct. 31The revolutionary fervor that shook Portugal two and a half years ago is gone. Gone are the red carnations, the chants and marches and the general mood of liberated irresponsibility that accompanied the toppling of the rightwing dictatorship.

title: Dorsett and Injuries Are Overtaking Bell in Heisman Race
description: John Robinson, Southern California's firstyear head coach, ordered Ricky Bell out of the game against California midway in the third quarter Saturday. He did not want to risk serious injury to the big tailback, who was running with a couple of nagging injuries. It was a difficult decision for the coach third play of the second half while Southern California was beating California, 20.6.

title: Harlem Opera Society Brightens Dreary Day for Newark Audience
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31It was a dreary day, and the audience inside Rutgers University's Paul Robeson Student Center was smallyet warmly receptive of the Harlem Opera Society's JassOp Ensemble.

title: Carter Says Ford Has a Long Record Without Distinction
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 31In his final campaign appearance in Texas, Jimmy Carter characterized President Ford today as a man with an undistinguished record in Congress unbroken by his tenure in the White House.

title: Washington Post Backs Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)Making its first endorsement of a Presidential candidate in more than two decades, They Washington Post said today that it was inclined to favor Jimmy Carter because he would bring a fresh view to serious problems that lie ahead. The newspaper acknowledged in an editorial, however, that its recommendation was not much of an endorsement. A spokesman said that the last time the newspaper had formally endorsed a Presidential candidate was when it backed Dwight Eisenhower in 1952.

title: G,O.P. EXPECTS TO WIN CONNECTICUT RACES
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 31Even behind the brave campaign rhetoric, the Republicans expect to do well in the elections in Connecticut on Tuesday, almost certainly winning another term in the United States Senate for Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and hanging on to the two of the six Connecticut seats in the United Statbs House of Representatives that the RepubIicans now hold.

title: DR. DOUGLAS D. BOND, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Douglas Danford Bond, a wellknown psychiatrist and former dean of Case Western Reserve School of Medicine in Cleveland, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Cleveland. He was 65 years old.

title: Advertising
description: Philip L. R. Du Val, president of HarperAtlantic Sales, will be leaving that post to join the already assembled highpriced talent that will begin Quest/77 a new sixtimesayear magazine in February.

title: Wendy Alexander is Bride
description: Wendy Alexander and Mitchell Cannold were married yesterday afternoon in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Irving Koslowe of the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Canrrold. The bridegroom is a vice president and producer with Mar Vista Productions Inc., an independent motion picture concern in Burbank, Calif. The bride's parents are Lillian Alexander of Sparsale, N.Y., and Alex Alexander of New York.

title: Woman on Cruise Ship Missing
description: MIAMI, Oct. 31 (AP)The Coast Guard searched today for a Canadian woman who disappeared from a cruise ship during a voyage from Miami to Nassau, the Bahamas, officials said. The woman, identified as Khin Saw Myint, 29 years old, was reported missing by a companion aboard the Veracruz Friday night, said i John Fasolino, spokesmen for the Bahama Cruise Lines. Miss Myint, a native of Burma, is a student in Toronto he said.

title: Cultural Activities in the South Grow With Its Economy

description: Meets at 3 P.M. on the occupied Arab territories.

title: Any Time Girl Scores Upset in Rich Oak Leaf
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP)Any Time Girl, a long shot, scored an upset today and captured the $121,900 Oak Leaf Stakes, richest race in the West for 2yearold fillies. The oddson favorite, Telferner, finished out of the money.

description: LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP)A United States Navy recovery team today retrieved Phoenix missile that fell off an aircraft carrier six weeks ago and dropped to the bottom of the North Atlantic, the Navy said.

title: New Mexico Citizens Back Lawful Election
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 31  A bipartisan group is offering rewards of $1,000 for information leading to the conviction of anyone violating the election laws in New Mexico.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Federal investigators have closely questioned high officials at the Agriculture Department in the last few weeks about alleged attempts by two Congressmen to influence departmental decisions involving rice and other export programs, according to Government sources.

title: Rosa Belfiore, Soprano, in Debut In a Recital of Songs and Arias
description: Rosa Belfiore has a voice as pretty as her name, and she displayed it to generally good purpose in her Alice Tully Hall debut recital on Tuesday night. The New York soprano has to her credit appearances in Italian opera houses, and she has studied in Italy as well as in this city.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Chief Counsel: Inside the Ervin CommitteeThe Untold Story of Watergate, by Samuel Dash (Random House, $10).

title: STOLEN CAR'S OWNER FIGHTS BUREAUCRACY
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 28A stolen car can be an agonizing bureaucratic headache even if it is paid for by insurance, as Edward H. Spencer, a lawyer who lives here, has found out.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: BISSELLLouis. A memorial service will be hold on Nov. 3, 1976 at 11 A.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, 71st St, and Madison Ave., New York City. The family request that flowers by omitted.

title: A CARTER ADVISER URGES HELP NOW FOR ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)Jimmy Carter's top economics adviser said today that would now recommend immediate help, such as a tax cut for the economy, which he said was seriously deteriorating week by week.

title: Has Campaign Cheated Voters?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31In a tough and caustically worded summing up of the Presidential race on the CBSTV Evening News the other evening, Roger Mudd placed the blame for a vapid and egoentric campaign squarely on the candictates jimmy carrer, the Democratic candidate, he dedared, condemned the campaign to an issueless status by making trust and integrity his main themes. President Ford then met his challenger on that battleground with the result, the CBS reporter contended, that most voters have a feeling as the campaign finally draws to a close that they have been vaguely cheated.

title: Driver Crashes in Last Race
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, Oct. 31 (AP)Phil Read, seven times the world motorcycle champion, crashed today in the last race of his career after setting a lap record in the Shellsport 500cc championship final. The 37yearold Read suffered a broken collarbone.

title: One State Contest May Be a Preview of 1977
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31The outcome of a State Assembly campaign normally would be of only limited interest in an election featuring a Presidential race and casino gambling.

title: Ford and Carter Set For TV Pleas Tonight
description: President Ford and Jimmy Carter will make their final appeals to the national electorate tonight in halfhour paid political broadcasts to be seen in prime time on each of the three television networks.

title: Dorothy Eidlitz, 85, Patron of Arts And Champion of Women's Rights
description: Dorothy Meigs Eidlitz, patron of the arts, a champion of women's rights and a successful amateur photographer, died Tuesday at her home in Winter Park, Fla., at the age of 85. Many years ago she was a resident of New York City.

title: Diplomats at the U.N. Wonder Why the American Public Appears Co Apathetic About the Election
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 31 When diplomats sit around these days discussing the American election, it is the apparent apathy of the public more than the policies of the candidates that stirs their interest.

description: Jungle Habitat, the Warner Brothers $10 million drivethrough zoo in West Milford, which opened in 1972, says it will not reopen next spring.

description: The Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission is about to improve the odds for speculators in commodity futures options by promulgating three radical regulations.

title: Middle West Teamster Locals Ratify Pact With Oil Companies
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Oct. 31 (UPI)Union locals representing 4,000 teamsters today approved a threeyear contract agreement with the major and independent oil companies and averted a midnight strike.

title: Dr. Kenneth Heisler Weds Kristen Kenny
description: Kristen Matina Kenny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Kenny of North Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Avery Heisler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Heisler of New York. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Royden C. Richardson of Centerville, Mass., at his home.

title: Shapp Says Chimes Will Ring Out Votes
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP)Gov. Milton J. Shapp believes that the best way to get out the vote is to ring chimes. The Governor has asked that all churches and buildings with bells ring their bells every hour on Election Day, Tuesday, Nov. 2, to remind citizens to vote.

title: On the Waterfront
description: Campaigning in South. Brooklyn's waterfront area, straining to be heard through a publicaddress system that did not work, a dispirited Jimmy Carter hurried through his stump speech until he came to the Wallacelike he likes best, exploiting littleguy resentment against the bigshot crooks who never get punished.

title: ISRAEL SAYS ARABS SEEK TO JOIN ARMY
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 31Scores of Christian Arab citizens of Israel have recently volunteered to serve in the Israeli defense forces, apparently in appreciation of Israel's military assistance to the Lebanese Christians in their civil war.

title: The Larches
description: They are like giant candle flames in the cool, damp woodlands now, preparing to shed their golden tan needles of all American trees of the pine family, only the larches and the bald cypresses are deciduous, and we have no cypress this far north. The larchessome call them tamaracksare among our oldest trees; they and their kind felt the earth writhe and convulse; they knew the long, deep cold of the Ice Ages. And here they still are, brightening the woodland just when the maples, the aspens and the ash are becoming gray and brown snecters of their summer selves. he learned to use larch sills for his early dwellings, since it is slow to rot. And when he learned to travel by water he found that larch keel and ribs made the best boats, since the tough wood holds its shape. Men who lived in cold countries used the larch every day of their lives.

title: PRESIDENTIAL RACE CALLED VERY CLOSE ON EVE OF THE VOTE
description: President Ford has scored gains in enough states to give himself close to an even chance of upsetting Jimmy Carter in tomorrow's Presidential election, according to a comprehensive, 50state electoral vote survey by The New York Times.

description: WASHINGTON  At stake for the nation in the election is our economy security and freedom. The choice is crucial, and I believe vastly more important than many voters understand.

title: Two Make City Opera Debuts In a Solid Madama Butterfly
description: Saturday mght's performance of Madama Butterfly at the New York City Opera featured two firststhe tenor, Ermanno Mauro, was singing his first local Pinkerton, and the conductor, Gigi Campanino, was making his house debut.

title: Dance: Royal Danish Adventure
description: COPENHAGEN, Oct. 31A few years ago when the world was a little younger and a great deal more innocent, the very idea of the Royal Danish Ballet doing anything that might conceivably have been thought of as modern would have been literally inconceivable. The Royal Danes were all light, grace and Bournonville, their famous 19thcentury choreographer who has forever left his imprint on their repertory.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OLD FRIENDS  Three seasoned pros, Myron Cohen, Geraldine Fitzgerald and Allan Jones, are still doing what comes naturally and, judging from their reviews, are teaching today's youngsters in show business more than a thing or two.

title: Mayor of Clyde, N.Y., Employing BusinessLike Methods to Cut $6.5 Million Cost Overrun
description: CLYDE, N.Y., Oct. 31 (AP)  When Louis Delisio became Mayor of this Wayne County village last spring, he took a good look at the books and said: One terrible mess.

title: Cooke and 250 Mourners Attend Services for 25 Who Died in Fire
description: About 250 mourners gathered in front of the charred remains of the Club Puerto Rico in the Morrisania section of the Bronx yesterday to recite the rosary for the 25 men and women who perished in a firebelieved set by an arsonistthat swept through the club a week earlier.

title: Clarence Chamberlin Dead at 83; Flew First Passenger to Europe
description: SHELTON, Conn., Oct. 31 (AP)Clarence D. Chamberlin, who was inducted into the Aviation Hall of Fame last year for being the first American pilot to fly a passenger across the Atlantic Ocean in 1927, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Greek Cypriots, Bowing to Pressure, Are Leaving Northern Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 31The Turkish Cypriots have accelerated their efforts to expel the ethnic Greeks from northern cyprus, and it is widely believed here That by spring this Mediterranean island will be completely divided along ethnic lines.

title: Bears Pin First Defeat on Vikings, 1413
description: A crowd of 53,502 in Chicago's Soldier Field watched Fran Tarkenton eclipse another Johnny Unitas record yesterday, but more importantly the Bears fans saw their team upset the Minnesota Vikings. Walter Payton broke loose for a 39yard touchdown run and Johnny Musso fumbled and then recovered on a 3yard plunge into the end zone for the Bears as Chicago held on for a 1413 victory over the Vikings, who had been the only undefeated team in the National Football League.

title: Youth, 16, Arrested in Murder Of a Queens Widow in Garage
description: A 16yearold youth was arrested last night and charged with the slaying of 54yearold widow, the mother of seven children who was found dead of stab wounds in the chest late Saturday night in the underground garage of her aaprtment building at 8345 116th Street, Kew Gardens. Oueens.

title: THURMOND CALLS REPORT ON 74 TOUR INACCURATE
description: AIKEN, S.C., Oct. 31 (UPI)Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, said today that a published report that he had parlayed a 13day Congressional tour of the Western Pacific into a shopping spree was politically motivated and full of inaccuracies.

title: I.R.S. ACTS TO HALT COALMINE LEASING AS 4 TAX SHELTER
description: Move Follows Wave of Offerings That Resulted as Law Ended Use of 4 Other SectorsThe Internal Revenue Service is rushing to block this season's hot favorite in tax sheltersthe leasing syndications for mining coal.

title: Red Smith
description: His big mistake, Alex Wojciechowicz said, was taking bonus from the Detroit Lions instead of straight salary. Dick Richards owned the club then, said the indestructible, unforgettable, unpronounceable center of the Fordham football teams of the middle 1930's. He offered me a $2,500 bonus and $2,500 for the season. Dutch Clark was the coach. Dutch only gets $7,500, Richards told me. You'll be the secondhighestpaid man on the club. So that first year. 1938, 1 got $5,000 altogether. The next year he raised me to $3,000, which was a $2,000 cut. How Sports much did you guys get for those promoof tions headlining the Four Horsemen? man asked Jimmy Crowley. A thousand The Times game, said Wojie's Fordham coach, keeping his voice low so he wouldn't top Wojie. I made seven or eight thousand in seven or eight games our first year out of Notre Dame, a gang of money then. was sending it home to my mother in chunks. Elmer Layden and I were in New York, and we each had about $3,000 a roll. We were in the old Pennsylvania Hotel. We put the money under the mattress, and it made such a lump we woke up with lame backs.

title: Vazsonyi Opens 32 Sonata Cycle By Beethoven
description: Balint Vazsonyi is apparently able in conversation to allay cynicsim about his current project, which is to play all the Beethoven piano sonatas over two days. The first half of this feat took place Sunday at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association and the second follows Nov. 14.

title: White South African Editor, Friend of Alan Paton, Faces Jail Gladly

And his friend, Alan Paton, the author, says he wishes he were going with him.

title: Defrauder of S.B.A. Sentenced
description: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 1 (AP)Samuel Ray Calabrese of Las Vegas, Nev., and Los Angeles, convicted in September of taking part in a scheme to defraud the Small Business Administration, was sentenced today to serve five years in prison and to pay fines totaling $45,000. He was the eighth person to be sentenced for participating in the fraud scheme, which involved chartering fake corporations solely to obtain loans and loan guarantees from the administration's Richmond office. Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. permitted Mr. Calabrese to remain free under $50,000 bond pending an appeal and the outcome of his trial on a charge of perjury.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1The tires of Jimmy Carter's big chartered plane yelped painfully when they touched down on the runway here today, a Pavlovian signal for the 90 or so journalists, staff members and Secret Service agents aboard to begin their wellpracticed ritual.

title: Employee of Theater is Injured
description: A 36yearold maintenance man was seriously burned early yesterday by steam blowing from a boiler at the Greenwich movie theater, the New York City police reported. The police said Louis Green of 175 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, had been taken to St. Vincent's Hospital with burns of the neck and face. His condition was described as serious but stable. Mr. Green was cleaning the boiler in the theater at Greenwich Avenue and West 12th Street when the steam erupted out: of a valve at about 9:45 A.M., the police said. There was no malfunction, said Lieut. Joseph Fullam of the West 10th Street stationhouse. The steam apparently just hacked up and then burst out.

title: McCulloch Oil Quits Land Development; Loss is $60 Million

title: College Presidents Wives Start to Change Course
description: The college president's wife, the woman who stands in receiving lines tirelessly and smiles with equanimity as hundreds of guests pass through her house, has begun to put aside her teapot. Women's liberation is really sweeping through the college presidents wives, said Joseph Palamountain, president of Skidmore College, whose wife, Anne, has the title of consultant in development and a stipend of about $100 a week. A few presidents wives have declined the opportunity to occupy the president's mansion, preferring to live in homes of their own. Some have their own careers. Others want the role of president's wife recognized as a timeconsuming job, possibly one deserving a salary. Some want recognition of the difficulties of a position described as fulfilling, rich and stimulating as well as sometimes lonely, and reouiring diplomacy, discretion and patience. Marguerite Corbally, whose husband, John, is president of the University of Illinois system, mailed questionnaires in March 1975 to 500 wives of university or college presidents. The 246 who replied said that they averaged 53.1 hours each week on the job20.5 hours in public relations and attending campus and town events, 13.6 hours entertaining and 19 hours supervising the house, including keeping accounts. Mrs. Corbally said that seven had fulltime jobs in their own field. Most had bachelors degrees, but only 12 had graduate degrees.

title: Study Finds Women's Jobs Fared No Worse Than Men's in Recession
description: A new study indicates that women did no worse in the job market than men during the recent recession, and in some respects did better.

title: British Betting Odds Favor Ford
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters) Leading British bookmakers made Gerald R. Ford the favorite today for the first time to win the Presidential election. William Hill took in $38,000 in bets today on Mr. Ford, who is now at 45 odds. Jimmy Carter's odds are 2120. Ladbroke's give Mr. Ford odds of 45 with Mr. Carter even.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Garden State Parkway reported that toll revenues were up almost percent for the year. The arts center, budgeted to produce $1.9 million, has taken in $2.2 million. Revenue from restaurants is 46 percent more than the first nine months of 1975, but revenue from service stations is down almost 9 percent. Miscellaneous income for 1976 now is projected at $175,000, about $25,000 more than originally figured. Tolls produced $45.4 million from Jan. 1 to Sept. 30, and the projected toll figure for the year is $58.4 millionup $2.8 million.
