description: PARIS, Nov. 1The men charged with energy security in the West are growing increasingly concerned over the skimpy results of oil conservation programs and what they feel is a dangerous complacency in the public mind about the problems of future supplies and prices.

title: U.S. Assigns Monitors of Voting In Alabama, Mississippi and Texas
description: LIVINGSTON, Ala., Nov. 1Twohundred and twentyeight Federal observers and 14 United States Attorneys have been assigned to monitor polling places tomorrow in 11 rural counties in Alabama, Mississippi and Texas, Attorney General Edward H. Levi announced today in Washington.

title: LOUIS N. FICKEISEN
description: Louis N. Fickeisen, a retired steel fabricating industry executive, died yesterday at his home in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: News Summary
description: The idea of setting a date for black majority rule in Rhodesia will be discussed today at the Geneva conference, Ivor Richard, British chairman of the parley on Rhodesia, announced. African sources said that two of the black leaders had proposed that next September be agreed on. The proposal seemed to surprise Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia, who said, I haven't given that one any thought, [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Walter Hinick

title: Improving The Next One
description: While the whole ordeal is fresh in mind, the 1976 Presidential campaign needs the sort of review that might lead to improvements for 1980, if there is a 1980. Here are a few ideas.

title: Business Records
description: IRMA WARREN, 1856 Lafabietio Ave., Bronx, N.Y. Llabitat ities 46,063; assets none.

title: 7 Parents Defying Schools By Setting Up Their Own
description: Vowing that they will not allow the city school system to cripple our children, seven black and Hispanic parents from Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx are keeping their 11 children out of school for the second year in defiance of compulsory school attendance laws.

title: Clue to Some Mental Illness Found In Test of Chemical on Rat Brains
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1A profound behavioral effect has been produced in rats by injecting in their brains small amounts of a recently discovered natural animal substance known to have painrelieving qualities.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: The Standings

title: A. V. MILLER, TREASURER OF THE NEW YORK TRIBUNE
description: A. V. Miller, who retired in 1960 as vice president and treasurer of The New York Herald Tribune, died Saturday in Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived at 85 Second Street Garden City. L.I.

title: 2 GambleSkogmo Board Members Resign After Chairman's Request
description: Bertin C. Gamble, veteran chairman and chief executive officer of GambleSkogmo Inc., asked for and received the resignations yesterday of two members of the board of directors. Resigning as directors were James F. Tracy, 57 years old, senior vice president, and Edwin O. Wack, 61, also a senior vice president. They will continue as officers, None of the principals could be reached for comment.

title: Keeping the Club Exclusive
description: I wish our public scolds would ease up on the poor devils among the electorate who won't be voting today.

title: Taxes & Accounting: Oil and Gas Present a Critical Rules Problem
description: Oil and gas accounting is already taking shape as the most critical of several make or break issues facing the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the oftenbeleaguered privatesector body that sets accounting rules.

title: I.R.A. Salutes Maire Drumm, A Slain Leader
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 1To the lament of bagpipes and the sharp crack of saluting pistols, about 20,000 people marched through the Catholic neighborhoods of Belfast today in farewell to Maire Drumm, a folk hero to the Irish republican movement.

title: Vote in Jersey On Casino Issue May Be Close
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1Procasino groups flooded New Jersey with advertisements today in a last appeal to the voters to approve gambling casinos for Atlantic City tomorrow. Most observers believe the vote will be close.

title: Boy Leaps 4 Floors From Fire to Safety
description: A 10yearold Bronx boy, trapped in a fourthfloor apartment fire, jumped from a window yesterday and was caught in a courtyard by the son of the apartment house superintendent, according to Fire Lieut. Robert O'Neill of Engine Company 46.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Dance Umbrella Presents Rooms
description: For the second year in a row, a number of moderndance groups have got together for a Dance Umbrella season. Considering the usual fratricidal feeling among the moderndance companies, such cooperation represents a considerable achievement.

title: PHARMACIES BOYCOTT OF MEDICAID SPREADS
description: A weeklong boycott of Medicaid prescriptions by druggist on Long Island, in Westchester and 20 other upstate counties spread into New York City yesterday in a widening protest over new state and Federal reimbursement guidelines.

title: 23 MORE FOOD OUTLETS FAIL SANITARY INSPECTION
description: The New York City Health Department has cited 23 more food establishments for violating the health code and has reported on final inspections at six previously cited establishments. The lists follow.

title: Voters Appear Willing to Accept Either Outcome Without Rancor
description: YORK, Pa., Nov. 1The last tattoos of the drummers resounded in the cold night air, signaling the end of the Halloween parade on Market Street, an annual event here.

title: Election Day
description: Parking  Sanitation restrictions (no parking 8 to 11 A.M. and 11 A.M. to 2 P.M.) and alternatesideofthestreet regulations (no parking 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.) suspended.

title: Ford's Son Says Carter Victory Would Not Be Major Catastrophe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)Jack Ford says it would not he a major catastrophe for America if Jimmy Carter wan the Presidency.

title: Westchester Panel IsNamed in Dispute Over New Hospital
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 1 The Westchester Board of Legislators named a special panel today to study a proposal for a medical center that the Republican majority leader, Edward Brady, said had been conceived on the assumption that we had the patients and the money for it.

title: Byrne, Shapp Support RacingDates Agreement
description: TRENTON, Nov. 1Gov. Brendan T. Byrne of New Jersey joined with his Pennsylvania counterpart, Milton J. Shapp, in recommending to their respective state racing commissions today a continuation and expansion of the understanding the states have on nonconflicting horseracing dates.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Pro Transactions
description: CLEVELAND (NHL)Recalled Mike Fidler, left wing, from Salt Lake City in Central lengue.

title: Green Haven Reports Increase in Prisoner Clashes
description: Top officials at the Green Haven Correctional Facility conceded yesterday that a new policy of sending the state's toughest convicts to that maximumsecurity prison while transferring lessdisruptive prisoners to other institutions had resulted in a dramatic increase in disciplinary problems at Green Haven.

title: DR. MILTON LEVY DEAD; BIOCHEMIST AT N.Y.U., 73
description: Dr. Milton Levy, a biochemist who was chairman of the biochemistry department at New York University's Dental School from 1956 to 1970, died Saturday in his home at 3935 48th Street, Long Island City, Queens. He was 73 years old.

title: Boeing's Quarterly Profit Up 31.2%
description: The Boeing company, the nation's largest aircraft producer, reported yesterday a 31.2 percent increase in thirdquarter profit.

title: WILEY L. JENNINGS
description: Wiley L. Jennings, who retired last January as a vice president of Westvaco Corporation, paper manufacturers, died Friday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 2 Alpine Road in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Notes on People
description: The Smothers Brothers are breaking up their comedy team after 18 years, and they're not doing it with a bang. Rather, Tommy Smothers, 39 years old, and Dick Smothers, 37, will wind up an engagement at the Town and Country Dinner Theater in East Rochester, N.Y., this weekend and quietly pack in their act. Tommy is flying to London to film what he called a cheaper movie, and Dick plans to return to Santa Cruz, Calif., where he is setting up a winery.

title: Big Crowds Cheer President By CHRISTOPHER LYDON
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 1President Ford whipped up big crowds today in two key states, Ohio and Michigan, and came home for the closing ritual of his Presidential campaign here tonight. He will vote here tomorrow morning and then return to Washington.

title: A Nominee Could Win With Small Popular Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Tomorrow's Presidential election is expected to be so close that it is possible that, for the fourth time in history, a President will take office after receiving fewer popular votes than his opponent does.

title: Shanghai Posters Said to Name Li the New Premier
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 1Wall posters in Shanghai said today that Li Hsiennien, China's Deputy Prime Minister for economic affairs, had been named Prime Minister, diplomatic sources reported. But spokesmen for the Chinese Foreign Ministry said in Peking that the position was still held by Hua Kuofeng, who is also Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Islanders Overcome Canucks, 32
description: VANCOUVER, British cniurntna, Nov. 1 (AP)  Clark Gillies's goal, on the only shot New York took in the third period, lifted the Islanders to a 32 National Hockey League victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: FORD AND CARTER GIVE FINAL APPEALS IN RACE STILL VIEWED AS CLOSE
description: President Ford and Jimmy Carter delivered their final appeals last night to an electorate whose sentiments in today's Presidential election appeared almost evenly divided between the two nominees.

title: Mounties Ride Into Town, Sitting Ever Tall in Saddle
description: Strollers in Central Park on the green Great Lawn, near the Delacorte Theater, saw red yesterday. But there was no rancor on the part of the New Yorkers. Rather there were cheers for the scarletjacketed troop, 32 strong, of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: ANACONDA HOLDERS BACK ARCO MERGER
description: Shareholders of the Anaconda Company yesterday approved the $760 million merger of Anaconda into the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: Networks Spend Millions to Project Election Results
description: The three major television networks are spending millions of dollars to project the Presidential winner tonight long before most of the votes are counted. But the voters may frustrate their effort by making the election so tight that it will be impossible to call it with confidence on the basis of the small sample of votes used by the networks.

title: Advertising Graphics From 1840 to 1900 on Display
description: Advertising has dominated the explosion of graphic arts that began in the 1950's and has never stopped. Until this month, however, our knowledge of 19thcentury advertising graphics was limited primarily to European theatrical posters in the Impressionist and Art Nouveau styles.

description: School Results

title: Namath Gets Call Sunday If He's Able
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI.. Nov. 1An aura of good feeling was present in the Jets locker room today as they watched a television tape replay of yesterday's 1914 victory over Buffalo.

title: BEAME AND 40 CHIEFS PLAN A CARTER BLITZ
description: Trying to preserve Jimmy Carter's slim lead in New York State, Mayor Beame met with 40 Democratic county and district leaders at Gracie Mansion late Sunday to press for a large turnout in Democratic districts in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queensthe banner Democratic counties in the state.

title: Pound is Firm and Dollar Mixed
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 (AP)Currency dealing was quiet around Europe today as the outcome of tomorrow's United States Presidential election was awaited and some markets closed for All Saints Day.

title: Beame Again Rejects Budget Plan Proposed by the Transit Authority
description: Mayor Beame again rejected the most recent budgetbalancing proposals from the New York City Transit Authority yesterday, charging that the authority had more than doubled an initial estimate of its deficit for this year without explaining why.

title: NORMAN C. RAMSEY, 66, LED BANKING INSTITUTION
description: Norman C. Ramsey, a retired savings hank executive, died Sunday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

title: Frank Zappa Not as Inventive With New Rock and Jazz Group
description: Frank Zappa, who was engaging in mockmacabre stage antics long before Alice Cooper and fusing rock and jazz before such fusions became widely popular, has mellowed. His Halloween show at the Felt Forum did include a few comedy bits and a sampling of Mr. Zappa's antisocial song lyrics, but for the most part it consisted of easygoing improvising over various funkstyle rhythm section figures.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association are scheduled to meet at 11 A.M. Thursday at the Holiday Inn, 440 Wet 57th Street., to consider the proposed collective bargaining agreemenT with the city. Details of the recommendations made by the special mediator, Michael I. Sovern, dear of Columbia Law School, have been sent to the city's 18,000 police officers. But the delegate body must act prior to a vote by the P.B.A. membership either by recommending approval or by referring the proposed agreement to members without a recommendation. The delegates could also reject the agreement without sending it to the membership for a vote.

title: Hayes Posts 66 for 275 To Take Pensacola Golf
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 1 (AP)Mark Hayes put together a fiveunderpar 66 and scored his second victory of the season today in the raindelayed windup of the Pensacola open golf tournament, the last individual event on the tour this year.

title: Folger Raises Price For Ground Coffee
description: The Forger Coffee Comnany, the nation's second largest coffee processor, announced yesterday it was raising wholesale prices for the eighth time this year on its ground coffee. The latest increase amounts to 5 cents a pound and is effective immediately.

title: Harvard's Single Wing Nostalgic for Old Fans
description: One of the biggest cheers at Harvard Stadium last Saturday rose from the middleage and seniorcitizen Harvard graduates during the second period of the Crimson's losing effort against Brown. The Crimson was leading, 70, at the time. But it was nostalgia and recognition of Coach Joe Restic's daring that brought the cheers from fans who did not quite believe their eyes for a while.

title: 2 Boys, Left Alone in Queens, Are Killed in Apartment Blaze
description: Two young brothersDavid Watts, 6 years old, and Willie, 2are believed to have been killed by smoke inhalation yesterday when a fire broke out in their home at 7528 Parsons Boulevard, Flashing, Queens, while they were alone.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (UPI)More than 5,000 persons tried to jam their way into the personnel offices at the Cadillac auto plant today looking for jobs that were not advertised and are not available.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: The Charm Of Finding Way Over Countryside
description: When I emerge blinking in the sunlight from some subway exit in New York City, I am always momentarily disoriented, a condition I could easily rectify if I took the time to learn the direction of traffic flow on the various avenues.

description: Viewers weary of the unending campaign coverage yesterday morning could have found a change of fare if they sought it.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP)The Supreme Court refused tpday to hear arguments of the Human Life Amendment Group against a state court order permitting the withdrawal of life supporting equipment from Karen Quinlan.

title: Books of The Times
description: Is the complete male chauvinist capable of loving a woman in a meaningful sense of that word? After reading The Girl on the CocaCola Tray, by Nancy Winters, I would be tempted to say no. in the relationship of Feen Feinstein to his wife Jenny Sue, she is almost entirely an exercise of his ego. I remember years ago remarking to a friend of mine that I nearly felt a stab of envy when I occasionally read in the newspapers of a man killing a woman for love. Don't you sometimes wish, I asked him, that you could be that carried away by love? it isn't love that kills, my friend answered it is the rejected egoHe was right, of course. Killing a woman is the ultimate male chauvinist gesture. Most of the breed are satisfied with torture.

title: Pharmacist Arrested in Shooting
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP)A West Orange pharmacist has been arrested in the shooting death of his wife, authorities said. The Assistant Essex County Prosecutor, Norman Menz, said Ann Jacobson was fatally shot Sunday. He said the woman's husband, Bernard, had been taken into custody by the police and was to be charged with with the slaying. Mr. Menz said that the couple, who had four children had been estranged for about two years and that the husband had moved back home recently. A revolver, believed to be the murder weapon was recovered with all five bullets discharged, Mr. Menz said.

title: 3 ON HELSINKI PANEL CURBED BY KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger withdrew permission today from three Administration officials to accompany a Congressional factfinding commission to countries of Western and Eastern Europe to check on how the controversial Helsinki agreement is being carried out.

description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 1 Nov. 1 (AP)Adriano Panatta, of Italy defeated Guillermo Villas of Argentina tonight in three sets and won the $10,000 first prize in an international tennis tournament. Panatta won, 76, 36, 62.

title: RESULTS
New Northeast Coalitions Fight Area's Decline
description: Several broad regional coalitions involving the Northeastern states have sprung up recently in efforts to mobilize political clout and unite on a program to reverse the region's economic Since last summer governors, state legislators and members of Congress from the Northeast have formed such groups. They have begun to work together to form programs that they hope will stem the loss of jobs, industry, population and revenue.

title: Chess:
description: HAIFA, Israel, Oct. 27The Italian team took the lead in the 22d Chess Olympiad here at the Dan Carmel Hotel with 7 points after two rounds of play. The Italians swamped Andorra, 40, in the opening round and then surprised Iceland with a 31 victory in the second round.

title: CONTRACTS ROSE 7% FOR CONSTRUCTION DURING SEPTEMBER
description: New construction contracts in September exceeded last year's September figures by 7 percent despite a drop in public works, utilities and other heavy construction, the F. W. Dodge division or McGrawHill Information Systems reported yesterday.

title: Printers Strike Six Newspapers
description: CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP)Members of the International Typographical Union went on strike today at five newspapers in Ohio and one in West Virginia owned by Thomson Newspapers, Inc. The strikes were at The Canton Repository, East Liverpool Evening Review, The Marion Star, Portsmouth Times and Steubenville HeraldStar, all in Ohio, and the Fairmont Times in West Virginia.

title: SOCIALISTS IN PORTUGAL REELECT SOARES LEADER
description: LISBON, Nov. 1Prime Minister Mario Soares was reelected leader of the ruling Socialist Party today but despite his appeals for unity a strong radical leftist faction emerged in the closing hours of his party's second national congress.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The candidate was wearing a long brown leather coat Over rust slacks and a pale rust sweater. At the Pittsburgh airport and on the morning flight to New York, several people recognized him but the candidate strolled unnoticed through La Guardia Airport into a waiting limousine. And now with a gold charm dangling from a thin gold chain round his thick neck, Tony Dorsett was having lunch yesterday with the New York Football Writers at the New York University Club. Displaying his instinctive moves as a brokenfield runner, the candidate hurried Sports through the filet of sole but sidestepped of the french fries. But he was not there for lunch. He was there for votes in the HeisThe Times man Trophy election. Johnny Majors, his coach at the University of Pittsburgh, and Al Romano, a middle guard big enough to win the Gallic Wars all by himself, also were there along with Dean Billick the sports information director, alias Tony Dorsett's campaign manager. All over the room were stapled sets of statistics and accolades tenderly titled Heisman Trophy Candidate that Dean Billick had placed alongside each napkin.

title: Carter's Church May Dismiss Pastor For His Role in Dispute Over Blacks
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 1The membership of Jimmy Carter's Baptist Church in Plains, Ga., will be asked some time next week to ratify a decision by the church's deacons to dismiss the pastor for his role in a dispute over whether to admit black activist minister to membership.

title: The SoninLaw of Mrs. Friedgood Says He Had Differences With Her
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 1A soninlaw of Dr. Charles E. Friedgood admitted under defense questioning today in the Friedgood murder trial that he had had disagreements with Sophie Friedgood, the physician's wife, mostly on money matters.

title: C.I.A. With holds Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  A Central Intelligence Agency spokesman said his office would have no comment on the allegation by Prime Minister Castro that the C.I.A. planted an agent in the Cuban Government and had maintained contact with him since 1966. Last month a spokesman for the State Department denied charges by Cuba and Guyana that the C.I.A. was involved in the sabotage of the Cuban airliner that crashed off Barbados.

title: New Architectural School's Seniors Face Grim Market
description: NEWARK, Nov. 1  The New Jersey School of Architecture, a division of the New Jersey Institute of Technology, has engendered great enthusiasm among its faculty and students and the state's architectural community, but its first class of graduates next June may face grim job prospects.

title: Margaret T. Applegarth, Author Of 35 Books About Religion, 90
description: Margaret T. Applegarth, author and lecturer on religious subjects, died Saturday at her Manhattan home. She was 90 years old and lived at 20 East 76th Street.

title: McCarthy to Skip Election Night Gathering of Faithful
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1Eugene J. McCarthy will spend most of election night far above the battlein a jet flying back from the West Coast. 'Dirty Hands,' a Chabrol Film, Little More Than Soap Opera
description: The peculiar state in which its American distributor has seen fit to release Claude Chabrol's "Dirty Hands" in New York prompts me to wonder whether I should review it or search for its pulse. It's alive but unwell, having been cut from its original 120 minutes to 102 and as poorly dubbed into English as anything I can remember seeing, though I do have a short memory for botch-jobs.When it opened in Paris in March 1975, it was called "Les Innocents aux Mains Sales," literally "Innocents With Dirty Hands," which has now been shortened to confuse it with the Jean-Paul Sartre play, which is another thing entirely.The film is set mostly in an elegant house just outside St. Tropez and is about an alcoholic husband (Rod Steiger), his younger wife (Romy Schneider) and the wife's lover (Paolo Giusti), who persuades the wife to join him in putting the old boy out of his misery, for their own fun and profit.When you watch Romy calmly (and idiotically, if you know your crime stories) bludgeon her husband's blanketed form in the bed, without checking to see if he's actually in the bed, you may correctly suspect that Mr. Chabrol is having an off-day and probably an off-picture.Mr. Chabrol's best films are never exactly what they seem. They have elaborately intellectual superstructures that illuminate the action below and are there for consideration if one cares to climb. "Dirty Hands" (at least in this version) has nothing upstairs, but more plot and, long before the twists start coming, one has stopped being interested in even who is doing what to whom. Forget why.The performances are of a pieceuniformly atrocious. Mr. Steiger surpasses his own earlier records for lumbering busyness. Within his first few minutes on screen he (1) gets drunk, (2) whines, (3) pleads for understanding, (4) weeps and (5) goes to bed alone. Going to bed alone is no big deal in most films, but when Mr. Steiger goes to bed alone, it's Napoleon the night after Waterloo.Miss Schneider, who was apparently filmed speaking English part of the time and French part of the time, is a beautiful woman, but even her beauty looks faked in this picture, as if she'd been preserved with wax.I have no idea how much the English dubbing and editing have damaged the original, but the "Dirty Hands" that opened yesterday at the Forum and other theaters is a junk movie.

Screen: Glass Slipper Into Sow's Ear
description: There've been times of tranquility and ease, without pressures, when I've thought to myself how pleasant it would be anticipating a new Hitchock film, or a new Bunel, or an Astaire-Rogers revival, or a classy new stage production of "The Importance of Being Earnest." Familiarity can breed fondness with expectation.But neverexcept possibly during a fever dreamhave I ever thought how great it would be to see an all-new, very lengthy, very elaborate musical version of the story of Cinderella, a movie with music and lyrics by Robert B. and Richard M. Sherman, the songwriting brothers who did "Mary Poppins" and "Bedknobs and Broomsticks," with Richard Chamberlain as the Prince, Gemma Craven as Cinderella and the late Edith Evans shoehorned in as the Prince's old granny. This is not idle talk. It's something every parent should consider before accompanying the children to see the film that opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall. Kids, we know, will sit through almost anything, from awful made-in-Yugoslavia cartoons shown on Saturday morning television to the classic "Wizard of Oz" and, if they have to, "Claire's Knee." If there's an image moving on the screen, children will continue to stare at it. It's adults who need to be protected."The Slipper and the Rose: The Story of Cinderella" is a movie to turn a prince into a frog.There aren't that many films one can take small children to these days that "The Slipper and the Rose" should be dismissed. It's harmless, I guess, but it goes on so long  128 minuteswith so little suspensethere's only so much that can be done about that unwearable glass slipper  that it may well outlast the staying power of children who stuff themselves with popcorn and then drink to excess."The Slipper and the Rose," a collaboration of the Shermans and Bryan Forbes, the director, was filmed partially in and around the "Sound of Music" country of Salzburg, Austria, an association that comes naturally enough during the film as one begins to long for a bit of Julie Andrews's chic and sophistication.The castles are pretty, the costumes are suitably candy-colored and the supporting actors excellent, including Michael Hordern, as the Prince's bubble-headed father; Annette Crosbie, as a most practical fairy godmother, and Margaret Lockwood, as the wicked stepmother.As the young lovers, Mr. Chamberlain and Miss Craven have impossible roles that are less like characters in a fairy tale than pictures on a jar of peanut butter.Mr. Forbes and Robert Sherman, authors of the screenplay, have stretched the fable without mercy, largely to accommodate a whole bunch of forgettable songs by the Shermans, who did very well by "Mary Poppins" and "Tom Sawyer," but who, when off stride, as here, sound as if they're parodying the worst of the Broadway musical theater of the 50's. Like Ross Hunter, they're devoted to an earlier tradition they've worn out.

The Screen: 'Maitresse' In Uniform
description: One night while burglarizing a Paris apartment he thinks is empty, Olivier (Grard Dpardieu), a healthy young man with no scruples about breaking and entering, is caught by Ariane (Bulle Ogier), the apartment's mistress, a sweet, gentle thing who runs a high-class parlor devoted to the needs of well-heeled masochists. It's the sort of place a fellow goes after a difficult day at the office, where he can rid himself of the tensions of being happy and successful by hanging from a cross, being put into a cage, beaten or having his penis nailed to a plank.Olivier is a modern youthbasically unflappable. When Ariane presses him, figuratively, of course, into helping with one of her customers, he goes along with the game. The truth is, he is falling in love with her. He admires the way Ariane goes about her tasks with the spunky dedication of a modern-day, whip-toting, leather-clad Florence Nightingale. She is indefatigable. For Ariane, it's work, work, work. When Olivier suggests it must be exhausting, she says, "Not at all . . . it's fabulous to be able to get into people's craziness, especially in such an intimate way."Because other people's hang-ups always are balmy to someone who doesn't share them, Barbel Schroeders "Maitresse," which opened yesterday at the Baronet, is likely to seem either unintentionally hilarious or disgusting to audiences who are not themselves into fancy S-M. Mr. Schroeder is a serious film maker ("More," "Idi Amin Dada") but I'm not sure it's possible to be serious about sado-masochism in a medium as graphic as film.The explicitness of the scenes of flagellation and nailing (performed, says a program note, by a "professional 'maitresse'") are so bizarre that their place in a metaphor about all love relationships is completely forgotten. The shock effect prevents the film from being about anything more than what we see on the screen, which is a pretty little hustler who makes good money catering to the nutty fantasies of people who can afford to pay.It may be, as Mr. Schroeder suggests in another program note, that there's some S-M in all of us, but there's a big difference between people who must act out their fantasies in elaborately contrived theatrics and those who simply want to torment a cab driver or who make an important appointment they know they can't keep.Mr. Dpardieu and Miss Ogier are two of France's most appealing young performers. Each also suggests a level-headed intelligence and comic self-awareness that are completely out of place in "Maitresse" except in those sequences that have to do with their own love affair. The ecstasy, anger, suspicion and helplessness of that affair makes the ritualized torture scenes seem not a projection of extreme psychological needs but clips from a different movie.

Incredible Sarah,' Film on Bernhardt
description: "The Incredible Sarah," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, is a foolishly romantic movie about the young Sarah Bernhardt as played by Glenda Jackson, who isn't foolish, romantic or remarkably young. Other things being equal, this might have damaged the film, but they aren't.Miss Jackson, striding about the screen in that firm, authoritative, brainy way that can sometimes be quite sexy, finding readings for unreadable lines that may be unexpectedly funny, is the only reason to put up with the cliched lunacies of "The Incredible Sarah" for more than five minutes. In every other respect, the movie is a disaster seemingly calculated to send women back to the kitchen forever.Women were apparently in charge of this movie and all they have shown is that, given the opportunity, they can make movies as rottenly as any group of men. "The Incredible Sarah" was produced by Helen M. Strauss, who, I assume, didn't have to have her arm twisted to hire Richard Fleischer as the director or to accept Ruth Wolff's screenplay. This is no more than a series of talking tableaux that begin when Miss Jackson, impersonating a stage-struck teen-ager circa 1860, wins a Comdie Franaise audition, vowing, "I shall be the greatest actress who ever lived."Thereafter the movie records without comment some of the more bizarre details of the legendary careerhow Sarah had a nobleman's son out of wedlock, slept in a coffin, had temper tantrums and insisted on being paid after every performance in gold. There are ups and downs in her career and Mr. Fleischer and Miss Jackson, without offering us tangible proof, ask us to believe the divine Sarah was the greatest actress of her century. Most publicized, maybe, but greatest? We have only the words of the screenplay to go on.We are shown bits and pieces of Bernhardt performances in "Le Passant," "Phdre," "La Dame aux Camlias" and "King Lear," in all of which Miss Jackson behaves more like Miss Jackson doing educational television than the most startling, most galvanizing actress of her age. No one makes any attempt to recapture the particular Bernhardt style that, some years later, prompted George Bernard Shaw to write several of his most scathing notices as he compared Bernhardt with Dusevery unfavorably."The Incredible Sarah" is an incredibly low-brow variation on the story of the actress who must make horrendous personal sacrifices in the name of her art. Considering the lightweight dopiness of the men around Sarah, though, the sacrifices are not all that great. Daniel Massey plays the admiring Sardou, less as a successful playwright than as the hair-dressing member of an actress's entourage. John Castle, who is the fellow Sarah marries, plays a very bad actor badly. Without exception, all the men in the cast are awful.Miss Jackson is never uninteresting to watch, but her best moments  and I'm not kidding  are her curtain calls, when, exhausted, somewhat dazed, she stands in front of the curtain to acknowledge her audience. One recognizes a real actress even if the bows, considering the movie that contains them, are unseemly.

ALWIN W. NEUMANN
description: Alwin W. Neumann, retired assistant treasurer of the Bowery Savings Bank in New York, died last Friday of cancer at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Yonkers,

title: James H. Buchanan, Industrialist And Mining Figure, Is Dead at 78
description: MIAMI, Nov. 7 (UN)  James H. Buchanan, a Texasborn industrialistfinancier and international mining figure, died Friday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 78 years old.

title: Von Karajan To Aid Class At juilliard
description: Herbert von Karajan, music director of the Berlin Philharmonic, will participate in a threeday program for students enrolled in the conducting program at the Juilliard School, on Nov. 17. 18 and 19.

title: LAMM INSTALLED AS HEAD OF YESHIVA
description: Dr. Norman Lamm, calling for increased governmental support for education, was installed yesterday as the president of Yeshiva University.

title: CONTROL BOARD APT TO MONITOR RHETORIC
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board, which monitors New York City's municipal spending and incdme, will monitor its political rhetoric, too, next year, the hoard's executive director suggested yesterday. The director, Stephen Berger, said he expected the board to speak out against any political promises that seemed likely to upset the fiscal plan.

title: NAVY AIDS NORTHROP IN BID TO SELL IRAN A NEW JET FIGHTER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7With active support from the Navy, the Northrop Corporation, a major defense contractor, is promoting a $4billion sale to Iran of a landbased version of a new Navy fighter plane, the F18.

title: LowKey Fledermaus' Given by City Opera
description: Saturday night's 'Die Fledermaus at the New York City Opera was a lowkey affair. Ilona Simon's Rosalinda, a debut, fit snugly into place dramaticallyshe has had considerable musical comedy experience. But Miss Simon's small voice was swamped in the ensembles, and the florid cadences so vital to the roleto the wellbeing of Strauss's operetta generally for that matterwere too thin to make much of an impression.

title: Miriam B. Leiderman Bride of Dr. Howard Rosenblum.
description: Miriam Brenda Leiderman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Arthur Leiderman of Far Rockaway, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Howard Warren Rosenblum, an intern in pediatrics at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Rosenblum of Brooklyn.

title: India's New Order Has Look of Permanence
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 7A young lawyer who used to talk about entering politics here, to help change what he thought was wrong about India, now talks instead of getting along in an unexciting corporate practice.

title: 2 New Senators See No Conflict Between Congress and Carter
Mefistofele Opens Season Of New Jersey State Opera
description: Boito's Mefistofele has moments of originality and even brilliance, but it is a clumsily written score for the most part, containing many arid stretches and requiring careful treatment from an opera company to bring out its best qualities. The New Jersey State Opera made a game stab at the work in Newark's Symphony Hall in its opening production of the season Saturday night, but the flavor of the performance could not entirety escape the charge of Italian provincial at its worst.

title: Dr. Rowland Mindlin Weds Sylvia Brendler
description: Sylvia Brendler of New York, widow of Ralph Brendler, a publisher, was married yesterday to Dr. Rowland L. Mindlin, also of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: NAVY AIDS NORTHROP IN BID TO SELL IRAN A NEW JET FIGHTER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7With active support from the Navy, the Northrop Corporation, a major defense contractor, is promoting a $4billion sale to Iran of a landbased version of a new Navy fighter plane, the F18.

title: Inaugural Costs Cut by a Change In Construction
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 7Long before the outcome of this year's Presidential election was known, preparations for the inauguration on Jan. 20 were well under wav.

title: Gettyls Seeking Rest of Mission And Skelly Oil
description: The Getty Oil Company announced last night that it planned to buy the remaining stock in the Mission Corporation and the Skelly Oil Company that it does not at present own.

title: News Summary
description: The Lebanese people were urged by President Elias Sarkis to end the bloodshed and ruin of their civil war. In a national broadcast, he appealed to the warring factions to welcome the Syriandominated peacekeeping force being established in Lebanon to disarm and control the opposing camps and end the 18month war. In his first major speech since he took office Sept. 23, Mr. Sarkis stressed that the peacekeeping force of about 30,000 troops would be directly under his command. He said he hoped their stay would be brief. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Bears Lose, Hurt by Wind And Whistle
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 It was windy in the Windy City today and the 17mileanhour northwesterplus a mistake by an officialcost the home team, the Bears, a victory as they lost to the Oakland Raiders, 2827, before a capacity crowd of 53,585 at Soldier FieId.

title: TRADE CENTER LOST $11,9 MILLION IN 1975
description: New York State's Comptroller, Arthur Levitt, reported yesterday that the World. Trade Center lost $11,935,000 last year, increasing a net deficit that was $7.874.000 in 1974.

title: Safer Black Neighborhoods
description: The extent to which black communitiesthroughout the country are plagued by crime is illustrated by a grim set of statistics and by a poignant report recently carried in this newspaper.

title: Robert S. Levy, OneTime Dentist, Owned Hotels in Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 7 (UPI)Funeral services were held today for Dr. Robert S. Levy, a dentist who became a Miami Beach hotel owner. He died Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center at the age of 80.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Shoemaker Captures 2d Big Race in 2 Days
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP)Irishbred Habitony rallied from last place to win the $132,150 Norfolk Stakes for 2yearolds at Santa Anita today. The victory gave Bill Shoemaker the richest weekend in his long riding career.

title: Dionne's 2d Goal Enables Kings To Tie Rangers
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (AP)Marcel Dionne scored his second goal of the game with 6 minutes 53 seconds to play, enabling the Los Angeles Kings to gain a 33 tie with the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at the Forum last night.

title: Advertising
description: The agency president's desk is a lambchopshaped butcher's block 10 feet long and 6 feet wide at its widest part. The office walls are a bronzeorange and the windows open on a terrace crowded with bushes, shrubs and trees. If you peep through the bushes you can see Bonwit Teller's and Tiffany's.

title: Closed Schools in Oregon District Pose Dilemma for the Taxpayers
description: EAGLE POINT, Ore., Nov. 6In mountainous southern Oregon's interior valleys, the lateautumn weather is marked by thick fog that lasts up until midDecember. If you live in such a valley, life becomes somber, some say depressing. This year this feeling is especially true in the Eagle PointShady CoveTrail area.

title: For Those Able to Do It Themselves, HiaStyled Furniture at Low Prices
description: It's goodbye to highpriced furniture for anyone who has the time and inclination to build it themselves. And, why not, indeed?

title: Hollander Displays Dazzling Style With Symphony of the New World
description: The Symphony of the New World, Everett Lee conducting, began its 12th season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with a sturdy program: Brahms's Fourth Symphony, Mendelssohn's Hebrides Overture and SaintSaens's Fifth Piano Concerto with Lorin Hollander as soloist

title: SARKIS BIDS LEBANON ACCEPT TRUCE FORCE AND END BLOODSHED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 7President Elias Sarkis called for an end to bloodshed and ruin today and appealed to the heavily armed warring factions in Lebanon to greet with fraternity and love the Syriandominated peacekeeping force that is being established in the country.

title: Leader of '60 Strike Hailed by Teachers At Union Luncheon
description: SoliCarity Forever and other labor songs resounded through the stately grand ballroom of the Pierre Hotel yesterday as the United Federation of Teachers celebrated the 16th anniversary of its first strike here and saluted its former president, Charles Cogen, who led that walkout.

title: Periodical on Books Being Introduced
description: Pages, a 304page periodical (a periodical but not a magazine) will be the guest of honor at a party at the St. Regis Sheraton Hotel Wednesday when Gale Research, a Detroitbased reference and textbook house, offers its first trade book publication. Pages is not only bookthick but also devoted to books.

title: Kupferman to Play New Works by Friends
description: Meyer Kupferman, the New York clarinetistcomposer, will give a Music by My Friends program on Nov: 29 in Carnegie Recital Hall in which he will play new works written for him by several nonAmerican composers. Four of the latter are CzechJan Kapr, Jindrich Feld, Jan Hanus and Steban Lucky, and two of these are blacklisted in their country, meaning that they cannot have their music played, published or recorded there.

title: LOUISE CRONIN FRY
description: Louise Cronin Fry, a registered nurse and the wife of G. T. C. Fry, an advertising executive, died of cancer Saturday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. She was 62 years old and lived at 75 Mount Hebron Road in Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: 3 Held in Coast PistolWhipping
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (UPI)Three young men accused of invading former Mayor George Christopher's home, robbing his guests and pistolwhipping a man were arrested last night seven hours after the event. The police arrested Travis Foster, 22 years old Leroy Greenwood, 18, and an unidentified juvenile.

title: Gloria Schaffer Sees Antifeminism As Minor Issue in Election Defeat
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 7Not that it mattered very much in the final result, but sexism was still a quiet issue in the Senate election held in Connecticut last Tuesday.

title: An Editor Wages A Bloody War Against Machines By Fabricating Classified Ads
description: Both of the classified advertisements in the Oct. 16 issue of Saturday Review were at the very least intriguing.

title: The Press and the Law
description: FRESNO, Calif.From the perspective of one who recently spent two weeks in jail in defense of the right to keep his' news sources confidential, you might expect a ringing plea for additional protection of the free press. But count this as one vote against proposals for national shield laws or any other attempt to legislate what I think is inherent in the First Amendment.

title: Underground Tunnels Threaten Town in Hungary's Wine Country
description: EGER, HungaryA honeycomb of ancient tunnels, which in various periods have provided Eger with building stone, sanctuary against invading Turks and cellars to mature fine wine, is threatening to destroy this old town.

title: Books of The Times
description: For all the vaunted American inventiveness, this country's major talent has lain in taking over the ideas cf Old World craftsmanship and turning them into massproduction itemsthe spinningjenny and the automobile being few examples. Americans can take an idea, engineer it, break it down into interchangeable parts, die and stamp it, package it and merchandise it with 30second television spots.

title: Cramer Skate Victor
description: PRAGUE, Nov. 7 (AP)Scott Cramer of the United States and Claudia KristoficsBinder of Austria won the men's and women's divisions of an international figureskating meet today. LisaMaria Allen an American, was second in the women's competition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATE PROFITS CONTINUED GROWTH: UP 14% IN QUARTER
description: American business continued to show solid earnings progress in this year's third quarter. Corporate profits climbed 14 percent from the yearearlier levels, exceeding the expectations of many financial experts in view of the economic slowdown since midyear.

title: Dutch Ballet Opens Tomorrow
description: The Dutch National Ballet, making its United States debut, will present two different programs by three Dutch choreographers during a weeklong engagement at the Minskoff Theater that opens tomorrow night. The company from Amsterdam is here on an official Bicentennial visit.

title: Wild Kingdom Is on Display At Bergen Mall
Leader of '60 Strike Hailed by Teachers At Union Luncheon
description: Solidarity Forever and other labor songs resounded through the stately grand ballroom of the Pierre Hotel yesterday as the United Federation of Teachers celebrated the 16th anniversary of its first strike here and saluted its former president, Charles Cogen, who led that walkout.

title: The B1 and the Election
description: Secretary of State Kissinger has read the election returns and let it be known that plans for foreign policy initiatives in the Middle East, China and at the strategic arms talks will be on the shelf for the next few weeks and left for the Carter Administration to handle. The Pentagon, it appears, has no such intentions.

title: Joseph Smith, Pianist, In FirstRate Recital
description: At his third Carnegie Hall concert, Saturday night, Joseph, Smith improved upon the generally favorable impression he made at the first two. This time he was firstrate.

title: Atlantic City Sees Itself Basking in the Sun Again
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 6.Sometimes, decaying resorts develop a certain rich, plummy, Tennessee Williams decadence. But in order to have decadence, some elegance is required.

title: 13 SENATORS IN ISRAEL TO STUDY ATOM PROGRAMS
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 7 (Al')  A delegation of 13 United States Senators arrived here today to begin studying atomicenergy programs in the Middle East.

title: Simpson Ejected for Fighting
description: For the first time in his eightyear pro career, 0. J. Simpson of the Buffalo Bills was ejected from a game yesterday, and the Bills went on to lose, 2010, to the New England Patriots at Schaefer Stadium, in Foxboro, Mass. Mike Haynes, Patriot rookie, returned a punt 89 yards for a touchdown, Sam Cunningham ran for 341 yards, and John Smith booted field goals of 46 and 33 yards.

title: Trudy Zibit Bride of Michael Boxer. Lawyer
description: Trudy Zibit and Michael L. Boxer were married yesterday at Hampshire House by Rabbi A. Allan Block.

title: Nixon TV Interviews Scheduled by British
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)  Former President Richard M. Nixon will be interviewed by David Frost, the British television show host, in March or April, and the programs will be broadcast here next May, the British Broadcast Corporation has announced.

title: The Rhodesian Tangle
description: LONDON, Nov. 7After nearly two weeks of negotiations between white and black Rhodesians, the Geneva conference on the future of Rhodesia has reached a fragile impasse. The single supposedly noncontroversial issue that the British seized on to give some momentum to the conferencethe date for a transfer to majority rule has bogged the talks down and turned the conference into a curious minuet between the bitterly divided black nationalists, the white Rhodesians, the British, the socalled frontline African countries bordering Rhodesia, and the United States.

title: Dixie 500 Auto Race To Marcis
description: HAMPTON, Ga., Nov. 7 (AP)Dave Marcis outraced David Pearson in a classic duel to the finish and won the $160,000 Dixie 500 NASCAR Grand National stock car race today by four lengths. Cale Yarborough, meanwhile, failed by a narrow margin to lock up the national championship

title: Cuba Is Completing Wide Administrative Changes
description: HAVANA, Caba is in the process of completing a major transformation of its administrative system, including a restructuring of the provinces.

title: Nancy Gerstein Married to John C. Novogrod
description: Nancy Ellen Gerstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Gerstein of New York and Atlantic Beach, LI., and John Campner Novogrod were married yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony at the Gerstein's New York home.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
Brooklyn College Beats Marist Eleven. 37 to 25
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 7Jerry Wright scampered for a school record of 203 yards and three touchdowns today as the Brooklyn College football team defeated Marist College, 3725.

title: Seagram Building Owners Plan To Seek Landmark Designation
description: The owners of the Seagram Building, the 38story bronze and glass tower on Park Avenue that most critics consider New York City's finest postwar skyscraper, plan to ask the city government to declare the building an official landmark, reversing the frequent practice of landlords opposing landmark designation.

title: Palm Wine Tappers Give Nigeria The Beverage That Cures All Ills
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 7With the aid of a coarse braided rope looped behind his back, stepping into notches hacked out with a machete and pumping his legs, Albert Amao can scale a 40foot palm tree in eight seconds.

title: Denise Ann Goldsmith Wed To Joel Gershowitz, Lawyer
description: Denise Ann Goldsmith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Goldsmith of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joel Michael Gershowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gershowitz of Syosset, L.I. Rabbi Edward Abranson performed the ceremony in Temple Ohav Sholom in Albany.

title: MOST CORPORATIONS PLAN TO USE INTERNAL FUNDS
description: United States corporations next year will continue to rely heavily on internally generated funds to meet their financial needs, according to a study made by the Conference Board and released over the weekend.

title: A Small Tribe Fights to Keep Its Reservation
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., Nov. 7The nation's smallest Indian reservation won the first round here last week in a fight for its survival when state officials decided that a onequarteracre suburban plot did indeed belong to the Golden Hill Tribe.

title: Fire in Ocean Cripples U.S. Ship Laden With Flammable Cargoes
description: An engineroom fire aboard an American container ship carrying flammable cargoes raged out of control for more than six hours In the North Atlantic yesterday, but seamen managed to snuff out the flames by nightfall, just as shipboard firefighting supplies ran out, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Connors Defeats McMillan In Final at Cologne, 62, 63
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Nov. 7 (AP)  Topseeded Jimmy Connors needed little more than an hour today to crush Frew McMillan, 6.2, 63, and win the $50,000 Cologne Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Manhattan Transfer in Concert
description: Manhattan Transfer's Saturday night concert at Carnegie Hall got off to a painfully slow start. The group attempts a broad range of material without being equally adept at all of it, but at least it had the good sense to crowd its most lackluster moments Into the first third of the program.

title: Pitt Becomes Kina of Hill as Michigan Falls
description: And then there were six.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a table of newly elected members of the House of Representatives that appeared in The Times last Thursday, the winner in New Hampshire's Second District was given incorrectly. He is Representative James C. Cleveland. Republican, who defeated Joseph Grandmaison, Democrat.

title: State Puts a Spotlight on Some Big ShortWeighters
description: Nearly $300,000 in shortweighting fines were levied against New Jersey food merchants in the first nine months of this year, consumer officials said yesterday.

title: Steelers Win, 450, Ending Chiefs' Streak for Scoring
description: It was the best of times, and the worst of times in Kansas City's Arrowhead Stadium yesterdaybest for the Pittsburgh Steelers, who scored 45 points their highest total since 1966, and worst for the Chiefs, shut out for the first time in 180 regularseason games, which was the longest current scoring streak in the National Football Leauge

title: Making Movies in New York City Now Bigger and Better Than Ever
description: Two tall water pipes switched on, wetting the sidewalk on the western side of Central Park West, but some of the extras were out of place. Hold the rain, commanded the director, Robert Wise, and the drizzle fizzled.

title: Brook to Direct Gurdjieff Film
description: Peter Brook will direct the film version of George Gurdjieff's autobiographical book, Meetings with Remarkable Men. Filming of the $3.5 million picture is scheduled to begin March 5, with shooting to take place on location in Egypt, Afghanistan and other countries.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP)Mayors of the nation's cities met today with a representative of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter in a search for ways to stem the flight industry and people from urban centers. The United States Conference of Mayors meeting centered mainly on the question of what the Democratic president will do for the cities.

title: Plains Church Again Bars Pastor After 15 Minutes in Sunday School
description: PLAINS, GA., Nov. 7The Rev. Clennon King, King, the black activist minister who was barred from worship at the Plains Baptist Church a week ago, spent 15 minutes today in the Sunday School class often taught by Jimmy Carter before he was ejected from the church and again locked out of the worship service

title: DANIEL B. MONAGHAN
description: Daniel B. Monaghan, a 28yearold son of George P. Monaghan, a former New York City Police Commissioner and Fire Commissioner, died Saturday of a brain hemorrhage. He lived at his family's home at 732 West 231st Street in Riverdale, the Bronx. In addition to his father, he is survived by his mother, Helen; two brothers, Patrick and Michael, and a sister, Anne Kitchens.

title: One,Missing as Tug Sinks
description: FALMOUTH. Mass., Nov. 7 (AP)A man was reported missing and eight crewmen were rescued today after their tugboat the Eileen Sea sank in Buzzards Bay while towing an oil barge. The missing crewman was identified as James Almette of Elizabeth City, N.C.

title: CON EDISON URGES ACTION AGAINST GAS SUPPLIER
description: Two major metropolitanarea utilities are joining the Consolidated Edison Company's appeal to the Federal Power Commission against increased cuts in gas deliveries proposed by the area's major supplier, the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation.

title: Waener Takes Title
description: Through a tiebreaking procedure, Susan Wagner became football champion yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Staten Island Division by defeating Port Richmond, 226. Those two teams and Tottenville ended the season with 31 records, but Wagner allowed a point fewer than either of the others.

title: British Ambassador Is Installed as a Knight in an Order of St. John
description: In a centuriesold ceremony of pomp and circumstance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine; Sir Peter Ramsbotham, the British Ambassador to the United States, was installed yesterday as a knight in the Order of the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem.

title: Professor Starts a New Industry In Garden State Worm Farming
description: FAIRFIELD, Nov. 7A former professor or English at the Long Beach (Calif.) College has introduced a new industry, earthworm farming, to New Jersey, and has set up operations on a 25acre site in this Essex County community less than 200 yards from Route 80.

title: SARKIS BIDS LEBANON ACCEPT TRUCE FORCE AND END BLOODSHED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 7President Elias Sarkis called for an end to bloodshed and ruin today and appealed to the heavily armed warring factions in Lebanon to greet with fraternity and love the Syriandominated peacekeeping force that is being established in the country.

title: Killing Suspect Is Held in Awe By Neighbors
description: The threeyear old white van in which James Savino drove other college students to military meetings stood in front of his home in Bayside, Queens, yesterday.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
DE GUSTIBUS
description: When we expounded on the virtues of grits some time ago, we received a letter containing a fascinating discourse on another dish made with a kind of ground corn called mamaliga.

title: Moscow Denounces Suggestion Czar's Family May Have Escaped
description: MOSCOW, Nov 7 (Reuters)A Soviet foreign affairs journal today condemned as a pseudohistorical falsification a new book by Western writers suggesting that Czar Nicholas II and his family might not have been killed by Bolsheviks in July 1918.

title: Article 5  No Title
Rockefeller Eulogizes Gustave Levy Of Wall Street as Fabulous Friend
description: Vice President Rockefeller lauded the late Gustave L. Levy yesterday as fabulous friend imbued with great compassion.

title: Cuban Offices in Madrid Bombed
description: MADRID, Nov. 7 (AP)A bomb exploded early today in the downtown offices of the Cuban national airline, Cubana de Aviacion, causing heavy damage but no casualties, the police said. There was no immediate indication of who had carried out the bombing or what motive was behind it.

title: Steven Arthur Branson Marries Lesley A. Solte
description: Lesley Anne Solte, daughter of Milton H. Solte of New York and Syril I. Feuchtbaum, was married yesterday to Steven Arthur Branson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Farrel A. Branson of Golden, Colo. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the ceremony at the TerraceonthePark in Flushing. Oueens.

title: A Holmes Cookbook: It's Alimentary, Watson
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 7  The greatest detective ever associated with the C.I.A. was honored at dinner here last night.

title: Rhodesia Parley Remains Stalled
description: GENEVA, Nov. 7Intensive British efforts during the weekend failed to loosen the deadlock between Rhodesia's whitecontrolled Government and black nationalist leaders on the time needed to prepare for a transfer of power to the nation's black majority.

title: Car Kills Worker on Jersey Pike
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 7 (UPI)A 37yearold construction worker, checking trafficwarning lights on the New Jersey Turnpike, was struck by a car and killed this weekend. The police said that the victim, James Burne of Jersey City, was dead on arrival at St. Elizabeth Hospital here at about 12:45 A.M. Saturday. Gary Terranova, 22, of Edison, whose car struck Mr. Burne was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol, the police said.

title: Unbeaten Hartwick Sends UConn to First Soccer Loss
description: STORRS, Conn., Nov. 7 (AP)A goal by Esteban Reynoso early in the second half gave undefeated Hartwick College, ranked second nationally, a 10 soccer victory today over the fourthranked, and previously unbeaten, University of Connecticut.

title: Robber Slays Man, 69, Going to the Aid of Son During Holdup at Home
description: A 69yearold man was stabbed to death early yesterday morning when he went to the aid of his son, who was being robbed by an intruder in their apartment in upper Manhattan, the police reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a table of newly elected members of the House of Representatives that appeared in The Times last Thursday, the winner in New Hampshire's Second District was given incorrectly. He is Representative James C. Cleveland, Republican, who defeated Joseph Grandmaison, Democrat

title: Concert: Afternoon Premieres
description: Victoria Bond has been ?? for a couple of years to ofier New York a concert of orchestral works by women composers conducted by herself. Yesterday afternoon at Columbia University's McMillin Theater, courtesy of the National Federation of Music Clubs, she finally pulled it off.

title: Ramses' Illness Was Fabricated, Scientists Allege
description: The mummy of the Pharaoh Ramses II, which is undergoing tests by French scientists in Paris for what was said to be an infection threatening its preservation, may actually be suffering from nothing more than a case of diplomatitis.

title: Ethnic Currents Run Deep in the Soviet Republic of Moldavia
description: KISHINEV, U.S.S.R.In the Soviet Union, where more than a hundred ethnic groups seek, submerge, revere, deny or flaunt their linguistic and cultural traditions in the face of Russian dominance, the question of ethnic assimilation and identity has become exceedingly complex.

title: When the Election Returns Came In
description: When the returns came in, Gerald Ford tried not to believe them. He went to bed about 3 A.M. insisting that he still had a chance and it was after noon before he conceded victory to Jimmy Carter. With Randall Leo Jones it was simpler. When Jack Lang, secretary of the Baseball Writers of America, telephoned the news that Jones had been voted the Cy Young Award, Randy said: After last year I kind of expected it. I would have been disappointed and frustrated if I didn't win it. I think Koosman is in the same situation I was in in 1975. Last year nobody had to ask, Who's Tom Seaver? This year nobody had to ask who Randy Jones was. While Randy talked from his home Poway, Calif., his wife, Marie came into the room carrying their 8dayold daughter, Jami Helen. ,Another daughter, Staci, is 2. Randy signaled thumbs up, hung up the phone and kissed Marie.

title: Algeria to Conduct Elections, With Boumediene Running Alone
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 7 (AP)Nationwide presidential and legislative elections will be held in Algeria during the next two months under a oneparty constitution soon to be adopted, the official Algerian press agency announced today.

title: Bridge:
description: The dedication and concentration of most duplicate players is so marked that it takes some extraordinary event to dislodge them from the tables. An announcement that the hotel was on fire once proved sufficient, though only after several repetitions.

title: Team Golf Won By Kratzert, Blackburn
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Nov. 7Bill Kratzert and Woody Blackburn, pair of supremely confident freshmen on the Professional Golfers' Association Tour, won the tour's national team championship today on the third hole of a suddendeath playoff on the Magnolia course of Walt Disney World.

title: OROFINO MAKES MET DEBUT AS THE RADAMES IN AIDA'
description: Ruggero Orofino is not likely to recall with affection in years to come his Metropolitan Opera debut Saturday night, as Radames in Aida. For he lost his voice above the staff toward the end of the third act, and had to coo his top notes falsetto or simply mime them for the rest of the night.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: that would raise load factors and thereby justify the fare reductions. History does not support such, a view. Between 1960 and 1970, for example, traffic on the major domestic airlines increased by more than 300 percent; during the same period load factors dropped from 59.5 percent to 49.3 percent.

title: New York Police in Jam Over Traffic Summonses
description: On West 82d Street near Amsterdam Avenue early yesterday afternoon, two police officers in a patrol car, without so much as a glance, rolled past several automobiles that were parked in front of fire hydrants or were doubleparked.

title: Davis Cup Group Bars Soviet Union in '77 Play
description: PARIS, Nov.7 (AP)The management committee of the Davis Cup tennis competition banned the Soviet Union today from the 1977 tournament for refusing to play Chile in the semifinals of this year's event for political reasons.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 7The State Legislature, having met infrequently since passing the state income tax last July, returns here tomorrow to begin winding up the 1976 session.

title: Guard Disaster Unit Tested in California In Pretended Quake
description: CAMP ROBERTS, Calif., Nov. 7In the largest field exercises in its history, the California National Guard tested for the first time this weekend a new military unit specially trained to help the local police in natural disasters and civil disturbances.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 7 (AP)A severe earthquake struck a mountainous region of northeast Iran this morning, killing at least 16 persons and injuring 32, according to the relief agency Red Lion and Sun, the Iranian equivalent of the Red Cross.

title: The Rhodesian Tangle
description: News Analysis

title: Egyptian Home From East Europe
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy of Egypt returned to Cairo today after talks with Soviet, Bulgarian and Yugoslav officials on Middle East developments and relations with his country.

title: The U.N. Today
SOVIET CELEBRATION IS AGAIN LOWKEYED
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7The Soviet Union staged a relatively lowkey military parade todayexcluding once again its intercontinental ballistic missilesand repeated its endorsement of dtente in celebrations of the 59th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Saturday's College Football Scores
Strong Effort Nearly Upsets Cowboys
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 77The Giants scored today.

title: Gallic Outsiders Lift a Toast To Inside Tours of France
description: Suddenly, it was the essence of Franca on West 86th Streetan accordionist squeezing out the haunting notes of La Vie en Rose, a tiny, blackhaired woman with that Piaf sob in her voice, and then everybody was singing, glasses of wine raised high.

title: Ridgewood Club Raises Funds for Women in College
description: RIDGEWOOD, Nov. 6  Benjamin Franklin Junior High School was an antique shop today as hundreds of shoppers bought merchandise for the benefit of collegebound women in the area.

title: Sophisticated Country Preacher'
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Years ago, Benjamin Lawson Hooks fancied the idea of identifying himself as just a poor little of country preacher. And now at the age of 51, long after the phrase has become inaccurate, he still insists on making the same declaration. In Memphis as a lawyer he tried it on juries, as a black leader in the civil rights movement during the 1960's he practiced it with hostile Southern sheriffs, just as he did later as a judge, a businessman, a moderator for television shows and a commissioner of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Commodities
description: Speculators are once again sending prices toward contract highs on the New York Cotton Exchange as they await the next moment of truth this Wednesday afternoon.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A smoke bomb stuffed into an envelope went off in the back of a mail truck, the police reported. A few hours later, the same driver found a similar device in a lower Manhattan mailbox. The police said the mail truck driver noticed blue smoke coming from a letter bag in the back of his vehicle as he was driving up Church Street at about 10:40 A.M. The driver, who was unhurt, threw the bag into the street and the police later found a small smoke bomb, made from a small vial of lighter fluid, a pocketwatch, and ninevolt battery, stuffed into a 9by12inch envelope.

title: Dr. O'Dea Honored
description: After 25 years of service as the show's veterinarian, Dr. John C. O'Dea was retired with ceremonial honor last night. A wreath of roses was placed around his neck. A blacksmith removed the doctor's shoes and the veterinarian was then led from the ring with a lead shank (line).

title: VETERANS OF SNICK' TURN MIDDLE CLASS
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 7They were noticeably older, some turning gray at the temples, others cradling babies.

title: 9 Among 200 Spectators Fined After Raid on Dogfight in Texas
description: CLARENDON, Tex., Nov. 7 (AP)A weekend raid on a dogfight attended by 200 people turned up persons from as far away as California and Canada, Federal agents said.

title: Rhodesia Lists 11 Dead In 2 Days of Warfare
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 7 (Reuters)A white Rhodesian soldier, eight black nationalist guerrillas and two black civilians have been killed in the guerrilla war in the last 48 hours, an official statement said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Twelve minutes after New Jersey's smallgame hunting season opened Saturday, Herman Prudin, 47 years old, of Burlington was accidentally shot by his hunting partner. Mr. Prudin died yesterday. The police said Mr. Prudin and an unidentified friend were hunting for small game in a wooded area off River Road in Burlington when Mr. Prudin was hit with shotgun pellets in the upper right shoulder and neck. He died a few hours later in Rancocas Valley Hospital. The hunting season for pheasant, rabbit and other small animals opened at 9 A.M.

title: 1,100 Tested in Michigan for Effects Of Toxin That Poisoned Food in '73
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 5Chris and Donald Rehkopf and their 2yearold son Thorin flew here from Brewster, Wash., this week to participate in the nation's first mass health survey for the effects of an environmental contaminant.

title: SOVIET CELEBRATION IS AGAIN LOWKEYED
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7The Soviet Union staged a relatively lowkey military parade todayexcluding once again its intercontinental ballistic missilesand repeated its endorsement of dtente in celebrations of the 59th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

title: World Chess Group Readmits S. Africa
description: HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 7 (AP)The International Chess Federation voted today to readmit South Africa, which was stripped of membership two years ago over charges of racial discrimination against blacks.

title: Atlantic City Sees Itself Basking in the Sun Again
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 6.Sometimes, decaying resorts develop a certain rich, plummy, Tennessee Williams decadence. But in order to have decadence, some elegance is required.

title: Construction by Elizabeth Thayer
description: A naive and dangerous idea is abroad in the landthe notion that a major change in airline regulation can somehow yield, as if by magic, better service and lower fares for everyone. These proposals are based on two incorrect beliefs: that airline prices are too high and that more competition would bring lower fares. Both views are inconsistent with historical evidence and are dangerous in that implementation of the proposals advanced to solve the problem would likely do major damage to the nation's airtransoortation system.

title: Cyclist Pedals Home After Touring World
description: Robert Morris, the 22yearold cyclist who rode his 15speed bicycle around the world, arrived home on schedule Saturday to the cheers of Randolph Township, N.J., residents.

title: INDEPENDENTS UPSET BY PUERTO RICO VOTE
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 7On Election Day, Ruben Berrios Martin, a Senator and the president of the Puerto Rican Independence Party, said, The only party that will come out winning from these elections will be ours.

title: The Labor Scene
description: As proof of the priority that unions assign to swift national action for full employment and economic revival, organized labor is ready to put on the back burner the commitments it received from Presidentelect Jimmy Carter and most victorious Congressional Democrats to back controversial specialinterest legislation long sought by labor.

title: Miss Merrill, Callaghan Win
description: Jan Merrill, the 20yearold Olympian from New London, Conn., and Dave Callaghan, 19, of Brooklyn, a sophomore at St. John's, broke meet records yesterday in women's and men's divisions of the National Road Runners Club agegroup crosscountry championships over a threemile course in Van Cortlandt Park. Miss Merrill's time of 16 minutes 4 seconds, broke her record by 27 seconds. Callaghan ran 1455, bettering the mark of 15:10.4 set last year by Joe Siedlicki of the North Jersey Striders. A field of 3,429 runners from 26 states competed.

title: If Onlys &
description: WASHINGTONOf all sad words of tongue or pen, gloomed the poet Whittier, The saddest are these: It might have been.' To which Bret Harte responded: More sad are these we daily see: It is, but hadn't ought to be.'

title: A List of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: ST. JOHN'S QUESTIONS KILLING BY HAZING
description: A St. John's University spokesman yesterday questioned the police version of hazing as the cause of the stabbing death of Thomas Fitzgerald and suggested the tragedy might have occurred in a training exercise set up by Reserve Officers Training Corps students on their own.

title: Joseph Lee Performs Romantic Piano Works
description: Joseph Lee Yit Tong, an Indonesian pianist who came to the United States eight years ago and now teaches at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, gave a mostly romantic program at Carnegie Recital Hall late Saturday afternoon. The exceptions were Mozart's Sonata in C (K. 330), and three Debussy Preludes, which bracketed the 19thcentury lineup of two Chopin Scherzos, a pair of Novelettes by Schumann, a Capriccio and Rhapsody of Brahms and Liszt's Hungarian Rhapsody No. 11.

title: CHARLOTTE BERGEN LEADS UNFUSSY MISSA SOLEMNIS
description: Charlotte Bergen, who is perhaps in her 70's, perhaps in her 80's, has been leading and paying for free concerts in the New York area for more than a decade. The passing years have done nothing to diminish her musical appetite. Saturday afternoon found Miss Bergen, who is also an estate owner, a farmer and a cellist, treating a packed house at Carnegie Hall to nothing less than the Missa Solemnis.

title: Hospital Coup'
description: Mayor Beame's bloodless coup in the semiautonomous Health and Hospitals Corporation is only the opening shot in what must become a comprehensiveand not so bloodlessrevolution in health care delivery for this city.

title: Money And Politics
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7When Jimmy Carter takes the oath next January, his situation will differ from that of other recent newly elected Presidents in one interesting respect: He will not be obligated to a single large campaign contributor.

title: Lease Survey Is Finished Nearly Year After Beame Ordered Property Study
description: The New York City Real Estate Department's longawaited survey of city lease space has been completed, Mayor Beame announced yesterday, eight months after the Mayor ordered thenCommissioner Ira Duchan to conduct one.

title: Koreans and Americans in Seoul Say Park Must Be Aware of Gifts
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7So many aides and confidants of President Park Chung Hee have been linked to cash payments to United States officials and pressing of American businessmen for contributions that certain Korean and American sources here say it is virtually impossible for the South Korean leader to have been unaware of them.

title: West Berlin Police Arrest 13 As NeoNazis and Seize Arms
description: WEST BERLIN, Nov. 7 (AP)Police raided a neoNazi meeting in a West Berlin apartment, seized weapons and Third Reich political pamphlets and detained 13 persons, a police spokesman said today.

title: Chess:
description: HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 2The Netherlands took over the lead in the World Chess Olympiad here by defeating the United States 21 in the sixth round. The Dutch then consolidated their position by drawing with England in the eighth round, after defeating Israel 31 in the seventh.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Article 6  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)  Two incoming Democratic Senators agreed today that the 25th Congress would assert itself but would not be in conflict with an activist Carter administration.

title: Catalans Clash With Police
description: MADRID, Nov 7 (Reuters)Riot policemen fired rubber bullets to dislodge stone  throwing Catalan nationalist demonstrators from behind a street barricade in Barcelona tonight, the national news agency Cifra reported. The demonstrators were celebrating the fifth anniversary of the founding of the region's major opposition forum, the clandestine Assembly of Catalonia. No arrests or injuries were reported.

title: Disadvantaged Youth Given Help On Vocational Guidance and Jobs
description: David is a 19yearold high school dropout with a police record who spends most of his time on the streets looking for a job or a victim.

title: Dr. William Clough, 65, Pioneer In. Improvhig Emergency Care
description: NEW.LONDON, N. H., Nov. 7 (UPI). Dr. William Clough, one of the nation's leading authorities on trauma, died at his home Friday after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Dissident Catholic Archbishop Consecrates a Church in Rouen
description: ROUEN, France, Nov.7 (AP)The dissident Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre consecrated a Roman Catholic traditionalist church in a garage here today with Latin mass while outside there were sat& fles between photographers and the archbishop's bodyguard.

title: Bangkok Eases Military Alert
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 7 (UPI) Bangkok's military commanders reduced their military alert today, with troops dismantling the last of their street bunkers and generally moving off the streets.
