The soldiers were put on a twothirds alert for the first time since the Oct. 6 military coup. A midnight curfew. remained in effect.

title: Nancy Benjamin Wed To Herbert C. Nolan
description: Nancy Benjamin, senior editor of Winthrop Publishers Inc., a division in Cambridge, Mass., of PrenticeHall, was married yesterday to Herbert C. Nolan, production director at Winthrop.

title: Article 1  No Title
Civilization Endangers California Condor
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7No one knows who did the shooting. Or why.

title: Market Place
description: The Dow Jones transportation average moved ahead last week as investors bought key coalcarrying railroads in expectation of a possible shift in energy policy under Presidentelect Jimmy Carter from nuclear power to coal.

title: Cypriots Build High White Walls to Enforce Their Estrangement
description: NICOSIA, CyprusFor all practical purposes the sovereign and independent state of Cyprus has ceased to exist. Cyprus is two nations now, one controlled by ethnic Greeks, the other by ethnic Turks.

title: $1 Million Contribution to BBC By Public TV Is Scored by Actors
description: The contribution of 61.2 million from the federally financed Corporation for Public Broadcasting to the British Broadcasting Corporation to help produce 36 Shakespearean dramas, in which Americans will have very few jobs, has drawn criticism, from the head of the actors union, but a spokesman for the agency dismissed the tempest, in effect, as much ado about nothing.

title: US. Team, Macken of Ireland Win International Titles
description: It was a struggle to the finish at Madison Square Garden last night as the United States captured the international equestrian team championship by staving off Canada's bid in the final event of the sixday National Horse Show.

title: Jets Beaten, 277, by Dolphins; Giants Lose 9th Straight, 93
description: When it mattered, the Miami Dolphins made the right plays yesterday to trounce the Jets, 277.

title: Saudi Troops Leave Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 7 (UPI)Seven thousand Saudi Arabian troops marched today in a farewell parade at Kerak, southern Jordan, before they were pulled out of the desert area where they had been stationed since the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: CHARLEMAGNE PALESTINE AT BOSENDORFER FETE
description: It made a nice kind of sense for the Bsendorfer Festival to wind up late Saturday night with a performance by Charlemagne Palestine. For it was Mr Palestine who started the whole thing

title: India's New Order Has Look of Permanence
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 7A young lawyer who used to talk about entering politics here, to help change what he thought was wrong about India, now talks instead of getting along in an unexciting corporate practice.

title: DIFFICULT DECISIONS IN MONETARY SPHERE WAITING FOR CARTER
description: PARIS, Nov. 7  Some hard international monetary decisions await Presldentelect Jimmy Carter and the economic advisers he will bring with hint to Washington, according to financial specialists in Europe.

title: Delays Persist for Liquefied Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7On the blue waters of a Norwegian fjord near the port of Stavanger, the $75 million tanker El Paso, Paul Kayser has lain at anchor since mid1975.

title: BATAVIA WILL LOSE SYLVANIA TV PLANT
description: BATAVIA, N.Y., NOV. 7This small upstate city near Buffalo, struggling to overcome an unemployment rate of nearly 10 percent, has been dealt a severe setback by an announcement that one of its principal employers plans to close its plant here and to consolidate production in the South.

title: ERNEST BARKSDALE
description: Ernest Barksdale, superintendent of transportation and maintenance operations of the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Authority, died of cancer Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived at 485 Lenox Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Barksdale had been a driver for the New York City Omnibus Corporation, starting in 1948, and rose to superintendent. The line was taken over by the city in 1962. He is survived by his wife the former Guinevere Inniss, and his mother, Luanna Barksdale of Corona, Queens.

title: Dr. Ruthellen Fried Bride Of Dr. Lawrence M. Boxt
description: Dr. Ruthellen Fried, a pediatric resident at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, and Dr. Lawrence Martin Boxt, a radiology resident at Metropolitan Hospital, were married yesterday at the Plaza. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silbermann, performed the ceremony.

title: To Attack Unemployment
description: The first major question of economic policy that awaits Jimmy Carter's decision when he assumes the Presidency in January will be whether to ask Congress for an immediate tax cut to stimulate the recovery and reduce unemployment.

title: Brezhnev Plans Visit to Rumania
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 8 (UPI)The press agency Tass said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, will visit Rumania in the second half of November, following a visit to Yugoslavia. Diplomatic sources said he might attend Warsaw. Pact meeting in Bucharest.

title: Little V A Little Humility
description: Jimmy Carter says he wants to make the Presidency more democratic with a little d'. Amen, to that, but some of us would feel a little more hopeful about it if Mr. Carter hadn't been so obviously delighted by his first ride in a Presidential jet.

title: On Ulster
description: The political dimension of the Northern Ireland crisis has been overshadowed in the public mind by the violence of the last seven years. It is the violence of the Irish Republican Army, the counterviolence of the Protestant paramilitaries, and the efforts of the security forces to counter both, that make the headlines in Ireland and abroad. Yet this violence has changed nothing in the underlying situation apart from retarding political progress.

title: PUBLIC'S VIEW OF BUSINESS TIED TO STOCKBUYING DIP
description: A survey by the National Investor Relations Institute showed yesterday that businessmen believe that the public's declinirg Opinion of business in general has contributed to an overall drop in public participation in the stock market.

title: Three Israelis In Yuval Trio Show Rapport
description: The Yuval Trio, which appeared Sunday night at the 92d Street Young Men'sYoung Women's Hebrew Association, is a piano trio of nativeborn IsraelisJonathan Zak, the pianist; Uri Pianka, the concertmaster of the Israel Philharmonic, and Simca Heled, that orchestra's principal cellist.

title: Providence Official Is Sentenced
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 8 (UPI)Robert J. Haxton, President of the City Councial, was sentenced to a year's probation today on a morals conviction, Haxton was convicted last September of transporting an 18yearold boy for indecent purposes on Jan. 16.

title: PHYSICIAN'S PATIENTS WANT HIM REINSTATED
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8 Patients of a suspended Pine Hill physician asked Judge George H. Barlow of Federal District Court today to restore their doctor's license so he could restore their health.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: All Kinds of Consolation for Giants, But the Biggest One Escapes Them
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 8 The bottom line on the Giants is 09 after yesterday's 93 loss to the Dallas Cowboys. But even at the bottom, things are looking up.

title: Plan for Home for the Retarded In Yonkers Is Strongly Protested
description: YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 8The leader of several Westchester County parents who plan to open a group home in a residential neighborhood for their severely retarded children says he has been harassed and threatened by residents of the community.

title: 2 MEETINGS ARE PLANNED ON U.S. POLICIES ON CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8As the personalities and policies of the Carter administration begin to be filled in, two groups with opposite viewpoints are planning national conferences in Washington on China policy.

title: Ballet: Joffrey's American Dream
description: Troupe Concentrates on Works by U.S. Composers, Closing a Good Season With an Effortless Style

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS ABORTION CURB NOW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 The Supreme Court refused today to block the payment of Medicaid funds for elective, abortions, at least for the time being.

title: R.O.T.C, Is Investigating Reports Of Hazing at St. John's University
description: Reports of possible hazings involving reserve Officers Training Corps students at St. John's University were under investigation yesterday, following the stabbing death last Friday night of a cadet in what an accused cadet's lawyer called an obviously accidental tragedy.

title: 6 Under Indictment For Alleged Fraud At TDA Industries
description: A lawyer and four business executives were indicted yesterday on Federal charges involving alleged schemes to defraud investors and stockholders in TDA Industries Inc.

title: COURT TO ACT ON BAN ON FOR SALE SIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on a Willingboro, N.J., ordinance barring for sale signs that had been adopted to prevent mass flight by white homeowners.

title: Dr. Ross A. McFarland, 75, Dies; Was Transportation Safety Expert
description: Dr. Ross A. McFarland, an expert and author on health and safety problems in transportation and industry, died Sunday at his home in Dublin, N.H. He was 75 years old.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
Events Today
description: Theater

title: New jersey Briefs
description: A boss who makes a pass at a woman employee;s not breaking a Federal law, but his company may be guilty of sex discrimination if it dismisses her for complaining about it, Judge Herbert J. Stern, ruled in Federal Court in Newark. He said the Public Service Electric and Gas Company did not violate Federal sex discrimination laws simply because a company supervisor allegedly demanded sexual favors from Adrienne E. Tomkins, a former clerk. But he ordered a trial on Miss Tomkins's complaint that the company discharged her to retaliate for her complaint that Herbert D. Reppin, her supervisor, put pressure on her to have sex with him to keep her job. Miss Tomkins, 31 year old, of Bayonne, said that she was transferred to another department after she complained, but that company officials continued to harass her until she was let go 16 months later. The utility company argued that she was discharged because of high absenteeism. She said she was out sick because of the mental and physical anguish she suffered.

title: Airlines Pressing U.S. to Ease Rules By Next Summer on Charter Flights
description: The international scheduled airlines stepped up pressure on the United States yesterday to ease charter rules by next summer's peak season so that large charter groups could be carried side by side with regular noncharter passengers on scheduled flights.

title: Ultra traditionalist Catholics Back Suspended Prelate
description: Eugene Berry, his wife and two of their six children drove 75 miles to church one recent Sunday morning, trekking from their Peekskill, N.Y., home to a rented hall of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Hicksville, L.I.

title: Bus Crash in West Germany
description: ROTH, West Germany, Nov. 8 (UPI)A school bus skidded off a wet road and overturned today, injuring 44 passengers, four of them seriously, the police said. The police said the bus carrying 60 passengers between the ages of 11 and 19 careened off the slippery road on bend and overturned.

title: Richard, King of Book Dealers, Set to Proclaim Welsh Kingdom
description: HAYONWYE, Wales  Richard Booth is an Englishborn Welshman, heir to the depleted fortune of a great uncle who married a Welsh brewer'sdaughter. He is a 38yearold bachelor, a man in rumpled clothes with stormtossed hair who, misses whole patches of his law when he shaves.

title: About New York
description: The hedgehog made a cautious, quivering circuit of the surface of the dining room table, a small, prickly muff of affection in the eyes of its owner, who carefully shepherded it from falling off the edge because love on the West Side is never having to say whoops to your net.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses China and expanding trade relations. Page 61.

title: Capitals' Forward Breaks Leg
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 7 (AP) Blair Stewart, a left wing for the Washington Capitals will be sidelined from eight to 10 weeks with a brokn right leg, the National Hockey League club announced today. Stewart suffered the injury last night against the Minnesdta North Stars.

title: 3 Killed in Barge Explosion
description: MERMENTAU, La., Nov. 8 (UPI)An explosion ripped through a barge being repaired at the Zigler Shipyards today, killing three persons and injuring six. The cause of the explosion and the amount of damage were not disclosed.

title: WILLARD R. SQUILLACE
description: Willard R. Squillace, secretarytreas. urer of Waverly Travel Ltd., a Manhattan travel agency, died of cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Article 3  No Title
Israelis Expect Friction With U.S. on Mideast Peace
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 8Israeli officials are predicting a year of renewed diplomatic activity aimed at finding a peace settlement that may result in conflict between Israel and the United States.

title: Hialeah Sold; Jerseyan Gets 30Year Lease
description: HIALEAH, Fla., Nov. S (AP) Hialeah Park, the financiallytroubled, elegant race track of another era, was sold today in a $13.3 million deal that gave control of the historic facility to the City of Hialeah and a New Jersey developer, stockholders announced.

title: KOREAN CHIEF LINKED TO ILLEGAL LOBBYING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Federal investigators have been told that President Park Chung Hee and other senior South, Korean officials conceived, organized and directed an illegal effort to influence Congressional policy.

title: Justice Inquiry on Schorr Continues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  The Justice Department is still carrying out a criminal investigation of the disclosure of a House intelligence report to Daniel Schorr, the former CBS News correspondent, even though a House ethics committee has dropped the case.

title: Millions in Medicaid Overbillings Laid to New York City Hospitals
description: Many New York City hospitals have claimed millions of dollars in questionable Medicaid reimbursements for the care of patients who actually had been released on weekend leaves, according to the State Department of Health.

title: Woman Is Slain In Floral Park; Suspect Is Held
description: The mutilated body of a woman who had been tied up strangled and stabbed several times was found yesterday afternoon in the home of a Floral Park, Queens, man, the police reported.

title: Police Identify Body Found in Field
description: MARLBORO, N. J., Nov. 8 (UPI)A decomposed body found in a field here Saturday has been identified as a mental patient who disappeared from Marlboro State Psychiatric Hospital on Oct. 13. Detectives said that 25yearold Steven Hannigan of Milltown, NJ., apparently had killed himself by jumping off a powerline tower. We think there's no foul play involved in this, a detective said.

title: 15 Major Nuclear Nations Will Discuss Ways to Curb Spread of the Ability to Make Atomic Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The 15nation Nuclear Suppliers Conference, an organiization of major exporters of nuclear technology and materials, is due to meet Thursday and Friday in London to discuss ways of improving controls to curb the spread of the ability to make atomic weapons.

title: China and Expansion of Trade Relations
description: About five weeks ago, George Weissman, vice chairman of Philip Morris Inc.. left New York on a Pan American nonstop flight to Tokyo to join two other high officials of the large tobacco company to prepare for their suddenly arranged interviews in China to discuss packaging techniques. While he was generally hopeful, he was also somewhat skeptical that any agreement could he consummated quickly. It had been three months since the China National Export Commodities Corporation first broached the possibility of talks on purchasing advanced knowhow, materials or plants in the paper and packaging field from the Philip Morris international subsidiary. Both sides had held informal discussions in the interim in Washington and then nothing further was heard from Peking until the latter part of September, when the Chinese extended an invitation for a prompt meeting in their capital.

title: Utah High Court Postpones Execution of Killer Who Pleads for Death
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 8The Utah Supreme Court today stayed the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore, a convicted killer who had pleaded with the court to allow him to die before a firing squad next Monday.

title: When It Comes to Network Programming for Children, Quality Does Exist but Is Rare and Costly
description: It is not as if the networks don't have the vaguest notion of what quality in programming for younger audiences might be. In fact, all three networks can claim at least one series of remarkably consistent accomplishment. ABC has been strongest and most visible with its monthly Afterschool Specials. NBC has been coming along nicely with Special Treats. Only CBS has been lagging, in terms of quantity, with the classy but sporadic Festival of Lively arts.

title: Gold Prices Rise Sharply Abroad On Fears Carter to Fan Inflation
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) The price of gold soared as much as $5 an ounce on European bullion markets today. Dealers attributed it to fears that Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's economic policy might touch off more worldwide inflation.

title: The Folks at Foggy Bottom View Life Without Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Henry A. Kissinger's departure as Secretary of State next Jan. 20 has already begun evoking nostalgia at the State Department, where Mr. Kissinger has ruled for the last three years like a stern but respected schoolmaster. You wonder who will replace him and you wonder if the place will ever be the same again, a senior assistant said the other day.

title: A Multimillion Dollar Export Industry Springs From Sea Urchin's Golden Roe
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Down in the sea off the California coast, divers and entrepreneurs have struck gold inside the shell of a spiny character called the sea urchin.

title: Pitt Is No. 1 in A.P. Poll As Michigan Falls to 4th
description: Pittsburgh became the first major college football team from the Northeast to be ranked No. 1 in the nation in 17 years yesterday when the Associated Press panel of 63 sports writers and broadcasters named the undefeated and untied Panthers to the top spot in the 10th weekly noll of the season.

title: I.M.F. and Gold Dealers Planning To Meet Before the Next Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov:8 (Reuters Staff officials of the international Monetary Fund will hold one of their regular consultations with gold dealers here, informed sources said.

title: KOREAN CHIEF LINKED TO ILLEGAL LOBBYING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8  Federal investigators have been told that President Park Chung Hee and other senior South, Korean officials conceived, organized and directed an illegal effort to influence Congressional policy.

title: World News Briefs
description: MANILA, Nov. 8President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines today dismissed 19 officers and 308 soldiers found guilty of various abuses, including the use of torture.

title: Some Nursing Homes May Refuse To Accept New Medicaid Patients
description: The organization representing 95 of New York City's privately owned nursing homes said yesterday that many of its members would refuse to admit new Medicaid patients, beginning at midnight tonight, in a protest against lower reimbursement rates announced by the state late last month.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS ABORTION CURB NOW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Supreme Court refused today to block the payment of Medicaid funds for elective abortions, at least for the time being.

title: Strauss Plans to Quit As Democratic Chief
description: DALLAS, Nov. 8 (AP)Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic Party, announced today that he would leave the post. Jan. 21, the day after Jimmy Carter is inaugurated as President.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE FILE ON THE TSAR. By Anthony Summers and Tom Mangold. 416 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $12.50

title: Appliance Makers Schedule Layoffs
description: Layoffs in the heavy appliances and television industries appear to be spreading as makers try to adjust inventories to meet slowing demand. While , some layoffs can usually be expected around Thanksgiving, the magnitude and duration of the layoffs this year seem to be unusual.

title: N.F.L. Helps Olympics
description: The United States Olympic Committee received a $25,000 grant from the National Football League Charities yesterday to help defray expenses of the 6,000 athletes selected for the 1976 Olympic trials earlier in the year.

title: Imbrie's Angle Has Debut on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8With a display of boldness that has come to characterize the San Francisco Opera, that company presented the world premiere Saturday night of Andrew Imbrie's Angle of Repose.

title: CAHN FRAUD CONVICTION UPHELD BY APPEALS COURT
description: The fraud conviction of a former Nassau County District Attorney, William Cahn, was affirmed yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 8 The State Supreme Court ruled today, in a split decision, that the Gallo Asphalt and Crushed Stone Company of Passaic, which pleaded guilty two years ago of conspiracy to defraud the state and local governments by bidrigging, collusion and illegal pricefixing, be allowed to bid once again for state contracts.

title: Seat Is Sold for $50,000; Price Lowest Since 1954
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $50,000, down $6,000 from the previous sale last Thursday. This marked the lowest price for a seat transfer since 1954.

title: Too Many Youths Found Aspiring to Too Few Jobs
description: HOUSTON, Nov 8A report released today by the National Assessment of Educational Progress gave fresh insight into the reasons why large numbers of college graduates were dissatisfied with their education and discouraged by their job prospects.

title: Bronfman Trial Jury Hears of the Ransom Cache Site
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 8 Morris Greenberger, in whose Brooklyn apartment Mel Patrick Lynch allegedly cached the $2.3 million dollar ransom in the Bronfman kidnapping case, testified today that Mr. Lynch's codefendant, Dominic P. Byrne, had long had the keys to the apartment.

title: Advertising
description: The Axiom Market Research Bureau, a subsidiary of the J. Walter Thompson Company, yesterday issued its fall edition of Target Group Index, a syndicated study of magazine audiences.

title: Dolphins and Steelers Meet Sunday in Survival Battle
description: Miami at Pittsburgh. That's the biggest game in the National Football League this Sunday and it will be televised here over Channel 4 starting at 4 P.M. These teams, winners of the last four Super Bowl games, have the same wonlost records, 54, and the one that does not win on Sunday will be eliminated from the playoffsrealistically if not mathematically. There are several teams with their backs to the wall as far as playoffs are concerned and the Dolphins are one of them. Nat Moore, described by Coach Don Shula as the maker of the big play for Miami all season, is gone for the season because of a broken foot bone suffered in the Jets game on Sunday.

title: A Multimillion Dollar Export Industry Springs From Sea Urchin's Golden Roe
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Down in the sea off the California coast, divers and entrepreneurs have struck gold inside the shell of a spiny character called the sea urchin.

title: FREIGHTWAYS SEEKS RESOURCES MERGER
description: Associated Freightways Inc., of Grand Rapids, Mich., announced yesterday that it was negotiating to merge into the American Natural Resources Company of New York through an exchange of stock valued at $22.15 million.

title: Senators Miss Israeli Nuclear Site
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 (AP)  Israel's Atomic Energy Commission has turned. down a request by a group of United States Senators to visit an isolated and secret nuclear installation, Israeli sources said today.

title: USE OF SEALED BIDS IS BEING EXPLORED IN IRVINE TAKEOVER
Giacomin Nears Career Shutout Mark
Posters in Shanghai Tell of Plot For Armed Rising Against Peking
description: PEKING, Nov. 8 Wall posters in Shanghai, read by foreigners in the last three weeks, say radicals there planned an armed uprising against the Peking Government last month, a revolt that never happened.

title: ELECTION FUND RUNS $23 MILLION SURPLUS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Federal campaign fund that furnished public financing for a large part of the 1976 Presidential campaign, the first subsidized contest in American political history, wound up the year with a surplus of nearly $23 million.

title: LOUISE WATSON IS DEAD; A FINANCIAL CONSULTANT
description: Louise Watson, a financial consultant and one of the first women to become prominent in Wall Street, died at her home in Manhattan yesterday.

title: OilProducing Nations Seeking Role In Bid to Aid Farming in Poor Lands
description: VIENNA, Nov. 8  The oilproducing countries are seeking a decisive voice in a new $1 billion undertaking to spur farming in thirdworld countries that do not grow enough food, officials here say. The instrument for this development strategy is the OPEC Special Fund, an $800 million facility that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries set up earlier this year.

title: Bridge
description: Opening bids of three clubs or three diamonds are not common, but when they do occur the responder may face some tricky problems. If he has a strong hand with a singleton in partner's suit he has a delicate choice between three notrump, in which dummy's long suit may be unusable, and a minorsuit game in which there may be three losers.

title: The Basic NoFrills Box
description: A Page One article in The Wall Street Journal last week was headlined ByeBye Basics? Anyone who has followed the year's educational debate, with its almost obsessive demand for a return to the basics, might have hastily jumped to the conclusion that the pendulum had begun to swing once again and that the basics are on the way out.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: After Pants, Bloomers Are Kicky Fashion
description: Straightleg pants, the kind that finally gained admittance to the best restaursints within the last decade, are far less prominent on fashion runways in both Paris and New York now.

title: The Whole Theater Company of Montclair Presents a Quality Staging of Rose Tattoo
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 8First a note about the Whole Theater Company, which is one of New Jersey's comparatively few profestional theaters. It is a theatrical cooperative of Equity members, most of them married couples, who have chosen to live and work here. It has plans for a new home, but

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)  A. Roman Catholic Archbishop today defended the church's stand on abortion but told his fellow prelates they must expand their concern to the sanctity' and dignity of human life at all stages.

title: Sachson Replaces Bouza, Whose Transit Job Is Fought
description: Two police officials with reputations as strict disciplinarians were appointed to top command posts in the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday, as.Transit Police captains went to court in an effort to stay a controversial command change in their department.

title: Notes on People
description: It may have been Muhammad Ali's  best performance, and he didn't even give it at a weighin, in the ring or in front of the cameras for the movie biography he is now filming in Houston. Early yesterday, two officers investigating a report of a shooting saw man running down the street and stopped him: It turned out to be Mr. Ali, out for his morning jog. The officers invited him to the jail to see he could fool other policemen by acting like an arrested drunk. The ham in Mr. Ali couldn't resist, and so he went along and put on a realistic performance, staggering around and yelling. When it was done, he signed autographs and asked modestly, Aren't I a good actor?

title: BERTHA ARONIN DIES AT 73; WAS NASSAU CIVIC LEADER
description: Bertha Danziger Aronin, who was active in civic affairs in Nassau County, died yesterday at Leroy Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Burundi's ExLeader Reported Held
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 8 (UPI)Former President Michel Micombero of Burundi, who was overthrown in a bloodless coup in the tiny Airman republic a week ago, has been placed under house arrest, according to officials of the new regime. A twoman military delegation from the new regime told journalists here during the weekend that Mr. Micombero is being well looked after under house arrest.

title: Public School Near White House Hopes to Enroll Carter's Daughter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI)Counselors at the Stevens School, a sevenroom schoolhouse built in 1868 for the children of freed slaves, would like to enroll Amy Carter in January.

title: Exxon Reduces Gasoline Prices; Other Fuel Costs Are Increased
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) The Exxon Company. U.S.A., has reduced the price of gasoline by I cent a gallon and increased the prices of heavy fuel oil, jet fuel and propane by varying amounts.

title: Prices Increase Sharply In Orange Juice Futures; Corn Of f on Crop Report
description: Orange juice futures advanced yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with the January delivery ending at 47.50 cents a pound, up from 47.15 Friday. After the close of trading the industry, plagued by a heavy juice supply, received some bullish news.

title: Article 2  No Title
Metropolitan Briefs
description: Richard Brown, the 33yearold brother of Justice Kenneth N. Browne of the State Supreme Court in Queens, was arrested for fatally shooting a man and then wounding a mutual woman friend in front of her apartment at 3217 110th Street in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Market Place
description: The success of the Municipal Assistance Corporation in selling $250 million in new M.A.C. bonds last week clearly reflected a feeling on the part of individual investors that Presidentelect Jimmy Carter would cure New York City's financial malady forthwith.

title: Angola Reported to Wage AllOut Drive on Guerrillas
description: OSHAKATI, SouthWest Africa, Nov. 8 (Reuters)Heavy fighting has reportedly broken out in southern Angola, with Government forces there seeking to crush a nationalist movement that has continued to wage guerrilla warfare against them.

title: The Ford Vetoes
description: An important factor in Presidentelect Carter's victory was the desire of many independent voters to have a President and Congress of the same political party. They could see the logical incongruity of electing a heavily Democratic and predominantly liberal Congress while also returning to office a conservative Republican President. Mr. Carter's election provides at least the opportunity for a more constructive and cooperative relationship between the White House and Capitol

title: WATER STARKIE, 82, EXPERT ON GYPSIES
description: Walter F. Starkie, a wandering scholar whose. understanding for gypsy life took him from his native Ireland to universities and gypsy encampments in many countries, died last Tuesday in Madrid, where he had made his home for many years. He was 82 years old.

title: HERALD TRIBUNE IN PARIS GETTING A NEW PUBLISHER
description: Robert T. MacDonald has resigned as publisher of The International Herald Tribune and is being succeeded by Robert R. Eckert, according to an announcement yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman of the publication.

title: Nuclear Power: No Green Light at the Polls
description: Spokesmen for the atomic power industry are suggesting that the rejection of nuclear regulatory proposals by voters in six states represents a green light for nuclear development.

title: An Argument for New York..
description: Of all the arguments for additional Federal aid for this fiscally stricken city, none is likely to carry more weight than that just issued by the economyconscious Citizens Budget Commission.

title: Halevy's La Juive Well Sung
description: French grand opera of the MeyerbeerScribe school may be an acquired taste, but a considerable number of people seem to be acquiring it lately. Sunday night's concert performance of Halvy's La Juive, by the American Opera Repertory Company at Town Hall, helped demonstrate why.

title: Police Union Seeking to Resume Negotiations With City on Contract
description: The head of the patrolmen's Benevolent Association has arranged a meeting with Mayor Beame for this afternoon at which he intends to ask resumption of negotiations to end the extended labor dispute between the city and the police, a union spokesman said yesterday.

title: Fraternity and Love
description: It has been a very long time since the situation in Lebanon has been marked by an atmosphere of fraternity and love. Yet it was that phrase President Elias Sarkis chose to use in appealing to his tragically divided countrymen to accept what comes very close to a Syrian occupation of Lebanon.

title: New York Court of Appeals Is in a Period of Transition
description: Their decisions are longer, and there are more of them. At times, the language is more strident than it has been in the past. And there has been a quantum leap in the number of dissents and concurring opinions in which judges state alternative grounds for agreeing with the result reached by the majority.

title: CORNELL COROT ART FOUND TO BE A COPY
description: Detective work by two Cornell University graduates has confirmed that a suspect Corot painting given to the university in 1959and appraised at $30,000 at the timewas, in fact, a copy of a Corot painted by one of his students and touched up by the master himself.

title: Anderson Apologizes to Dear Thurman
description: DAYTON. Ohio, Nov. 8 (UPI) The Cincinnati Reds manager. Sparky Anderson, has sent a letter of apology to the New York Yankees catcher, Thurroan Munson, for remarks he made following the final game of the World Series.

title: NEWS WOMEN'S CLUB PICKS 10 FRONT PAGE WINNERS
description: Ten women newspaper and television reporters and magazine writers and a woman news photographer have won this year's, Front Page awards of the Newswomen's Club of New York. The awards will be presented at the club's annual Front Page dinner dance on Nov. 19 at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: Securities Leader Sees More Commission Cuts
description: The incoming chairman of the Securities Industry Association, a national trade association of some 600 brokerage and investment banking firms, said yesterday that he expected more brokers to offer commissionrate discounts to their retail customers.

title: RANDOLPH BROWN JR., 52, A ST. LUKE'S HEADMASTER
description: Randolph F. Brown, Jr., a headmaster at St. Luke's School, New Canaan, Conn., and a former magazine publisher, died yesterday at his New Canaan home. He was 52 years old.

title: Tax Exemption Is Voted For Business Machinery
description: TRENTON. Nov. 8 The State Senate gave final approval today to a bill exempting business machinery and equipmient from the 5 percent state sales tax.

title: Recount Starts in LeFanteCampenni Race for House
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 8 Election officials began a vote recount here today in the narrow victory by the State Assembly Speaker, Joseph A. LeFante, Democrat of Bayonne, over Anthony L. Campenni, Republican of Bayonne, in their Congressional race in the 14th District.

title: Robert's Rules Keep Order As Parliamentarians Convene
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Nov. 8 Anyone who has ever been confused about a quorum or ruffled by a rollcall should take note: There are 75 qualified parliamentarians in the state available to help organizations revise their bylaws and run their meetings.

title: 2 Justices Say Court Endangers Its Repute by Summary Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Justices William J. Brennan Jr. and Thurgood Marshall declared today that the Supreme Court was jeopardizing its respect by its practice of deciding many cases summarily, without hearing arguments on them and without issuing written opinions, and then requiring the lower courts to follow these decisions as precedent.

title: Queens Man Is Winner Of the Lottery Jackpot
description: John Sartoretti, a 26yearold telephoneinstaller from Queens, last night won the New York State lottery's jackpot prize of $1,000aweek for life.

title: Wood, Field G
description: CLAREMONT, N.H.  When galeforce winds and bitter cold drove Hanson Carroll of Norwich, Vt., and me down from a backpacking, muzzleloading deer hunt on Mount Sunapee, I continued my quest alone in the lowlands.

title: Meanwhile, Back at The World
description: With its usual obtuseness, the world kept right on doing its things while we were all in deep political immersion here in the United States. For those interested in catching up, here are some of the things that happened:

title: Beast: a Meditation on Beauty Offers New Songs by Carmines
description: THE BEAST: A MEDITATION ON BEAUTY, by Al Carmines. Choreographed and directed by Dan Wagoner; setting by Lee Guilliatt; lighting by Earl Eidman; costumes by Dean H. Reiter; production stage manager, Simon O'Hanion. Presented by the Judson Poets, Theater. At 55 Washington Square South.

title: British Chairman Of Rhodesia Talks To Report on Snag
description: GENEVA, Nov. 8The Briton who chairman of the deadlocked conference on Rhodesia was summoned to London tonight to report to Foreign Secretary Anthony Crosland.

title: Newhouse Acquires Booth Chain Of Newspapers for $305 Million
description: Samuel I. Newhouse yesterday completed the purchase of Booth Newspapers Inc., publisher of eight Michigan dailies and the Sunday supplement Parade, for what was reported as the highest price paid in American newspaper history.

title: New Trial Set in Saxe Case
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP)Chief Justice Walter H. McLaughlin of Superior Court today set Jan. 10 for the second murderbank robbery trial of Susan E. Saxe, the antiwar activist. He announced that he was assigning Judge James C. Roy to hear the case, The trial of the former Brandeis honor student in September ended in a mistrial after the jury reported it was deadlocked.

title: Man Killed as Car Hits School Bus
description: LICEVILLE, Ala., Nov. 8 (UPI)A sports car smashed into the rear of a school bus near this west Alabama town today, killing the driver of the car, troopers said. They said that none of the children were hurt. Joseph Sherrod, 201 yers old, of Carrollton, who was alone in the car, was killed and his auto demolished.

title: Ancient Basilica Found on Cyprus Linked to St. Paul
description: PAPHOS, CyprusFor centuries travelers puzzled over three stone columns poking out of the ground near a medieval church here. Recent excavations have shown that the columns belonged to one of the largest and earliest Christian basilicas to be built on this Crossroads Island.

title: Move in UNESCO To Readmit Israelis Is Making Progress
description: NAIROBI, Kenya. Nov. R (AP)The United Nations Educational. Scientific: and Cultural Organization voted today; to let each regional group select its own! members, moving a step closer to reversing the exclusion of Israel from the European group two years ago.

title: College Football Standings
Slow Acceptance of Vaccination For Swine Flu Called Deceptive
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP)The apparent reluctance of Americans to get swine flu inoculations during the first month of the vaccination program does not indicate the program will prove ineffective, an official of the Center for Disease Control said today.

title: Article 1  No Title
DOW FALLS BY 9.39; LOSS SINCE ELECTION IS 3324 IN 4 SESSIONS
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 9.39 points yesterday amid increasing fears over the sluggish economic recovery is well as concern that policies likely to be followed by Presidentelect Jimmy Carter might lead to steppedup inflation.

title: Tokyo Parley Seeking New Rules On Japanese Fishing Off the U.S.
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8The United States, which has declared a 200mile coastal fishing zone effective early next year, opened talks with Japan here today an effort to establish new procedures and quotas for harvesting vital marine life threatened with depletion.

title: School for Performing Arts Hopes Cutbacks Won't Upstage Its Style
description: The School for Performing Arts is going to have to cut faculty positions in February but its officials are now wondering whether the rigid seniority system that is a way of life in the financially strapped city will become flexible enough to accommodate the school's uniqueness.

title: CRIMINAL CHARGES BELIEVED SUPPORTED IN INQUIRYON F.B.I,
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Justice Department lawyers have reportedly concluded that they have evidence to support criminal charges against 10 to 20 past and present officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who either knew of or approved illegal investigative techniques employed by bureau agents in recent years.

title: First National Opens 3 Minibanks In Grand Union's Jersey Stores
description: Acting on the principle that a bank should go where the people are, the First National Bank of New Jersey opened three fullservice minibanks yesterday in Grand Union supermarkets in northern New Jersey.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The U.N. Today
Summary of Actions Taken by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) Attorney General Edward H. Levi waived today objections to two proposed deepwater Gulf parts provided the Transportation Department imposed license restrictions to meet certain antitrust problems.

title: STEEL OUTPUT RISES 1.2%; USE OF CAPACITY ALSO UP
description: Steel production for the week ended Nov. 6 rebounded from the preceding week and reached 2.35 million tons. the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 1.2 percent over over the 2.32 million tons poured in the final week of October.

title: ... an Urban Agenda
description: New York is not alone in its need for more understanding and generous Federal assistance, a fact that was underscored by a weekend meeting of more than 100 of the nation's mayors in Chicago.

title: Goldin Reverses Stand on S.I. Park
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has reversed his stand favoring the proposed 146acre amusement park on Staten Islanda move that further jeopardizes the controversial plan.

title: Bengals Win by 2012 On 3dPeriod Surge
Bearne Requesting Pension Funds To Reschedule City's Borrowings
description: Mayor Beame is negotiating with the municipal employee pension funds to reschedule the city's borrowing in a way that would save up to $75 million in debtservice costs next yeara saving that would substantially ease the requirement of more budget cuts.

title: Help for Pound Explored
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Nov. 8 (Reuters) Bankers from the West's 11 major industrialized nations today examined ways of reducing the foreign exchange weakness cf the British pound through international help in financing Britain's balanceofpayments deficits, monetary sources said.

title: U.S. Says 2,500 Earned $100,000 Or More From Medicaid Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Federal Government released today the names of 2,500 doctors, dentists, laboratories and pharmacies that earned more than $100,000 each from the joint Federalstate Medicaid program last year, and it was immediately attacked by organized medicine for doing so.

title: Millions in Medicaid Overbillings Laid to New York City Hospitals
description: Many New York City hospitals have claimed millions of dollars in questionable Medicaid reimbursements for the care of patients who actually had been released on weekend leaves, according to the State Department of Health.

title: CRIMINAL CHARGES BELIEVED SUPPORTED IN INQUIRY ON F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Justice Department lawyers have reportedly concluded that they have evidence to support criminal charges against 10 to 20 past and present officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who either knew of or approved illegal investigative techniques employed by bureau agents in recent years.

title: Flourishing Hungarian Enterprises Can Pirate Talent
description: BUDAPESTI get the talent I need because I can pay for it, the Communist industrialist said, thumping his imposing desk. Headhunting is just one of our practices that might seem familiar in the West, and we do it well.

title: Furphy Leaves Toros
description: MIAMI, Nov. 8 (UPI)  The Miami Toros of the North American Soccer' League announced the resignation today of Coach Ken Furphy, just 39 days; after he joined the club. The club said Furphy and his wife had a difficult: adjustment period in Miami and had nOtdeveloped many friends during their slay. Furphy had been coach of the New York Cosmos for half of last season.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TURNING LEAVES Starting today, four prominent writers with new books will take part in a series of discussions with Leonard Probst at 11 A.M. on Tuesdays. The place is the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., off Lexington Avenue.

title: A TongueinChic Boutique Revives the 60's
description: Highheeled boots with pointed toes in fluorescent colors tagged at $110. Crazy? You bet. It's the sheer outrageousness of the boots that sold 100 pairs last month at the Fiorucci boutique. They're meant to be worn with $38 jeans, a big mohair sweater in wild colors and a gold plastic tote bag emblazoned with the company logo.

title: JOHN G. ALEXANDER
description: John G. Alexander, former corporate secretary of the Olin Chemical Company now the Olin Company, in New York, died Sunday at his home in Irvington, Va., where he had moved from Larchmoat, N.Y. when he retired in 1969. He was a 1926 graduate of Princeton University and received a degree from the Harvard University Law School in 1930. He was a member of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. He is survived by. his wife, the former Rachel M. Sheldon: a son John G. Jr.; a daughter, Cecily Spitzer, and six grandchildren.

title: In Evicting a Stanford White Design, Virginians Gain Apparent Jefferson
description: CHARLOTTESVTLLE, Va.Stanford White, whose buildings epitomized the free use of historical styles in the late 19th century, is usually the hero of preservation efforts. But here at the University of Virginia, he is the villain. The reason is that White redesigned the Rotunda, the central building of the Thomas Jeffersondesigned campus here, after an 1895 fire destroyed Jefferson's interior. For years the Rotunda was, thus, more a White building than a Jefferson one.

title: THEODORE SHEDLOVSKY, LIFE CHEMISTRY PIONEER
description: Dr. Theodore Shedlovsky, a leader in applying techniques of physical chemistry to the study of life processes and a professor emeritus at Rockefeller University, died Friday in New York Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 419 West 118th Street

title: DR. JOSEPH WILDER DEAD; PSYCHOTHERAPIST WAS 81
description: Dr. Joseph Wilder, associate editor of The American Journal of Psychotherapy who had practiced psychiatry and neurology in New York City before his retirement eight years ago, died on Oct. 31 in West Hartford, Conn., where he lived. He was 81 years old. He had been associated with numerous hospitals in New York.

title: 9 Urban Renewal Sites, Left Vacant, to Be Parks Under Beame Program
description: Until large Federal grants become available to resume New York City's urban renewal construction programs, smaller Federal grants will be used to turn nine vacant rubblestrewn and weedcovered renewal sites into parks and playgrounds, Mayor Beame said yesterday.

title: L. Alfred Jenny, 91 Rail Engineer, Aideto Pershing and Eisenhower
description: L. Alfred Jenny, a railroad engineering consultant who served two fivestar generals in two World Wars, died Sunday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 91 veers old and a resident of Dumont.

title: MacLeish Joining CBS News
description: Rod MacLeish, who has been chief commentator for the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company since 1966, with frequent exposure on WINS in this area, is leaving to join CBS News later this month as a commentator. Mr. MacLeish, nephew of the poet Archibald MacLeish, had organized the Westinghouse Washington bureau in 1957 and later the company's foreign news service, since disbanded. Before lie became chief commentator, he served for seven years as London bureau chief for Westinghouse.

title: N.B.A.'s New Format Gives Home Clubs a New Edge
Taxes &
description: If public accounting may be likened to shoemaking, the shoemaker's kids still go shoeless. Among the accounting firms that annually audit thousands of companies, only oneArthur Andersen & Company, the profession's outspoken maverickmakes its own financial statements public.

title: Public Broadcasting Corp. and PBS Argue Aid for BBC's Shakespeare
description: The Public Broadcasting Service and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the two bureaucracies of public television that have collided over a number of issues recently, are in disagreement again. This time the dispute is over the corporation's proposal to lend financial support to the British Broadcasting Corporation for the production of the complete dramatic works of Shakespeare.

title: Dibbs, 2 Other Americans Defeated in First Round
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 (APP) Eddie Dibbs tonight became the third seeded player to be knocked out in the first round of the $150,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament. Mark Cox of Britain beat the American, 75, 62. Victor Pecci of Paraguay and Antonio Zugarelli of Italy were previous upset victims.

title: SouthWest African Talks Resuming
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, Nov. 8 (Reuters)  Multiracial talks on the future of SouthWest Africa resume tomorrow for what many delegates believe could be a makeorbreak session on forming an interim government leading to full independence from South Africa.

title: Namath Knee Worse, Future Hangs on Test
Posters in Shanghai Tell of Plot For Armed Rising Against Peking
description: PEKING, Nov. 8  Wall posters in Shanghai, read by foreigners in the last three weeks, say radicals there planned an armed uprising against the Peking Government last month, a revolt that never happened.

title: Tacoma Gets Boat Contract
description: The United States Coast Guard announced the award of an $18,8 million contract to the Tacoma Boatbuilding Company of Tacoma, Wash., for construction of four icebreaking tugboats.

title: Music: Chicagoans Bring Chorus
description: CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Sr Georg Solti, conductor; David Ward, baritcne; Chicago Sympncny Chorus, Mar??et HiIlis, director. At Carnegie Hall.

title: Prides Decline in Credit Markets in Quiet Trading
description: Prices declined yesterday in the Government and corporate sectors of the credit markets as investors continued to ponder the likelihood of a shift in emphasis in Federal Reserve monetary policy. Trading was quiet, described as largely professional in nature and marked by what several specialists termed a lack of retail demand. The Government market drifted lower from the outset and this appeared to influence the direction of the corporate market.

title: Syria's Army Makes Final Plans For Expected Entry Into Beirut
description: ALEIH, Lebanon, Nov. 8The Syrian Army today made final preparations in this area 10 miles east of Beirut for its expected entry into the Lebanese capital as the first and most powerful contingent of the Arab force that is supposed to reestablish peace throughout the country.

title: Nation's Mayors Bid Carter Establish Policy to Aid Cities
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 8More than 100 of the nation's mayors urged Presidentelect Carter today to set a national tone of concern for the country's cities.

title: Trial of Fried good Told About Letters From His Mistress
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov, 8 (UPI)Letters purportedly written by Dr. Charles Friedgood's alleged mistress and a photo of a nude woman were found in a safedeposit box kept by the physician's late wife, according to testimony today at the murder trial of the physician. The judge sustained objections to admitting the letters into evidence.

title: East Side Methadone Clinic Upsetting Block
description: The East Side Center. a methadone clinic whose patients are mostly Medicaid clients, has become a disruptive fact of life for the residents. restaurateurs and tradesmen of East 53d Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

title: BRITISH GOVERNMENT NARROWLY SURVIVES 3 TESTS IN COMMONS
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 Britain's Government narrowly survived three crucial tests tonight in which it sought to speed passage of controversial legislation, much of it demanded by the governing Labor Party's left wing.

title: BRITISH GOVERNMENT NARROWLY SURVIVES 3 TESTS IN COMMONS
description: LONDON, Nov. 8Britain's Government narrowly survived three crucial tests tonight in which it sought to speed passage of controversial legislation, much of it demanded by the governing Labor Party's left wing.

title: Greek Government Is Moving to End Criminal Prosecution for Adultery
description: ATHENS, Nov. 8 (AP) The Greek Government proposed a bill today that would end prosecution for adultery and redefine a minor as someone under 14 rather than 16.

title: Paint Bomb Is Hurled at Spivakov, But Violinist Never Drops a Beat
description: The atmosphere was unusually tense in Carnegie Hall Sunday night during Vladimir Spivakov's violin recital. Security guards were stationed at the doors and near the stage, as they invariably are for concerts given by Soviet artists these days.

title: People and Business
description: The chairman of the board of the United Steel Corporation, Edgar B. Speer, said in Boston yesterday that tax reforms to stimulate capital investment were needed to expand production and create jobs.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Jenny Turrall, Swim Star, Retires in Australia at 16
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 8 (AP) Jenny Turrall, the Australian swimming star, announced her retirement at the age of 16 because the old drive which helped her break world records is not there any more.

title: A New View From Venice
description: The Roberta di Camerino designs present another Italian view. They come from Venice, their price tags run higher ($600 for a polyester dress, for instance) and they are more likely to appeal to the international country club set.

title: Ultra traditionalist Catholics Back Suspended Prelate
description: Eugene Berry, his wife and two of their six children drove 75 miles to church one recent Sunday morning, trekking from their Peekskill, N.Y., home to a rented hall of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Hicksville, L.I.

title: Abstinence Without Tears
description: A few years ago, when the price of nee had risen even higher than usual, and a national boycott was announced. I watched an interview on the evening news with a Midwestern housewife, on the subject of eating meat. The woman explained that she sympathized with the protest and would buy no meat. Interviewed under a McDonald's arch, one day into the boycott, she and her family had come to buy hamburger:, because, she said, We've got to live.

title: In Case You Don't Know Beans About Chili...
description: It's getting to be virtually impossible to get a decent bowl of chili anymore.

title: The Presidential Election: One Week Later, the Politicians Tell How It All Happened
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9You face unique challenge, one of President Ford's senior strategists told him last summer. No President has ever overcome the obstacles to election that you will face following our convention this August.

title: All About: The Kitchen Stove
description: Kitchen ranges are better than ever. Kitchen ranges are worse than ever. According to two dozen manufacturers, distributors, dealers, home economists, kitchen designers, cooking teachers and cookbook authors, both claims are valid.

title: Whalers Get a Tax Break As Hartford Takes Over
description: ln a decision with farreaching implications, the City of Hartford has taken over as promoter of its professional hockey team.

title: Action Industries Is Forced by S.E.C. To Name Rebaters

title: Of Wives and Their Skills, Of Men and Their Dreams
description: I was very surprised, I lived for those letters from home, and :lad not yet tasted the jays of a furlough. But food? My attention had simply never turned to the subject. I remembered dimly that the food at school in England was bad, home good, at prep school in Millbrook, N.Y., tolerable, the Army about what one would expect which, if served with ketchup, which it always was, as also tolerable. This then, was my inteilectual introduction to the importance good food. I was an opsimath. Others come to an appreciation of food early.

title: Critic's Notebook
description: How do writers write? How do they actually execute the physical task of writing, and with what tools? And does it make any difference? About 10 years before he died, Edmund Wilson was asked to what he attributed his success as a writer. He answered (only partly facetiously. I think): My invariable habit of writing in pencil on those legalsize yellow padsthe kind that are ruled with blue lines. I believe that composing on the typewriter has probably done more than anything else to deteriorate English prose.

We drink it flat and sweet and from plastic cups at tedious receptions and we pour it It on the heads of the winning pitchers. It is a ritual to be observed, more than a drink to be enjoyed. Hugh Johnson, the British wine writer, once said: Champagne continually has to defend itself against the danger of becoming a notion rather than a wine.

Miller, chairman of Milgo. said the board had declined the proposal because it was not in the best interets of the shareholders and does not reflect the longterm prospects of the company. Applied Digital had offered to exchange 2,773,500 shares of its stock valued at $52.7 million for about 1,849.000 shares of Milgo on the basis of 1.5 shares of Applied Digital for each share of Milgo.

title: Red Smith
description: The Bobo Newsom Memorial Fan Club is a little band willful men dedicated to the proposition that Ashflat, Ark., must be heaven because Preacher Roe came from there. Incidentally, Binger, Okla., where Johnny Bench grew up, must be somewhat like Ashflat. Johnny was saying recently that after the World Series, when he led the Reds to victory over the Yankees in four straight, he went back to Binger and there was a great big celebration. Everything was going fine until someone realized that everybody in town was in the parade and there was nobody to watch it. Anyhow, at a meeting of the Bobo Newsom Club the other night, a member said it didn't seem to him that warmweather types like Mickey Rivers and Catfish Hunter were meant to play ball on wintry nights in October. He said the climate at that season was more suitable for players like Gene Freese, the Pittsburgh infielder of a decade ago, and Cool Papa Bell of the old Negro Leagues.

title: Scientists Are Still of Two Minds About Life on Mars
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9After more than three months of operations on Mars, Viking spacecraft have left scientists of two minds on the question of Martian life. Some scientists say maybe. Others say probably notat least not now or where the spacecraft landed.

title: Notes on People
description: Although he's old (86), ailing, frail and almost deaf, Grouch Marx is in Washington, for the first time in 30 years, to be lionized. Tonight he'll present the Smithsonian Institution some famed items of Marxian memorabiliathe swallowtail coat, pith helmet and jodhpurs he wore as Captain Spaulding in Animal Crackers. Tomorrow night, Groucho will speak, if I feel up to it, at a moneyraising benefit called Washington Greets Grouch, for Ralph Nader's Public Citizen organization. Valerie Perrine, George Fenneman (Groucho's announcer) and Chevy Chase will read from Mr. Marx's letters and other writings. Reached by telephone before he left his Los Angeles home, Mr. Marx said he was glad Jimmy Carter had won the election, but if Betty Ford had been running I would have voted for her. The last time he was in Washington, he said, F.D.R. was in the White House and I visited his wife. Eleanor. We were taking walk in the garden and a Marine band was playingrather badly. I turned to her and said, No wonder you keep travelling.'"

She didn't attend the party for two, tact keeping her away, although artfully she had hung peonies and irises in the living room where it took place. Whitney Warren has a sense of style; propriety, too.

title: Arts in America
description: IN THE ARTS, this city is like the athlete who has learned to lift automobiles with his teeth: certain muscles are remarkably welldeveloped while others are neglected to the point of atrophy. In fictionwriting, for instance, Chicago may not have much to offer beyond Saul Bellow, but he bulges out so dramatically that he won a Nobel Prize the other day. When you ask Chicagoans about other fictionists they are likely to think hard and then suggest a promising youngster such as William Brashler or a journeyman such as Harry Mark Petrakis. Good men, no doubt, but nothing to bellow about.

title: Jazz Inflicts Defeat on Nets, 11099
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9 (UPI)Pete Maravich and Gail Goodrich combined for 52 points and sparked a fourthquarter rally tonight to give the New Orleans Jazz a 11099 victory over the New York Nets.

title: RESTAURANT PRICES EXPECTED TO RISE
description: Americans dining at their favorite res taurants have often opened their menus to find a rather unappetizing surprisea notice announcing sharply higher prices Yesterday, the National Restaurant As sociation said that further increaset would soon be served up.

description: Near the heart of the most desolate area of the South Bronx lie three lovely blocks of row houses built in the late 1800's, anchored by a spectacular turnofthecentury church and the security provided by the station house of the 40th Precinct.

title: A Lively Irish Leader
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 9Dr. Patrick J. Hillery. a brisk and popular oppositiov politician who appeared destined to be Prime Minister someday, was declared Presidentelect of Ireland today. At the age of 53, he is the youngest man to be awarded the Irish Presidency under a political system that makes an election to the largely figurehead office unnecessary if there is no other candidate. Although the post is traditionally reserved for an elder statesman in retirement, Dr. Hillery said it is an honor he could not refuse.

title: The Great Slavery Boom
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn. The last decade has witnessed a remarkable outpouring of books on Negro slavery. They have been written by popularizers and specialists, by black scholars and white scholars, by Marxists, liberals and conservatives. Over a dozen national prizes, including Pulitzers and National Book Awards, have been bestowed on books by Carl N. Degier, Robert W. Fogel and Stanley L. Engerman, Eugene D. Genovese, Winthrop D. Jordan, Edmund S. Morgan, and this writer.

title: Spurs Silas to Have Surgery
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 9 (AP)James Silas, a San Antonio Spurs guard, will undergo surgery on his left knee next Monday, team officials announced today. Doctors said tests today showed a tear on the inside cartilage of the knee. The Spurs captain, who averaged 18.2 points per game last year, hurt the knee in a preseason game against Kansas City on Sept. 30.

title: ENERGY AGENCY AIMS TO CUT DEPENDENCE ON IMPORTS OF OIL
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 Western industrial nations today signaled the seriousness with which they view prospects for overreliance on imported oil by announcing a series of cooperative procedures to reduce denendence over the next decade.

title: JaiAlai Matinee Tomorrow

description: MINEOLA. L.I., Nov. 9Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, today proposed a $30 _million spending increase in the county budget for 1977. but because of a rise in the county sales tax, the property tax levied by the county would drop by about 8 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation.

title: CIVIL SERVICE CHIEF ASKS LARGE FEDERAL PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 9 (AP)Salaries for the Government's top career professionals and managers have fallen so far behind the economy that it is hard to keep employees in the Federal work force, the chairman of the Civil Service Commision said today.

title: Letter Carrier Is Second to Win Lottery's $1,000 a Week for Life

title: Alternative for Britain?
description: Even in normal times, however they may be defined, the survival of a British Government by one vote on major issue in the House of Commons would touch off speculation about the dissolution of Parliament and new elections. The narrow escape for Prime Minister Callaghan's Labor Government on three crucial Commons divisions this weekone of them by a single voteinevitably sharpens the doubts everywhere that it can endure long enough to revive a floundering economy and a sinking pound.

title: LEBANON CHRISTIANS ACCEPT SYRIAN ROLE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 9Lebanese rightwing Christian leaders agreed in meeting with President Elias Sarkis today on the stationing of Syrian troops of the Arab peacekeeping force in Christian areas of Beirut and its suburbs.

title: Queens
O'Dwyer: Figurehead Or a Major Political Force?
description: Someone had had the temerity to suggest that the old lion seemed a little tired and toothless these days, whereupon Paul O'Dwyer tossed his white mane and roared.
