title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Oct. 30 incorrectly stated, as a result of a typographical error, that according to Amnesty International Iran had arrested thousands of Kurds. It should have said that Iraq had been accused of the action.

title: New Jersey
Real Savings Needed
description: When the Emergency Financial Control Board laid down its wage guidelines last spring, it insisted that any new pay increases for municipal employees must offset by productivity gains, reduction of fringe baiiefits or through other savings (or other revenuse)

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR EARLY BIRDS Those current lowprice previews for Comedians. Mike Nichols's staging of the London hit by Trevor Griffiths, mean a saving of several dollars for theatergoers eager to see shows for less. The preview price range before Tuesday (the original opening night date at the Music Box Theater), is $5 to $10 nightly at 8 P.M. and for Saturday's matinee, with today's matinee scaled at $5, $6 and $7.50. Chargit, the creditcard service, takes preview reservations at 2397177; otherwise don't telephone, go to the box office at 239 West 45th Street

title: He Recalls Asking for Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 Former Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he had warned the State Department in 1970 to be careful of a covert South Korean lobby and had suggested to the department that the Justice Department should be asked to investigate the legality of the operation.

title: Article 3  No Title
Richard to Press on for Date
description: GENEVA, Nov. 9Ivor Richard said tonight on his return from London that he would continue to seek an accord on the date for the projected turnover to black majority rule. He said that he proposed to continue the discussion on the date until we are convinced that it's not possible to arrive at any kind of consensus.

title: 31 MEAT INSPECTORS INDICTED IN PAYOFFS
description: Thirtyone Federal food inspectors were indicted in Manhattan and Brooklyn yesterday on Federal felony charges of accepting yearly payoffs of $125,000 from meatpackers and processors in the metropolitan area.

title: Hastings Trial Stays in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UPI)Federal District Judge June L. Green refused today to move the trial of former Representative James F. Hastings, Republican of western New York, from Washington to Buffalo because of the heavy case load in the Federal District Court in that city. Mr. Hastings is accused of taking kickbacks from his Congressional staff. Mr. Hastings attorney, Gerard Mitchell, had argued that a trial in Washington would cause undue inconvenience for defense witnesses.

title: Loans to Developing Lands By U.S. Banks on Increase
description: Despite widespread concern in the banking community and in Congress about the ability of many developing nations to meet mounting foreign debt payments, American bank lending to these countries has continued to climb in the last year, according to figures accumulated by the Federal Reserve Board. Moreover, these loans are more heavily concentrated in fewer nations than had earlier been estimated.

title: An Agenda for the Cities
description: WASHINGTON A striking convergence is emerging on two important domestic issues. In recent months, political leaders in the Northeast and Midwest have called national attention, rightly, to the relative decline of the old industrial states visavis the Sunbelt. For a longer time, observers of the urban scene have been calling attention in a similar way, again rightly, to the serious conditions of decay and hopelessness of the nation's infected core cities.

title: Miss Hearst Wins Prison Transfer; Inmates Tell of Temper Tantrums
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9Patricia Hearst was transferred suddenly this morning from the campuslike surroundings of the Federal Correctional Institution at Pleasanton, 60 miles southeast of here, to the 12story Metropolitan Correction Center in San Diego.

title: AMMAN PAPER SAYS AGNEW DECRIES U.S. BOYCOTT VIEW
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 9 (AP) Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew said today that American Jaws to counter the Arab boycott of Israel were not in the interest of the United States, according to an Amman newspaper.

title: Best Buys
description: With the impact of a Presidential election still lingering, this week's bargainhunting shoppers might do well to take their cue from the lexicon of politics and explore the possibilities of the pork barrel or a chicken in every Pot.

title: Repainting: There's Nothing Nice to Say
description: What is the most disorienting, disrupting and degrading trauma that any apartment dweller or homeowner must periodically endure?

title: Hospitals Found Taking Patients Just to Get Most Out of Medicaid
description: Officials of the New York State Department of Health said yesterday that they had uncovered a statewide pattern of unnecessary hospital admissions and protracted stays that were apparently calculated to get the most possible income from Medicaid reimbursement funds.

title: Bridge
description: Readers of this column who enjoy testing their own skill in cardplay should cover the South and East hands shown in the diagram and plan the defense from the West side of the table.

title: BELL ISSUE PLACED AT YIELD OF 8.30%
description: A new $100 million issue of triple A Bell System bonds was priced yesterday to give investors a return of 8.30 percent on their money  a little higher than similar issues marketed earlier this falland the rate proved attractive enough to place tile entire issue. The performance of this key bond offering gave some thing of a lift to the credit markets, which otherwise lacked much of a sense of direction. It was z:n active day for new financing, hut interest rates generally were little changed from their recent levels. Even the new Bell issue's yield was up only 5 basis points from the 8.25 percent rate on the preceding telephone company bond issue, which was sold Oct. 19.

title: F.T.C. Approves Sales Plan By BorgWarner of Division
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced its approval of the plan of the BorgWarner Corporation to sell its unit parts division to a group of investors headed by Jack H. Vollbrecht, president and chief executive officer of the AerojetGeneral Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Tire and Rubber Company.

title: Hart wick Is Seeded First For N.C.A.A. Soccer Event
description: The majority of the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoff berths having been assigned, action in ,all three divisions will begin as early as Saturday. Except for the teams from the Middle West and the West regions, which will be announced Saturday or Sunday, the list of the University Division teams reads almost the same as last year, although the seedings have changed slightly.

title: The Best Pts in Charcuteries
description: Of all the many glories of French gastronomy, one of the least known to the American public is charcuterie. In its most literal meaning, it sounds dull indeed, for a charcuterie is a shop selling meat (char) that has been cooked (cuit), and it is understood that the meat referred to is pork. But to call a charcuterie a cooked pork meat store is about as inadequate as to describe the Sistine Chapel as a church with paintings all over the walls.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 9 Governor Byrne signed legislation today providing additional funds to school districts and said the state had finally settled into thorough and efficient educational program for its public schools.

title: Real Estate
STATE COURT ASSAILS S.I. JURY SELECTION
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice found yesterday that the pool of prospective jurors on Staten Island was hopelessly and irremediably tainted because of the systemic exclusion of women and people under 21.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Thailand: The Junta's Helpers

title: Guerrillas Said to Kill 5 Persons
description: SALISBURY, Nov. 9 (Reuters)Five members of a Rhodesian road gang working in the Honde. valley near the eastern border were bound together and shot to death by guerrillas, a communique said today. A sixth worker also was shot but survived. The communique also said Lance Corp. Matthew Charles Lamb,. 28, a native of Canada, had been killed, but gave no details.

title: Layton and Shelton Bedevil Bullets
description: Moe Layton, a journeyman guard and Lonnie Shelton, a heralded rookie pulled the Knicks out of their secondhalf shooting doldrums last night and led New York to a 10697 victory over Washington before a crowd of 13,244 at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks sixth triumph in 11 games snapped the Bullets threegame winning streak.

title: She Does Cube Roots in Her Head
description: She forgot, momentarily, that she had visited the United States once before, 20 years ago, but she could give you the cube root of 188,132,517or almost any other number in the time it took to ask the question.

title: Student Killed at R .T .C. Exercise Won Commendation in a Prior Test
description: Thomas Fitzgerald, who was fatally stabbed during a Reserve Officers Training Corps unit program last Friday, had heen commended and complimented earlier this fall for refusing an order to fire a pistol at another student. The incident involved the same Pershing Rifles military honor society.

title: Samuels Attendance at Meeting Of Mayors Strengthens Carter Tie
description: Howard J. Samuels, whose political career seemed at an end after his four unsuccessful attempts to gain the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, has emerged as one of the top New York Democrats with ties to Presidentelect Jimmy Carter.

title: 22 Soviet Jews Tell of Ordeal in Jail
description: MOSCOW. Nov. 9Twentytwo Jewish activists. denied permission to emigrate to Israel. were released last night and today after having served 15day sentences for protest demonstrations in central Moscow last month. In interviews, a few of the dissidents offered unusual glimpses of life in Soviet jails.

title: Yes, but What Do You Mean?
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa. From where I sit, I can hear the woman in the next office discussing her marriage. Bob and I have a good relationship, she says. And her listener must understand what she means for they move rapidly to another subject.

title: People in Sports
description: Billie Jean King, the tennis ace, underwent knee surgery at Long Beach, Calif., yesterday. She is expected to be in Pacific Hospital for five days and after recuperating for six weeks hopes to be back on the court.

title: He's First a Music Lover, Then a Philanthropist
description: Avery Fisher was standing in the middle of his living room a few days ago, surveying the familiar scene with obvious affection.

title: Melinda: Afraid No More
description: HOLLYWOODThey're talking here these days about a promising newcomer with a vaguely familiar nameMelinda Dillonan actress who was called a promising newcomer on Broadway 14 years ago.

title: U.S. SAVS Inquiry Found No Illegal Activities by Shah's Agents Against Iranian Students
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9The State Department said today that an inquiry had failed to turn up evidence confirming any illegal or improper activity by the Iranian Government in the United States.

title: Quebec Minorities Irked by Language Issue May Sway Vote
description: MONTREAL. Nov. 9Several thousand angry Italian immigrants crowded into the basement assembly hall of church in northern Montreal Sunday to denounce what they termed discrimination against their children in the schools of predominantly Frenchspeaking Quebec.

title: Estimate Board Likely To Reconsider Approval Of S.I. Amusement Park
description: Reconsideration of the city's preliminary approval of a $40 million, 146acre amusement park near the southern tip of Staten Island appeared certain yesterday as Mayor Beanie reported that the prospective developer had not submitted sufficient financial data to qualify as bidder for the cityowned land on which the park would be built.

title: Rangers Try to Analyze Poor Home Record
description: In Madison Square Garden, where the Long Islandbased New York Rangers are visitors 40 times per season, the homeice advantage is never assumed. Of seven games in the Garden this autumn, the Rangers have lost five, including their last four.

title: Market Place
description: United States Steel Corporation stock, a big favorite in Wall Street earlier this year, has dropped to within a few points of its splitadjusted 1976 low as a pause in the economy has dashed hopes for a capitalspending boom.

title: Customs Barred From Interfering With Japanese Film
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred the Customs Service from interfering with the distribution and exhibition of the Japanese film In the Realm of the Senses, which was removed last month from the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: BROCK CONSIDERING G.O.P. CHAIRMANSHIP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Senator Bill Brock of Tennessee will probably seek the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee as a candidate of party unification if, as expected, Mary Louise Smith resigns the post, wellplaced Republicans said today.

title: A Positive Movie on Blacks
description: Bobby Roth's "Independence Day," which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is about Fred (Mel Rosier) and Delores (Gammy Burdett), a young black couple who move from Memphis to Los Angeles in hopes of finding a better life.Fred takes a job in a foundry. Delores first works as a domestic, goes to night school, and then lands a job in an office. They live in a nice apartment, have all the usual appliances, including a Princess telephone, and, even during the strike at Fred's foundry, there's always enough Scotch to drink and a roast in the oven. Fred and Delores fight and part and eventually obtain some sense of individual identity.Mr. Roth, who wrote and directed "Independence Day," describes it as an attempt to make "a positive film about black working people . . . an alternative to the commercial exploitation films."I guess it is, but good intentions aren't enough. "Independence Day" is a movie without any real emotional or intellectual momentum. Fred and Delores are essentially nice, decent people but because the writing, directing and acting are solemnly commonplace, their lives amount to little more than the acquisition of liberated attitudes that, like their appliances, are mass-produced.

title: Grumman Jet Intensifies 3attle for Corporate Market
description: The scramble for tomorrow's market in corporate jets intensified yesterday when the design was announced for the Grumman Gulfstream III, a plane with improvements in fuel consumption and a 4,600mile range.

title: ThreeAlarm Chili
description: Good chili is very easy to cook. A basic recipe calls for two pounds, of chopped beef. If the beef is a little fat, so much the better.

title: Viewers Can Dial News Articles Onto TV Screen, Editors Are Told
description: The use of home television screens to display news stories, which the viewer may select at will by simply pushing button or dialing the telephone, is being tried out. on several hundred television sets in England.

title: Flyers Dupont Hospitalized
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP)Andre Dupont, a Philadelphia Flyer defenseman, was admitted to Temple Hospital today for treatment of strained ligaments in his lower back, a team spokessaid. Dupont, who was hurt in Sunday night's National Hockey League game with the Buffalo Sabres, will be out of action for an indefinite period, the spokesman said.

title: Von Cramm Is Dead
description: Baron Gottfried von Cramm, the German tennis star of the 1930's, died in a car crash on a business trip in Egypt at the age Of 66. Obituary on D17.

title: Teleprompter Posts Net Of $910,000 in Quarter, Its First Profit Since 72
description: The Teleprompter Corporation, the nation's largest operator of cable television, reported yesterday net income of $910,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, its first profit since the December quarter of 1972.

title: Y &
description: It is getting to be one of the great truths in the agency business that if there is some form of specialty advertising where there is a buck to be made, Young & Rubicam will create or buy a subsidiary to tap the golden flow.

title: Private Lives
description: You are 37 years old, which, according to Aristotle, is the ideal age for a man to marry. And so you have decided to marry, for the second time. It is odd how much morbid interest such a decision excites in a city otherwise prepared to tolerate almost any bizarre relationship among animals, vegetables and minerals. Marry? Again? Row quaint? What for? Friends walk around your behavior, poke at it with a stick: take snapshots, as though they were anthropologists happening upon a Druid or the Ik.

title: About Education
description: Two years ago Henry Rosovsky, dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University, issued a widely publicized appeal for the reformation of undergraduate education.

title: China Expands Praise of Hua in Apparent Effort to Enhance His Image
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 9In what seemed to be a major effort to bolster the legitirnacy of Hua Kuofeng among the Chinese people, the Peking Government eulogized the new Chairman of the Communist !Party today in stronger terms than ever.

title: Advertising
New MultiTenant Building for Offices/light Industry in Prestigious Business Park
description: Units of 2,500 sq. ft. or more available: or will build to suit up to 100,000 sq. ft. This new 47acre park is strategically located at the intersection of Routes 22 and 1684, near IBM world headquarters and American Can, minutes to Westchester Airport, White Plains, Greenwich and Stamford. Ramada Inn with restaurant and conference facilities now open.

title: OAKES RECEIVES AWARD OF THE AUDUBON SOCIETY
description: John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page of The New York Times, received last night the Audubon Medal for making The New York Times the most persuasive voice for conservation in America.

title: CHARLOTTE W. SPEER, 80, A FORMER HEADMISTRESS

West Side Board Delays Action on Center for the Mentally Disabled
description: Community Planning Board 7 declined at, a noisy meeting last night to take an immediate stand against plans to relocate a socialrehabilitation center for the hardcore mentally disabled in the ground floor; of the 16story Brewster Hotel, at 21 West 86th Street.

title: TV: Shrew as Commedia dell'Arte
description: SHAKESPEARE purists, those hardy few who will brook no tampering with the master, are warned to avoid this evenings production Of The Taming of the Shrew. WNET/13's Theater in America is offering, at 9 o'clock, the play in a commedia dell'arte style devised by William Ball for his American Conservatory Theater Group in San Francisco. Not only entire scenes, but also portions of a single line have been cuf with merry abandon. And, as is inevitable when one style is imposed upon another, hits and pieces of the comedy stubbornly resist being stuffed into the overall concept.

title: US AIDES SAID TO ASK FOR PRESSURE ON IRAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10High Ford Administration officials are urging the United States to tell the Iranians that an increase in the price of oil would lead to reconsideration of the multibilliondollar American program of arms sales to their country, according to wellplaced officials.

title: East Germany Seeks U.S. Grain
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 10 (Reuters)East Germany wants to import up to two million metric tons a year of United States grain to keep up its livestock levels and raise meat production, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Yunich Calls for Reduced Service In City Transit, Saving $42 Million
description: David L. Yunich, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, made public a financial plan yesterday calling for service adjustments or cutbacks to close a $42 million gap in next year's transit budget.

description: There's the Children's Aid Society. And the A.S.P.C.A. And NOW.

title: The Baker's Wife' Closes Out of Town
description: David Merrick will close his production of The Baker's Wife, the musical adaptation of Marcel Pagnol's 1938 French film, La Femme du Boulanger, after Saturday night's performance at the Kennedy Center's Opera House in Washington. The show was to have made its Broadway debut NOV. 21 at the Martin Beck Theater. It stars Paul Sorvino, who succeeded Chaim Topol in the leading male role on Oct. 25.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: RAILROADS ASKING I.C.C. FOR 4% FREIGHT RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Reuters)The nation's railroads formally asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve a 4 percent acrosstheboard increase in freight rates effective Jan. 1.

title: About New York
description: We have all heard something of the city's American Indian community: Iroquois ironworkers surefooted above the white man on the skeletal frames of new skyscrapers. And so forth and so on toward another of the peculiar legends that whites seem to prefer for reds.

title: Ethiopian Official Is Slain
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 10 (AP) A highranking civilian official was shot to death last night by what the military Government calls anarchists. according to a Government announcement today. Guetenet Zewde, permanent secretary in the Ministry of Labor, and Social Affairs, was killed as he was leaving his office in Addis Ababa, the announcement said.

title: Economic Ministers Are Shifted in Egypt; Political Aides Stay
description: CAIRO, Nov. 10A new Cabinet involving major changes in Egypt's economic leadership but none in political figures was sworn in today by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Undocirinaire Inspiration
description: Watching Rosina Lhevinne give piano lesson was as much a lesson in history as it was a ramble through one particular piece of music. In her head were seven or more decades of pianistic history, in which she had participated directly and through her husband. Her husband had been Josef Lhevinne, one of the immortals of the keyboard. She herself had won the Gold Prize at the Moscow Conservatory. Josef and Rosina were a team in life as well as on the concert platform, and each constantly learned from the other.

title: E.P.A. Backs CleanAir TradeOff Allowing New Industrial Pollution
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 10The Environmental Protection Agency announced today a controversial new airpollution enforcement policy that would permit new pollutioncausing industry even in areas where Federal air quality standards have not vet been met.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UPDContinental Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association announced tentative agreement today on a new contract that could end a 19day strike and put the company's airplanes. back in the sky next week.

title: Cadets at West Point Will Assume Full Responsibility for Honor Code
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 10West Point cadets voted by a wide margin last night to assume complete responsibility for the adjudication of suspected honor code violators, eliminating officer review boards, while seeking to improve legal safeguards in the newly strengthened cadet boards.

title: 34 DOCTORS BARRED FROM MEDICAID ROLE; Physicians in New York City Area Cited on Unacceptable Practices
description: The State Health Department barred 34 New York Cityarea physicians from the Medicaid program yesterday in its broadest crackdown on socalled Medicaid mills since Governor Carey ordered an investigation of them Oct. 6.

title: New Powerful Computer Line Added By Sperry Rand's Univac Division
description: Sperry Univac announced its most powerful computer system to date yesterday as well as new data communication equipment and software. It is the most significant product thrust thus far in the 1970's for the computer division of the Sperry Rand Corporation.

title: Annenberg Offers Metropolitan Museum $20 Million For Art Communications Center Headed by Hoving
description: A pledge of $20 million to the Metropolitan Museum for a communications center to make the world's art more available to mass audiences has been made by Walter H. Annenberg, former Ambassador to Britain and a Metropolitan trustee since 1974.

title: 40,000 REPORTED HELD IN HARSH LAOS CAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Thousands of former rightist and neutralist Laotians are confined in harsh and repressive internment camps scattered throughout Laos, according to accounts being received here.

title: Lawyers Seek Broader Curbs On DNA Study
description: Federal safety regulations that limit Governmentfunded research in a new area of genetic experimentation involving recombinant DNA should be extended to govern similar research by all laboratories, including those of private industry. This contention is made by the country's two largest environmental law firms a petition to the Government to be filed today.

title: Earthquake Toll Near Record
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Reuters)Earthquakes have killed more people in the first 10 months of 1976 than in any year since 1970 and the final toll could exceed the 143,000 toll recorded in 1923, the Geological Survey reports.

title: 2 Dozen Ask to Join Firing Squad; Warden Tells of Utah Volunteers
description: DRAPER. Utah, Nov. 10The countdown resumed today for Gary Mark Gilmore's execution by firing squad, scheduled for Monday.

title: Boys Choir, Turned Coed by U.S. Regulation, Seeks Ways to Preserve Unique Sound
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn.To Washington lawyers and tinear bureaucrats, Reg. 45CFR, Part 86, Sec. 901, Title IX of the Higher Education Act was law against discrimination in choirs, limiting membership requirements to vocal range and quality.

title: Sauce For The Gander
description: BOSTON, Nov. 10One of the early problems to confront Jimmy Carter as President will almost certainly be the ripening scandal of South Korean coVert activities in this country. It is a delicate problem with disturbing implications, involving as it does both foreign policy and domestic politics, morals and law.

title: Curator Finds Her Specialty Is Old English
description: Jean Thorkildsen is curator of the Schenectady County Historical Society. On weekdays, she is in charge of the collection in the upstate building situated in the Schenectady Stockade, which dates to the 17th century and is one of the first designated historic districts in the United States.

title: 2 East Hampton Policemen Indicted
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 10Two members of the East Hampton Town police force were indicted by a grand jury here this morning, one of them for allegedly filing a grudge traffic ticket against a personal enemy and the other for allegedly having taken two impounded bicycles home to his children.

title: Who's In Charge Here?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10One of the great George Price cartoons of a generation ago pictured a hapless zookeeper inside a monkey cage trying to get his hat back from the monkeys, who were gaily tossing it around, as an irate lady visitor outside tapped her umbrella on the ground and demanded, Who's in charge here?

title: 34 DOCTORS BARRED FROM MEDICAID ROLE

title: Corn Gains Reported
description: The harvest of a record 1976 corn crop of 6.06 billion bushels has almost been completed and corn prospects have Improved by 3 percent since an estimate it month ago, the Agriculture Department reported. Page 62.

Palmer Is Cy Young Winner 3d Time
description: Rejected for the AllStar Game last July, Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles had the last laugh yesterday as he became the American League's first threetime winner of the Cy Young Award. He earned the same honor last year, and in 1973.

description: When John Curry first approached Twyla Tharp about breaking the ice with him, it was almost worse than preparing for an Olympic final.

title: Bridge:
description: If one had to pick a country to win a world title in the next decade that has never won one in the past, the selection would have to be Sweden. Thanks in part to their statebacked programs of bridge education for teenagers, the Swedes have a formidable number of brilliant young players.

description: NEWARK, Nov. 10Thirteen more persons were indicted today on charges of using Si million of a bank's funds for financing loanshark and gambling operations.

Last year the Governors lost to New Dorp, 1916, in a playoff semifinal. In 1974 Jefferson held on to beat the Bronx school, 86, in the final. Those are bad memories.

description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 10Dennis Shaw, who didn't want to play football 10 months ago, became a Giant today and Coach John McVay immediately said he hoped Shaw didn't play Sunday.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 10Gov. Wendell R. Anderson announced today that he would succeed Walter F. Mondale in the United States Senate when Mr. Mondale resigned to become Vice President.

title: Rutgers, Quietly and Smoothly, Entering BigTime Sports Era
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 10Oklahoma, Indiana, North Carolina. State and Rutgers are prestigious state universities that dress their varsity athletes in bright red and white uniforms, receive considerable state funding and are dedicated to similar costly but sometimes profitable bigtime intercollegiate athletic programs. The Sooners, Hoosiers and Wolfpack arrived as super powers in college sports many years ago.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 10The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a nineyearold state law preempted local rent control ordinances.

title: It Was a Dance All Right, but Few Danced
description: Carly Simon was teetering on the brink of having a baby, so she didn't dance.

title: College Results
description: SOCCER

title: U.F.T. Sues to Keep Its Checkoff
description: The United Federation of Teachers has sued in Federal Court in Manhattan for an injunction to forestall the union's doss of the dues checkoff as a penalty for an illegal fiveday strike last fall.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on a mathematical prodigy in yesterday's Times incorrectly stated, because of a transcription error, that Jan. 14 and Dec. 14, 1935, fell on Tuesday and Sunday, respectively. They fell on Monday and Saturday.

title: E.P.A. Backs CleanAir TradeOff Allowing New Industrial Pollution
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 10The Environmental Protection Agency announced today a controversial new airpollution enforcement policy that would permit new pollutioncausing industry even in areas where Federal air quality standards have not yet been met.

title: New Concern to Acquire Three Appliance Units
description: The Canadian Government announced yesterday that the appliance divisions of GSW Ltd., Canadian General Electric Company and Westinghouse Canada Ltd., will be acquired by a new company in which GSW and Canadian General Electric will each hold 50 percent of the voting shares.

title: Bonn Debate on Nazi Ace Delayed As Minister of Defense Is Stricken
description: BONN, Nov. 10Georg Leber, the West German Defense Minister, was hospitalized for an abdominal infection this morning just before a Parliamentary debate was to have been held on his controversial dismissal of two air force generals for defending a rightist extremist who was a Nazi divebomber pilot in World War II.

title: School Bias Charge...
description: The charges of discrimination leveled against the city's public school system by the Federal Government contain an odd mixture of legitimate and illogical criticism. The report by the Civil Rights Office of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare exposes practices which work to the detriment of racial minorities and of women in the competition for teaching and supervisory jobs. Regrettably, the investigators have confused what is theoretically desirable with what is practically attainable.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Probably no other subject these days arouses expressions of business frustration with Washington as easily as the Arabs economic boycott against Israel.

title: In Northwest, It's Cascades
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 10 (UPI)The new Northwest entry in World Team Tennis will be known as the Sea Port Cascades. Marty Loughman, the club's vice president and general manager, said the Cascades were trying to talk Ilie Nastase into another season of team tennis. Sea Port will play in both Portland and Seattle.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Another Male Bastion Falls: 21 Hires a Waitress
description: The 21 Club, repository of the old speakeasy tradition and bastion of boardroom macho, has bowed to legal pressure and hired its first waitress.

title: Vietnam Refugees Reach Australia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 10 (Reuters)A group of 50 Vietnamese arrived in Australia today in a fihing junk and the Government here said hundreds of additional refugees could be on their way. The group, 13 men, 13 women and 19 children, sailed their 35foot junk into Darwin after a 2,000mile, twomonth voyage from Vietnam.

title: U.N. Proposes Building Expansion To Provide Room for 170 Nations
A Long Criminal Career
description: Frankie Carbo was variously known as New York City's underworld czar of boxing, the man who pulls the strings and makes managers and fighters dance, and one of the nicest killers you could ever meet.

title: Direct LongDistance Dialing in 26th Year
description: ENGLEWOOD, Nov. 10The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company congratulated itself today with a big blue and white birthday cake on the 25th anniversary of direct longdistance dialing.

title: Arkansas Governor Says He Got Fund Offers From South Koreans
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 8Gov. David Pryor said today that he had twice refused to accept campaign contributions offered him by South Koreans, and that he had seen as many as 300 members of Congress attending parties held in Washington in the late 1960s and early 1970's that were given by Park Tong Sun,

title: World News Briefs
description: BERN, Nov. 10 (Reuters)  A police inquiry has found that the former air defense chief, Brig. JeanLouis Jeanmaire, spied for the Soviet Union with the help of his wife, Public Prosecutor Rudolf Gerber said today.

title: At Roosevelt..
description: After 3 weeks of programs in competition with the new Meadowlands track in New Jersey, George Morton Levy Sr., president and founder of the Long Island oval, sounded glum yesterday about his track's future.

title: 4 Hungarian Fencers Quit
description: BUDAPEST, Nov. 10 (UPI)  Four Hungarian fencers announced their retirement as an obvious result of their disappointing showing at the Montreal Olympics, the Hungarian news agency M.T.I. said today. The fencers were identified as Jenoe Kamuti, Laszlo Kamuti and Sandor Szabo, all foil fencers, and Pal Schmitt, an pe fencer.

title: Notes on People
description: Vera Zorina, the former prima ballerina, has been appointed general director and artistic administrator of the Norwegian Opera in Oslo. Miss Zorina, who was born in Germany of Norwegian parents, has been an American citizen since 1943, but she has been active in Norwegian cultural affairs for many years. In her new post, which she assumes next August, Miss Zorina succeeds Gunnar BrunoII. One of her predecessors was Kirsten Flagstad, the late

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTER AIDE CHOSEN TO GUIDE TRANSITION
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 10Postelection competition between two of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's chief aides has apparently left Jack Watson, Mr. Carter's liaison with the Ford Administration, in charge of a major share of all transitional responsibilities.

title: Senators on Israeli Visit Suggest Carter Appoint Kissinger Special Envoy
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 10Six United States senators today Jimmy Carter appoint U a special envoy to negotiations between Israelis. 10Six United recommended that Henry A. Kissinger initiate new peace the Arabs and the

title: Arson Alleged in School Fire
description: POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 10 (AP)Arson was to blame for a $100,000 fire that wrecked a cafeteria building at the Pine Forge Academy in nearby Douglas Township, Fire Marshal Edward Gleason said today. The building's interior had been doused with diesel fuel, Marshal Gleason said. Investigators also found a trail of fuel leading 135 feet to the building from a large container, he said. There were no injuries.

title: Beene Delivers Style 76 But Quietly.
description: Thousands of fashions destined to be worn next spring are being paraded on Seventh Avenue this week. Many of them are commercial, which in current fashion parlance means they are familiar enough to be easily understandable and flattering enough to most bodies so that women will buy them. Some of them are pretty. Few have style.

title: Sculpturgraphics Help Blind See by Feeling
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10Martin Lynch saw the Statue of Liberty today. He is 78 years old and blind.

title: Amin Takes Over Air Force
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 10 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda has taken over his country's air force during an investigation into the Israeli raid on Entebbe airport, the Uganda radio said today. It quoted him as saying that the acting air force commander had been sent on leave pending completion of the inquiry into last July's raid in which Israeli commandos rescued hostages of a hijacked French airliner.

title: MOZART'S REQUIEM OPENS SERIES AT ST. THOMAS
description: Sundays offer the most bountiful harvest of music in our city churches, but don't write off the weekdays just yet. One of the more ambitious choral series in town began Tuesday evening at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue at 53d Street, with well over 1,000 listeners at a, concert performance of Mozart's Requiem.

title: The U.N. Today
Pyotr N. Goremykin, 74, Is Dead; Former Soviet Arms Industry Aide
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 10 (Reuters)Pyotr N. Goremykin, who was closely connected with Soviet arms production during part of the cold war era, has died at the age of 74 after a long illness.

title: South Africa Dismisses Vote in U.N
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 10South Africa reacted contemptuously tonight to the antiapartheid resolutions approved yesterday by the General Assembly of the United Nations, vowing that it would never yield to international pressure even if it was forced into complete diplomatic isolation.

title: Stage: A Timeless Oedipus
description: Some 20 years after Sophocles created Opedipus Rex he wrote Oedipus at Colonus, showing us how the raging torrents of tragedy can turn into seemingly endless suffering. Confession and selfaccusation have not led to catharsis. Oedipus, old, blind, dressed in his regal rags, and finally on the precipice of extinction, has come to the outskirts of Athens, led there by his faithful daughter, Antigone.

title: ADVANCE IN RETAIL SALES IN OCTOBER WAS MODEST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)Retail sales in October turned in a disappointing performance for the fourth consecutive month, Government figures showed today.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Rosina Lhevinne, Pianist, Is Dead; Juilliard Teacher of Noted Students
description: Rosina Lhevinne, the noted pianist and teacher, died of a stroke Tuesday at the home of her daughter in Glendale, Calif. She was 96 years old. She moved only a few weeks ago to the West Coast from the Claremont Avenue apartment and studio in Manhattan where she had lived since 1944.

title: FRANCES E. BLAUFARB
description: Frances E. Blaufarb, who spent 40 years in the New York City public school system teaching disturbed elementary pupils, died Monday in her home in Washington after a long illness. Her age was 70.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: When the Left Isn't Right
description: LONDON, Nov. 9 (Reuters) Umberto Berlen, a 39yearold waiter, complained today that he was dismissed from his job at a London nightclub because he served wine over a diner's left shoulder instead of his right.

title: TV: Gibbsville on NBC Tonight
description: NBC has mercifully laid to rest Gemini Man in the big electronic graveyard for failed series. With some jiggling of the schedule, it is being replaced tonight at 10 with Gibbsville, which is based loosely, very loosely, on stories of John O'Hara.

title: COSTLIER INSURANCE FOR CARS PREDICTED
description: McAFEE, Nov. 10A special consultant to Governor Byrne told members of the Independent Insurance Agents Association today that by the end of the year more than onethird of the motorists in this state will be driving without liability insurance offered through regular market channels.

title: Susan Brown, Decorator, Married to Martin Baker
description: Susan K. Brown, an interior decorator, was married last evening to Matin S. Baker, a lawyer with Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen law fim. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel performed the ceremony in the home in Riverdale, the Bronx, of the bridegroom's mother, Elizabeth Baker.

title: 'Next Man' Plays on Paranoia
description: "The Next Man," which opened at the Rivoli and other theaters yesterday, is a suspense melodrama made by people whose talent for filmmaking and knowledge of international affairs would both fit comfortably into the left nostril of a small bee.It's about a visionary Saudi Arabian minister of state named Khalil Abdul-Muhsen, played by the very Scots-sounding Sean Connery, who proposes to defuse the Middle East by signing a mutual assistance pact with Israel and by making petroleum and petroleum by-products available virtually at cost to poor nations."The Next Man" is the story of the attempt by various vested interests in this country, the Soviet Union and the Middle East, acting separately, to put an end to this dreadful scheme by putting an end to Khalil.Like a lot of other films these days, "The Next Man" is obsessed with political assassination but it never really identifies its villains, preferring, instead, to cop out by playing on natural paranoia that assumes that everyone everywhere is on the take from someone somewhere. This attitude is too easy to represent true cynicism. It's simple laziness.In "The Next Man" the forces of reaction are represented entirely by a mysterious, exceedingly well-dressed young woman named Nicole Scott, said to be the daughter of a former American ambassador to Great Britain, a Bryn Mawr graduate, and a girl who apparently slays not for pay but for thrills of a sort you don't get in the Junior League.This character is played by Cornelia Sharpe, a new actress who is well on her way to becoming the actress producers will hire when they can't get Faye Dun-away. Miss Sharpe is stunning looking and model-skinny, and you don't for a minute believe her to be an international assassin any more than you believe Mr. Connery to be an Arab anything.The movie appears to agree. As if to take our minds off such matters, "The Next Man" moves rootlessly around the world like a fretful tourist, from New York to the Middle East, the south of France, London, Ireland, Bavaria, and the Bahamas, though nothing much happens in any one of these places that couldn't as easily happen somewhere else.The characters are always getting in and out of jets and coming upon colorful local festivals (including the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade in New York), and if there's no parade to look at, the script will arbitrarily have someone decide to climb into a helicopter to go sight-seeing. "The Next Man" is the first film I've ever seen that is so acutely bored with itself that it tries to go away.Who is responsible for mindless movie-making of this magnitude I've no idea, though it was produced by Martin Bregman, who also shares credit for the film's "original story" with Alan Trustman, who himself shares the screenplay credit with Mort Fine, David M. Wolf and Richard C. Sarafian, who directed the film. It looks as if too many people got into the act.There have been more expensive films this year, and more foolish ones, but "The Next Man" must be the most foolish film of such expense.

title: Power Bloc in Arab World
description: CAIRO, Nov. 10After months of political estrangement, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia have once again aligned their policies and agreed upon a joint Arab strategy aiming at negotiating an overall settlementin stages of the conflict with Israel. This in short, Arab diplomats say, is the meaning of the realignment that has taken place in the Arab world in recent weeks.

title: Senator Brooke Fighting Request For Data Sought in Divorce Suit
description: BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP)A lawyer for Senator Edward W. Brooke asked the State Supreme Court to block a request today by Mr. Brooke's wife for confidential Senate records she wants to use in divorcing her husband.

title: Jersey Company Is Fined $140 After Blast Injures TeenAger
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 11 (AP) A dental company whose teenage employee was blinded and burned when his automobile carrying volatile liquid gas exploded has been fined $140 for violating state child labor laws.

title: Suffolk Is Snowed Out
description: BOSTON, Nov. 10 (AP)Horse racing was canceled at Suffolk Downs today because of snow. A spokesman for the track said racing was expected to resume tomorrow.

title: Estimate on Corn Is Raised by 3% In a U.S. Survey
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)Farmers have almost finished harvesting a record 1976 corn crop of 6.06 billion bushels, the Agriculture Department said today. The department's Crop Reporting Board said corn prospects improved 3 percent since the previous estimate was made month ago.

title: The Poppies. The Stillness.
description: PEORIA, Ill.The 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month. That meant something special back in the days when people of my generation were growing up between the wars. Armistice Day was not so big as Christmas or July 4th, but big, even though most of us had come no closer to the war than reading about it in such books as The Army Boys in France or in the Collier's Illustrated History of the Great War.

title: Israel and South Africa
description: An ominous impression is gaining currency that there exists a sinister relationship between Israel and South Africa. This charge is being disseminated by forces In the third world, egged on by the Soviet Union. It focuses on Israel's trade and arms sales to South Africa, as evidenced by the controversial resolution adopted by the General Assembly on Tuesday that condemned Israel.

title: Capitals Rout Rangers, 75, With 4 Goals in Final Period
description: The New York Rangers allowed an enthusiastic, hardskating and remarkably fit Washington Capitals team to dictate the terms last night as they lost, 75, before an indignant home crowd that now has seen them lose five consecutive games.

title: Cleveland Businessman Indicted
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10A Cleveland businessman was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today for allegedly defrauding Japanese and Taiwanese industries of more than $1 million by failing to deliver highgrade plastic resins ordered by the concerns. Indicted was Jack A. Sharwell, 53 years old. who is alleged to have operated through J.S. International, a company with offices in New York and Los Angeles, and Marbon Distributors, New York.

title: SYRIAN ARMY UNITS MOVE INTO BEIRUT TO ENFORCE TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10Columns of Syrian tanks and combat troops entered Beirut today without firing a shot, in effect beginnning the final phase of Syria's military occupation of Lebanon in an effort to end the 19month civil war.

title: Utah Court, Granting Killer's Wish, Authorizes Death by Firing Squad
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 10The Utah Supreme Court, by a vote of 4 to 1, ruled today that a convicted murderer, who had asked to die like a man, can be executed by a firing squad next Monday.

title: U.S. REPORTEDLY ASKS RESIGNATION OF JUDGE
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia, Herbert A. Fogel, has been informed by high officials of the Department of Justice that he should resign from the bench after he refused to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating a criminal case and cited his constitutional rights against possible selfincrimination, according to Justice officials.

title: All Aboard for The Game
description: More than 700 Yale students will board a 10car Amtrak Special in New Haven on Saturday morning hound for Boston and The Game between Harvard and Yale at Cambridge, Mass.

title: Books of The Times
description: At a distance, one can make out what John Updike is up to in Marry Me: A Romance, the eighth novel and 20th hook he has published in his prodigiously productive career. At a distance, one can discern that he has written a more or less psychologically realistic story, yet framed it in such a way that we aren't supposed to identify with the characters or take their problems too seriously. The story concerns two suburban Connecticut couples, Jerry and Ruth Conant and Richard and Sally Mathias, each of whom has three young children, Jerry Cohant and Sally Mathias are in the midst of a heated affair with each otheran affair of winey beach trysts, secret trips to Washington and 10 A.M. telephone talks in the presence of the babysitter. They would like to leave their respective partners but must cope with questions of loyalty, the children, God's punishment and the possibility that they only desire each other because of their mutual unavailability. Their passion is realistically played out, at least to the extent that Mr. Updike evokes, as only he can with his exact and graceful prose, precisely what it must feel like to he caught in such an untenable yet compelling predicament

title: Perils of a Chemical World
description: In 1973 a fire retardant containing a toxic industrial chemical called PBB was accidentally mixed into annual feeds in Michigan, poisoning hundreds of thousands of farm animals and producing wideranging complaints of illness among people who ate PBBcontaminated animal products.

title: Meany Opposes WagePrice Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10  George Meany, organized Iabor's chief spokesman, expressed strong opposition today to any reintroduction of wageprice guidelines, but said that labor would be willing to discuss wageprice restraint with business under White House auspices.

title: Figure Skating Growing As a Performing Art
description: When John Curry first approached Twyla Tharp about breaking the ice with him, it was almost worse than preparing for an Olympic final.

title: Commodity Futures Make Firm Gains As Soybeans Lead
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP)Farm commodity futures moved firmly ahead on the Chicago Board of Trade today, led by soybeans again of more than 10 cents a bushel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thirteen more persons were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Newark on charges of using $1 million of a bank's funds for financing loanshark and gambling operations. The defendants include Alexander T. Smith, 42 years old, of Ramsey, N.J., president of the State Bank of Chatham before it collapsed On April 4, and George Fiore, 45, of Chatham Township, N.J., and Anthony Maltese, 40, of Saddle River, N.J., former members of the bank's board of directors. The latest charges followed the indictment Tuesday of Robert L. Prodan, former president of the Bank of Bloomfield, and Donald Spears, former president of the State Bank of Springfield, along with 10 others, on similar charges involving the illegal use of $4.3 million of bank resources.

title: DIFFERENCES PERSIST ON CAREER EDUCATION
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10More than 6,000 supporters of career education are meeting here thiis week to take stock of movement that in less than six years has reached into thousands of school systems and caused a reappraisal of the relationship between the roles of education and work.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: Ford Aide Says President Weighs Variety of Options for His Future
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 10President Ford, still recuperating from his losing campaign, is slowly coming to grips with a fundamental question: What does a reasonably young and vigorous exPresident do with the rest of his life?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Article 2  No Title
Island Where Killing Took Place Known as Site of Illicit Activities
description: INDIAN ISLAND, Nov. 10This milesquare nature sanctuary has been the scene of many forbidden activities in the last few yearshunting, camping, the making of fires and beerdrinkLast Friday night, it became the scena of what the Suffolk County police are calling a murder.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Boys 12 and 14 Held After Mugging Of 103YearOld Brooklyn Woman
description: Officers of the anticrime police unit arrested two boys aged 12 and 14 yesterday after they knocked a 103yearold woman to a Brooklyn sidewalk to steal a bag of groceries.

title: Arms Talks Off Till Next Week
description: GENEVA, Nov. 10 (UPI)Soviet and American negotiators at the talks on limitation of strategic arms held a 45minute meeting today, the 176th of the second and current round of the talks that began on Nov. 21, 1972. The next meeting was set for a week from today.

title: British Government Loses a Key Vote On DockUnion Bill
description: LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Britain's Labor Party Government was defeated in Parliament early today on amendments to a key bill being promoted by Prime Minister James Callaghan at the insistence of the party's powerful left wing.

title: RACHEL NEWMAN
description: Rachel Newman, mother of Phyllis Newman, the Broadway and television actress and singer, died Tuesday in Christ Hospital, Jersey City, after a short illness. She was 76 years old and lived at 2465 Kennedy Boulevard, Jersey City.

title: Fine Major Barbara, for the Love of Shaw
description: PRINCETON, N.J.Over the last few years the McCarter Theater, with its peculiarly symbiotic relationship with Princeton University, has become one of the best resident theaters in the country. This has been due to men such as Lou Criss, Dan Seltzer and, nowadays, its current producing director, Michael Kahn. It not only offers a generally good repertory, but it also has an unusually high level of production values.

title: Article 1  No Title
BLOOD, SWEAT AND TEARS PLAYS THE EMPIRE ROOM
description: Blood, Sweat and Tears arrived at a perfect pop formula in 1967. Blend one inoffensive but personable vocalistDavid ClaytonThomaswith a rock rhythm section, some jazz horn players and as many catchy hit tunes as possible. For a while it worked like a charm. Then a jazzier band tried to succeed on its own while Mr. ClavtonThomas began a solo

title: ... Rational Response
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker has underscored the futility of discussing hiring procedures at a time when the system's major problem is one of laying off teachers. This does not make corrective steps irrelevant, if only to prevent discrimination in the rehiring of teachers. This does not make corrective step irrelevant, if only to prevent discrimination in the rehiring of teachers as retirements or improved city finances may make it possible to bring back some of the dismissed teachers.

title: Gold Hits $136.50 An Ounce
description: LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP)Gold prices made another substantial advance in London today, reaching their highest level since early January.

title: Celebrations and Protests Greet Hirohito on His 50th Anniversary
description: TOKYO, Nov. 10Some Japanese celebrated the 50th anniversary of Emperor Hirohito's reign today. Others did not, and some even protested.

title: People and Business
description: Harvey Kapnick, a persistent critic of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, yesterday urged the rulemaking group's architects to reconvene at once and review its lack of performance.

title: Florida Man Indicted for Murder
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 10 (AP)A grand jury has issued kidnapping and murder indictments against a Pompano Beach painter accused in the death of an 8yearold girl. The Broward County grand jury charged yesterday that James Rose, 30, had abducted Lisa Lynn Berry from a bowling alley, killed her and left her body in a weedchoked canal 12 miles away.

title: BIG JOE TURNER'S BACK, WITH THAT 40'S WARMTH
description: It is more than 30 years since Big Joe Turner was last heard in a New York club shouting the blues in his huge, sonorous voice. That was when he had a fiveyear run at Cafe Society in the early 40's with Pete Johnson rolling out a thunderous boogiewoogie accompaniment on piano. After this long absence, Barney Josephson, who owned Cafe Society, has finally lured Mr. Turner back to town to sing at his current restaurant, The Cookerie, University Place at Eighth Street.

title: Conference Room 4BIn Use
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 10Across from the conference room, soft bells signal the arrival of elevators as secretaries shuffle quietly along the beige carpet. Copies of Business Week magazine adorn the coffee table surrounded by four chairs and a plastic plant in the waiting area. In the office cubicles, bankers with vests and attache cases mull investments here on the fourth floor of the modern Rhode Island Hospital Trust National Bank building. Inside the conference room, Jerry Kapstein sits in a purple chair at a gleaming rosewood table and discusses investments with baseball club officials sitting in similar chairs. But outside there is no secretary, no name on the door, no identification, only a small, unobtrusive sign, Conference Room 4BIn Use. And it's in almost constant use. Jerry Kapstein, intense, deepvoiced, blackhaired, short, slim, 33 years old, is handling the negotiations for 10 of the 14 most coveted baseball players now available as free agents Joe Rudi, Gene Tenace, Bert Campaneris, Rollie Fingers, Don Baylor, Don Gullett, Dave Cash, Bobby Grich, Wayne Garland and Doyle Alexander.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An official involved in the 20,000acre Hackensack Meadowlands development said yesterday that construction;had surpassed $53 million this year,making 1976 the most productive period in the sixyear effort in the area. The official, Commissioner Richard Milano, told his fellow members on the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission that construction permits for the first 10 months of 1976 had totaled $53,420,000. Construction totaled $39.3 million during all of 1975, according to Mr. Milano, who predicted total construction in the region this year could surpass $60 million by Dec. 31.

title: Recital: Obraztsova's Passion
description: The unusual voice and highly theatrical style that made Elena Obraztsova's debut at the Metropolitan Opera this fall so sensational were constantly in evidence in her first recital here on Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall. They won her a big success with the large audience that came prepared to love her with rhythmic clapping at the end.

title: DR. MIHRAN H. EXERJIAN
description: Dr. Mihran H. Exerjian, a practicing physician in the metropolitan area for 54 years, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 2517 23d Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, where he also had offices.

title: The Rev. C. Leslie Glenn, 76, the Former Rector Of Church of Presidents,
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The Rev. Dr. C. Leslie Glenn, subdean of the Washington Cathedral and former rector of St. John's Church here, known as the church of the Presidents, died of a heart attack Monday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Parking Ticket Politics
description: The laws and regulations governing parking are not at all mysterious. The city abounds with signs which explain where parking is or is not permitted. Fire hydrants are offlimits. Doubleparking is illegal. New yorkers should be entitled to assume that enforcement of these rules is considered by the police as a matter of routine, not of whim. And there can be no question that the parking and other traffic laws require a rigorous enforcement that they seldom receive.

title: Frankie Carbo, Underworld Figure Once Known as the Czar of Boxing
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 10 (AP)Frankie Carbo, onetime underworld boss in a boxing organization, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 72 years old.

title: Campaign Will Seek Parochial Students
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10 (UPI)  The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark is recruiting parents of parochial school pupils to increase enrollment by promoting the benefits of a religious education.

title: Last Execution Was In Colorado in 1967
description: CANON CITY, Colo., Nov. 10 (UPI) On a cabinet near the gas chamber of the Colorado State Penitentiary hangs a small tarnished ,brass tag engraved with the prison number and name of the last, person to be executed in the United States.

title: College Aide Denies Embezzling
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10 (AP)James Dale of Dover, a former fiscal officer tor the Urban Institute at Montclair State College, has pleaded not guilty to charges he embezzled more than $24,000 in state funds. Mr. Dale, 31 years old, was released yesterday on $5,000 bail.

title: Bay State Is Trying to Revive Potentially Rich Coalfield
description: MANSFIELD, Mass.For the last four months, strange machines, looking vaguely like spindly Erector sets, have been traversing the southeast corner of Massachusetts on the backs of pickup trucks in search of coal.

title: Rates Advance as a Heavy Volumes Of TaxFree Issues Come to Market
description: Interest rates on state and city bonds rose yesterday as the taxexempt securities market shouldered a heavy volume of new issues, with Pennsylvania selling $147 million and Washing $84 million. Elsewhere in the credit markets, however, prices rose slightly and interest rates moved downward as traders prepared for today's slowdown resulting from the Veterans Day partial holiday.

title: Bernard A. Culloton Dies at 79; ExMotor Vehicle Aide in Albany
description: Bernard A. Culloton, a former deputy commissioner of Motors Vehicles and chief administrative officer of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, died Tuesday in Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y., after a heart attack. He was 79 years old and lived at 175 Pearl Street. Kingston.

title: The Northeast Organizes
description: Buoyed by hopes of a more sympathetic Administration in Washington, the governors of sevenand possibly moreNortheastern states will meet in Saratoga Springs this weekend with representatives of industry, labor and education to develop plans for obtaining more Federal assistance for regional redevelopment.

title: Key Witness Jailed For Not Testifying At Castellano Trial
description: The Federal Government's main witness against Paul Castellano, the brotherinlaw of the late Carlo Gambino, decided yesterday that he would rather go to jail than testify against Mr. Castellano, who is on trial with six other men on loansharking charges.

title: AirAide Who Complained Is Out
Charges Against Mao's Widow Now Extend to Movies
description: HONG KONG, Nov.10Chiang Ching, Mao Tsetung's widow, and her three political colleagues now reported under arrest helped make a movie this year that symbolically atttacked Chou Enlai, the late Prime Minister, and the new party chairman, Hua Kuofeng, according to the Chinese press and radio.

title: Rebel Angolans Said to Be in Flight
description: OSHAKATI, SouthWest Africa, Nov. 10 (Reuters)South African officials said today that Angolan guerrillas who had been locked in fierce fighting with Angolan Government and Cuban forces for five days were trying to retreat into the bush to escape superior firepower.

title: SYRIAN ARMY UNITS MOVE INTO BEIRUT TO ENFORCE TRUCE; NO RESISTANCE ENCOUNTERED; Action, Under an Arab Agreement, Is Part of Military Occupation Aimed at Ending Civil War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10Columns of Syrian tanks and combat troops entered Beirut today without firing a shot, in effect beginnning the final phase of Syria's military occupation of Lebanon in an effort to end the 19month civil war.

title: Iceberg Shortage Ahead?
description: Mention icebergs and most people's minds immediately turn to thoughts of danger, to recollections of the Titanic sinking beneath the sea with terrible loss of life, after crashing into one of those huge, frozen masses In the North Atlantic. Such images begin in elementary school when children learn about the patrols that chart the number and paths of floating icebergs to warn ships and prevent repetition of a Titanic disaster.

title: Power Bloc in Arab World
description: CAIRO, Nov. 10After months of political estrangement, Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia have once again aligned their policies and agreed upon a joint Arab strategy aiming at negotiating an overall settlementin stages News of the conflict with Israel. This in short, Arab diploAnalysis mats say, is the meaning of the realignment that has taken place in the Arab world in recent weeks.

title: Miss Lamhut Demonstrates Dance Variety
description: Phyllis Lamhut and her company made their first appearance Tuesday at the Roundabout, Stage One as part of the Dance Umbrella series, with Hearts of Palm, a dance dedicated to the late James Waring, for whom sense of style was inborn.

title: Cowens Given Leave From Celtics' Team
description: Dave Cowens, the center for the Boston Celtics, was granted a leave of absence for an indefinite period for personal reasons before last night's game against the Los Angeles Lakers at the Boston Garden.

title: TELEFUNKEN TO SELL KRAFTWERK INTEREST
description: AEG Telefunken, the West German electrical equipment manufacturer, said yesterday that it was selling its 50 percent interest in Kraftwerk Union, a major powerplant producer, to Siemens AG, another large electricalequipment manufacturer, for $255.8 million.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, second to the United States Steel Corporation in production, announced yesterday that it had closed certain operations due to a slackening in demand for steel.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on a mathematical prodlgy in yesterday's Times incorrectly stated, because of a transcription error, that Jan. 14 and Dec. 14, 1935, fell on Tuesday and Sunday, respectively. They fell on Monday and Saturday.

title: Margiotta May Replace Rosenbaum As G.O.P. Chairman in New York
description: Vice President Rockefeller and Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican leader of Nassau County, have discussed the possibility of Mr. Margiotta's replacing Richard M. Rosenbaum as the Republican chairman of New York State, a spokesman for the Vice President said last night.

title: Pupils See Teacher Shot to Death
description: DETROIT, Nov. 10 (UPI) An elementary school teacher was shot to death today in her classroom in front of her 30 pupils in the first and second grade. The police said that the gunman barged into the classroom and shot Bettye McCaster, 45 years old, at least twice in the head. She died instantly. The police later arrested a man they believed to be her estranged husband in connection with the slaying.

title: WORLD CHESS OLYMPIAD IS WON BY THE U.S. TEAM
description: HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 10 (Reuters)The United States won the World Chess Olympiad here today, taking a title held for 24 years by the Soviet Union, which declined to take part in this year's competition.

title: Hanna Talks to Grand Jury
description: Former Representative Richard T. Hanna of California has appeared before Federal grand jury and testified of his secret partnership with Tongsun Park, his lawyer confirmed today.

title: Connecticut to Fight Whalers Tax Escape
description: A maneuver by the City or Hartford that will prevent Connecticut from taxing tickets to New England Whaler hockey games was criticized yesterday by the state's Tax Commission. We're upset about it, said Gerald Heffernan, commission chairman, and we intend to, ask for legislation that will close this loophole.

title: Connors Triumphs, 63, 61; Borg, Vilas Hard Pressed
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 10 (AP)Bjorn Borg and Guillermo Vilas had tough battles today in advancing to the third round of the $150,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament.

title: American Motors Deficit Sets Record as Sales Lag
description: DETROIT; NOV. 10The American Motors Corporation, mired in a serious sales slump for nearly a year, reported today a record loss of $51.1 million for the three months ended Sept. 30.

title: Canadian Prices Up in October
description: OTTAWA. Nov. 10 (UPI)Canada's consumer price index rose 0.7 in October from September, Statistics Canada announced today. The increase, the highest monthly advance since May, brought Canada's annual inflation rate to 6.2 percent, down from the 10.7 percent recorded for the same month a year ago.

title: The Problem of Enormous Buildup of International Debt
description: The biggest single worry in financial markets these days is over the enormous buildup of international debtmuch of it owed to private commercial hanks. There is no way to conceal the danger that some heavy borrowers from abroad may be unable to meet their obligations. Nobody really knows just how large the mountain of international debt is. But what is important is not the aggregate figure, which runs into hundreds of billions of dollars, but the ability of particular nations to meet their payments.

title: Big Board Seat Sold at $45,000
description: The price of a membership declined again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The price fell to $45,000, off $5,000 from the prior sale on Tuesday. Seats are now quoted at $40,000 bid and $60,000 offered.

title: 40,000 REPORTED HELD IN HARSH LAOS CAMPS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Thousands of former rightist and neutralist Laotians are confined in harsh and repressive internment camps scattered throughout Laos, according to accounts being received here.

title: Sex Talk Parlor Loses Licenses
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 10 (UPI)The city commission yesterday revoked the license of Madames, described as a sex talk parlor that the commission claimed defrauded male tourists by promising sex but not delivering. An unidentified California visitor said that advertising had lured him to the place. He thought he would get sex but instead found bikiniclad girls reading from sexy books.

title: Utah Court, Granting Killer's Wish, Authorizes Death by Firing Squad; Appeal of 4to1 Decision Is Still a Possibility Prisoner Makes Plea to Die Like a Man
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 10The Utah Supreme Court, by a vote of 4 to 1, ruled today that a convicted murderer, Who had asked to die like a man, can be executed by a firing squad next Monday.

title: Closings Are Partial On Veterans Holiday
description: Public schools, banks and most New York City and state agencies will be closed because of the Veterans Day state holiday today, and alternate side of the street parking regulations will be suspended.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STAMPING GROUND That enterprising downtown showcase for the arts, the Theater for the New City, at 113 Jane Street, is presenting a festival of new works by Greenwich Village writers dealing with the Village. The event starts today and will run through Nov. 24.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: DEMOCRATS DEBATE OVER BEST METHOD TO HALT RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov.10Members of the liberal Democratic establishment in the economicpolicy area, who think pretty much alike:most of the time, are finding themselves divided as they attempt to devise the policies they believe may be necessary to speed up the recovery from the recession.

title: Boys Choir, Turned Coed by U.S. Regulation, Seeks Ways to Preserve Unique Sound
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn.To Washington lawyers and tinear bureaucrats, Reg. 45CFR, Part 86, Sec. 901, Title IX of the Higher Education Act was a jaw against discrimination in choirs, limiting membership requirements to vocal range and quality.

title: Alex Gordon, Tennis Pro, Dies At 56He Headed U.S.P.T.A.
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 10 (AP)Alex Gordon, the immediate past president of the United States Professional Tennis Association, the teaching pros group, died yesterday in a hospital. His age was 56.

title: Philadelphia Hotel Closing, a Casualty Of Legion Disease
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10The Bellevue Stratford, this city's principal convention hotel and a cultural landmark in whose ballroom thousands of Main Line debutantes waltzed into Philadelphia society, became today another casualty of last summer's unsolved mystery epidemic of legionnaires' disease.

title: New York City's Presidential Vote Fell Compared With Rest of State's
description: New York City voters cast only 32.6 percent of the total state vote in last week's Presidential electiona share that was down 4 percentage points from the 1972 election and 10 percentage points from the 1960 Presidential election.

title: Beame Seeks RealtyTax Change to Offset Loss From Overdue Payment
description: Mayor Beame is quietly seeking a change in the way the city calculates its real estate tax rate, to permit future increases that take into account the revenues lost from property owners who are delinquent in their tax payments.

title: Bomb Suspects Face Joint Trial
description: PORTLAND, Me. Nov. 10 (AP)A joint trial is scheduled to begin Dec. 13 in United States District Court for two suspected bombers, Richard J. Picariello and Edward P. Gullion Jr. The date was set today by Judge Edward T. Gignoux, who denied defense motions that the two be tried separately and that the trial date be postponed. They were among four persons indicted here last summer on charges of transporting explosives used in the July 1 bombings of a National Guard truck in Boston, a jetliner at Logan International Airport, and the Essex County Courthouse in Newburyport, Mass.

title: Pact Ends SitIn at Lincoln Hospital
description: About 100 sitin demonstrators ended their protest at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx yesterday after they and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation negotiated a settlement of their demands for a voice in the appointment of a new executive director.

title: 200 Attend Queens Mass for Student Killed During R.O.T.C. Exercise
description: The day started chilling, drizzling yesterday. But then a bright sun came out, and it was almost a symbol of the promise of resurrection being affirmed in the Roman Catholic Mass for the mourning family of Thomas Fitzgerald.

title: Corning Galloping Into Museum of West
description: CORNING, N.Y., Nov. 10Before Hollywood laid claim to it, the picture of the American West was conveyed to the rest of the country mostly by Eastern artists, such as Frederic Remington, who journeyed out to capture images that showed up in stereopticons and on the pages of Harper's Weekly.

title: 3 Guilty of Slaying a Man Helping Off DutyOfficer Avert a Brooklyn Holdup
description: Three men were convicted of murder yesterday in the slaying last December of a Good Samaritan seeking to aid an offduty policeman and thwarting the holdup of a Brooklyn candy store.

title: 8 OKLAHOMANS ACCUSED OF TAPPING OIL PIPELINE
description: TULSA, Nov. 10 (UPI)A Federal grand jury reported today that a secret tap on a TexastoOklahoma pipeline was used to siphon $335,000 worth of crude' oil until the tap was discovered.

title: Celebrations and Protests Greet Hirohito on His 50th Anniversary
description: TOKYO, Nov. 10Some Japanese celebrated the 50th anniversary of Emperor Hirohito's reign today. Others did not, and some even protested.

title: Editors Get Advice on How to Halt Decline in Newspaper Readership
description: It has been a kind of American newspaper tradition for the news side of a newspaper to look askance on suggestions or anything resembling pressure from the business side, on the belief that freedom of the press is best served this way.

title: Police Management Tightened by Codd To Cope With Cuts
description: Commissioner Michael J. Codd yesterday announced the establishment of a managerial team to help the Police Department cope with a reduction of nearly 18 percent in the force in the last two years because of the city's financial difficulties.

title: Muti Leads the Philadelphians
description: Because Riccardo Muti has been appointed principal guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra for next season and must, therefore, be regarded as a leading candidate to succeed Eugene Ormandy as its music director, the Italian maestro's appearance wth the orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night was of more than passing interest.

title: Olympic Plans Of Lake Placid Are Criticized
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 10 (AP) The 1980 Winter Olympic Games, as currently planned, threaten to destroy the beauty and wilderness values of the Adirondack Mountains, especially the famed high peaks, the Sierra Club charged today.

title: Cherry River, Bought for $600, Top Contender in Aqueduct Dash
description: Some of the older horsemen at Aqueduct did considerable reminiscing yesterday when they learned that Douglas Oliver's Cherry River had arrived from California to take part in this after non's $50,000 added Sports Page. Cherry River is the 6yearold gelding who was purchased by Oliver  he's also the trainer  as a 2yearold colt at Saratoga for only $600. The youngster was gelded immediately but wasn't much of a racer as a juvenile. Since then he's improved steadily and now has earnings of $245,460.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: I.T.T. Reports 30.2% Gain in Profit For Quarter and Raises Dividend
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday a 30.2 percent increase in thirdquarter earnings. Harold S. Geneen, chairman, announced a quarterly dividend increase to 44 cents from 40 cents.

title: BONN TO PAY UNEMPLOYED WHO MOVE TO DISTANT JOBS
description: BONN, Nov. 10The West German Government approved a limited $180 million plan today to pay the unemployed to move and find new jobs. There are 944,000 persons without jobs, or 4.1 percent of the labor force.

title: Annenberg Offers Metropolitan Museum $20 Million For Art Communications Center Headed by Hoving
description: A pledge of $20 million to the Metropolitan Museum for a communications center to make the world's art more available to mass audiences has been made by Walter H. Annenberg, former Ambassador to Britain and a Metropolitan trustee since 1974.

title: HENRY PRICE DOMINATED BY BARBER'S BURLESQUE
description: Sarah Caldwell's production of II Barbiere di Siviglia is burlesque opera rather than comic opera, and probably ought to have talent on the order of Jerry Lewis or Zero Mostel to carry it off properly. At Tuesday night's City Opera performance, at any rate, the only members of the cast who consistently prevailed over the stage business and the ridiculous costumes were Beverly Sills, the unsinkable soprano, and Nicholas Muni, in a mime role.
