The others, including Henry Price, who was singing his first Almaviva with the company, were pretty well overshadowed.

title: Taxi Unit Called a Failure on Gypsy Cabs
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission was accused yesterday by City Council Finance Committee members of failing to enforce regulations against illegally cruising gypsy taxicabs.

title: Copper: Gloomy Picture for the Industry
description: Two months ago, market letter writers were forecasting that copper would rise to an average of 80 cents a pound. They saw the price at $1 by the end of 1977.

title: Philadelphia Hotel Closing, a Casualty of Legion Disease
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10The Bellevue Stratford, this city's principal convention hotel and a cultural landmark in whose ballroom thousands of Main Line debutantes waltzed into Philadelphia society, became today another casualty of last summer's unsolved mystery epidemic of legionnaires disease.

title: FRANK J. VOLZ
description: Frank J. Volz, an assistant vice president with the stock brokerage firm of Shields, Model & Roland in New York City, died Monday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital. Mr. Volz, who lived in North Caldwell, N. J., was 68 years old. He was the founder and a charter member of the Hunterdon County Sportsmen Association, a hunting club. He is survived by a son, Christopher: a daughter, Barbara Ann; a brother and two sisters.

title: BILLY ARNOLD, WHO WON 1930 INDY 500, IS DEAD
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 10 (AP)Billy Arnold, winner of the 1930 Indianapolis 500mile race by 17 miles, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 66 years old and a native of Chicago.

title: British Make a New Bid To Break the Deadlock At Rhodesia Conference
description: GENEVA, Nov. 10Britain made a new effort today at the conference on the future of Rhodesia here to break the deadlock on the date for legal independence under black majority rule.

title: AUTO REBATE MOVE DEPRESSES STOCKS
description: Worrisome news from Detroit's automobile industrythe pacemaker of the economic rebound earlier this yearsent the stock market abruptly lower yesterday to its fourth decline in a row.

title: Advertising
description: Mego International, the toy company that promises to spend $15 million for media advertising next year, has chosen Ted Bates & Company to be its agency beginning Jan. 1.

title: Music: Cleveland Quartet Begins Beethoven Cycle
description: The 16th Beethoven quartets are in effect the calling card of any important string quartet. Credentials are immediately established. Last night in Tully Hall, the Cleveland Quartet gave the first concert of their Beethoven cycle, choosing a representative work from each periodthe B flat Quartet (Op. 18, No. 6), the F major (Op. 59, No. 1) and the A minor (Op. 132).

title: Islanders and Bruins Play Alike and Tie, 22
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11  Justice triumphed at Boston Garden tonight. Two of the National Hockey League's best clubs, the Islanders and the Boston Bruins, checked, shot, saved and scored each other into a stalemate, the game ending in a deserved 22 tie.

title: Revenue Service Unveils A New 1040 Tax Form That's More Complicated
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11(AP)The Internal Revenue Service, two weeks behind schedule, unveiled today a more complex 1040 tax form that will mean more effort by taxpayers when they calculate how much they owe for 1976.

title: Art of Russian Stage Design Is Shown
description: Stage Designs and the Russian AvantGarde (19111929), the very fine exhibition that runs through tomorrow in the main gallery of the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, recalls Serge Diaghilev's dinnertable judgment on these first Russian manifestations of modern art.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Ballet: Dutch National in Three by Three
description: The second program of the Dutch National Ballet arrived at the Minskoff Theater last night and, as with the first, it offered a sampler of the company's three choreographic directors, Rudi van Dantzig, the troupe's artistic director, Hans van Manen and Toer van Schayk.

title: Unmarried Couples: Women May Be Losers Under the Law
description: One of the nation's leading authorities on Family Court matters warns that women are very likely to be the losers among unwed couples who are increasingly and, in her opinion, misguidedly deciding against legal marriage even when there are children.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Nov. 11, 1976

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Department of Commerce reported today that total, retail store sales last week were an estimated $12.51 billion, up about 7 percent from the year  earlier level of $11.74 billion. Department store sales were about $1.37 billion, a rise of about 7 percent from $1.29 billion last year.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT IS TOO EASY to laugh at The Sorcerer of Bolinas Reef, which may be seen as the afterbirth of Charles Reich's bestselling The Greening of America. Like that book, this one is incrediblyhis favorite wordgreen, which is to say naive, simplistic and sentimental. The language alone is enough to set your teeth on edge. In his doctrinaire emotionalism, Mr. Reich reminds me of a scene in a fine old Grard Philippe movie. Mr. Philippe plays a halfhearted gigolo who is attempting to exploit a soulful young Englishwoman acted by Joan Greenwood. It is one of her peculiarities that she insists on caressing his face against the grain, from the chin up to the forehead, pulling his features out of shape in the process. Mr. Reich's language and his ideas are rather like that. He means to be soulful, but the effect is often abrasive.

title: U. S. Riders Laud Japanese Racing
description: TOKYO, Nov. 11  The jockeys are well paid. First class room and board are free. Races are held only on weekends. The horses run the wrong way. The crowds are orderly and quiet. No one speaks English or Spanish. There are hills on the tracks and everyone at the race course is happy, friendly and polite.

title: Santa Clara Valley Leads in Circuitry
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.In the intellectual boom towns of Silicon Valley, electronics engineers who want to earn degrees from nearby Stanford University have been able to take courses for credit via live television for the last seven yearsat a vast saving in commuting time for themselves and for the hightechnology companies that foot the bill.

title: Buying on Impulse Along Canal Street
description: Decisions, decisions. There I was last Saturday at the Canal Jean Company after a day's browsing and picking at bargains along Canal Street with only $4 left of my original $25 bankroll, and I didn't know what to buy.

title: Town Hall, 55, Has Something To Sing About
description: LIKE AN AGING BEAUTY who can boast of a glamorous youth, but who now lives in somewhat seedy surroundings and has an uncertain future, Town Hall is going to celebrate its 55th birthday Sunday night with a chinup tribute to its considerable past and present achievements. It will be a starstudded party, as befits an auditorium where such artists as Josef Hofmann, Fritz Kreisler, Emanuel Feuermann, Lotte Lehmann, John McCormack and Billie Holiday once performed.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Plea to Halt Classes Rejected
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Nov. 11 (UPI)The administration at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro has denied a request to halt classes until an intestinal virus epidemic is brought under control. The student government made the request yesterday after school officials reported that 550 students had been treated in the university clinic since the epidemic began last Friday.

title: POLITICAL PARTIES RESTORED IN EGYPT
description: CAIRO, Nov. 11President Anwar elSadat announced tonight the reinstitution of a limited version of the multiple political party system that was abolished in Egypt shortly after the 1952 revolution headed by Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Union Commerce Corporation, parent of a billiondollar Cleveland bank, disclosed in a document made available today at the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was conducting a special investigation into certain transactions that appeared to involve the international division of the Union Commerce Bank.

title: Rep. Hechler Concedes Defeat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)  Representative Ken Hechler conceded defeat today in his West Virginia reelection bid, giving House Democrats the same number of seats they had in the last Congress290with three elections still undecided. Democrats were winning one of the undecided races and were losing two. If the elections wind up the way they're going now, the new House will have 291 Democrats and 144 Republicans.

title: Pop Music: Cate Brothers
description: Ernie and Earl Cate have been playing rock music for a decade, now, but most of that time was spent as a highclass bar band in their native Arkansas. More recently they've been on the road as part of a quartet called the Cate Brothers. A year and a half ago they did a tour with Queen, in one of booking's more curious pairings. At that time they sounded like a slightly younger version of the band. Ernie Cate's voice was reminiscent of Levon Helm, and in fact it turned out that not only was the Cate Brothers' drummer, Terry Cagle, a nephew of Mr. Helm, but that Mr. Helm himself had played drums off and on with the group in the past.

title: Joseph Klingenstein, Broker, Dies; Helped Found Mount Sinai in 1927
description: Joseph Klingenstein, honorary chairman of the New York investment banking concern of Wertheim & Company, 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, which he had helped found in 1927, and longterm benefactor of Mount Sinai Hospital, of which he had been president, died yesterday at his home at 1120 Park Avenue. He was 85 years old.

title: HIDDEN SUBSIDIES IN HOUSING SCORED
description: John G. Heimann, who will shortly take over an expanded and more powerful office of New York State Housing Commissioner, yesterday urged an end to what he called hidden subsidiesthe kind of tax relief and reduced borrowing costs for developers that have long been a hallmark of housing and other construction programs in New York and elsewhere.

title: EXECUTION IN UTAH STAYED BY GOVERNOR
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 11Gov. Calvin L. Rampton today stayed the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore until after the State Board of Pardons meets Wednesday.

title: Hidden Subsidies In Housing Scored
description: John G. Heimann, who will shortly take over an expanded and more powerful office of New York State Housing Commissioner, yesterday urged an end to what he called hidden subsidiesthe kind of tax relief and reduced borrowing costs for developers that have long been incentives for housing and other construction: in New York and elsewhere.

title: DONALD WASSON
description: Donald Wasson, a librarian, died Tuesday, at his home at 45 East Ninth Street In Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: Studs Lonigan's Hall of Fame
description: From now until February, sportswriters in every city in the major leagues will be favored with campaign literature  as if they needed it this soon after Nov. 2from volunteers promoting various candidates for the baseball Hall of Fame. It is almost always baseballhardly ever football, which has shrines for college players and for professionals, or basketball or golf. Maybe that is because most of the electioneers are getting a trifle long in the tooth and were baseball fans in their youth, because baseball was by far the most popular spectator sport then. One such fan is James T. (Studs Lonigan) Farrell, who is nobody's campaign manager but does enjoy writing and talking baseball and remembering the players he watched when he was growing up in Chicago. Now and then, when he has time to kill between lectures on literature at Harvard or Notre Dame, he'll knock out something like this:

title: Art: New Collages By William Dole
description: FEW ARTISTS give so delicate and so consistent a pleasure as William Dole, whose new collages are on view at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, through Nov. 27.

title: Publishing: Seeing Freud's Place in Vienna
description: IN 1938. SHORTLY AFTER THE Nazis overran Austria in what they called the Anchluss, or union, influential friends of Sigmund Freud in other countries were working to his safe passage to England. He finally made the journey in June 1938. But in May of that year a friend of Freud's suggested to Edmund Engelman, a 31  year  old engineer and photograph buff, that a pictorial record ought to be made of the offices and living quarters where Freud and his family lived for 47 years and where psychoanalysis was horn. Despite the hazards, Mr. Engelman agreed to do the job.

title: A Lebanon Christian Leader, Edde, Escapes Gunman
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 11A prominent Christian politician who is the most outspoken Lebanese opponent of Syria's dominating military presence survived a machinegun attack upon him today from a passing car in Moslemdominated west Beirut.

title: For Children
description: Plays

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: FROM ITS BEGINNINGS around 23d Street all the way up to 57th Street, Madison Avenue is a serious working street. Office is piled upon office, the business suit is mandatory, supplicants cower in waiting rooms, and chairmen of the board glare across desks as big as billiard tables. Madison Avenue begins with a thumping great No. 1 (the 50story Metropolitan Life Insurance Building of 1909) and goes on much like that all the way up to the Fuller Building on the northeast corner of 57th Street. It has the Morgan Library at 36th, it has two huge hotels of a miscellaneous sort (the Biltmore and the Roosevelt), it has the prettiest girls in town (in and out of the Vogue Building at No. 350), it has that best friend of the watchless, the clock at the top of the Newsweek Building, and it has (but for how long?) the Villard Houses at 50th. But fundamentally, it's a heavy, earnest, unsmiling sort of street, where the work of the world gets done any people don't often stop to stand and talk.

title: Alexander Calder, Leading U.S. Artist, Dies
description: Alexander Calder died in New York City yesterday of a heart attack at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert Howar. He was 78 years old.

title: Pro Football Statistics
Troy Taking Care of Constituents From His Federal Prison Cubicle
description: Dolores Troy stood before the members of the Board of Estimate last Tuesday in the jampacked Queens Borough Hall. She was nervous as she quietly read a statement prepared by her father, Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., in his prison cubicle.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1976

title: Braves Send Nuggets to First Defeat
description: BUFFALO, Nov 11 (AP)The Buffalo Braves withstood a fourth  quarter shooting flurry by David Thompson and handed the Denver Nuggets their first National Basketball Association loss tonight, 10594.

title: U.S. and Britain Divide Opening Cup Matches
description: LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP)Chris Evert beat Virginia Wade, 62, 36, 63, then Sue Barker rallied to defeat Rosie Casals, 16, 63, 62. tonight leaving the United States and British women's tennis teams tied at 11 after the two opening singles in the Wightman Cup competition.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: It's not that we think of ourselves as feminists. It's just that we try to be rightminded; we try to raise our daughter as free of stereotypes as possible.

title: Harvard's Problem Is to Throttle Yale's Running Game Tomorrow
description: Harvard and Yale. Once those were the magic words in intercollegiate football. But the national glamour, the gloss has disappeared. The growth of state universities and the proliferation of television games among the football factories have left the Ivy League far behind. But HarvardYale is still The Game to thousands of alumni, and tomorrow in Cambridge, Mass., these two most ancient of the Ancient Eight will have at one another once more, If Yale wins, the Elis will share the championship with Brown, which most likely will beat Columbia. In that case the Elis and the Bruins will finish with league wonlost records of 61. It will be Brown's first title since formal roundrobin play began in 1956.

title: School Results
No Disclosure Punishment
description: The stock market does not appear to punish companies that disclose bribes or improper payments, a statistical study of trading in stocks of 75 companies has disclosed. Page D5.

title: Teamster Fund to Cite Kleindienst As Defendant in Insurer Fraud Suit
description: The principal welfare fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters decided yesterday to name Richard G. Kleindienst as an individual defendant in a $14 million damage suit that it filed last August alleging fraud by five life insurance companies.

title: Article 6  No Title
New Zealand Games Off For Lack of Responses
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 11 (UPI)The Christchurch, New Zealand, Games, scheduled for next January, were called off today because of slow ticket sales and lack of response from overseas athletes.

title: ST.REGIS IS SEEKING SOUTHLAND SHARES
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that it was prepared to meet with major shareholders of Southland Paper Mills of Lufkin, Tex., to consider terms for the acquisition of Southland by St. Regis. To purchase Southland common shares that it does not already own, St. Regis would invest about $175 million. St. Regis owns 4,001,925, or 37.3 percent, of Southland's 10,719,025 shares outstanding.

title: Life Another Way: They Do Without For the Sake of Art
description: Jerry Zeniuk once decided that to be truly rich, is to not need a watch because, among other things, one does not need to get to work on time. Though he is 30 years old, he has never had a fulltime job, nor does he own a watch.

title: PROPOSALS TO SPUR ECONOMIC ACTIVITY OPPOSED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned today against the possible inflationary consequences of trying to stimulate the economy through tax cuts, increases in Government spending or a looser monetary policy.

title: Alexis Minotis Plays Oedipus in His Autumn
description: I have lived too long, but I have lived a conscious life; that is the Important thing.

title: Inmate Sentenced for Threat on Ford
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 11 (AP)A Federal prison inmate who pleaded guilty to threatening President Ford and a Secret Service agent was sentenced to an additional year in prison today in Federal District Court. Mary Shellborn, 24 years old, serving a sentence of six months to six years for carrying a pistol without a license and assaulting a taxi driver, made the threats in letters.

title: Carter Is Seen Resisting Pressure By Ford's Aides to Act on OPEC
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 11High Ford Administration officials are privately saying that they intend to press the Carter transition teams to take a stronger stand against an impending oil producers' increase in prices.

title: Article 2  No Title
Weekend Gardening: Indoor Tomatoes
description: This is the beginning of the plastic tomato season. Perhaps no other fruit or vegetable symbolizes so well the simultaneous rise and fall of modern agriculture as does the semisynthetic pale pink little ball sold four to a plastic tray at the local supermarket under that uninviting euphemism hardripe. Modern agriculture has designed a highly productive tomato vine whose fruit picks well, stores well, ships welland tastes terrible.

title: Film: 'A Child Is a Wild Young Thing'
description: THERE are television commercials that take perfectly lovely shots of children running across fields, all tangled up in light. But we aren't moved. The intention cancels the beauty.Peter Skinner's "A Child Is a Wild Young Thing" is often quite beautiful to look at. Considering it is his first moviehe wrote, directed, produced and photographed itit is made with some skill. But it is a dreadful and wrongheaded vision of its subject, a wrenched picture of childhood.Set on a Brittany island, the movie centers upon Adam, a curly haired 2-year-old. Ostensibly  the level of reality shifts somewhat at the endit is a record made by the narrator, a psychologist who is Adam's father, of the child and the child's mother.To be exact, the form isn't precisely narration. As the camera shows Adam moving about, playing, eating, crying, prancing, and the mother and three teen-age girls who have come along as vacation baby sitters, what we hear is an interminable argument.It is the psychologist and his wife tearing at each other. She resents his project, his cold and hidden stance behind the camera in an effort to try out theses about animal behavior on his son. Beyond that, she appears to resent his position as a male, his domination, his philandering.For his part, he is jealous of her total absorption in the child, her insistence on letting him run around naked and do whatever he pleases, her continual fondling and nuzzling of him.At one point, the mother lies naked on the beach and holds Adam on top of her in a posture of simulated intercourse. It is not especially shocking, but it isn't healthily natural, either. It is, simply, inappropriate: One more instance of the film's projecting adult ideas of childhood onto this child.The language of the parents is stilted and exaggerated. They hurl clichs about child development at each other. Each filmed sequence of Adam calls up a stream of the most banal and irritating comment. Occasionallyin one of the film's most depressing deviceswhat are presumed to be Adam's thoughts are rendered by songs.In some sense, it seems to be an attempt at psychodramareal or fictional or a mixture of bothto try to purge the tensions between husband and wife. At one paint, Adam is represented as dying, and one of the movie's genuinely charming bits comes when he refuses to stay out of camera range and is seen skipping about at his own "funeral."But what ultimately is least real in this movie is what should be most real: the child himself. He is an instrument, an occasion for the interminable acrimony of the parents.The camera virtually never leaves him, and the movie virtually never thinks of him. Children are not meant to be watched so persistently, so intensely. If they are, they are not seen. They change, they act up, they are distorted by the eye and thoughts of the person who watches them. The only way to look at children is with peripheral vision. Adam, so beautiful, so expressive, is virtually invisible in "A Child Is a Wild Young Thing." It opened yesterday at the Quad Cinema.

title: Losing Air
description: To clean the nation's air of deadly pollutants and to keep it clean involves unremitting struggle. Pollutioncontrol technology can be expensive. Many businessmen are reluctant to invest in it when the intangible gains to the community do not appear on profitandloss statements. Often they have a difficult choice to make between upgrading an old plant or shutting it down to construct a new facility somewhere else. State and local officials, particularly in areas hard hit by unemployment, are likewise reluctant to enforce pollutioncontrol plans and deadlines for fear of hastening the flight of jobs and the shrinking of the tax base. Mean while, as old factories are brought under control, new sources of pollution come into existence.

title: FrenchPakistani Atom Deal Fading
description: PARIS, Nov. 11Following virtual ultimatums to Pakistan by the United States and Canada and what are interpreted as changes in France's attitude, it seems more and more unlikely that the French will provide Pakistan with a controversial nuclear reprocessing plant.

title: Forecast for Electronics Industry: Boston Area Hazy, California Sunny
description: American industry is being increasingly influenced by new electronic capabilities for rapid calculation and communication. The Boston area once seemed to dominate these capabilities through its pioneering work in minicomputers. Now, there is a widespread belief in the electronics industry that the innovative and competitive advantage is shifting to the region south of San Francisco. This is largely because of that region's dominance in ultraminiaturized semiconductor circuitry, such as the computer on a chip, which crucially affects the price and features of such electronic machinery as minicomputers. For the Massachusetts area traversed by Route 128 and its concentration of hightechnology companies, the forecast is cloudy. But for the California region known as Silicon Valley, named for the vital element in the microelectronic chips, the climate is decidedly sunny.

title: U.S. Finds UsedCar Odometer Frauds in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10Federal officials said today that scores of usedcar dealers in New Jersey employed rollback specialists who manipulated socalled tamperproof odometers to reduce the recorded mileage of automobiles, enabling the dealers to sell nearly burnedout cars as oneowner cream puffs.

title: Around the Nation
description: ALEXANDER, Va., Nov. 11 (AP)The Justice Department expects the Allied Chemical Corporation voluntarily to pay for cleaning up Kepone contamination from the James River, the United States attorney for northern Virginia said today.

title: Girl Eats Traffic Ticket
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Nov. 11 (AP)The police said that a teenaged motorist, stopped for driving violations here, accepted the summons, then put it into her mouth, chewed it up and swallowed it. The motorist, 17yearold Janice Rosasco of North Salem, was charged with driving while intoxicated, failure to keep to the right side of the highway and operating a car with a junior license after dark.

title: BUFFALO INTERNIST HEADS STATE'S MEDICAL SOCIETY
description: Dr. George L. Collins Jr., a Buffalo internist, assumed the presidency of the 27,500member Medical Society of the State of New York yesterday as the organization's 170th annual convention closed at the Americana Hotel.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of the E. F. Johnson Company, the biggest domestic manufacturer of citizens' band radio equipment, have fallen to 14 from a high of 34 last spring.

title: NEW ZONING TO CURB PORNOGRAPHY PLACES SUBMITTED BY BEAME
description: New York City's array of massage parlors, peepshows, adult bookstores and topless bars would be banned from residential areas and their numbers sharply reduced in commercial districts under proposed new zoning changes announced yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: Catholic Bishops Reaffirm Stands On Sexual Ethics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Catholic bishops of the United States approved today by a vote of 172 to 25 a pastoral letter on morality that strongly reaffirms the Roman Catholic Church's traditional teachings on sexual ethics in the face of rising discontent within the church.

title: DPL License Plate Offering Immunity for Scofflaws
description: With a device weighing just a few ounces, Sergei Roudenko has been able to save hundreds of dollars a year in the operation of the car he drives in New York City.

title: An Old Blues Singer Still Belts It Out
description: RockandRoIi? Joe Turner, the celebrated blues shouter, survivor of the heyday of Kansas City jazz and of the prerock era of rhythmandblues, and the star attraction at the Cookery 8:30, 10:30 attraction at the Cockery thes weekend rolled the words around on his tongue. Rockandroll?

title: Lauda Has Eye Surgery
description: ST. GALLEN, Switzerland, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Nikki Lauda, an Austrian racing driver, underwent plastic surgery tonight lasting several hours to correct problems with the lid of his right eye, a clinic spokesman said. Lauda, a world champion driver last year, was unable to close the eye properly. The clinic said he would need at least two weeks of complete rest.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Cyclist Helmets Backed
description: The Medical Society of the State of New York announced yesterday that it had unanimously adopted a resolution opposing efforts to repeal the state law requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets. Delegates at the society's 170th annual convention in New York City took the action after noting that the death rate in motorcycle accidents had been cut 40 to 50 percent since the law was enacted 10 years ago.

title: Volunteer Executioners
description: The issues surrounding the case of Gary Mark Gilmore, the convicted murderer who has asked to be allowed to die like a man by facing a firing squad in Utah, will long be hotly debated by legal experts and a lay public interested in crime and punishment.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: SOCCER

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Woes in Massachusetts Cited by Executives
description: SOUTHBORO, Mass.The head of an emerging giant in the manufacture of minicomputers in Massachusettsthe Data General Corporationthinks the state is becoming a place where winners don't choose to work.

title: The Conflict With Nyquist
description: The recent demand by most members of the New York State Board of Regents for the resignation of Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner, is, in many respects, a conflict rooted in a dispute over their respective roles. But the issue here has been exacerbated by an ideological schism between a board that has become increasingly conservative and more politicized in recent years and a Commissioner whose liberal views on racial integration and other issues have alienated many Regents and political officials.

title: Colorado Town, at the End, Couldn't Put Trust in Carter
description: YUMA, Colo., Nov. 10In the end, it came down to trust versus loyalty. Loyalty won.

title: Maureen Forrester Turns Clock Back 20 Years
description: It is not every singer who could, or would dare to, return to the scene of a debut recital 20 years after the fact, to repeat all the songs that made up the original program and with the same accompanist.

title: Rhodesians Celebrate 11th Anniversary of Breakaway
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 11Just before midnight Prime Minister Ian D. Smith approached a polished brass bell at a tobacco auction hall here and solemnly rang in the 12th year of Rhodesian independence and defiance.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: Friday

title: Namath Works But Won't Start
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 11 Joe Namath worked out today for the first time this week, testing his injured right knee, and although the Jets' No. 1 quarterback is available for duty Sunday, Richard Todd will start against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers at Shea Stadium.

title: At the Movies
description: I WOULD RATHER have one minute at this age than a month at 21, said William Holden, who was Hollywood's earnestly grinning boynextdoor until he weathered into the tough cynic of Sunset Boulevard, Stalag 17 and Bridge on the River Kwai. Beginning Sunday, at the Sutton Theater, he can be seen as the decidedly mature, slightly dissipated husband and father who philanders with Faye Dunaway in Network. The film, written by Paddy Chayefsky and directed by Sidney Lumet, is a tragicomic grenade aimed at the television industry, a sweeping indictment of behindthescene manipulators whom the film holds responsible for the creation of an entire generation of apathetic, brainwashed blobs.

title: Giant Victory Over Redskins on Sunday Could Provide Hairless Results
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 11Two and a half months ago, Dave Gallagher vowed not to shave until the Giants beat the Washington Redskins.

title: P.B.A. Negotiators Picked
description: A negotiating committee of 50 delegates has been appointed by Douglas D. Weaving, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, to meet with the city officials next week in a new effort to resolve the long and heated contract dispute.

title: Journeys Behind the Scenes At the Metropolitan Opera
description: Alice would have felt at home backstage at the Metropolitan Opera House. And even the most jaded opera buff is likely to have the feeling of falling down the rabbit hole into a fantasy world on the Metropolitan Opera Guild's tour of the house. With the Opera season under way, this weekend may be the time to take the plunge.

title: Management
description: Whatever else may befall corporations that disclose bribes or improper payments, the stock market does not seem to punish them.

title: 10 Indicted on Trading in Industries International
description: A 20count Federal indictment charged 10 men yesterday with having carried out a fraudulent scheme to drive up the price of the stock of Industries International Inc. from 50 cents a share to $6.50 a share in less than a month in 1973.

title: Prices Steady on Corporate and TaxExempt Bonds
description: Corporate and taxexempt bond prices held steady in light trading yesterday, and the Government securities market was closed in observance of Veterans Day. Much of the credit markets operated with skeleton staffs, and there appeared to be no immediate reaction to the testimony of Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, before the Senate Banking Committee. Dr. Burns noted that the Federal Reserve had eased money conditions slightly in recent weeks, adding that the central bank would ease them further if the economy needed it. But he also warned that it would be ruinous to take restraint off money supply growth. None of this sounded very to the credit markets.

title: Experts Say New Campaign Law Had Major Impact on '76 Election
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The campaign law that Congress enacted in 1974 in the wake of the Watergate scandals had a profound impact on last week's election, although the political revolution it brought about was very nearly invisible to the voters.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN U.S. WINE LABELS
description: A series of sweeping changes in the labeling of United States wines, including a new Government seal to be awarded to wines meeting the highest standards, was proposed yesterday by the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

title: ELLSBERGCASE CHARGES AGAINST TWO DROPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)A Federal judge today dismissed an indictment charging Bernard L. Barker and Eugenio R. Martinez with conspiracy in the 1971 breakin at the office of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist.

title: 2d Trial of Rubin Carter Starts With Reporter Called as Witness
description: PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 11The second trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis began today with attorneys for the defense and prosecution describing, in opening statements, events surrounding the barroom slaying of three persons here more than 10 years ago.

title: Payments by General Telephone Up $2.1 Million, to $4.3 Million
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 11 (AP)The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, which last year admitted making $2.2 million in improper payments, said today that the earlier figure was $2.1 million too low.

title: Rangers Trade Beverley and Fairbairn To North Stars for Goldsworthy, a Wing
description: Within hours of his team's 75 loss to the Washington Capitals Wednesday night, an enraged John Ferguson, the New York Ranger general managercoach traded Bill Fairbairn and Nick Beverley to the Minnesota North Stars for Bill Goldsworthy. Ferguson announced the transaction yesterday morning.

title: CALLAGHAN VISITS PARIS FOR TALKS ON ECONOMY
description: PARIS, Nov. 11Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain arrived here today to discuss his country's economic plight with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Illegitimate Births in Washington Exceeded Legitimate Ones in '75
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)For the first time since records have been kept, more children were born out of wedlock last year in the nation's capital than were born to married women, the city's Human Resources Department has reported. The National Center for Health Statistics here said yesterday that Washington was the first major American city where that had occurred.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 11The upper house of Parliament today approved a bill amending the Constitution to give the Government more powers. Most of the opposition party members boycotted the debate, as happened in the lower house last week when the bill was passed there. The voting in the upper house was 1910.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: Antiques
description: THE GOLD SWORD presented by the Continental Congress to Gen Marie Joseph Layette in 1779, is back in the United Statesand this time it is up for sale. An unidentified descendant of the Marquis de Lafayette, acting through an agent, has consigned the sword to Sotheby Parke Bernet, where it will be exhibited for a week beginning tomorrow, before the auction house's sale of Americana on Saturday, Nov. 20.

title: U.S. Money Supply Rose $200 Million In Week of Nov. 3
description: The nation's money supply called M1 and defined as demand deposits and currency, averaged $310.6 billion in the week ended Nov. 3, up $200 million from the previous week. The broad money supply, known as M2 and including consumertype time and savings deposits at commercial banks, rose $1.6 billion, and averaged $729.3 billion in the latest week.

title: Bridge:
description: Politics and bridge rarely make contact, but they will touch tangentially next weekend in Fairfield, Conn.

title: 2 Detroit Ordinances Have Greatly Limited Sex Shops.
description: DETROIT, Nov. 11  City officials, trying to crack down on the pornography that still thrives along commercial strips here, have not been able to zone away adult theaters and bookstores.

title: About Real Estate
description: ISLIP, L.I. The first thought in many minds when the Landon K. Thorne estate on Great South Bay went on the market two years ago was to make it a park. Islip's chief planner recommended as much. But the cost was high.

title: Fellow Artists, Others Pay Tribute
description: As news of Alexander Calder's death spread through the art world yesterday, fellow artists, critics, museum people and admirers paused to reminisce and pay tribute to him both as a friend and an artist.

title: F.T.C. Adding Children's Apparel To an Investigation of Price Fixing
description: The Federal Trade Commission, which last January began an investigation of restraint of trade and price fixing in the women's apparel industry, will now also investigate alleged similar practices in the children's clothing field.

title: Separatist Party in Quebec, Favored in Election, Says It Will Seek Talks With Ottawa on Autonomy
description: MONTREAL, NOV. 11If a separatist government is elected in Quebec next Monday, it will open talks with the federal authorities in Ottawa for the gradual transfer of sovereignty to this Frenchspeaking Canadian province.

title: For One Couple, Tarnished Golden Years
description: The Golden Years. It is a term that causes many elderly Bronx residents to smile sardonically or snort derisively. You simply cannot enjoy life knowing that whenever you go out for a walk, someone may be following you, said Mae Cohen, who is 68 years old.

title: Catholic Bishops Reaffirm Stands On Sexual Ethics
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Catholic bishops of the United States approved today by a vote of 172 to 25 a pastoral letter on morality that strongly reaffirms the Roman Catholic Church's traditional teachings on sexual ethics in the face of rising discontent within the church.

title: New Drama Off Off Broadway (Page C3); New Drama Goes Off Off Broadway
description: Off Off Broadway's most significant contribution so far this season has been its wealth of new plays and new performers. While Broadway, for financial and artistic reasons, is becoming increasingly inhospitable to new drama, Off Off Broadway is opening its stages to all varieties of new work, traditional as well as experimental. And it is finding the young actors capable of meeting the challenges.

title: Carter, Kennedy and Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Searching for clues about what is likely to happen in Jimmy Carter's Administration, political analysts here are reviewing the relationship between President Kennedy and Congress in the early 1960's. There are, to be sure, a number of striking parallels. But there have been significant changes in Congress in the last decade, and they appear in many Instances to outweigh the similarities between the situation faced by Mr. Kennedy and that Mr. Carter will face when he takes office in

title: U.S. Gives Insurance Companies Access to Medicaid Computers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Government has installed computer terminals in the offices of two private insurance companies that permit the companies to obtain information about hundreds of thousands of Medicare patients directly from the files of the Social Security Administration.

title: World Premiere of Communion to Be at Fabian in Paterson
description: PATERSON, Nov. 11 The halfcenturyold Fabian Theater, once a major motionpicture hall in the metropolitan area, will present Saturday night a world premiere benefit performance of Communion, a murder mystery filmed largely in this city.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group Shows 42% Decline in 3dQuarter Profit
description: The Royal Dutch Shell Group of Companies reported yesterday that thirdquarter net income was down 42 percent from a year ago. The drop was attributed to foreigncurrency transactions.

title: Japan Starts Returning Soviet's MIG
description: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 12 (UPI)Japan began returning a dismantled supersonic MIG25 jet fighter flown there by a defecting Soviet pilot Friday morning, handing over 13 stainless steel crates to Soviet officials at the port of Hitachi.

title: Alexander Calder, Leading U.S. Artist, Dies
description: Alexander Calder died in New York City yesterday of a heart attack at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert Howar. He was 78 years old.

title: Loan Defaults Rose, ExIm Bank Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)  The United States ExportImport Bank reported today that its loan delinquencies jumped sharply last year, but Stephen M. DuBrul Jr., the chairman, said he was confident a more cautious approach would enable the bank to avoid asking Congress for more money.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Dow Reverses 4 Successive Drops To Advance 7.39 in Thin Turnover
description: Stock prices bounced upward yesterday, but light trading volume underscored the cautious nature of the recovery.

title: Screen: Early, Exuberant Fassbinder
description: IN 1969, when he was 23, Rainer Werner Fassbinder made his first feature film, "Love Is Colder Than Death," and three more besides that one. In 1970, he stopped fooling around. He made seven features, including "The American Soldier" and "Recruits in Ingolstadt," both of which have already been seen in this country. He also made "Beware of a Holy Whore" (Warnung vor Einer Heiligen Nutte), which opened yesterday at the Film Forum and is as fascinating and dissonant as might be wished by anyone who admires this young German film maker as I do."Beware of a Holy Whore" has the informal manner of a practice exercise but it leaves the kind of wounds one receives in a knife fight."Beware of a Holy Whore" is Mr. Fassbinder's comic, self-consciously absurd, slightly dizzy "Contempt," "Day for Night" and "The Last Tycoon," made in the manner of the post-"Eat," pre-"Trash" Andy Warhol.A dozen people, including Eddie Constantine as Eddie Constantine, are hanging around the lobby of a none-too-posh Spanish seaside hotel waiting to start a film. Until the director of the film shows up, the production manager, played by Mr. Fassbinder, is in charge, which means he can be rude and sarcastic and more or less removed from the small intrigues that take place at the bar.The virile speech coach makes a tentative play for the director's young boyfriend. A young German actress is wrapped up in a German technician until Eddie Constantine looks her way. Another German crew member drinks so many Cuba libres he becomes confused about the love he is drinking to forget. When the director finally arrives, he treats the production manager as badly as the production manager has treated everyone else, and makes his point by taking the production manager's wife away from him. The director is bored with his boyfriend."Beware of a Holy Whore" is not really about movie making at all. It's about connections and disconnections. The members of Mr. Fassbinder's movie company spend most of the time moving about the large, gloomy hotel lobby like people trying to make trans-Atlantic calls to one another when the atmospheric condictions are terrible. No sooner has contact been made than there is an inexplicable interruption. Sentences are arbitrarily splintered. Syllables are lost. Wires are crossed.The Fassbinder view of the world is very special. His images contain not reflections of vital reality but of psychological stress. Mr. Fassbinder's characters are never fully revealed. They are hinted at. The movie, thus, is impossible to enjoy in the conventional sense of a narrative film that has an easily recognzable beginning, middle and end. All of the images are part of a single image, which, in this case, has a number of uproarious funny details though the overall tone is one of despair."Beware of a Holy Whore" is the work of a very young, very gifted film maker. In a movie by a director of lesser talent and natural exuberance, some of Mr. Fassbinder's showy, often Godardian effects would be impediments we look around or beyond to appreciate a major career that is erupting with the force of a natural phenomenon.

title: College Results
Notes on People
description: Dr. F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will return to his old job as president of the University of Alabama in January, but it is not just because the country will get a new President then, a university official said yesterday. Dr. Richard Thigpen, acting chief executive of the university, said he had gone to Washington to discuss matters with Dr. Mathews, and he has authorized me to tell you his plans are to return to the university when his term as Secretary is completed in January. Dr. Thigpen added: Dr. Mathews's plans in fact have not changed since he took a leave of absence from the university and agreed to serve in President Ford's Cabinet. Dr. Mathews is expected to be back in Tuscaloosa on Jan. 19, the day before Jimmy Carter's inauguration.

title: Tradition of Armenian Lace Lives On in Leonia
description: LEONIA Nov. 11Marie Bedikian says her hands are not pretty now, not as pretty as they were in the years before World War I when she was growing up a Constantinople and learning music and how to make Armenian lace.

title: Commodity Futures Drop Sharply on U.S. Report Of a Higher Corn Yield
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP)Farm commodity futures fell heavily today on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department's estimate yesterday that the corn yield at 6.06 billion bushels would he 3 percent more than previously estimated.

title: Many Elderly in the Bronx Spend Their Lives in Terror of Crime
description: Clara Engelmann recently moved a bed into the foyer of her Bronx apartment. Every night, she crawls into it fully dressed, Her old black coat rests on a chair nearby, and she plans to grab it and run out the front door at the first sound of robbers jimmying her bedroom window.

title: Advertising
description: Tonight, in the top 10 markets, the Ball Corporation will take to television to reach those confirmed modernmusic lovers and record collectors it has missed in print. The vehicle will be Midnight Special, the rock music extravaganza on the NBCTV network. Additional Ball commercials will run on the network's stations during Saturday Night. And after Jan. 1 Ball will become a full network advertiser on Midnight Special.

title: DR. WILLI HENNIG DIES; AUTHORITY ON INSECTS
description: BONN, Nov. 11Dr. Willi Hennig, an internationally recognized authority on insects, died of a heart attack at his home in Ludwigsburg last Friday. His age was 63.

title: Zarb Weighing Bid For Oil Pact Data
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Federal Energy Administrator, Frank G. Zarb, is moving to require oil companies to disclose to Washington the major details of their agreements with foreign governments.

title: U.S. Bicentennial Exhibition Is Opened in Moscow;
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11America's best face was put on display here today with the opening of a United Statessponsored exhibition to celebrate the Bicentennial.

title: Lawyer for Miss Hearst to Ask Court Today to Free Her on Bail
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 (UPI)An attorney for Patricia Hearst said today that tomorrow he would ask for her release on bail on the ground that the only place she was safe in prison was in solitary confinement, and that such confinement would constitute inhumane treatment.

title: Rally by Nets Fails as Spurs Win, 108 to 104
description: SAN ANTONIO. Nov. 11 (AP)George Gervin connected for 30 points as the San Antonio Spurs withstood a late New York Nets' rally sparked by Nate Archibald and posted a 108104 victory in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: Hypocrisy at Turtle Bay
description: Malawi's delegate to the United Nations spoke blunt truth when he accused some of his African colleagues and their fellow sponsors of doublefaced hypocrisy in resolutions they rammed through the General Assembly Tuesday, condemning specific nations for trading with South Africa. J. T. X. Muwamba referred particularly to the singling out of the United States and its major allies, along with Israel, for selling arms to South Africa; but his indictment applies to other trade as well.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Advocates of Women's Rights Oppose Prison Indignities at Conference
description: EAST BRUNSWICK. Nov. 11Women's rights advocates asked today that the state end what they called indignities that women underwent in state prisons and jails and begin programs to teach women convicts how to get and keep jobs.

title: Carter Returns to Plains Home; Resumes His Work on Transition
description: PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 11Presidentelect Jimmy Carter flew back home today after a fiveday vacation at a plantation on St. Simons Island off the Georgia coast.

title: Fraud in Used Cars Held Rife in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Nov. 10Federal officials said today that scores of usedcar dealers in New Jersey employed rollback specialists who manipulated socalled tamperproof odometers to reduce the recorded mileage of automobiles, enabling the dealers to sell nearly burnedout cars as oneowner cream puffs.

title: In Memoriam
description: GREBINMarian Sue. November ?? 1975. Most darling daughter and sister. In cherished never diminishing memy of our Irreplaceable loss.

title: Pravda Editor Sees Improved Relations With Peking Regime
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 (UPI) The editor of the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that he detected signs of an improvement in SovietChinese relations.

title: EXECUTION IN UTAH STAYED BY GOVERNOR
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 11Gov. Calvin L. Rampton today stayed the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore until after the State Board of Pardons meets Wednesday.

title: Photography Center Shows Masters
description: The International Center of Photography will celebrate its second anniversary with an exhibition entitled Masters of the Camera: Stieglitz, Steichen and Their Successors.

title: The U.N. Today
News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1976

title: NO PROGRESS IS REPORTED AT MEETING ON RHODESIA
description: GENEVA, Nov. 11Black Rhodesian nationalists said today that they had failed to make progress on a date for independence under black majority rule at a meeting of two hours and 40 minutes with Ivor Richard, chairman of the conference on the future of the whitecontrolled territory.

title: Jets Are Favored Over Buccaneers; Giants Underdogs to Redskins
description: It's too bad Tampa Bay and the Giants, both without a victory, are not playing each other. At least one would go away happy. The Buccaneers will be at Shea Stadium on Sunday, with the Jets favored by a touchdown, while the Giants take on Washington at the Meadowlands. The latter game is sold out and will be televised here (Channel 2, 1 P.M.). The second television game is Miami at Pittsburgh, Channel 4, 4 P.M. On Monday night Buffalo plays at Dallas, Channel 7, 9 P.M. Previews of all games follow, with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT SAN ANTONIO

title: Music: Clarion Discoveries
description: CLARION CONCERTS, founded and conducted by Newell Jenkins is celebrating its 20th year this season. It was appropriate that its opening program on Wednesday night in Alice Tully Hall reflected the diverse aims of the organization very neatly.

title: HERBERT GREENSTEIN
description: Herbert Greenstein, a liquor industry executive, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 59 years old and a resident of Suffern.

title: Airwick to Promote Invisible Freshener
description: Airwick Products, which has just about doubled its 7.5 percent share of the solid airfreshener market with its Twins brand, will be looking for further increases with the help of Stick Ups. The entry is intended to be used in new areas and is intended to appeal to the one housewife out of six who doesn't use such products, believing that a visible air freshener is a confession of odors in the home.

title: BRONERS DENOUNCE APLAN TO INCREASE SEATS ON EXCHANGE
description: At a tumultuous meeting yesterday of the membership of the New York. Stock Exchange, angry floor members spoke out sharply against a proposal to increase thenumber of available seats.

title: Carter Names 4 Transition Aides on Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Three former aides of Henry A. Kissinger and a former Pentagon official in the Johnson Administration will lead Jimmy Carter's transition teams into the foreign policy bureaucracy.

title: Loss of $32 Million Is Listed by Conrail For Its 2d Quarter
description: Conrail reported yesterday a net loss of $32 million on revenues of $809.2 million for its second quarter of operations as the Government  sponsored successor to the bankrupt railroads of the Northeast.

title: Priests Urge No Sunday Shopping
description: ANSONIA, Conn., Nov. 11 (AP)Seventeen Roman Catholic priests in Ansonia, Derby, Seymour and Oxford called on all Christians today to refrain from Sunday shopping. Their joint statement was in response to recent Sunday openings of some department and grocery stores in the Naugatuck Valley.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Albany Orders Contact Visits for the Prisoners In Upstate Jails, Drawing Sharp Protest by Sheriffs
description: The State Commission of Correction has ordered that upstate county jails immediately allow contact visits to prisoners, setting off a legal challenge by the New York State Sheriff's Association against the way the commission has set minimum standards in all six areas of prisoner treatment so far.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1976

title: Madrid Seems Unable to Check Attacks by Rightist Commandos
description: MADRID, Nov. 11The Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Surez has moved cautiously against some bastions of the hard right. But its seeming inability to check neofascist commandos has become something of an embarrassment and a test of its democratizing, intentions

title: Udall Warns of Civil Service Abuse During Transition
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11As the old order passeth, the chill wind of political change sweep through the Federal Government's nooks and crannies and, according to Representative Morris K. Udall, probable next chairman of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, bureaucrats are already seeking shelter.

title: State Questions New York ProductivityPay Rise Plan
description: There is a $4.5 million snag in New York City's attempt to finance costofliving raises for municipal employees out of improved productivity by the employees. Although $4.5 million is not much in the larger scheme of city finances, the snag poses a threat to the entire productivity program.

title: Environment Agency Recommends Airports Be Made to Reduce Noise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency recommended today that major airport operators be required to develop ways to reduce the impact of airport noise on people.

title: Shapiro Preview of Carter Administration
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  While the financial markets and many businessmen continue to, manifest concern over the economic recovery and the policies they expect from the Carter Administration, there is an island of calmness and patience here in the executive suite of one of the nation's largest business enterprises. This is the corporate home of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the world's biggest diversified chemical producer and one of the largest manufacturers in the United States, with sales this year likely to cross the $8 billion level for the first time.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 1.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.4 billion tonmiles, up 1.9 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 482.625 cars. off 1 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage rose 7.9 percent from a year ago.

title: U.S. JOINS U.N. COUNCIL IN CRITICISM OF ISRAEL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11The Security Council today unanimously deplored the establishment of Israeli settlements in the occupied Arab territories, and declared invalid the absorption of eastern Jerusalem into Israel.

title: Odd Tale Of Colt Kept From Races
description: Wine Treasure's handlers think their colt is good enough to win next year's Kentucky Derbyif he doesn't turn to vinegar first.

title: Broadway
description: LOTTE LENYA is something of a treasure of the musical theater, and today an exhibition, Kurt WellLotte Lenya, opens at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. There is a little bit more on my career than on Kurt Weill's, but this is because Kurt Well died in 1950 and I'm still here, Miss Lenya said. He left his whole estate to me, and I don't feel like sitting back and collecting royalties the way so many widows do. That is why we are having the exhibition of stage sets, photographs, manuscripts and drawings. Besides my work on stage, the major part of my life is Kurt Weill. I'm not so important

title: For British Parliament, Stiffer Battles and Greater Tests
description: LONDON, Nov. 11London is something of a political circus these days, full of odd happenings. There is, for example, the spectacle of a Prime Minister fighting like a tiger for five pieces of legislation to which he does not seem emotionally attached and which, in themselves, are clearly secondary to his main concern, the British economy. The votes in the House of Commons, meanwhile, have become abnormally and excitingly close. A crucial vote is cast by a nursing mother who is allowed to bring her baby to the very doors of the chamber, another by an Irishman who hasn't been heard from in two years.

title: Many Elderly in the Bronx Spend Their Lives in Terror of Crime.
description: Clara Engelmann recently moved a bed into the foyer of her Bronx apartment. Every night, she crawls into it fully dressed. Her old black coat rests on a chair nearby, and she plans to grab it and run out the front door at the first sound of robbers jimmying her bedroom window.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 11Governor Byrne said today he would insist on tougher, more comprehensive regulations for casino gambling in Atlantic City than sponsors had provided in an early draft.

title: GOLD PRICE LOWER IN LIGHTER TRADING
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 11 (UPI)The price of gold lost yesterday's gains on bullion markets today, while the dollar was steady in light trading due to the Armistice Day holiday.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: Morning

title: People and Business
description: The Government was urged yesterday by a representative of two of the country's leading banking groups not to expand its role in the operations of electronic payments systems, which could largely replace the use of checks and cash in the future.

title: Restaurants
description: AFTER suffering through so many highpriced restaurants that cram diners into elbowtoelbow seating arrangements amid deafening noise, Brussels comes as an oasis of quietude and spaciousness.

title: State U. Is Accused Of Bias in Its Hiring
description: The State University of New York was charged yesterday with having made little progress in the hiring and promotion of minoritygroup and women faculty members despite a commitment in 1971 to equalopportunity programs. The charge was made by the New York State Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Pop Life
description: WITH THE PRETENDER, Jackson Browne has probably made his finest record. It win almost definitely be greeted as a masterpiece by those who love singersongwriters in general and Mr. Browne especially. Yet to this listener, it seems ultimately disappointing, as if now that we've seen what Mr. Browne can really do, it isn't quite enough.

title: NEW ZONING TO CURB PORNOGRAPHY PLACES SUBMITTED BY BERME
description: New York City's array of massage parlors, peepshows, adult bookstores and topless bars would be banned from residential areas and their numbers sharply reduced in commercial districts under proposed new zoning changes announced yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: Rodgers' Contract Extended
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 11 (UPI)  The Georgia Tech Board of Trustees handed Pepper Rodgers a new threeyear contract today as head football coach in the wake of last Saturday's 2314 upset of Notre Dame.

title: An Urban Peace Corps To Rebuild Cities Urged By Rohatyn,M.A.C.Head
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation in New York State, tonight proposed an urban peace corps to held rebuild the cities.

title: Lisbon Reds Demand Cabinet Role
description: LISBON, Nov. 11Portugal's Communist Party opened a fourday congress here today with a demand for entry into the Government and with a restatement of its strongly proSoviet position.

title: Navy Ship Recovers Fighter Off Scotland
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)The Navy announced today that a sunken F14 Tomcat fighter plane that it had been trying to recover for more than a month had been successfully lifted aboard a civilian salvage ship off the Scottish coast.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: DR. LEON SCHNEYER, EXPERT ON SALIVATION, DEAD AT 57
description: Dr. Leon H. Schneyer, an authority on salivary secretion and a professor at the University in Birmingham, died Oct. 23. He was 57 years old.

title: DAGGETT HARVEY SR., 69; CIVIC LEADER IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 11Daggett Harvey Sr., one of Chicago's most active civic leaders and former owner of the Fred Harvey restaurant chain, died last night at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he was being treated for a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: Dr. Harry Denman, ExSecretary Of Methodist Evangelism Board
description: Dr. Harry Denman, who was general Secretary of the board of evangelism of the Methodist Church from 1939 to 1964, died Monday in Birmingham, Ala. He was 83 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
The Public's Buildings
description: The city is always the last to know. It has taken a privately sponsored study by the New York Landmarks Conservancy and the Columbia Graduate School of Architecture and Planning to find that more than 18,000 buildings in New York City are publicly owned, and that the city itself owns over 90 percent of them; the rest are state and Federal structures. Of these, 760 are noted as buildings of architectural merit, from listed landmarks to lesser gems and curiosities.

title: RADIO
description: Music

title: Article 5  No Title
More Than Just A Touch of Claes At SoHo Gallery
description: FEW ARTISTS in any period actually alter the way we look at the objects around us, and fewer still make us laughor at least smileat what we see as a result. It is Claes Oldenburg's distinction as a sculptor to have succeeded on both counts, and over and over again. With his giant typewriter eraser constructions and cigarettebutt sculptures, with his Good Humor and Lipstick and clothespin monuments, he has established Pop satire as one of the respectable conventions of contemporary public art. The joke implicit in such work now looks a lot gentler than it used to, but it is still there, and is now joined to a new elegance and grace.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: SLAVKO VORKAPICH DIES; EXPERT ON FILM MONTAGE
description: Slavko Vorkapaich, Yugoslavborn authority on the use of montage in film making, died Oct. 20 in Mijas, Spain. He was 82 years old and was visiting his son at the time.

title: Other Companies List Their Earnings Results
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

title: The Sounds of Balalaikas To Vibrate at Tully Hall
description: When the 22 performing members of the Balalaika and Domra Society convene on stage at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night at 8, it will be with fierce pride in their past, and not a little apprehension about their future. Costs are rising, good balalaika and domra players are hard to come by, and the society's treasury is down to the point where a full house is as much a financial necessity as an artistic moralebooster.

title: Welterweight Fight Reset
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 (AP)The twicepostponed World Boxing Council welterweight championship fight between Carlos Palomino, the titleholder from Westminster, Calif., and Mando Muniz of Los Angeles will be held Jan. 22. Promoter Aileen Eaton of the Olympic Auditorium announced the new date today.

title: Stage: O'Neill's Forgotten Dynamo Recalled
description: DYNAMO is one of Eugene O'Neill's forgotten plays. It opened on Broadway in 1929, the year after Strange Interlude, and lasted only 50 performances. George Ferencz's revival at the Impossible Ragtime Theater is the first New York production in 47 years.

title: Hawks 107, Trail Blazers 105
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 11 (AP)John Drew sank a 24foot jump shot with 3 seconds left and gave the Atlanta Hawks a 107105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight.

title: Guard Denies Guilt in Escape
description: A 31yearold guard at a Federal jail in Manhattan pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a jailbreak scheme that was thwarted last month. He is George D. Phillip of the Bronx, one of two guards accused of conspiring to arrange the escape of Yolanda Sarmiento, a major narcotics defendant who was being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan. The other accused guard. Yasin A. Wahid, has pleaded not guilty.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Article 3  No Title
Lawyers to Collect Bulk Of $2 Million Awarded To Gulf Oil Shareholders
description: PITTSBURGH, NOV. 11Lawyers will get all but about $300,000 of the $2 million in cash that the Gulf Oil Corporation is to receive as part of the settlement of eight shareholder suits, which stem from the company's operation of its illegal political slush fund.

title: Commodity Price Index Increases 1.8 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 197 from 195.2 last week.

title: PROPOSALS TO SPUR ECONOMIC ACTIVITY OPPOSED BY BURNS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned today against the possible inflationary consequences of trying to stimulate the economy through tax cuts, increases in Government spending or a looser monetary policy.

title: Rhodesians Celebrate 11th Anniversary of Breakaway
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 11Just before midnight Prime Minister Ian D. Smith approached a polished brass bell at a tobacco auction hall here and solemnly rang in the 12th year of Rhodesian independence and defiance.

title: StockMarket Blues
description: Wall Street has worked itself into a state of the blues over the election of Jimmy Carter. The basic reason appears to be that most of the financial community wanted President Ford to win and had accepted the view of Mr. Ford and his chief economic aides that a Democratic Administration would try to spend its way back to full employment and thereby breed deep deficits and worse inflation, which in turn would drive up interest rates and drive down stocks and bonds. Indeed, some businessmen and investors have come to fear that a Democratic Administration would mean an undermining of the profit and investments on which the capitalist system depends.

title: Along 8th Avenue, Where Leer Is King...
description: If Mayor Beame's latest proposals to restrict pornography are adopted and enforced, Eighth Avenue will never be the same.

title: A Police Novel a Cut Above The Usual Detective Story
description: Chief of Detectives Earl Eischied of the New York Police Department has a problem, and it is not the sensational, coldblooded greasegunning down of two policemen that kicks off Robert Daley's novel To Kill a Cop. No, the chief's problem is more, well, personal. Seems he took a couple of suits on the arm (or is it on the pad?) for himself and his son from the department store owner who wanted the chief to fix a shoplifting arrest of the department store owner's son. Eischied couldn't help, but took the suits anyway and now the big shot has complained to the police commissioner, putting Eischied in line for criminal chargesnot to mention the loss of his nice job that pays $40,000 a year plus perks, such as a chauffeurdriven car that trails him around the town on his dates as well as official business.

title: Oyvind Fahlstrom Dead Of Cancer in Stockholm; Artist and Satirist Was48
description: Oyvind Fahlstrom, an artist known for his satirical works that criticized the social order, died of cancer Monday in Stockholm. He was 48 years old.

title: Art People
description: WHO SHOULD POP into town this week but Ansel Adams, the photo poet of our Western landscape and one of the last of photography's grand old men? His latest book, Photographs of the Southwest (New York Graphic Society, $32.50), is just out, an exceedingly handsome treasury of the wellknown Adams propsrocks, canyons, dunes, thunderclouds, riverbeds, crosses, old churches and cacticrisply rendered in glorious black and white, Mr. Adams's favorite medium.

title: Grain Futures Weaken; Traders See Possibility Of Big Crop Carryover
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP)Corn and oats futures declined more than 3 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today in selling influenced by a possibility of increased stocks and smaller usage of feed grains into next year.

title: ARMY PICKS CHRYSLER TO DEVELOP NEW TANK AT $4.9 BILLION COST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Army selected the Chrysler Corporation today to develop and build its new main battle tank in a weapons program that is expected to cost $4.9 billion over the next decade.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Tentative Accord Reported in Strike At United Parcel
description: The United Parcel Service and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have reached agreement on basic terms for ending an eightweek strike of warehousemen and deliverymen in 15 Eastern states, informed sources said yesterday.

title: Company's Workers Advised Not to Help Inquiry Into Koreans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The attorney for the Pacific Development corporation here of Tongsun Park, the South Korean businessman, said today that he was advising the company's employees to cease all forms of voluntary cooperation with a Federal investigation of Mr. Park because the Justice Department had given some of the information to newsmen.

title: Burns, Clarifying Stand, Says He Will Aid Carter
description: He took advantage of a meeting that had been previously scheduled for another purpose with Chairman Henry S. Reuss of the House Banking Committee to explain that he expected to be able to cooperate with Presidentelect Carter's economic policies.

title: U.S. Leads Britain, 31, In Tennis
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP)Chris Evert and Rosie Casals, the No. 1 American doubles pair, beat Virginia Wade and Sue Barker, 60, 57, 61, tonight, giving the United States a commanding 31 lead over Britain in the Wightman Cup tennis competition.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PAIR OF ACES Because Eugene O'Neill's A Touch of the Poet and Cole Porter's Kiss Me Kate are seldom revived locally, their reappearances are welcome reminders of two masters. The O'Neill drama is being restaged on a ThursdaySaturday schedule through Dec. 12 by the Irish Arts Center, while the Porter musical tonight begins SaturdaySunday performances that will run until Nov. 28 at Temple Israel.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 33yearold unemployed maintenance man who had been arrested in Puerto Rico by two New York detectives was charged yesterday with seconddegree murder in the shooting of Fernando Anon, a striking picketer in a bitter fight between two labor unions at a Woodside, Queens, metal works last May 19.

title: Cranford's Law Makes Bike Thefts Riskier
description: CRANFORD, Nov. 12  Notice to bicycle thieves: don't try it here. Chances are the bikes will be recovered and you will face prosecution. This Union County community has put the brakes on bike thefts.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: THIS SUIT AT FINE STORES NATIONWIDE $260

title: Stage: Knights
description: When a distinguished national theaterindeed one of Europe's major companiescomes here visiting on a Bicentennial goodwill mission, one longs to be courteous. But unfortunately, with its presentation of Aristophane's Knight's at the City Center 55th Street Theater, the National Theater of Greece is giving a quite dismally brilliant object lesson in how not to offer a foreignlanguage production for an Englishspeaking audience.

title: Fossils in Montana Hint a Golden Age of Sharks
description: In the rocky ravines of a vast cattle ranch in the middle of Montana, 6,000 feet above sea level, an Adelphi University zoologist has found fossil evidence of what appears to have been a golden age of sharks that flourished in a now extinct sea and perhaps around the world more than 320 million years ago.

title: People in Sports
description: Major league baseball's perennial bad boy, Dick Allen, became a free man yesterdayfree to deal with any of the 26 teams for the 1977 season.

title: U.S. Is Called More Vulnerable To Nuclear Attack Than Russia
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)The United States has let itself become more vulnerable to nuclear attack than has the Soviet Union, according to a study published by the Library of Congress today.

title: Pistons Rout Knicks by 11197 As Aching Lanier Scores 30
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12Bob Lanier, the Detroit Pistons' big man, was hurting. He complained of tendinitis in the knees, a grievously sore back, a painful left, elbow and assorted aches and pains.

title: West German Rich: Hard Work and a Bit of Luck
description: REGENSBURG, West Germany Some of them have always had it. Some of them lost all of it in World War II but have made it back again. Some of them have acquired it only recently. All of them have trouble keeping it.

title: Beame Set to Leave For Israel and Rome
description: Mayor Beame is scheduled to leave tonight for a 10day visit to Israel and a stopover in Rome for a private audience with Pope Paul VIthe first trip to Europe.

title: Mobile in Uproar Over U.S. Judge Who Told It to Revise Government
description: MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 11A Federal court ruling ordering Mobile to scrap its city government and replace it with a new one more favorable to blacks has generated a storm of protest in this city, including a petition drive to impeach the judge.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Lebanese Continue Shooting As Syrians Delay Advance
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 12In what are supposed to be the final hours, or days, of the 19month Lebanese civil war, sporadic violence and killing are continuing here within earshot of Syrian peacekeeping troops.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that ground had been broken for an $862 million petrochemical complex in South Korea in which the American company is investing about $150 million.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters)A leftwing Cabinet minister called today for outright and complete abolition of the House of Lords, which is trying to block. approval of key Labor Government legislation.

title: Burns vs. Carter?
description: In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee this week, Chairman Arthur Burns of the Federal Reserve Board said he wanted to cooperate with the Carter Administration, but apparently only on his own terms. Indeed, his statement was interpreted as a warning Mr. Carter that the Fed is prepared for a confrontation, if the new Administration seeks to promote a faster recovery by applying greater fiscal stimulus.

title: LOUIS COHN
description: Louis Cohn, a New York lawyer with an active private practice for nearly 70 years, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.

title: Iranians Are Erecting 430Foot Barn Near Utica, Stirring Some Rumors of International Intrigue
description: BOONVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 12The Iranian owners of a 420acre farm outside this Oneida County village are putting up what may be the biggest dairy barn in the Northeast, but many people hereabouts say there is something mysterious about the thing.

title: Vote by U.S. Against Israel at U.N. Linked to Effort for Mideast Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12The decision of the United States to join in the Security Council's criticism of Israel yesterday was part of what might be the final effort by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to enhance American influence among the moderate Arabs, in expectation of possible Middle East peace talks early in the Carter Administration.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Financial Follies Boards S.S. Cotton Picker
