description: The annual Financial Follies, a parody of the year's activities in the worlds of business, finance and Government, was presented last night in the form of an updated minstrel show aboard a mythical showboat, the S.S. Cotton Picker.

title: PETER ROSENFELD OFFERS A LIVELY CELLO RECITAL
description: Peter Rosenfeld's cello recital at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night was that of a rocksolid musician steeped in the finest interpretive tradition who happens to play the cello and does it quite well.

title: E. LAWSON MAY
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., Nov. 12 (UPI) E. Lawson May, whose news career covered more than 50 years, died last night at Hutchinson Hospital of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.

title: Article 12  No Title
Queens Jury Is Looking Into Zoning Payoff Charges
description: A special grand jury in Queens is looking into allegations that Robert T. Groh, former deputy borough president there, helped arrange a political payoff by executives of the Sheraton Corporation in exchange for a zoning change, sources familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: BEAME DEFENDS USE OF HIDDEN SUBSIDIES
description: Mayor Beame expressed serious reservations yesterday about the call by New York State's next Housing Commissioner for an end to hidden subsidiessuch as tax abatements and taxexempt construction bondsthat are designed to provide incentives for housing construction and other development projects.

title: Article 5  No Title
Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$7,000. pace, mile.

title: Atrocities by Angolan Forces Described by Refugees
description: OMUNGWELUME, SouthWest Africa, Nov. 12The civil war in Angola sputters on, and here in the semidesert nine miles south of the Angolan border, fugitives from the killing huddle together pathetically beneath a blazing sun, dependent on white South Africans, who administer this territory, for their survival.

title: Corn Crop Offers Hope of Food Price Rein
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 12The largest corn crop American farmers have ever grown, even larger than the Agriculture Department expected a month ago, will help assure the world of adequate grain supplies in the coming year and will offer consumers the hope that retail prices of meat, poultry and milk will not rise significantly in the next six months.

title: Article 1  No Title
Barons Tie Flames, 3 to 3, On Lat Goal by Hampton
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 12 (AP)  Rick Hampton, a defenseman, scored a thirdperiod goal on a power play and gained the Cleveland Barons a 33 tie with the Atlanta Flames tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1976

title: PollTakers Voice Some Reservations in Analysis Of Coverage by Newspapers of Campaign Polls
description: The polltakers who spent the campaign analyzing the electorate for the news papers are in turn analyzing the newspapers' coverage of their polls. On the whole they are giving it good marks, but with reservations, according to remarks made yesterday at the Associated Press Managing Editors conference at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: 2 Men Assaulted By Band of Youths In East New York
description: Two men were assaulted with knives and chains in the East New York section of Brooklyn on Thursday evening by between 10 and 20 youths at the foot of the stairway of the elevated Van Sicklen station of the IRT line, the police reported yesterday.

title: Personal Investing
description: The Government National Mortgage Association, which has sold about $4.7 billion worth of mortgage participation securties to underwriters in the last 22 months, is scraping the bottom of its nortfolio.

title: Aqueduct Racing
John Denver Purveys His Message at Garden
description: Everything is fine, really fine. The mountains are lovely and majestic, the river is courageous, the eagle, flying high above the forest, is free, and we will always be friends.

title: Young Criminals
description: The recent rash of muggings, robberies and violence committed by youths against old and infirm victims is a reflection of the brutalization of urban society. It also underscores the need for changes in the judicial system's approach to youthful offenders.

title: Article 11  No Title
Engineering Students at Princeton Use Ingenuity to Race Model Cars
description: PRINCETON. Nov. 12The students glued the wheels in place, checked the fenders for dents and then prayed that their wobbly wooden model cars would not crash off the track today at Princeton University's Engineering School.

title: Utah Official Indicates It Is Likely Slayer's Death Sentence Will Stand
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 12George W. Lattimer, chairman of the State Board of Pardons, indicated today that there was a good chance that the hoard would uphold the death sentence of Gary Mark Gilmore, the murderer who has pleaded with the courts to he executed without further delay.

title: Remote Capital of Saudi Arabia Now Busy Cosmopolitan Center
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaIn a fragrant barber shop Saudi sheiks have their mustaches trimmed by a Palestinian. At the Riyadh airport a flock of Japanese businessmen is shepherded by a Sudanese. In the hotels the restaurant buffet tables are thronged with Americans, Britons, Frenchmen and Italiansand the waiters are mostly Egyptian. This solemn and secretive capital, set in the remote heart of the Arabian Peninsula, is getting to be downright cosmopolitan thanks to the Government's oil revenues of $30 billion a year, give or take a few million.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took steps today to counter the impression he left in many minds yesterday that he might be headed for a major fight over economic policy with the Carter Administration.

title: Pistols In Their Book Bags
description: ANKARA, TurkeyAlthough the nationalist revolution here started more than half a century ago it has never gained, sufficient headway. One result of this sad fact is a growing realization that Turkey is not yet economically qualified to join the European Community, much as it would like to do so for political reasons plus a recognition that mass social inequalities continue long after the death of Kemal Ataturk, father of the modern republic.

title: Greenspan Sees Recovery Slower Than Ford Forecast
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 12The nation's economy is recovering more slowly than forecast by the Ford Administration, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today.

title: 430Foot Barn Upstate Stirs Wild Rumors
description: BOONVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 12The Iranian owners of a 420acre farm outside this Oneida County village are putting up what may be the biggest dairy barn in the Northeast, but many people hereabouts say there is something mysterious about the thing.

title: Judge Tells Keystone To Let Horse in Race
description: In a court ruling believed to be without precedent, a Federal judge ordered Keystone Race Track last night to let a horse named Wine Treasure run M today's $150,000 Heritage Stakes.

title: Reserve Bank Abandons Plan To Build Tower
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had abandoned plans to build a 42story office tower adjacent to the bank's headquarters in the financial district.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Glenn Olds, the educator who was called in to restore tranquillity at Kent State University after the shootings in 1970 in which National Guardsmen killed four students, resigned Thursday night, but the university trustees rejected his resignation. Dr. Olds, who took over as president in 1971, told the trustees in a long letter that the tasks of healing and restoration had been completed. Dr. Olds said his decision had not been easy, but then nothing about my tenure at Kent State from the day I arrived has been easy. Advances had been made, he said, despite the tragedy of 1970, loss of funding to higher education in Ohio, a reduced enrollment and a close faculty vote in favor of unionization. The trustees, in rejecting the president's resignation, apparently were opening the door to a renegotiation of his contract.

title: Vote by U.S. Against Israel at U .N . Linked to Effort for Mideast Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12The decision of the United States to join in the Security Council's criticism of Israel yesterday was part of what might be the final effort by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to enhance American influence among the moderate Arabs, in expectation of possible Middle East peace talks early in the Carter Administration.

title: Loans to Business by Large Banks Climbed to $114.5 Billion in Week
description: Business loans at large commercial banks across the nation rose $847 million in the week ended Nov. 3 to a total outstanding of $114.5 billion, data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.

title: U.S. NOW LISTS MOSCOW AS AN UNHEALTHY POST
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP)The Soviet capital, never regarded as a cushy spot for American diplomats, is now being listed as an unhealthy post and hardship benefits for embassy employees are being improved.

title: U.S. CHECKS RIGGED BIDS IN STATEOWNED TIMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)The Justice Department is looking into the possibility of bid rigging in the sale of timber in national forests in California. a spokesman said today.

title: Brown's Date With Ivy Immortality
description: In the glow of Brown's 3521 victory over Dartmouth last week, John Anderson addressed his team. You people, the coach intoned, have a date with immortality at Columbia next week. Through nearly a century of Brown football, dates with immortality have been broken more often than kept. But today Brown has an opportunity to share, and possibly win, its first Ivy League championship. If the Bruins defeat Columbia at Baker Field, they are assured of at least a share of first place with Yale; if the Bruins win while Yale loses to or ties Harvard, they will win the title for the first time since the Ivy schools were twined together formally in 1956. Not that John Anderson is surprised by the imminence of immortality. When he took command at Brown in 1973, he promised eternal fame for the muscular scholars he persuaded to enroll at the college that has overlooked Providence, R.I., since 1770 but had been overlooked by football players who wanted an Ivy League education.

title: West German Rich: Hard Work and a Bit of Luck
description: REGENSBURG, West Germany Some of them have always had it. Some of them lost all of it in World War II but have made it back again. Some of them have acquired it only recently. All of them have trouble keeping it.

description: PARIS, Nov. 12 (AP)Jacques Jean Rat, office manager of the Paris bureau, of The Associated Press since 1946, died today at the age of 59 after a long illness, He is survived by his wife and three daughters.

Tony Alfero added a 5yard touchdown run in the third period for the Setters, who are 71. The Peacocks finished their season at 52.

description: Starting Monday, two major Passaic County hospitals will stop accepting indigent patients because of accumulating unpaid bills, hospital officials said yesterday. However officials at St. Joseph's Hospital and Barnert Memorial Medical Center in Paterson said, that they would continue providing emergency treatment for the poor.

title: F.T.C. Seeks to Block Pillsbury Pizza Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today opposing the proposed acquisition of the frozen pizza business of Fox DeLuxe Foods Inc. of Chicago by the Pillsbury Company.

title: Be Warned About 'Two Minute Warning'
description: "Two Minute Warning," about a mad sniper in a crowded football stadium, has the suspense, the compassion, the human vision and the individual nuance you would expect in a movie about a foot stepping on an anthill.But why, you may ask, would anybody make a movie about a foot stepping on an anthill?Exactly."Warning," which opened yesterday at several local theaters, is more or less of the genre of "Towering Inferno," "Juggernaut," "Jaws," "Hindenburg" and so on. Something terrible is happening, that is, and will somebody stop it, and how are we going to get out of here? And, by contrast, it makes any of themeven "Hindenburg"look like cinematic poetry.It assembles its characters in a familiar series of cameos. There is the killer, or rather bits of him: hands, feet, eyeballwe only see all of him once, blurredly, near the very end. He shoots a passing cyclist for practice before placing himself in the top tower of the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.There are the police, or rather there are two groups of the police. The first is the good guysgood, but ineffective, that isled by a captain, Charlton Heston, who worries about people getting hurt and is dubious about the methods of the second police. These, in overalls and looking like homicidal plumbers, are a tactical commando group. They are mean, violent and messy.Finally, there are the selected spectatorsa quarrelsome middle-age noncouple, a gambler who will be dropped out of a high window if Los Angeles doesn't beat Baltimore, a girl switching boyfriends in midpass, as it were, a harried young father with wife and children, a pickpocket and so on.Except for the gambler, who is played with comic but touching desperation by Jack Klugman, none of them have the slightest dimension. They could be placards. Some of them, it's obvious, will die, and the spectator is mildly sorry and mildly curious but that's all.Curiosity is not suspense. For suspense, some involvement is required. Through almost the whole length of the movie we know nothing about the threatwho he is, what he wantsand nothing about who is threatened or why. It is an abstract threatat some point somebody is going to begin shooting and some people will be killed and that's all we have.And because it is all so unspecific, the efforts of the police to catch the sniperall their ladder-climbing and maneuveringare no more exciting than watching a group of linesmen at work up a telephone pole.The movie is a blank, in other words, until the end. And then, suddenly, a lot of people are killed very gorily; and there is a mass stampede, and the football crowd becomes a panicked, murderous mob. And even the panic lacks emotion. It has momentumlots of feet stepping on facesand viciousness. Nothing more.

title: Jockey Sets Mark for Purses Won
description: Sandy Hawley, the 27yearold Canadian, accepted the congratulation of rival riders at Aqueduct yesterday after setting a North American record for purse money earned in one year by a jockey.

title: Police Unit Hunts Predatory youths, Aids Their Aged, Terrorized Victims
description: Two hardeyed detectives in loosefitting leisure suits (which tend to hide holsters the best) bent over Lily Stein in a lobby of Bronx Family Court the other day, trying to reassure the distraught woman that the 15yearold youth who had robbed her at knifepoint would not try to retaliate.

title: West Virginia Killer Sentenced
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov 12 (AP) Eugene Paul Clawson was sentenced today to life in prison without hope of parole for kidnapping, raping and beheading two 19yearold women students of West Virginia University in 1970. Mr. Clawson, 36 years old, said that he was not guilty of the crife he had earlier confessed to Mr. Clawson's victims were Karen Ferrell of Quinwood, W. Va., and Mared Malrik of Kinnelon, N.J. Their bodies were found three months after the women had disappeared while hitchhiking.

title: Public Employee Unions Propose: InflationProof Pensions at Age 55
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12Representatives of public employee unions called today for changes in pension regulations that would permit most state workers to retire at age 55 and provide 100 percent costofliving adjustments in pension payments to retired state workers.

title: Remembering Thornton Wilder: Affectionate, Unpretentious
description: HAMDEN, CONN. For us who live on Mill Rock in the town of Hamden, it's hard to walk up the hill past Thornton Wilder's house, knowing that the study with the casement window is empty. In years to come, biographers will try to recreate Thornten's personality; scholars will analyze his books and plays; readers may accord him immortality. But for us who were his neighbors, the real person, the lively, affectionate, unpretentious man is gone.

title: First Global Concerts for Casals Prove a Success in Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12The First International Casals Concerts wound up here last night with an allBeethoven program that gave a rousing finish to a fourweek festival that musicians, critics and audiences all agreed was a great success.

How skillfully he maneuvers for the rights to his life story could mean the difference between merely a large advance and the biggest advance in book publishing history.

title: Atrocities by Angolan Forces Described by Refugees
description: OMUNGWELUME, SouthWest Africa, Nov. 12The civil war in Angola sputters on, and here in the semidesert nine miles south of the Angolan border, fugitives from the killing huddle together pathetically beneath a blazing sun, dependent on white South Africans, who administer this territory, for their survival.

title: Release of Patricia Hearst Asked; Judge Likely to Rule in a Few Days

Edgar Hoover, the late director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a highlevel bureau source said today.

title: Bridge:
description: There is one aspect of tournament bridge that distinguishes it from almost all other competitive activities: In any session a player does not have any precise knowledge of whether he is winning, although he will certainly have a general impression. In a team match, or a pair contest, a player will sometimes have to make an educated guess about events at one or more other tables before deciding whether he needs to take chances in pursuit of victory.

title: A Thoughful Concept By Chicago Symphony
description: This observer has been a little backward about appreciating the mystique of Sir Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony. While others rhapsodized about the power, solidity and personality of their Carnegie Hall performances. this listener generally heard a fine orchestra under a conductor who often interpreted the music sensibly and correctly, but who revealed sometimes a surprising lack of personality and even intensity. Too often, the phrasing sounded impersonal and bland, and even the orchestral execution had its unexpected imprecisions.

title: Philharmonic Plays Bruckner
description: It will take a while for listeners to know all about the new Avery Fisher Hall. As the weeks go by and different kinds of music are heard under different kinds of conductors, the character of the remodeled concert room should disclose many facets that until now have not been evident. On Thursday night, for instance, the New York Philharmonic played Hindemith and Bruckner under the direction of Rafael Kubelik, who is about as different a musician from Pierre Boulez as could be imagined. The results suggested that Mr. Kubelik had not yet had time to take the hall's acoustical measure, let alone to achieve a really polished orchestral performance.

title: Newer Landmarks
description: One of the most unwanted honorsto the real estate community and many building ownersis landmark designation. And one of the gestures made to investors by the drafters of the city's landmarks law was to make buildings less than 30 years old ineligible for designation. The idea was to keep New York's newer and larger structures completely negotiable, a kind of tradeoff for support of the law, which imposes severe limitations on the disposition of landmarks. A more philosophical argument was that it took time to know the architectural gems from the duds.

title: Gold Price Up Abroad; Dollar Also Moves Ahead Except Against Pound
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP)The price of gold rose today in both London and Zurich, Europe's major bullion centers. The dollar made fractional gains against most European currencies but lost a bit against the British pound and Italian lira.

title: Journalism Society Names Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (UPI)Richard Leonard, editor of The Milwaukee Journal, was named today as new national president of Sigma Delta Chi, the Journalism Society. Alf Goodykoontz, managing edit or of the Richmond Va TimesDispatch

title: Britain Cuts Trade Deficit
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (UPI)Britain's trade deficit with the rest of the world narrowed by $25.6 million in October, but all but $1.6 million was attributed to special factors.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The name of one of Alexander Calder's daughters was incorrectly given in the obituary that appeared in The Times yesterday. She is Mrs. Robert Rower.

title: News Summary
description: Increased American Influence in socalled moderate Arab countries is being sought by Secretary of State Kissinger. United States diplomats said this was the explanation for Washington's joining in Thursday's unanimous criticism by the United Nations Security Council of Israeli policies in occupied Arab territories. Mr. Kissinger's efforts, the diplomats said, are being made in expectation of possible ArabIsraeli peace talks next year. [Page 1, Cols. 45.]

title: 2 Say Gamble Hid Arabs' Tender Offer
description: Two former members of the audit committee of GambleSkogmo Inc., the large retail chain based in Minneapolis, charged yesterday that the company's recent registration statement failed to disclose a proposed tender offer for all or some of the concern's stock by an unidentified Arab consortium.

title: PollTakers Voice Some Reservations in Analysis Of Coverage by Newspapers of Campaign Polls
description: The polltakers who spent the campaign analyzing the electorate for the newspapers are in turn analyzing the newspapers' coverage of their polls. On the whole they are giving it good marks, but with reservations, according to remarks made yesterday at the Associated Press Managing Editors conference at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: 11th St. Tenants Tilt With Windmill and Con Edison
description: The day they decided to put a windmill on the roof of the building at 519 East 11th Street was the day Consolidated Edison shut off the electricity, causing the waterheating solar collectors to overheat.

title: Article 8  No Title
Radio
description: Music

title: HILDA TUMA
description: MONTAUK, L.I., Nov. 12Hilda Tuma, for many years the owner of Tuma's Dock at Montauk Lake, died today in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset of cancer. She was 75 years old.

title: The Men Who Come Across for Culture
description: ASK Nicholas Ullrich about the highlight of his three years on the job as Suffolk County's culture czar and he replies immediately:

title: Tigers Suffer Their 11th Straight Loss at Home, 33 to 7
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13Princeton University's football team, once a respected power in Ivy League football, has fallen upon dismal days.

title: Conferees Say VaccineMaking May Be in Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The entire system by which vaccines are developed and put in use in this country may be in jeopardy, scientists and others suggested today at a national conference on immunization policy.

title: Sear It, Sew It, Stuff It, Wear It
description: The rising popularity of skiing, camping and backpacking has brought prosperity to some of the companies that cater to the sewathome crowd. Do  it  yourself kits for down  filled parkas, vests, bib overalls, comforters nd sleeping bags represent a business that has grown rapidly and now amounts to perhaps $20 million a year.

title: Lone Inmate Tells of Life On New York's Death Row
description: Joseph Eli Davis spends 23 hours of each day locked in an 8by6foot cell under extraordinary security precautions in a remote area of Green Haven prison known as K Gallery. K Gallery is more commonly known as Death Row, and Mr. Davis is its only occupant.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It's been accepted critical practice for years to express pity for actors who appear in bad movies or plays. Everybody else is responsible never the actors. I grew up reading lofty condolences on the order of, .... and Sophie Lewis, one of our most talented, dazzling actresses, was trapped in the proceedings, along with everyone else in the flawless cast. Or, Robert Forgan does the best he can with the idiotic material, though no one could have saved it. Admitedly, actors and actresses must eat. They have to support families. They have dentist bills and school tuitions to meet, and there aren't that many films or plays that they can always be choosy. Also, there are plenty of films that don't succeed in spite of the talent, taste, imagination and discipline of the people involved. Yet there comes a time when actors who've reached a certain status must share the blame. Should we shake our heads in sorrow when Gene Hackman turns in a multimilliondollar bore like Lucky Lady and suggest it's not his fault? No more. Gene Hackman was paid a bundle to make that movie and for us to feel sorry for him is ridiculous. You might as well send a CARE packageto Nelson Rockefeller. Hackman made that film because he wanted to. No one held a gun to his head.

title: At Large: Strategies For the Nonskier
description: The enchantments to be found during a week of skiing vary greatly with the individual. Some hearty souls enjoy the thrill of downhill racing, with the powder flying, while others prefer the contemplativeness of cross country. For myself, the principal pleasure I derive on such an out ing always comes in the late afternoon when I can sit out in the crisp mountain air with a drink in my hand and listen to the snapping of femurs echoing from the distant hills, knowing each crack means that, come spring, there will be one less lunatic cluttering up the golf course.

title: Where Are the Reformers?
description: Just a decade agoalthough it seems like historyAmerican education was feeling the rumbles of revolution.

title: Jane G. Greenblatt Engaged To Dr. Arnold C. Gunther
description: Jane G. Greenblatt, an urban planner for New York City, and Dr. Arnold C. Gunther, a resident in ophthalmic surgery at the New Jersey Medical School's affiliated hospitals, will be married this winter. Mr. and Mrs. Nathan E. Greenblatt of Wyckoff, N..J, announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Gunther of Clifton, N. J.

title: The Zodiac
description: The Zodiac, by James Dickey, is a poem in 12 parts, a major undertaking and, I should hazard, achievement. According to a headnote, it is based another poem of the same title, written by a Dutchman, one Hendrik Marsman, who was killed by a torpedo in the North Atlantic in 1940. But, the headnote asserts, this is no mere translation, for only a few lines are drawn from the original. And the reader can easily understand how Dickey's temperament would have led him to relive and rewrite and, in the process, transform Marsman's poem.

title: In a Dispiriting War, One Little Victory...
description: At 11:20 A.M. the bell rings. Fifth and sixth graders at Public School 31 fill the halls as they head for their daily reading period.

title: Fighting Dismissal In the Civil Service
description: TRENTON IN ANY given year, several thousand public employees in New Jersey displease their superiors by not corning to work, by being obnoxious or by suddenly becoming incompetent.

title: Metropolitan Basketball: Rutgers, St. John's and Hofstra Best
description: Reggie Carter and Bernard Rencher wore secondteam blue jerseys as they scrimmaged. When Carter drove to the basket, penetrating through a mass of first team red jerseys for a layup, Coach Lou Carnesecca of St. John's smiled and said, It's nice to have guys like that in the ice box.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Sales of the threecoin, 40 percent silver Bicentennial uncirculated coin sets got a definite boost when the U.S. Mint inaugurated its bulkrate sales program late last year. Now the Mint has given these sets another plusa colorful holiday gift packagingthat should appeal not only to numismatic collectors but also to anyone looking for a distinctive Christmas gift with a direct link to the Bicentennial As shown above the package is dominated by an oldfashioned winter scene, a through a snowrimmed window view of historic Independence Hall in Philadelphia. The principal colors used in the packaging are crimson and white.

title: ART
description: HUNTINGTON LOCKWOOD DE FOREST, the subject of an outstanding, ambitious exhibition at the Heckscher Museum, was one of those delightful 19thcentury creations that civilization no longer produces. To say that he was a polymath of a manan architect, painter, decorator, businessman, ideologue, writer and teacher does not seize his imaginative spirit, breath and complexity. Nor does it do justice to the important role he played in the development of a solid American aesthetic as well as an American appreciation for the arts.

title: TruckHijacking Loss in Jersey Is Estimated at $20 Million a Year
description: NEWARK (UPI)  Truck hijacking is becoming a fastgrowing crime in New Jersey, with hijackers selling a variety of stolen goods through a web of wellorganized underground networks, according to Federal authorities.

title: Hava Kohav Presents Narrative for Dancer and Film
description: It's discouraging to see a live dancer make the basic mistake of trying to compete with film for audience attention. After the experimentation of the last 15 years one thought that it was common knowledge that people will watch film exclusively, given half a chance, so that the choreographer must be very clever about not giving them the opportunity.

title: All 11 in Cabinet Starting to Make PostFord Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13They got their to be laid off notices in the chill hours before dawn on Nov. 3. But unlike millions of other Americans, they are not likely to swell the unemployment lines this winter.

title: Superiority of Golf Over Tennis
description: Tennis was not always such a popular sport. In the 1950's, things were different.

title: Alison Newton Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sy Newton of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Hope Newton, to Steven Nakash, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nakash of Dix Hills, L.I. Miss Newton is a senior at Hofstra University, from which her fianc graduated last June. The wedding will take place in September.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN applying varnish with a brush, never dip the brush into the liquid by more than onethird its bristle length, and don't rub or wipe the brush across the rim of the can to remove the excess. Instead, slap the bristle tips lightly against the inside of the can or pail, above the level of the liquid, in order to tap off excess and prevent dripping. This will leave the brush still fully loaded. Wiping across the rim creates tiny bubbles that ran back into the varnishand these make it almost impossible to get a smooth job later on.

title: Rye Neck Triumphs by 357 And Gets Postseason Berth
description: Rye Neck finished the regular season yesterday as the only unbeaten team in Westchester, crushing Briarcliff, 357, for the Panthers' eighth victory and a trip to the Section I Class C bowl game next weekend. Once  beaten Pleasantville is the likely opponent.

title: Australian Golfer Ties Mark
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 13(AP)Australia's Randall Vines shot an 8underpar 64 today, equalling the course record, and moved into a fourthplace tie, three strokes behind the leaders, Australia's Kel Nagle and New Zealand's Simon Owen, who lead after three rounds of a golf tournament here with 207. Gil Morgan of the United States was second with 208, followed by fellow American Mark Lye at 209.

title: Thoreau, Machiavelli and a dash of Emma Goldman
description: In the fall of 1918, when half the world was still at war, a militant pacifist confronted a Federal judge in a New York City courtroom. The charge: willful violation of the draft laws. The plea: guilty. And then Roger Baldwin, at 34 the national director of a fledgling organization for the defense of conscientious objectors, spoke his mind.

title: U.S. Takes Tennis Cup From British Team, 52
description: LONDON, Nov. 13 (UPI)  Chris Evert rallied today to defeat Sue Parker, 26, 62, 62, and help the United States snap Britain's twoyear hold on the Wightman Cup.

title: InnerCity Option: Catholic Schools
description: Betty Porter is black, Protestant, and lives in one of the better neighborhoods of Chicago's South Side. She has taken her secondgrade daughter out of the Chicago public schools and enrolled her at Holy Angelsa curious choice: it is a 1,283student, allblack Roman Catholic school in the most impoverished neighborhood in Chicago. Seventyfive percent of Holy Angels children live in the poorest onethird of the city's neighborhoods. At least onethird of its students receive welfare support.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, Nov. 13 (UPI)  The Vatican today took one of the final steps toward proclaiming a 14thcentury Philadelphia bishop the first male saint from the United States by declaring the ??ure of cancer of a Philadelphia man a miracle.

title: Miss Michels, Leland Badger To Wed Dec. 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Michels of West Hartford, Conn. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Nan Michels, to Leland James Badger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Kelly Badger of Kenilworth, Ill.

title: Clinton Defense and Bayside Offense Prevail, Setting Stage for Showdown
description: Clinton, with an impenetrable defense, ended Jefferson's quest for a third straight Public Schools Athletic League football title, and Payside, with an explosive offense, dominated Susan Wagner in semifinal playoff games yesterday.

title: BLANCHE L. GOODMAN
description: Blanche L. Goodman, a board member for many years of the Grand Street Settlement on the Lower East Side, died yesterday at her home at 1085 Park Avenue. She was 79 years old.

title: Soviet Releases Dissident
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (AP)Pyotr Starchik, a songwriter and dissident, was released today from a mental hospital after nearly two months of forced drug treatment for what was termed socially dangerous behavior, dissident sources reported. Authorities offered no explanation for the release, but Mr. Starchik's friends believed that the state was influenced by a protest campaign abroad.

title: Army Officer Is Named Premier In New Burundi Government
description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Nov. 13 (Reuters)A Belgianeducated army officer. Lieut. Col. Edouard Nzambimana, has been appointed Burundi's Prime Minister, according to a Government list announced today.

title: PENNSYLVANIA PENNSYLVANIA
Colleen Lyons Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Lyons Jr. of Blue Point, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Colleen Ann Lyons, to Harold James King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart S. King of Sayville, L.I.

title: Notre Dame Tops Bama; Slager Star
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 13 (UPI)Rick Stager completed 15 of 23 passes for 235 yards, including a 56yard touchdown pass to Dan Kelleher, and led Notre Dame to a 2118 victory today over Alabama in a regionally televised name.

title: New Book Salutes Marine Veterans
description: PRINCETON Lucy's neighbors are giving her an autograph party this afternoon, and there are signs that it's going to be a big one. An admiral is coming up from Washington for the occasion, and some United States Marines are corning down from New York. So the neighbors say.

title: Locked Up: The Safe Life
description: Jewels in the bathroom hamper. That's an old trick. The burglar knows it.

title: An Episcopal Bishop Will Ordain The Woman Who Sparked Dispute
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 13 (AP)An Episcopal Bishop said yesterday that in accord with recent changes in church law he would ordain Betty Bone Schiess, whose irregular ordination two years ago sparked a controversy over women in the priesthood.

title: POLITICS
description: PAUL T. JORDAN'S name was not on the ballot in the recent general election, but the Jersey City Mayor and gubernatorial aspirant was one of the losers.

title: Building a Community for the Deaf
description: WASHINGTONIt is homecomingfor the Gallaudet Bisons. They are in a tough game against Anne Arundel College. The cheerleaders and pompom squad present a flurry of yellow and blue. The homecoming queen, crowned by a tiara, is enthroned before the bleachers.

title: Home, Cheap Home
description: THE mailman saw a house. It was brown, pink and blue outside, a shambles on the inside, with boards aver the windows the garage in pieces and the lawn left unmowed for several years. Naturally, he bought it.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: New York City Reflected in Its Schools
description: After long study, the Federal Government has issued a report criticizing widespread discrimination in the New York City school system's hiring, assignment and promotion of minorities and women. The report confirmed what many believed, but it was limited in prescribing what can be done, and who can do it, within the conditions created by Government itself and by the seminal discrimination in the wider society.

title: Carey's New Man For Mental Health
description: HAUPPAGE JUST about a year ago, Governor Carey appointed a special committee of mentalhealth experts to advise him on policy alternatives in the field of mental hygiene.

title: Dr. Seuss, Theo. Le Sieg
description: For nearly 40 years since his first children's book, And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street in 1937, Theodore Seuss Geisel has been winning the hearts and minds of children by the sneaky stratagem of making them laugh. With the appearance of two new books this fall, his total book count now stands at 41. Their total sales worldwide approach 70 million copies, according to Geisel himself. Beginner Books, a company he founded with his late wife, Helen, in 1958, to produce early reading books for preschoolers and first and secondgraders, some of which Geisel writes, has by now 100 titles out, with sales in the 50 to 60 millioncopy range by rough estimate. Geisel sold the company to Random House in 1960, but he remains its president and editor in chief.

title: Royal Ski Takes Heritage, With Wine Treasure Last
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Nov. 13 Favored Royal Ski won the $150,000 Heritage Stakes today at Keystone as Wine Treasure, the unwanted colt added to the field by court order, finished last.

title: The cafe terrace of Amsterdam's modern art museum, the Stedelijk, overlooks the sculpture garden.
description: If You Go ... ... museumhopping in Europe and want to devote full time to viewing the masterpieces while grabbing a bite on the run, here is a list of establishments with restaurants that might help you pace yourself. Museum hours (and prices) change as frequently as the seasons, so it is always advisable to check in advance to find out whether the kitchens and/or museums themselves are open.

title: JOHN J. IRVINE
description: John J. Irvine, a retired corporate secretary and general partner of Arthur Young & Co., an international accounting company, died Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.J. He was 61 years old and lived at the Roslyn Estates.

title: Collecting Rock OldiesRecords That. Go Jingle
description: The popular 45rpm recording could well become the most collectible artifact of postWorld War II America. Introduced by RCA Victor in March 1949 to rival the Columbia Records longplaying 331/3rpm disk, within a decade the doughnuthole 45 became the standard format for all single commercial recordings issued in the U. S. As such, it can lay claim to being the most tangible and easilystored memento of the popular culture of recent times.

title: President Park Ousts South Korean C.I.A. Official Reportedly in Charge of Operations in Washington
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, Nov. 14President Park Chung Hee has secretly ousted the thirdranking official of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. The official was reportedly responsible for coordinating the activities of a network of operatives in Washington, including Park Tong Sun, a businessman known in the United States as Tongsun Park, and Pak Bo Hi, a key official in the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.

title: Miss Thurber Fiancee Of Ferdinand Lauffer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harris E. Thurber of Middlebury, Vt. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Jane Thurber, to Ferdinand Lauffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Lauffer of Dauchingen, West Germany, where his father is a town administrator.

title: John Lewis Is a Personal Symbol for a Historic Period
description: John Lewis is a name from the past in the American civil rights movement, but it is also a name from the present, and perhaps the future, of American politics. Mr. Lewis, normally the most selfeffacing of men, was prideful and expansive last week in declaring, as others have, that Southern black voters had been responsible for electing a Southern white politician President.

title: The Country Is in Precarious Economic Shape and Has Been Beset by Strikes
description: JERUSALEMIsrael right now is a bit like a house in which the residents are arguing with one another (the politicians), the roof is leaking (the economy) and hostile neighbors are discussing changing the property line (the borders). The mood of the country is sour and discordant and that has more to do with pressing internal matters than with the everpresent threat from the Arab nations.

title: Merrilee Cox Fiancee Of Robert Berkowitz
description: Merrilee Cox, a reporter with United Press International Audio in Washington, and Robert Berkowitz, a reporter and national news editor for the Associated Press Radio in Washington, plan to be married in Washington in January.

title: Paterson: Plea For Regional Survival
description: HOW badly does Paterson and its region want to survive? Thoughtful men and women no longer have to be persuaded that our state, the most densely populated in the nation, cannot prosper in time, even functionunless prompt recognition is made of the fact that our cities and our suburbs are one.

title: How to Tell What Tests Really Show
description: Educators rely heavily on tests to tell them how well students are doing in reading. The usual method is by a standardized test that has been administered to a representative sampling of students in the same grade throughout the United States.

title: Going to College  One Way to Spend a Weekend
description: John and Laura Tompkins discovered a new and appealing way to spend their leisure time. On one weekend out of every three they became weekend students at Elizabeth Seton College near Yonkers. Laura studied languages. John worked toward an associate in liberal arts degree.

title: The Nation
description: Administrations and their fiscal policies come and go, but there is always the Federal Reserve Board, its cautious monetary policy and its consistent and cautious chairman, Arthur F. Burns. Last week Mr. Burns let Presidentelect Jimmy Carter know that, right now at least, he thinks any attempt to speed recovery from the recession is not only unnecessary, but would be dangerous.

title: The Lame Ducks Can Leave Behind a Nest of Time Bombs
description: WASHINGTONThe sportsmanlike cordiality with which President Ford and Presidentelect Jimmy Carter have begun the 80day transition to the new Administration belies the inherent awkwardness and the crippling suspension of power of the prolonged American interregnum.

title: Afternoons in MidAmerica
description: It's probably unfair that we find auctorial churlishness more appealing in Nabokov than In Edward Dabiberg, and odder still that the politics of Lillian Hellman are presumed to be of greater moment than, let's say, James T. Farrell's. Literary judgments as they trickle into these side issues sometimes do seem whimsical. More central are the sea changes that occur in the way we look at a writer's entire subject matter: for instance, that the South of Flannery O'Connor supplanted the South of Erskine Caldwell for most students of fiction. Neither author's view is going to carry you terribly far in the Sunbelt, both are dating at a rate approximately consonant with their dates of birth. But I still have a soft spot for Caldwell, especially in his own sort of country at firsthand.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: At first glance, the color photographs of Stephen Shore currently on view at The Museum of Modern Art strongly resemble picture postcard views of unusually drab and boring Middle Western towns. Even when he photographs a picturesque city like Charleston, S.C., Shore ignores the beautiful old churches, houses and gardens that have been the principal subject matter of all previous photographers of Charleston in favor of corner filling stations and the backsides of nondescript commercial buildings. Usually, however, he avoids even the proximity of the picturesque and concentrates his attention on the kind of dismal small town where the principal sights are the drivein movie theater, the new suburban residential section, the litter of motels, trailer camps and truck stops on the outskirts and the threeorfourstory downtown commercial district. old churches, houses and gardens that have been the principal subject matter of all previous photographers of Charleston in favor of corner filling stations and the backsides of nondescript commercial buildings. Usually, however, he avoids even the proximity of the picturesque and concentrates his attention on the kind of dismal small town where the principal sights are the drivein movie theater, the new suburban residential section, the litter of motels, trailer camps and truck stops on the outskirts and the threeorfourstory downtown commercial district.

title: Radio Misuse, on Rise, Called Sea. Peril
description: Marshall McCluhan, where are you? Our mediums are cluttered, and good buddies are messing up our messages. In fact, the growing use and abuse of VHFFM marine radios threaten the emergency communications on which lives at sea may depend, according to a marine electronics executive. When doublesideband (AM) radiotelephones become obsolete Jan. 1, recreational boatmen will be relying on VHFFM for shortrange and the single sideband (AM) for longrange communications. The problem with double sideband was that, with all the background noise, interference and limited channels, it was difficult to get a message through. And that's still the problemeven with VHFFM.

title: Unbearable Bearbearing Books
description: At one time or another, we have used the shoulder blades of bears to mow down grass, the guts to make windowpanes and snow masks, the paws for food, the fat for cosmetics and the penile bone for a coat hook. The bear has been known as the Dog of God, has been said to possess the strength of ten men and the sense of twelve. Some Swiss believe that bears, not Adam and Eve, were our first ancestors. According to Finnish legend, the offspring of a woman and a bear is a hero. The bear alone gets two constellations of stars, the Great and the Lesser, named after him. Bears, like Romantic poets, tend to die shortly after their 30th birthdays.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fire in a patient's room on the sixth floor of the psychiatric section of the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center at 525 East 68th Street was quickly extinguished by firemen. Twelve of the patients were removed from their rooms and taken to another area as a safety precaution.

title: Individualizing College Instruction Through SelfPacing
description: Thirty years ago Fred Keller was looking for a better way to teach Morse code to soldiers. The method he devised and later developed into a sophisticated teaching technique is now one of the fastest spreading innovations in college classrooms.

title: BURIAL OF PESTICIDE AT ISSUE IN IDAHO
description: BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 13The Idaho authorities are pondering whether to allow the Allied Chemical Company to bury tons of Kepone wastes, now in Baltimore, in an abandoned Titan missile silo 2,000 miles away in this state.

title: When Virtuosos Get Together for a Summit Meeting
description: The musicians who perform on the recent recordings discussed here are larger than life personalities who for one reason or another rate the general title virtuoso. What constitutes their virtuosity can sometimes elude analysis, but on the whole they do share one if not all three of the following characteristics: technical superiority on their chosen instrument, an individual point of view toward the music they interpret and, most intangible of all, a personal aura that grips an audience the moment they appear on a concert platform.

title: Cindy Becker Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Becker of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Cindy G. Becker. to David M. Farber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Farber of Bayonne, N.J. A wedding in March is planned.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: The Autumn, Visit The NEW HOPE MOTEL The Motel in The Woods Write Dept, N., for Brochure New Hope, Penna. 18938

title: Food
description: In times past, a student boarding away from home had to raid the school's kitchen or otherwise buck regulations to prepare a meal for himself. Note, for example, the account of M. F. K. Fisher, a venerable writer on the subject of food (and life surrounding the partaking of it), in Those Were Happy Days (from Consider the Oyster): I shall remember always the mysterious beautiful sensation of wellbeing I felt, when I was small, to hear my mother talk of the suppers she used to eat at boarding school. They were called midnight feasts, and were kept secret, supposedly, from the teachers, in the best tradition of the 1890's. They consisted of loaf.

title: CrossCountry A 6Day Tour Through the Rocky Mountains
description: The early sun cast a pale glow across the vast white landscape of Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado. After a breakfast of fresh fruit and oatmeal, the six of us had driven the few miles from the inn at Estes Park to Lawn Lake Trailhead inside the park. Now, as the sun lit the wild, steep peaks, we stood beside our parked cars supping on rucksacks, gloves, touring skis and poles. It was 10 degrees above zero and eight inches of fresh powder snow lay underfoot.

title: Area's Economic Decline Has Hurt Its Airports, Too
description: Add a new victim to the list of casualties of New York's declining economic fortunesthe area's three major airports.

title: Happiness Is a New Home
description: HOBOKEN JUST after school, in the courtyard playground of the Clock Tower Apartments, eight or nine brightly bundled children are celebrating the home they've lived in for only a few monthsa tormer factory converted to apartments tor 174 families, all moderateincome but otherwise almost exotically varied.

title: House Unit Will Get Memo Saying Oswald Planned to Kill Kennedy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13  A 1964 memorandum saying that Lee Harvey Oswald told Cuban officials he was going to kill President Kennedy more than a month before the assassination is part of a packet of new material found in Government files that will be turned over to a special Congressional investigating committee, reliable Government sources said today.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT MAY NOT SEEM as significant or important for some of you to know as the fact that supermarket milk is even more watery these days, or that blue cheese is $1 a pound cheaper in Summit than in Montclair, but to others it will be important to know that there appears to be deep intellectual divisiveness in Mensa.

title: Jury Volunteers Sought
description: The Queens County Clerk, John J. Durante, has issued an appeal for volunteers to serve on grand juries, the panels that hear evidence and decide whether to issue formal charges in criminal cases. Applicants, who must be 18 to 75 years old and able to speak, read and write English, should apply at Room 100 of the Queens Courthouse at 8811 Sutphin Boulevard in Jamaica between 9 A.M. and 3 P.M. on weekdays, City, state and Federal employees are ineligible.

title: If You Go...
description: ...to South India to sec the Hindu temples, you can fly to Madras from New York on a roundtrip excursion fare, good 14 to 120 days, for $835. The additional round trip from Madras to Madurai is $40.80. You can also fly all over India on a Discover India ticket, good for 14 days, offered by Indian Airlines, for $200.

title: A Bridge to the Working World
description: A new search for a way to build bridges between schools and the working world has created the latest academic fadcareer education.

title: Closing Suburban Schools Is Traumatic
description: Commack, L.I., knows what happens when elementary school enrollments drop. Schools close, and the community is likely to find itself locked in battle. In Commack the problem was Marshmallow Drive. When the school board announced last year that two elementary schools would be closed this fallone of 18 such actions on Long Island and almost 50 in the state in the last 12 monthsit meant that some children would have to cross a heavily traveled highway carrying fastmoving trucks to the town dump. Parents and teachers took to the picket line.

title: Pope John Lengthens Unbeaten Streak to 41
description: SPARTA, N.J., Nov. 13Pope John today extended New Jersey's longest winning streak to 21 games and the longest unbeaten skein to 41 by blanking Newton, 420, for Pope John's eighth success this season. Chris McGrath scored on runs of 43, 17 and 6 yards, as Newton was dealt its fifth defeat in eight games. Pope John totaled 262 yards on offense, and Newton lost 6 yards on the day.

title: Improving Law School Aptitude Is Big Business
description: When John Sexton enters the classroom of his Law School Aptitude Test (LSAT) Preparation Center, his assistant stands waiting with a steaming mug of coffee. The one provision under which I teach is coffee every half hour. I drink 20 cups a day, he said, Coffee kills my appetite. Eating takes too much time!

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Most of advantages in taking a summer vacation in the fall.
3 Jailed in Jersey for Refusal To Testify in Corruption Inquiry
description: NEWARK, Nov. 12 (AP)Three men have been jailed for refusing to answer questions before a grand jury investigating alleged corruption of police and public officials in Union City.

title: Next: Congress
description: We believe that Congress should do just that. In this year's election much of the special interest money that once would have gone to the Presidential candidates went into Congressional campaigns instead. Where special interest groupsbusiness, professional, labor, agriculturalinvested $12.5 million in the Congressional races in 1974, as much as $25 million is believed to have been poured into them in 1976. To discourage a flood of candidacies by frivolous or demagogic selfpromoters, Federal money for Congressional campaigns might well be put on a matching basis for the regular election, as they are now in Presidential primaries.

title: Quebec's Critical Vote
description: Quebec's voters go to the polls tomorrow in an election that has revived dramatically the question of whether that largely Frenchspeaking province should remain in the Canadian federation or strike out on its own as an independent nation. Interest in that issue was intensified last week by an opinion poll which showed twice as much support for the separatist Parti Qubcois as for Premier Robert Bourassa's Liberal Government.

title: Newspaper Editor to Wed Janet Watrous
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Watrous Jr. of Montrose, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Couper Watrous, to Robert Charles Kochersberger Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kochersberger of Sinclairville, N.Y. The couple plan to be married May 14.

title: Epilogue
description: A civilian intelligence officer who was stripped of his special security clearances for publicly criticizing the views of the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff has resigned from the Air Force. On Oct. 19, in an interview with The New York Times, Joseph Churba criticized Gen. George S. Brown's views that Israel was a military burden on the United States. Mr. Churba said that these views were dangerously irresponsible. Mr. Churba, who was the Air Force's senior intelligence officer for the Middle East, said that he had been told by his superior that because of the newspaper interview his special clearances had been suspended and that he was no longer of any value to the Air Force as an intelligence estimator.

title: Two novels
description: Perhaps this is the only country where as violently a revolutionary novel as The Monkey Wrench Gang could be published with impunity to author and publisher. But not at all oddly, no particular attention was given the book when it first appeared a year ago. The novel is a long, extravagant, finely written tale of ecological sabotage in the American Southwest, and no small sabotage at thatgreat bridges, trains, mining and road building equipment are destroyed.

title: INACTION ON LOBBYING BY KOREA IS LINKED TO ITS VIETNAM ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13A former State Department official in charge of Korean affairs has asserted that senior officials of the Nixon Administration did little to curb an improper South Korean lobby here because they did not want to jeopardize the Korean commitment of 52,000 troops to the war in Vietnam.

title: Partial List of Drugs U.S. Calls Ineffective
description: Following is a partial list of drugs that newspapers in Brazil said the United States Food and Drug Administration had ruled ineffective. The FDA in Washington has confirmed that they are so listed. The manufacturers' names are in parentheses.

title: Book Ends
description: New Urizen. A new publishing house, called Urizen Books, has announced that it will share a portion of its profits with all its authors and employees. To get to the bottom of this apparent new deal for the working author, we braved a rachitic, though manned, elevator in a nice old building on West Broadway in the shadow of the World Trade Center, and entered the firm's cluttered, Dickensian offices. There we met Michael Roloff and Wieland SchulzKeil, who, with Bernard Hassan, make up Urizen's editorial staff.

title: Alexander Calder
description: From Lincoln Center to Jerusalem to Japan, in open plazas and in confined museums, the genius of Alexander Calder's mobiles and stabiles will continue to delight men, women and children. By liberating sculptural forms and dispatching the most mundane materials into his twirling universe, he evoked smiles and sent imaginations soaring.

title: Best Sellers
ART VIEW
description: The departure of Thomas P. F. Hoving from the directorship of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Dec. 31, 1977reported by Grace Glueck in this paper on Nov. 5will mark the end of an extraordinary chapter in the history of American museology. The Hoving decade at the Met has been a decade of ebullition, and we shall be a lung time coming to terms with the vast changes that have resulted from to terms with the vast changes that have resulted from the Incessant, sometimes inspired, often solid but also often damaging and wearying activity that has been the distinguishing feature of this most publicized of all museum careers.

title: A Natural Treatment For Sewage
description: LIKE King Midas turning copper into gold, scientists at the Brookhaven National Laboratory here have been turning household sewage into drinking water. A new treatment system, in operation at the laboratory for more than a year, filters sewage through a series of meadows, marshes and ponds. The resulting purified water is recharged into the dwindling groundwater, which Long Island residents draw on for household use.

title: The TV Question
description: Finally, the question of television time cries out for examination and solution. It may be that allowing a Eugene McCarthy the privilege of debating with the major party nominees would have opened the door to tenman debates and chaos. But that conclusion is where the problem begins, not where it ends.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Hunter Matures
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N. H. A feeling that I will never be more than a mediocre deer hunter, born in me after an emptyhanded week in central New Hampshire, grew to maturity during several equally unsuccessful days in the bleak northern reaches of the state.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: There are more good women artists around right now than you could shake a stick at. Some of them are famous, some of them aren't. Sometimes their work reproduces beautifully, sometimes it is virtually indecipherable unless you get to see it at first hand, Some of the artists in question are politicized, some of them aren't. But the point is that they set up the kind of benign pressure across the whole panorama of imaginative effort which was exerted by women novelists in the 1920's and 1930's, when Djuna Barnes and Virginia Woolf and Elizabeth Bowen were in their heyday.

title: Fitzgerald's Plans for Completing Tycoon
description: Not long ago, I rediscovered two letters I wrote shortly after the death of F. Scott Fitzgerald with whom I spent the last years of his life. Both letters concerned The Last Tycoon, a novel he hoped would restore his reputation to the heights he had achieved with This Side of Paradise and The Great Gatsby.

title: GiantRedskins Statistics
A People Cookbook
description: MRS. BEETON, stand aside. Andy Marki has arrived on the scene with his Monsieur BonBon's Secret Fooj. The recipe Is one of 300 submitted by 128 parishioners of Christ Episcopal Church in Middletown for the Christ Church Cookbook.

title: Albany Views TaxCollection Plan
description: New York State budget officials, troubled by sagging monthly tax revenues because of the slow economic recovery in the state, are considering a proposal to increase the collection rate of taxes by hiring 900 additional collection and auditing employees,

title: Soviet Oil Experts in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 (Reuters)Four Soviet experts have arrived here on a threeweek visit to discuss exploration for oil, the Jordanian news agency announced. The Russian arrival is linked to a cooperation agreement signed by King Hussein when he visited Moscow in the summer. Earlier drilling in Jordan by Americans, Yugoslavs, West Germans, Canadians and Britons yielded no oil. The Russians are expected to explore in a desert region where the Yugoslavs drilled without success.

title: NEW ARMS CUT CALL BY SOVIET EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The meeting of seven leaders of the Soviet bloc scheduled for Nov. 2425 in Bucharest is expected to produce a new call for East West disarmament moves and troop reductions, Eastern European diplomats report.

title: 30 Points Push Black well Within 32 of State Mark
description: Ted Blackwell, New Providence's brilliant halfback, moved into position yesterday to become the leading football scorer in New Jersey season history.

title: N.F.L. Standings
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: Engagements
description: KliglerCantor

title: Red Sonja, Star Of the Comics Fans
description: WONDER WOMAN, look out! Red Sonja, that other leading lady of the comicsbook world, is about to be the first character to have a comicsart convention devoted entirely to her.

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: FOOD
description: A GOOD pork storeand there are fewer of them with each passing yearis something to treasure. One such, the Farmview Pork Store at 11 South Walnut Street, Ridgewood, has been attracting customers to its pristine quarters for 30 years with its barrel sauerkraut (49 cents a pound), imported German wine sauerkraut (59 cents a pound) and its long list of sausages that make the mouth water.

title: Fashion
description: The hottest news from the Paris spring praporter collections is the mini. And the man who put it hack in the spotlight is Kenzo. He wants women in shorts or short skirts this summer, and what he wants he often gets. Why short lengths now? Because, Kenzo says, couture is like cuisine: If you eat steak every day, it's boring.

title: Gallup Pollsters Take a Time Out
description: PRINCETON WITH the nation's Bicentennial election now a matter of history, the rush to take America's political pulse has subsided for the pollsters at the Gallup Organization, the nationwide polling concern that has its headquarters here.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: Do you get premonitions of disaster when a tennis opponent sends up a lob? Does the thought of the overhead smash you'll have to hit give you the screaming meemies?

title: Black Presence Grows in Higher Education
description: WASHINGTONAccess to colleges around the nation has improved dramatically for blacks over the last 10 years but the persistent tendency of minority students to drop out of high school makes it unlikely that blacks will soon achieve parity in college attendance with whites.

title: CLASH ACROSS BORDERS REPORTED BY RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 13 (Reuters)Rhodesia reported today that its troops had exchanged fire with Mozambique forces in a fresh clash between the two neighbors.

title: Columbia College Seeking a Dean But Not Many Applicants Seek Post
description: The job of dean of Columbia College has remained vacant for nearly a year because the university's larger financial problems make it unattractive to prospective candidates.

title: CITY HOUSING AUDIT BY LEVITT IS GLOOMY
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that despite New York City's attempt to remedy serious financial problems in its MitchellLama housing program, the program was still in a steadily worsening situation that further threatened the city's tenuous fiscal health.

title: City Planning Hovercraft Service From Manhattan to La Guardia
description: New York City expects to initiate waterborne rushhour transit service to La Guardia Airport from the Wall Street area and from midtown by next August, using 84passenger aircushion vessels, Transportation Administrator Alexander J. Mautner has announced.

title: The Charm of Country Dining
description: UNLIKE most other rural eateries in New Jersey, Le Deauville Inn has the look and feel of a true French relais de campagne (country inn). The restaurant occupies an old Gatsbylike estate that is set far hack from the road amidst lawns and trees, and the gabled main dining room is spacious, comfortable and inviting, what with tiny candles glowing on each table.

title: Chart of Ladies Handicap
description: ?? 1976 by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Floods and Cape May
description: LAST August, the beachfront and coastal areas within the City of Cape May were flooded by water trapped 9 feet above mean sea level (better than 3 feet above the high tide for that day) on the land side of a 14foot sea wall.

title: TheTrick Is Matching A Nursery To a Child
description: About 2 million children of preschool age are going to American nursery schools this year. Because nurseryschool education is optional and outside the public school system parents must decide where, if anywhere, a child will go. The choices are numerous, varied and confusing, and the selection process may take months.

title: Article 7  No Title
PORTUGUESE HAUNTED BY FATE OF ALLENDE
description: LISBON, Nov. 13The memory of what happened to the Marxist experiment of Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens in Chile haunts the Portuguese.

title: A conversation with Sheik Zaki
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki alYamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, received me at his palatial stone residence at Al Hada, surrounded by trees of fig and pomegranate, atop the plateau of the Hejaz mountains, not far from the summer capital of Taif. In the presence of Tamam, his new and lovely young wife, and his two nubile daughters, we conversed from midnight until the small hours of the morning. A commoner, Sheik Zaki is reputed to be less powerful than he was during the reign of King Faisal, who considered him a son. Today, the crucial decisions on Saudi oil are taken by Crown Prince Fand and King Khalid, who are said to he less fond of their ingenious minister. Nevertheless, Yamani's advice in formulating oil policy is indispensable, and he remains the world's most knowledgeable expert on the problems of petroleum and their political implications

title: South
description: Rutgers 29, Tulane 20

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Sunshine Law Article Found to Be a Bit Hazy

title: Reforming the Campaign Reform
description: The public financing of Presidential campaigns has come through its first trial very wellwhich is not to Say perfectly. Those who have long opposed the domination of American politics by big money can feel gratified that for the first time since the earliest days of the Republic a President will soon assume office without obligation to distribute ambassadorships, Cabinet posts and other plums as quid for the quo of generous campaign contributions.

title: TwentyFive Years of the Best
description: This year marks the silver anniversary of The Times best illustrated book awards. One hundred and fiftyone illustrators have been singled out over the years for this special accolade. On that first list of honors in 1952 the names of Maurice Sendak and the husbandwife team of Alice and Martin Provensen appeared. Mr. Sendak and the Provensens appear again this year. Sendak has been the most frequent winner with 17 previous books; the Provensens are second with this, their sixth award. Roger Duvoisin and Andre Francois are next with five each. On this page are illustrations from the books with which these illustrators first won the prize.

title: The Bishops and the Flock
description: THE four auxiliary bishops named last spring to bring the Roman Catholic Church closer to its 1.5 million people in the Archdiocese of Newark say that their efforts to decentralize authority and reach out to the people are meeting wth success.

title: DELAY ON B1 DECISION IS URGED BY PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Defense Department, in a move to ease the transition of power, is seeking to work out an arrangement that would relieve Jimmy Carter of the necessity of making a major decision on the B1 bomber program shortly after he becomes President.

title: Ancient Peru: The Mysterious Images of the Nazca Plains
description: 1927. Toribio Mexta Xesspe, member of a Peruvian aerial survey team, gazes from his cockpit over the endless sameness of the ground below. The desert whiteness has been replaced by brown barrenness as the plane has moved inland, but the mnotony of the lifeless coastal terrain of southern Peru remains almost hypnotic. Suddenly there is something. Long lines stretch across the flat tableland between Nazca and Palpatoo many for mule tracks. He makes another run over the area. The ground is covered with straight lines, crisscrossed lines stretching on for miles, plus markings that seem to resemble animals.

title: Northeast Democratic Governors Drafting Aid Requests for Carter
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Nov. 13Democratic Governors of seven Northeastern states met in this Revolutionary War hamlet today, optimistic about putting together a shopping list for Federal aid to the Northeast that would be looked on favorably by the incoming Administration of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter.

title: South Rises, Crushes North In Toms River
description: Don Smith ran for three touchdowns and Don Hampton for two as unbeaten, oncetied Toms River South rolled to a 420 victory over Toms River North yesterday and won a place in the South Jersey Group 4 playoffs.

title: Brown, Yale Share Ivy Title
description: Brown and Yale finished in a tie for the Ivy League football championship by winning yesterday. Brown rallied in the fourth quarter and beat Columbia, 2817, at Baker Field. Yale defeated Harvard, 217, at Cambridge, Mass. Details in Section 5.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT DETROIT

title: Door Closers Save Heat and Prevent Slamming
description: Although pneumatic and hydraulic door closers have long been popular for use on storm and screen doors to prevent annoying slamming and bangingand to eliminate the need for continually reminding youngsters to close that door!  energyconscious homeowners often forget that they can be important moneysavers well.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Hey, you missed one. You missed it, that is to say, unless you are a Phoenix Theater subscriber and sufficiently loyal to have followed the organization uptown this year to its new, handsome, comfortable, probably temporary home at the Marymount Manhattan Theater on East 71st Street. (I say probably temporary because the Phoenix has always been probably temporary, possessed by wanderlust, shifting its headquarters along with its tactics as necessity and convenience have seemed to dictate; it hasalso proved as durable as that bird it took for guardian angel.)

title: New Acidophilus Milk Is Not Sour
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 16 (AP)It might not taste, smell or look different, but the milk many New Jerseyans are drinking contains a bonus culture of lactobacillus acidophilus.

title: Headliners
description: The case of Gary Mark Gilmore, a convicted murderer who was sentenced to death in Utah and has vigorously lobbied for his own swift execution by firing squad, went through several phases last week. First the Utah Supreme Court indefinitely postponed the execution until the legal issues can be resolved. But Mr. Gilmore discharged his attorneys and hired a new one, who withdrew an appeal of the case. The court then ruled that the execution take place tomorrow. Then Governor Calvin L. Rampton of Utah postponed the execution once again, until the Utah Board of Pardons rules on the case next week. Mr. Gilmore claims the delay of execution constitutes cruel, unusual, and inhuman treatment, but attorneys for other Utah defendants who have. appealed death sentences are concerned that if the execution proceeds without final review by the Utah Supreme Court, thus setting a credible legal precedent for the Utah death penalty, it may be difficult to overturn it in the future.

title: InjuryRiddled Knicks Turn Back Bucks, 11097
description: With almost. $1 million in salaried talent injured, including three starters, Walt Frazier and the Iowerpaid Knicks defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 11097, last night before a crowd of 14,298 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Midnight Baby
description: At the start of the 1970's the composerlyricist Dory Previn began creating a special place for herself in the world of popular music. Her melodic songs with their terrifying lyrics (you were doin it alone, you were screamin in your car in a 20 mile zone) charted her own emotional landscape: poverty, Catholicism, 16 years of analysis and several mental breakdowns including a highly publicized one that occurred when her husband, conductor Andre Previn, left her for Mia Fanow. Shortly afterward she found herself screaming uncontrollably aboard Pan Am transcontinental jet.

title: Pay in Gold Sovereigns Skirts Tax
description: CROYDON, England, Nov. 13 (UPI)The seven employees of the St. James printing company are technically among Britain's lowestpaid workers. But they could hardly be happier with their lot.

title: Hearings This Week Set by Council Panels
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council commitees this week:

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Guest, Rabbi Judah Cahn, Metropolitan Synagogue.

title: Ernest Hemingway and the Tough Dodger
description: Ernest Hemingway was a dominant man. He dominated just about everything and everybody he encounteretd. He dominated American literature to the extent many critics rate him our leading writer, although, I'm a William Faulkner man myself.

title: Spurs 113, Blazers 101
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 13 (AP) George Gervin scored 32 points to lead six San Antonio players in double figures, and the Spurs defeated the Portland Trail Blazers, 113101, tonight.

title: MANDEL PROSECUTOR NEARING END OF CASE
description: BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 13The prosecution is expected to rest its case Monday or Tuesday in the political corruption trial of Goy. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and four of his friends and business associates, bringing near the first testimony by the star witness, Mr. Mandel himself.

title: New Realism on View At the Morris Museum
description: MORRISTOWN IT is occasionally refreshing to see an exhibition where no overriding theme is the raison d'tre for the display. This is the case of the show at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences. It is an assemblage of paintings in which no school of artists is highlighted and no particular styles are stressed, although the majority of pictures on view adhere to the new realist preferences.

title: Nyack Wraps Up Crown on Shutout
description: Nyack captured its first county championship since 1969 by whipping Tappan Zee, 140, yesterday. Suffern, the defending champion, finished second in the standing despite a 1613 victory over North Rockland.

title: A Slaver's Log Book
description: Historians of the African slave trade have long puzzled over a book called Captain Canot; or, Twenty Years of an African Slaver (1854), which, according to its title page, was written out and edited from the Captain's journals, memoranda and conversations by a Baltimore newspaperman, Brantz Mayer. Though Mayer's book bore obvious internal evidence of authenticity, it was suspect because the extensive records of the international slave trade nowhere record the name of a Captain Canot, who boasted that he was the Machiavelli of Africa. Besides, these presumed reminiscences were written in a florid style more characteristic of a Baltimore journalist than of an uneducated sailor.

title: Article 15  No Title
description: The forgotten woman offender See Page 24

title: Sister Irene's TV Network
description: Sister Irene Fugazy touches a spent vacuum tube. It cost $900 to replace, she says. I keep it on my desk to pray for the good health of all the others.

title: Three Sites Still Being Weighed For a Solar Electric Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)Nine proposed sites for an experimental solar electric plant have been narrowed to three finalists, the Energy Research and Development Administration says.

title: Parents of 1,600 Children Who Are in Foster Homes Reportedly Still Get Aid
description: The parents of about 1,600 children who have been placed in foster homes are illegally receiving a total of $2 million in welfare payments every year for their care, Harrison J. Goldin, New York City's Comptroller, chareed yesterday.

title: Farmingdale, Berner Use Shutouts to Clinch
