description: Farmingdale and Berner registered decisive victories yesterday to wrap up the county's Conference I and II championships, respectively. Farmingdale scored in every period to overwhelm Syosset, 290, and Berner took advantage of Bellmore Kennedy's sluggish offense to nost a 160 decision.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We were keenly disappointed in Roger Starr's remarks on New York's housing crisis [Refusal to Face Facts a Peril to City, Oct. 3] Mr. Starr could have used this forum to outline the real nutsandbolts problems that must be tackled if the city's housing stock is to survive and expand. Instead, he chose to limit his remarks to a defensive explanation of his unfortunate planned shrinkage statement.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Nazca, you will first fly to Lima, Peru. Aero Peru, the airline with which you will likely do most of your flying, has daily flights to Lima from Miami (New YorkLima seryice is tentatively scheduled for early next year). Braniff International flies New YorkMiamiLima six times weekly with a minimum of two stops between Miami and Lima.

title: A Course to Lift the Spirits
description: AT CORNELL there is a bit of Bacchus in many a baccalaureate. Two credits' worth, in fact, thanks to a course that could leave many a student high above Cayuga's waters.

title: Lebanon's Last Chance?
description: About 6,000 Syrian soldiers armed with heavy artillery and tanks have surrounded Beirut in apparent preparation for an advance into the city's center in order to finally impose the peace that Christians, Moslems and Palestinians have been unable to achieve themselves.

title: When Falling Leaves Drift By
description: THE foliage season this year they say has been finer on the Island than anywhere else around, including Vermont, which has held the franchise on this sort of thing for many years. As with any major spectacle, the last word on it comes from the people who have to clean up after it.

title: Four Employees of U.S. Company Believed Dead in Irish Air Crash
description: SHANNON, Ireland, Nov. 13 (AP)A light plane crashed and burned on the runway at Shannon Airport, killing four employees of the Americanowned company Digital Equipment International and their pilot, airport sources said today.

title: West Essex,80, Gains Playoffs; Bradley Stars
description: Unbeaten West Essex survived its biggest test of the season so far when it rolled over a strong Morristown team, 217, in Morristown yesterday and gained the playoffs in North Jersey's Section 2. Group 3.

title: WOMEN MINISTERS BACKED BY NEW LUTHERAN SYNOD
description: Delegates to the inaugural assembly of the new East Coast Synod of the Association of Evangelical Lutheran Churches appeared yesterday to be overwhelmingly in favor of ordaining women to the ministry.

title: Miss MacMillan Fiancee of E. N. McMillan 3d
description: Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Allen MacMillan Jr. of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lalande MacMillan, to Edward Neil McMillan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McMillan Jr. of Wenham. Mass.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: DEMOCRATS PONDERING A TAX CUT are trying to decide whether a oneshot or permanent cut would benefit the economy most, and whether a cut should be confined to Federal income tax or extended to social security payments... Meanwhile, Federal Reserve chairman Arthur E. Burns told a Senate Banking Committee that all such measures are inflationary and warned against them... The nation's money supply [currency and demand deposits] totaled $310.6 billion in the latest week, up $200 million over the level of the week before.

title: State Feeling Pinch Of Crowded Jails
description: TRENTON OVERCROWDED prisons and jails and a backlog of untried criminal cases in the courts are forcing New Jersey into selective prosecution of criminals. It has not yet begun, but Attorney General William F. Hyland said last week that it was almost upon the state.

title: Buggy Riders To the Sea
description: FISHERMEN reputedly spend half their lives fishing and the other half dreaming up ways to catch fish. For some surf fishermen, probably the most recurrent dream is of the day they will drive their first beach buggy onto the sand.

title: Robert A. Uihlein, Chairman of Schlitz, Is Dead at 60
description: Robert A. Uihlein Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company and a member of one of the country's most prominent brewing and banking families, died Friday night at Milwaukee County Medical Complex, which he entered on Oct. 21 for treatment of leukemia. He was 60 years old.

title: The World
description: The critical question facing southern Africans all along has been whether the transfer of power to the area's black majority will be accomplished through diplomacy or war. Events last weeka continued stalemate at the Geneva talks on Rhodesia and new fighting in Angola reportedly drawing in guerrillas from neighboring SouthWest Africaappeared to shift the momentum in the direction of a widening racial conflict.

title: LINGUISTS LOOK FORWARD TO CARTER AS PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Linguists say that Jimmy Carter would be making a big mistake if he were to try to mute his Southern accent when he becomes President.

title: Willowbrook Parents Accuse 3 State Aids Of Contempt of Court
description: Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb, the New York State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene. and two other state officials have been accused of civil contempt for their failure to carry out a court order to improve living conditions for the mentally retarded at the Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island.

title: Kids in the Kitchen
description: By the time each of my daughters was 4, she could read The San Francisco Chronicle and make a perfect omelet. Simple skills, elegantly executed. However, despite their casual but continuing interest in the culinary arts, both have rou tinely turned up their little noses at children's cookbooks, tossing them aside in favor of Nancy Drew, Babar, or Spiderman.

title: Roosevelt
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% stare tax

title: Betty Ford, Nominee
description: The nominations from the floor included Betty Ford and Rosalynn Carter. No, it wasn't a rerun of the Presidential race. In fact, it had little, if anything to do with politics.

title: Cross Country
description: N.Y. STATE SECTIONALS

title: Violins And Shovels
description: A short time ago in San Francisco, a friend took me to see the old beach chalet built by the city. These days, it is leased by the Veterans of Foreign Wars as a bar. We didn't go to get loaded; we went to see the W.P.A. murals painted on its walls in the mid1930's by Lucien Labaudt. The murals are very much of the time. They betray a heavily Mexican influence (Siqueiros, Orozco and Rivera were in the United States at the time) and the men are blocky, the women lumpy and the murals all contain little murky clots of social comment. Very much of their time, indeed.

title: Rhodesians Seeking Malawians Instead of Local Blacks to Work in Guerrilla Area
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 13This week The Rhodesia Herald, the country's major newspaper, carried the following display advertisement:

title: Key Witness in Carter Trial Gives Testimony That Apparently Conflicts With What She Said in 1967
description: PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 13A key prosecution witness in the second murder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis today gave the court seemingly conflicting testimony when she described the getaway car she saw at the scene 10 years ago.

title: Vietnam Statement on U.S. Talks Seen as Sign of Future Progress
description: PARIS, Nov. 13Although the State Department said that during the talks with Vietnam here yesterday there was no progress on the issue of Americans missing in action, French diplomatic sources took the communiqu issued late last night by the Vietnamese delegation as an encouraging sign that serious negotiations could begin once there is a new administration in Washington.

title: Once Upon A Time and Ever After
description: Whatever may be the fate of the novel or other fictions these days, the fairy tale flourishes. It is obviously immortal, having survived centuries of storytelling to remain the same classic tale of Puss in Boots or Cinderella told in many versions, no two exactly alike yet always familiar. The Wonder of our heritage is that every child comes to know these stories. They seem to improve by endless repetition.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Norm Snead, Giants backup quarterback, considers the team's spirit remarkable in view of its alllosing record: This team is unique. Not very good, but unique.

title: Auxiliary Police Force Called On To Help Stem Assaults on Elderly
description: The New York City Police Department has called on the 5,000member auxiliary police force to aid in the effort to stem the rash of assaults upon and robberies of the elderly.

title: In the Slammer, It's Still a Man's World
description: EVEN though the crime rates for women have increased dramatically, the woman offender has been forgotten in the midst of the public's greater demand to combat male criminality. Nowhere is this oversight more dramatic and more dangerous to the public welfare than in our correctional system.

title: Midwest
description: Indiana 15, Wisconsin 14

title: The High Cost of Health
description: RECENT pleas by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York for a rate increasethe sixth since 1971have served as an unpleasant reminder that hospitalization costs have soared dramatically in the last decade.

title: The ABC's Of Learning From K to 8
description: Reading is a complex task, not always as easy to measure as the simplified figures produced in reading tests would indicate. It involves looking at a printed page and being able not only to know the sounds of the letters, but also to derive meaning from the words, sentences and ideas they convey.

title: Transport: Suggested Cures
description: PRIVATE consultants hired by the state are offering some detailed answers to that soggy question: What does it take to pull New Jersey's public transportation up and out of the mire of deepening deficits? Key recommendations made by the consultants for the state's Department of Transportation are these:

title: Islanders Rally to Defeat North Stars On Trottier's ThirdPeriod Goal, 3 to 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 13The Islanders escaped from Metropolitan Stadium tonight with a 32 victory over the Minnesota North Stars that would have surprised even Nick the Greek.

title: From the Middle
description: DAYTON, Ohio  I am 35. White. Middleclass. A suburbanite. I own two cars and onefourth of a ranch house. The bank owns the rest.

title: Army Is Hoping for a Severe Winter on the Upper Great Lakes So FoulWeather Navigation Can Be Tested
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Nov. 13Navigation will be maintained on the upper Great Lakes this winter for as long as the Sauk Locks here can be kept open, According to Brig. Gen. Robert Moore of the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: This is a season of French opera, and two of than are coming up this week, both for the first time in New York. Le Roi Malgr Lui by Emmanuel Chabriet will be presented by the Juilliard American Opera Center on Thursday, to be followed the next evening by Joan Sutherland and her cohorts in Esclarmonde by Jules Massenet. Chances are that the Massenet will be complete ly unknown to most listeners at the Metropolitan Opera, though ?? will be a few who heard the opera with Sutherland in San Francisco. At least one section of Le Roi will be familiar, for Balanchine (who is choreographing the work for the Juilliard) used the long Fte Polonaise in his popular ballet, Bourre fantasque.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Knicks are the only local pro basketball team at home this week, playing in Madison Square Garden against the Atlanta Hawks at 7:30 P.M. Tuesday and the Denver Nuggets at 8 P.M. Saturday.

title: Foreign Policy Group Picks Editor
description: The appointment of Wallace Irwin Jr. as editor of the Foreign Policy Association has been announced by Carter L. Burgess, the association's chairman. Mr. Irwin has spent 14 years in government, serving as principal writer at the United States Mission to the United Nations and in other assignments. He replaces Dr. Norman Jacobs, who was editorinchief of the Foreign Policy Association since 1962 and who is retiring from the association and moving to Paris to concentrate on his own ?? and ??sear.

title: School Official Orders Students To Disrobe in Search for a Key
description: MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Nov. 13 (AP)Clinton Township School officials say they do not plan to discipline an administrator who ordered a class of eighth graders to disrobe in a search for a missing key.

title: STAMPS
description: The 28th annual National Postage Stamp Show, a high point of each fall's philatelic season, and one of the largest exhibits in the Western Hemisphere, takes place the end of this week, Friday through Sunday, Nov. 1921, in the Exposition Rotunda of Madison Square Garden. The show, which is sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers Asso ciation, is the final event of National Stamp Collecting Week. A new 7.7cent bulk rate postage stamp in coil form that is being issued by the United States on Nov. 20 in New York City will make its debut at the show.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Colorado to ski tour, remember that snow conditions are best from New Year's to midMarch. For satety, go in a party of at least three and try to spend a few relaxed days getting acclimatized to the altitude before tackling the more strenuous trails.

title: Article 13  No Title
description: ANGERS, FranceIt didn't hurt my learning experience at the Centre Internationale d'Etudes Francaises to have a teacher named Philippe Boivin whose father was a local vintner. Nor did looking out study hall windows and seeing the spires of a 13thcentury cathedral.

title: Meryl Feinstein Betrothed
description: The engagement of Meryl Robin Feinstein to David Wayne Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs, Irving Schwartz of Whitestone, Queens, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Max Feinstein of Bayside, Queens. The couple are students at Adelphi University.

title: A Shortstop With Style(s)
description: Now that the off season's here, Bud Harrelson of the Mets is putting in some time making personal appearances, like the one that brought him from his East Northport home to model some new clothes at a fashion breakfast at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan not long ago. The Mets' shortstop and his wife, Kim, who helped provide photos from an envelope for a steady stream of autograph seekers, share their home with a couple of catsCaspurr and Patches. Coming up next month is a trip out to the Coast to spend some time with Bud's family. Then it's off to Florida in January to get ready for next season.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Saturday. Nov. 13. 18th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: PUBLIC TV BOARD VOTES CONTRIBUTION TO THE BBC
description: Despite objections from organized labor, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's board of directors has voted to contribute $1.2 million toward the British Broadcasting Corporation's sixyear production of all 36 Shakespearean dramas for television.

title: Children's Books Fall 1976
description: In this issue, on Pages 23 through 58, is a special section devoted to children's books, with essays and reviews by John Updike, Alison Lurie, Helen Bevington, John Leonard and others. Also included are the 25th annual awards for the best illustrated books of the year and a selected list of outstanding children's books of 1976.

title: Melanie's Back And She's Not Kissing Cows
description: She still looks the samethat friendly roundish face framed in bangs and long, dark hair, the body swaddled in an embroidered, Slavicpeasant long dress. She can't really be said to have retired. Yet Melanie's new album, Photograph, and her current performancesshe did a run at the Bottom Line last weekend, but she isn't really on tour yetmost definitely constitute a comeback.

title: Churches Found Still Largely Segregated
description: The congregation of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's church in Plains, Ga., is expected to reconsider today its explicit ban on black members, a policy that was once widespread among white churches but that has largely gone the way of the segregated lunch counter.

title: Anniversaries
description: Schmukler

title: Naftali the Storyteller and His Horse, Sus
description: Yes, individual creatures die, but this doesn't end the story of the world. . . . One endless and wondrous story that only God knows in its entirety.

title: Bruins Rally to Top Columbia Here
description: Brown's determined football team, at first stymied by its own mistakes, rebounded just in time yesterday to reap the rewards of the school's most successful season in 27 years. The Bruins thus gained their first Ivy League championship, though they have to share it, and enjoyed beer instead of soda in the postgame celebration.

title: Point of View
description: This is a plan for an intensive campaign to revitalize our cities. Its primary thrust is to make urban middle class housing affordable.

title: Nuggets 128, Kings 96
description: DENVER, Colo., Nov. 13 (AP)Paul Silas passed the 10,000point mark in career scoring and picked off 14 rebounds as the Denver Nuggets crushed Kansas City, 12896, tonight.

title: 3 SYRIAN BRIGADES POISE FOR ADVANCE INTO BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 13 (AP)Three more Syrian armored brigades moved into position today for the final phase of a plan to halt fighting in Beirut after 19 months of civil war.

title: Monroe Enjoys Football Success After 20 Years
description: Monroe had gone through hundreds of players and numerous coaches in the last 20 years, looking for a successful football season. The Eagles found the right people this season, Coach Jerry Horowitz's first. With Ed Brown scoring three touchdowns yesterday, Monroe defeated Midwood, 288, to complete its first winning season in 20 years.

title: Outstanding Books of the Year
description: AMISH PEOPLE. By Carolyn Meyer. Illustrated. (Atheneum/ McElderry. $5.95.) An excellent introduction to the Amish in which the author sympathetically describes the life, words and often curious and misunderstood customs of these Pennyslvania people.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: The symptoms were headaches, nausea, stomach pains, some difficulty in breathing anal sensations of being intoxicated, and after 100 workers at the Essex International electronics assembly plant in Kittanning, Pa., were afflicted, the company furloughed 300 employees last Oct. 7 and closed.

title: A plea for a mundane mollusk
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio. There are surely better ways to spend an afternoon than sloshing through Big Darby Creek searching for the northern riffle shell. Another wildlife enthusiast, for example, might choose to while it away looking for Attwater's prairie chicken, the unarmored threespine sticklehack, the pigfooted bandicoot or even the Santa Cruz longtoed salamander. All these creatures share something in common besides their ungainly names: They are among the 250,000 species of animals and plants whose very existence is endangered by man's encroachment upon their habitats, and are thus candidates for protection by the United States Government.

title: Monmouth Racing
description: OCEANPORT N.J. By The Associated Press

title: 2 Jersey Businessmen Receive 8 Years and Fine in Tax Fraud
description: NEWARK, Nov. 12 (AP)Two businessmen convicted in a $2.3 million tax fraud scheme have been sentenced to eight years in prison and fined more than $130,000 each in what authorities said was one of the largest tax fraud prosecutions in New Jersey.

title: Black Education: How Good?
description: IN THIS AGE of declining College Board scores and wholesale cutbacks in school spending, concerns about quality have come to dominate education In this country at all levels. For blacks, such concerns are being raised in especially dramatic ways.

title: Letters
description: Befouled bass

title: Irish Eyes Are Smiling When Macken Rides
description: It has been almost two decades since Ireland has produced a rider capable of winning with any degree of consistency on the North American indoor horse show circuit. But when Eddie Macken arrived this year for his. first appearance outside Europe, he changed the complexion of the circuit. Macken, who is 27 years old, finished as coindividual champion of the Washington International show in Landover, Md., and won the title outright at the National Horse Show, which wound up a sixday run in Madison Square Garden last Sunday.

title: Notes from the Oil Capital
description: HOUSTONThe toast over drinks at Houston's Petroleum Club is, Health and hydrocarbons. The firsttime visitor is indulged with the explanation that hydrocarbon is the chemical term for the petroleum industry and its products. As for health, well, that seems synonymous with Houston, selfproclaimed oil capital of the world.

title: Barrie Ann Trieger And S. Simon Jacob To Wed on Dec. 26
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman Trieger of Larchmont, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barrie Ann Trieger. to S. Simon Jacob, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Jacob of Cedar Grove, N.J. The couple plan to be married Dec. 26.

title: Memorial Services
description: HETHERINGTONJames Cameron. Memorial services Tuesday, Nov. 16, 1976, 7:30 P.M., Christ Church Methodist Church, 520 park Ave. ?? 60th St., N. Y. C.

title: Motorola Minus TV
description: CHICAGOTwo years ago last May, Motorola Inc. sold its enormous television set manufacturing business to a Japanese corporationand all but vanished from public view. Out of sight, perhaps, but into bigger business

title: Fly by Night
description: In the few years before his sudden death in 1965, the poet and critic Randall Jarrell devoted surprisingly much of his energy to the creation of children's books. Translations from the German of the Brothers Grimm were followed by The Gingerbread Rabbit and The BatPoet in 1964 and the NewberyHonorwinning The Animal Family in 1965. Nov, after a delay longer than its 30 spacy pages would seem to require, the final and slimmest entry in the Jarrell juvenile canon arrives, entitled Fly by Night. It is illustrated, as were the previous two, by Maurice Sendak; the illustrations are intense and loving and uneasymaking, in tune with the prose they illumine.

title: Ah, Not to Be Sixteen Again
description: No one I know would care to be 16 again, or would have the stamina to reexperience those awesome, awful years of our adolescence. Surrounded by a world almost irreparably stripped of any pretense of virtue, teenagers must still struggle to gain some sense of self and of their futureand the good news is that it can be done.

title: Future Events
description: Nov. 17Special awards will go to Sarah Caldwell, the director and conductor, for distinguished achievement in music and to Texaco, sponsor for 37 years of the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, for distinguished service to music at the Third Street Music School Settlement's 82d Anniversary Luncheon at the Pierre. Last year's event in honor of Burt Bacharach and the F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company netted $23,000 for the school, where students are mostly in the 818 age group. Tickets $25.

title: Saul Bellow Taking Laureateship Lightly
description: When he was going to college during the Depression, Saul Bellow was advised by the chairman of an English Department that it would not be wise for him to become a graduate student in English Literature. It was not a question of talent, but, rather, that the antiSemitism that existed in the higher faculty realms of academe could hold back a career.

title: Influence Peddling, a Global Industry
description: WASHINGTONThe time was the spring of 1970. The Nixon Administration had shocked the South Koreans, allies by treaty and by troops fighting alongside Americans in Vietnam, by informing Seoul that 20,000 of the 64,000 American soldiers posted in Korea would be withdrawn the following year. The Koreans feared the American commitment to their defense had begun to crumble.

title: I The Case of Dave Cowens
description: In the arenas of the National Basketball Association, he was always differenta redheaded center who performed in the bonfire of hyperactive intensity. Off the court, Dave Cowens was even more different. Despite a $250,000 salary, he drove a yellow Jeep van instead of RollsRoyce, he wore plaid shirts and corduroy pants rather than customtailored clothes, he lived in a suburban flat above a toy store rather than in a fancy pad. Now he's more different than ever. He talks of feeling guilty about not earning his salary, a phenomenon among today's highpriced athletes. He's off the payroll on a leave of absence from the Boston Celtics that may last a few days, a few weeks, a few months or possibly until next season.

title: Southwest
description: Oklahoma 27, Missouri 20

title: Article 12  No Title
A World Full of Strangers
description: This first novel has sold over a million copies in paperback. Its author is described as the wife of a prominent San Francisco physician who, five years ago and in her mid50's, decided to stop being an interior decorator and start being a writer. Her real name is Bea Feinberg and a short note at the back of the book tells me that she has written two other novels which will be published in the near future.

title: A Commitment to Culture
description: DRING a recent fortnight, Long Islanders with healthy appetites for culture and a tankful of gas could have caught Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops in Uniondale; heard Eugene Istomin and the Long Island Symphony play Beethoven's Emperor Concerto in Southampton, Huntington and Hempstead; hummed along with Die Fledermaus in English in Commack or Der Rosenkavalier in German in Hauppauge; laughted at Nol Coward's Blithe Spirit in Kings Park or Oliver Goldsmith's She Stoops to Conquer in East Farmingdale; seen What the Community Collects in 20thcentury American prints and drawings in Lawrence; kept time to the Long Island Jazz Quintet in Sea Cliff, or attended a cinematic lecture on the sculptors de Creeft, Naguchi and Calder in Roslyn.

title: When Blacks Run the Schools
description: EUTAW, Ala.The Greene County school buses, leaving trails of yellow dust on the back country roads, gather the poor black children from their seethrough clapboard shacks and carry them daily to some of the most modern, innovative and expensive education in this state.

title: Is Mondale's Work Over or Just Beginning?
description: WASHINGTONI am Vice President, observed John Adams, the first American who could make that statement. In this, I am nothing. But I may be everything. Later, after some onthejob experience, he revised his views, calling the post the most insignificant office that ever the invention of man contrived or his imagination conceived.

title: Catholic Laity Group Acts to Take Sexuality Out of the Confessional
description: We, the people, are the church, says Joan Harriman, president of Catholic Alternatives. We intend to remove the entire area of sexuality out of the confessional.

title: Court Seals Data From Interpreter For Croatians in Hijacking Case
description: A tape recording given to New York City detectives by an interpreter accused of serving as a police informant in the hijacking case involving Croatian nationalists was sealed by a judge last week on the ground that revelations of its contents could bring harm to the interpreter.

title: Superhighway System, in 20 Years, Has Tied a Vast Nation Together
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 13No bands will play. No birthday parties are planned. Few people hereabouts are even aware of the occasionnot even here in the wide open spaces, where superhighways are not only an inseparable part of the free life but almost an article of faith.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The slowing pace of newcar sales proved a damper for the stock market last week as the Dow Jones industrial average retreated 15.38 points to close at 927.69.

title: After Moonrise, I Always Get This Yen for a Pickle
description: Maybe its an upturn in irresistible cravings in the middle of the night, or the desire to beat crowds, or that more people are living alone and they only have to shop for one. Whatever the reason, convenience stores, those openearly, openlate, mini supermarkets like 7Eleven. Shoo 'n Go and Cumberland Farmshave practically become a ne cessity of life for many people.

title: Public Advocate, The People's Defender
description: CALIFORNIA tried one. Wisconsin wants one. New Jersey has one. The agency provides lawyers for the people and protects the legal rights of prisoners and mental patients. It is an official gadfly and ombudsman, and it brings lawsuits against governmental bodies. And it is paid by the very state that it regularly does battle with.

title: Halftime at Canton
description: CANTON  What a difference a month can make. Before the Oct. 15 opening of China's 40th semiannual Export Commodities Fair here, gloomy predictions abounded.

title: The Letters of Virginia Woolf
description: Life would split asunder without letters, Virginia Woolf wrote in Jacob's Room, the high point in this period of her working life. During itbetween 1912 and 1922she wrote 600 of those saving letters. They are published now as Volume II in the projected six being edited by Nigel Nicolson and Joanne Trautmann.

title: Wrong Response
description: Publication by the Federal Government of the names of 2,500 doctors, dentists, laboratories and pharmacies as recipients last year of more than $100,000 each Medicaid payments constitutes no slur against the medical profession. It merely suggests that there have been some practitioners who treated the Federalstate health program for the poor as a means of getting rich.

title: 1,600 Acres of Education
description: AMONTHLONG renovation of summer cottage on an old estate, the hiring of an enthusiastic and competent program director and the availability of several parttime naturalists were apparently all that was needed to open Caumsett Outdoor Environment Center, a new educational facility in Lloyd Harbor on the North Shore.

title: $8 Million in Medicaid Restitutions By Doctors in New York City Seen
description: New York City officials, citing the findings of a new computer audit, say they expect to recover at least $8 million from physicians who allegedly overbilled Medicaid during the last two years.

title: NORTH HILLS SCORED ON ZONING PROPOSAL
description: NORTH HILLS, L.I., Nov. 13A plan by the trustees of this affluent village to change the zoning regulations and institute a master plan that would radically change the character of the community has met strong opposition.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The story of William M. Batten, chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange, could be summarized as A Tale of Two Reports.

title: Wagner, Siena, Army and Fairleigh Set Higher Basketball Goals
description: Among the Division I colleges seeking basketball prominence in the East this year are two newcomers and three oncestrong teams trying to make comebacks.

title: Medical Schools Fighting Pressure To Admit Americans From Abroad
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13A storm of protest is gathering at medical schools around the country M reaction to a new law under which certain Federal funds would be withheld from institutions that failed to accept as transfer students Americans who have studied abroad.

title: Miss Riccardi Plans to Wed
description: Count Roberto Riccardi, Italy's Ambassador to Luxembourg, and Countess Riccardi of Rome have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Riccardi, to Alexander Miller of New York, assistant treasurer of the J. Henry Shroeder Banking Corporation.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Mayor Kevin H. White, acknowledging that it was a blatant publicity stunt, went from door to door today distributing leaflets aimed at putting pressure on the state to come to the aid of his financially strapped city.

title: Pitt Overcomes Mistakes, Halts West Virginia, 2416
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13Pittsburgh found that being king of the hill is a percarious position but the undefeated and untied Panthers, ranked No. I in the nation, overcame their own mistakes and jitters and beat West Virginia, 2416 today, clearing the way for an allexpensespaid trip to the bowl of their choice.

title: Beirut's Peace Mood: Hide the Guns, Just in Case
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 13In the ruins of the downtown port area, the Mediterranean is visible in blue patches framed by smashed buildings and holes in walls. But along the major street running up the hill from the port, the gunmen are not looking at the sea and the shooting continues even though the end of the 19month civil war seems to be approaching.

title: Malverne Girls Prove Class of Meet
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 13The name Malverne High has become synonymous with basketball excellence in Nassau County. But after yesterday's outstanding performance in the Section Eight girls' track and field championships at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, the Mules' boys' basketball team may have to share equal time in the limelight.

title: Panel Finds Top Federal Salaries Too Low to Satisfy Capable Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Pay for the top 22,800 Federal officials has been so eroded by inflation that the Government is having trouble attracting and retaining the highly qualified people it needs, according to testimony before a Governent commission.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1976

title: Notes: The Ski Show, Lift Prices, Packages and Citizens' Races
description: Nothing warms the hearts of exhibitors at the annual Ski Show, which arrives in New York on Thursday, like a November blast of cold air. It's good for attendance. But whether or not snow is dusting the sidewalks around the Coliseum, the show personnel inside will be trying to generate excitement. The traveling fourday extravaganza leaves Boston tonight for Manhattan to complete its sixcity circuit.

title: Slicing the Food Dollar
description: Early last month, Elinor Guggenheimer, New York's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, announced that sugar prices here had dropped from $3.60 for a fivepound bag to $1.25, their lowest point in almost two years. Then, Mrs. Guggenheimer said she couldn't help but wonder why sugarrich foods had not shown a corresponding decline in price. She is not the only one asking that ticklish question especially in this, the cake and candy holiday season.

title: Colgate Loses First, 2913, At Hands of Army and Hall
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 13Army spoiled Coglate's bid for bigtime recognition today with a 2913 victory over the previously unbeaten Red Raiders.

title: Rae E. Brooks Engaged To Danielson Eastman
description: Rae Everitt Brooks and Danielson John Eastman, directors of IRMA, an information and referral service of the New York City Department of Social Services, plan to be married in April.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE back of the menu tells the history of this 19thcentury manor house and among other things, explains the beautiful woodwork in the various rooms. It provides the only clue that you are in Jamesport or even on the island.

title: The epidemic of money
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia. It is hellishly hot, midafternoon, in late September, near the end of Ramadan, the holy Moslem month of prayer, penitence and fasting. We stand on the docks of Jidda's port, on the eastern shore of the Red Sea. contemplating an extraordinary mixture of opulence and squalor. In the harbor, nearly 200 ships, many of them queued up for months, bearing a million tons of goods, are each of them waiting to discharge a cornucopia of food and merchandise. Brownskinned Yemenis, the kingdom's hewers of wood and drawers of water, are struggling to unload a consignment of cows from a Bulgarian vessel. The Yemenis are shorttempered, for they have fasted since dawn, but it is the cows who provoke pity. They are sickly skeletons who seem never to have been fed; the Yemenis hoist them in slingstwo, three, four cows togetherthen dump them atop each other upon the dock, where the cows wobble and wander, thirsty and dazed.

title: DEATH PENALTY IS RULED ILLEGAL IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (UPI)Pennsylvania's death penalty, passed in 1974 over the veto of Gov. Milton J. Shapp, has been ruled unconstitutional by a panel of three county judges.

title: Medal for Mrs. Weintraub
description: Mrs. Stanley H. Weintraub, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Gala Auction to be held on March 6, will be honored tomorrow at a luncheon in the Grand Tier Restaurant at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mrs. Weintraub will be the first woman to receive the gold medal of the Comit de l'Excellence Europene in recognition of her social and philanthropic activities. Cochairmen of the luncheon are Louise Fitting, Edith Levin and Beatrice Joyce.

title: GARDENING
description: THE Island abounds with a wide variety of rhododendrons, azaleas and other broadleaf and needleleaf evergreens, but the most desirable new kinds are not always available through the nurseries and garden centers. There is often but one solution if you wish to have these unusual plants: Find a source of stalks from a plant society or a friend and propagate your own.

title: A WellAdvertised StopSmoking Program Is Eliciting Complaints
description: About three months ago, a woman with a packaday smoking habit, heard a radio advertisement for a program that promised to make her stop smoking in five days. She went to see Dr. Brent Garber, the man advertised as the program's director.

title: Endpaper
description: KILMOGANNY, Ireland. For a number of years people in the publishing business on both sides of the Atlantic have warned me that the Guinness Book of World Records had become determined to record at least some of the various coups aux superlatifs which my wife and I have made it our policy to perform. The Guinness compendium of championship ratings verifies extremes in, on, and beyond the earth such as which are officially the largest, smallest, fastest, heaviest, longest, highest, slowest, oldest, fattest, most deadly or any other superlative of action, degree, relationship, description or tensility of anything, anywhere.

title: Monk Seal on Endangered List
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)  The Hawaiien monk seal, said to be in danger of becoming extinct, has been placed on the Government's endangered species list to give it added protection. A Federal study showed that the sea mammal was suffering a high mortality in pups, a low reproductive rate and harassment in its habitat. The seal breeds only on the islands of the Leeward chain.

title: Law Is Having Its Day in School
description: Virginia Schlotman's sixthgrade class at SS. John and Paul School in Larchmont, N. Y., was playing a new game, Pass the Eraser, one day recently, but the rules kept changing.

title: The 90,000 Ghosts Who Haunt The Schools
description: THE 15YEAROLD boy pointed to his signatureDune 1an artfully spraypainted nom de graffiti in bold, 4foot letters on the concrete wall of a school playground. Everybody knows my name, he said proudly. I painted it all over the city.

title: Article 2  No Title
Patchogue: A Downtown That Didn't Die
description: PATCHOGUE TERRY PARISI got out of the hospital the other day, looking good and feeling happy. It was a warm afternoon, and her feet wanted to take her someplace nice, someplace familiar, so she went downtown.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: UTAH CONVICT WANTS TO WED BEFORE DEATH
description: SALT LANE CITY, Nov. 13Gary Mark Gilmore, the convicted killer who had pleaded with the Utah authorities to es cute him, may attempt to be married on death row before his date with the firing squad.

title: She Brings Duncan's Artistry Back to Life
description: Iam not Isadora, Annabelle Gamson retorts. Costumed in the sort of flowing Greek tunic which Isadora Duncan made famous, sweating and panting after a runthrough of her reconstruction of Duncan's Five Waltzes, Miss Gamson adds emphatically, I simply dance her dances. I am not imitating Isadora or trying to evoke that flamboyant personality. She will be dancing her revivals of several Duncan dances, as well as her own choreography, in a solo program at Roundabout Stage One on Wednesday and next Saturday and Sunday as part of theDance Umbrella series.

title: Is Suffolk Soft on Porn, or Is Nassau Just Uptight?
description: AS a university professor concerned with the history and nature of the censorship of communications from antiquity to the present day, I have far more to do than worry about the legal curiosities that influence the kind of pornographic films shown to citizens of the three counties that run in a straight line from Lone Island City to Montauk Point.

title: Portable Paintings? Why Not?
description: Old handbags should never die, according to Susan Rostan. They should be framed and hung on a wall.

title: A Lebanese Executed in Saida For Murder and Theft of Auto
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Nov. 13 (AP)Palestinian and leftist authorities executed a young Lebanese In a public square here today and displayed his body tied to a monument for tour hours.

title: Yesterday's Results in Scholastic Sports
description: Locals

title: Elia Kazan: The Movie We Made Is Realistic Hollywood
description: The novel that we know as The Last Tycoon is a study of ambition and success. Monroe Stahr is a 19thcentury Horatio Alger figure, and, as such is an anachronism in 1936.Matthew J. Bruccoli in The Last of the Novelists: F. Scott Fitzgerald and the Tycoon.

title: Home $weet Home...
description: NEW PROVIDENCE WE recently celebrated our 10th anniversary as suburban homeowners. They have been 10 very happy years for us, years in which we have enjoyed the benefits of raising three children in a lovely suburban town with clean, safe streets, nice neighbors, a fine school system and recreational facilities for the whole family.

title: Miss Archer Is Engaged
description: Katherine Allyn Archer, a candidate for a master's degree in business administration at LoyolaMarymount University, Los Angeles, and Gary William Hampar, an assistant professor at the LoyolaMarymount Business School, plan to be married next June.

title: Sunday, Quiet Sunday
description: VICTORIAN architecture is Ocean Grove's strongest link to the 19th century. But Ocean Grove also enforces several antique ordinances that have come under attack recently. The Sunday ban on vehicular traffic is the most controversial.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The United States has two giant companiesNew York City Ballet and American Ballet Theaterwhich are in the top league of international classic dance. (In the moderndance category, America, of course, virtually exerts total dominance, although nowadays a few companies of importance are emerging in Europe.) Apart from these two major ballet companies, there is the Joffrey Ballet, smaller, but also a company with international importance, worth ranking with, say, the Stuttgart Ballet; and a number of other companies, at present slightly less wellestablished and less wellknown, yet also of major artistic importance. After the City Ballet, Ballet Theater and the Joffrey, perhaps the next two most important classic companies in the country are the Eliot Feld Ballet and the Pennsylvania Ballet. (In fairness Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem is rapidly developing, and there are some companies in the West, including Ballet West in Salt Lake City, the San Francisco Ballet and John Clifford's Los. Angeles group that I, with that peculiar East Coast provincialism, have not even seen.) Certainly the Joffrey, the Feld and the Pennsylvanians are fascinating young companies, and national treasures.

title: Is Integration Aiding Grades?
description: Do black children read better if they go to school with whites? Do they add and subtract better? Do they narrow the gap in achievement that has long separated them from white youngsters? What has been the tangible impact of a decade of often painful desegregation?

title: BRIDGE
description: The best way to present an international bridge match to an audience of several hundred enthusiasts has long been a subject for controversy. In 1958 the Italians produced the first Bridgerama, a complex electrical board on which each card is illuminated until it is played. The audience can therefore see at each stage which cards the players have left in their hands

description: JETS' STATISTICS

title: WILDLIFE GROUP TO FIGHT ALASKA WOLFKILLING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Alaska is going to have environmentalists as well as the wolves to deal with this winter if it carries out its plan to kill hundreds of wolves.

title: Grimes of North Shore Captures State Run And Fabrigas Helps Wagner Repeat in City
description: Tom Grimes of North Shore High won the Class A title as Long Island runners captured five of the 12 divisions yesterday in the state intersectional crosscountry championships at Bear Mountain State Park.

title: Integration Problems Now Vex European Schools
description: LONDONThe bashful Moslem girl in Britain's gray Northeast, the frail Algerian child on the doorstep of a residential hotel in Paris, the quartet of grinning Turkish boys shouting boldly to the TV camera, We are Berlinersthey are all children of a new generation who are forcing European educators to face for the first time some of the same debates on the education of ethnic and racial minorities that have preoccupied their American counterparts for more than two decades.

title: Time to Tuck in the Tenderest Plants Before Winter Arrives
description: Athough winter will not officially arrive until Dec. 21, the time has come to start putting the garden to bed. Last minute planting and cleanup should be finished soon.

title: Busiest People Ever
description: Busiest People Ever is a hymn to employment if ever there was one, with all these little workaholics of the animal kingdom going at their specialized tasks (hay baler, hay lifter, grass mower) with a nearly obsessed vengeance. People who aren't actually involved in gainful employment get called by the name of whatever they are incidentally doing at the timeBanana Eater, Lazy Fisherman, Sandwich Eater. It brings to mind an issue of Time magazine in which a rapist was called Rapist John Smith, as though it were a job you could get from a want ad.

title: Connecticut Judge Dies
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 11 (AP)Judge Yale Matzkin of Superior Court died today at St. Mary's Hospital. He was 67 years old. He collapsed in his Waterbury home late last night and was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital early today. Judge Matzkin was a lawyer for 28 years before being appointed a Circuit Court judge in 1961. He was elevated to the Superior Court bench late in 1974.

title: ARGENTINA STEPS UP WAR AGAINST LEFTISTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13Argentina's war against leftwing subversion has intensified with nearly 100 suspected guerrillas killed in the past two weeks. But political assassinations and bombings contributed to continued insecurity in many sectors.

title: CORNELL ADDS TO LIST OF BOGUS ART WORKS
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 13The director of the art museum at Cornell University confirmed this week that he had added three ??intings, an 18thcentury sculpture and several woodcut prints to a list of the university's works of art whose authenticity had been challenged.

title: Theismann Faces Giants Here Today
description: Ara Parseghian, the Notre Dame coach, assembled his freshman hopefuls. High school stars from Pennsylvania and Ohio wondered whether high school stars from Michigan and New Jersey would turn out to be better football players

title: Arrivals and Departures
description: The only time I ever laid eyes on him was at one of those White House conferences on something or other that the Johnson Administration was always throwing in the Shoreham Hotel. Into the big spiritless room came this fellow who did have something of a different air about him, partly because he was attended by a retinue. A small retinue, to be sure, but still clearly a retinue. There, the reporter sitting next to me said with husky awe, goes Richard Rovere of The New Yorker.

description: TodaySuburban Essex. Woodland Avenue, West Orange, N.J. All dressage, training level through Grand Prix. 8:30 A.M.

description: CAPE MAY COURTHOUSE, N.J. (UPI) A fourcounty radio network for relaying flood and tidal information has been set up in New Jersey.

title: Don't Just Blame the Schools
description: SEVERAL years ago, the National School Boards Association, in conjunction with the National Education Association, issued a joint statement: The schools dare not be less magnificent n scope and design than the society they are asked to sustain.

description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Edward Kantrowitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Faith Kantrowitz, to Matthew Gladstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Gladstein. Both families live in Teaneck, N. J.

title: The Alps: Majestic, Fearsome  but Not For Experts Only
description: A strange irony, to be feared for beauty and fame. Those who have never seen more than a postcard of the Alps use such terms as awesome, malestic towering, and the images combine to leave a lot of Americans afraid to ski them. For experts only, goes the myth, based on the simple illogic that to ski down from the foot of the Jungfrau in Switzerland is as difficult and treacherous as it is to climb up it. Not so.

title: U. C. L. A. Turns Back Oregon State, 45 to 14
description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 13 (AP)The University of California, Los Angeles, scared three touchdowns in the second quarter, two on runs by a backup halfback, James Owens, and rolled to a 4514 Pacific8 Conference football victory over Oregon State today.

title: Philadelphia to Fight For Convention Trade
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (AP) Civic officials here are mapping out sales strategy for convention business to make sure that casino gambling in Atlantic City does not take trade away from Philadelphia.

title: CUNY Cuts Bring Anger and Despair
description: Anthony Mujic is a junior at Hunter College, one of 19 units that make up the giant City University of New York. There are 60 students in his chemistry class and this year, when a question comes to mind in class, he has learned to stifle the impulse to raise his hand.

title: Picture Books
description: The season's picture books range from avantgarde to zany, from pithy to surreal, from cabbages to kings. Or from A to Z, which brings us to alphabet books. Interesting that two of the three here are in the form of a mystery tour. By the time you reach Z, you've solved the mystery. Stan Mack's THE KING'S CAT IS COMING (Pantheon, $2.95) asks, What kind of cat is the King's cat? The possibilities (Angry, Bashful, Curious, Dangerous) are pictured in a frenetic and funny cartoon style.

title: Cathie Axelrod Engaged To Dr Dean A. Schaffer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carlin S. Axelrod of Harrison, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathie Lynne Axelrod, to Dr. Dean Andrew Schaffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Schaffer of Scarsdale, N. Y. A wedding next May is planned.

title: DR. LESTER FOX
description: Dr. Lester Fox, a dermatologist in New York City for 28 years until he moved to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., four years ago, died Friday of a heart attack in a hospital in Miami Beach. He was 62 years old.

description: Susan Thorndike, a senior editor with Random House Inc., and Louis Basil Dotti Jr., general manager of New Times magazine, plan to be married in January. description: Psychoanalysis, which might have confirmed the necessity of conflict within society, has chosen rather to support the established order. Where women are concerned, the profound conservatism of psychoanalysis has left women a choice that Is no choice at all: between guilt and submission. Women's impulse to growth has been

title: Bureau of Indian Affairs To Expand Its Education Of Handicapped Children
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 13Encouraged by a newly demonstrated interest on the part of Alaskan native and American Indian parents in the education of their handicapped children, the Bureau of Indian Affairs has announced that it would provide funds for a vast increase in special education programs for youths with physical and mental disabilities.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: James J. Needham won't be going back to the boardroom of the New York Stock Exchangehe'll be hanging around in the waiting room of William M. Batten's office.

description: MADRID, Nov. 13Publicopinion polls and pollsters are entering their golden age in Spain.

title: The Unique And Necessary Presidency of Gerald Ford
description: WASHINGTON  The President's eyes were redrimmed, his lace hollowed by fatigue. He sat, in shirtsleeves, in the private cabin of Air Force One as the silver plane whispered through coalblack Southern skies toward the capital. He sipped from a white plastic tumbler and coughed, briefly convulsed. Gerald R. Ford's visitor, pretending not to notice how spent he was that night last May, was dimly aware of what Calvin Coolidge must have meant in saying, half a century earlier, I am only in the clutch of forces that are greater than I am.

title: Bible Stories You Can't Forget
description: Children's books are written for children. Adults' books are written for adults. There remains a shady noperson's land: chadult books, which are written for the adults who buy children's books. This is cute, says Aunt Martha, who has just had her fancy tickled and her purse pried open by Tommy the Tapir Takes a Trip or How Big Is Little? or Round Is My Head, Round Like a Breadall written not for the reader but for the buyer.

title: Abortion Foe Is Undaunted.
description: A TRADITIONAL woman had to do something untraditional, said Ellen McCormack as she looked back at not only an untraditional event but also an extraordinary oneher candidacy for the Presidential nomination earlier this year.

title: Schools With a Special Delivery
description: Correspondence schools have always begin treated as unwanted offspring by the educational establishment. The history of homestudy instruction is often an unpleasant one: dishonest school owners have sometimes plundered the field, exploiting the naive. Bogus colleges whose only campus is a post office box have frequently satdsfied the mania for degrees and diglomas with phony Ph.D.'s.

title: Puli and Maltese Win Big in Toronto
description: In a gardenlike setting, with multicolored mums and green shrubs, the little dogs had their way at the two biggest shows of the year in Canada last weekend. After a puli, the smallest of the herding breeds from Hungary,

title: Braves 118, Celtics 107
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 13 (AP)Two former Notre Dame stars, John Shumate and Adrian Dantley, teamed for 49 points tonight, powering the Buffalo Braves to a 118107 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: High design at a profit
description: HOUSTON. Architects and realestate developers often have had use, but rarely admiration, for each other. Architects like to think of themselves as concerned with innovation, esthetics and the sheer pleasure of the building art; developers, on the other hand, put up buildings to make moneya goal that seldom leaves room for those aspects of design that most interest the architects. By now, major developers like Tishman and Uris in New York have shied away from serious design for so long that they are accustomed to seeing designconscious architects as their inevitable antagonists. Instead of using architects noted for design quality, many developers hire large commercial firms which do little more than fit the maximum rentable space into a physical box.

title: Pringle's Loses Some Skirmishes
description: The Great Potato Chip War that broke out last year when Procter & Gamble opened its national marketing campaign for Pringle's in their tubeshaped red packages is still going strongand the big and highly regarded company has been taking some lumps.

title: News of Realty
description: In times of retrenchment, the first projects to be relinquished by most developers are usually the most distressed. But not always.

title: Sally Zanger and Daniel Nadis Plan a Wedding in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Zanger of Holyoke and Truro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally E. Zanger, to Daniel Nadis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Maxwell Nadis of Southfield, Mich.

title: The Long Tunnel
description: Writers are essentially office workers who tend to let their bias for welllighted, airy offices and a certain amount of freedom on the job color their interpretations of bluecollar work. It is particularly difficult to exclude that bias when writing about coal miners. How can anyone endure the darkness, the entrapment, the sheer violence of the job, you ask yourself, as you stand hunched over in a fourfoothigh mine shaft watching shadowy figures operate snarling machines, afraid to move lest you electrocute yourself or cause a roof fall.

title: The Standings
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

description: ALTHOUGH they are gradually declining in their intensity, the aftershocks from the election of Jimmy Carter are continuing to register on the charts of the financial markets and on the confidence seismographs of the business world.

title: Car Inspection Cost Rise
description: James Melton, the State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, has recommended that the cost of having automobiles inspected be increased by $2 a vehicle. The proposed increase, contained in a departmental budget recommendation submitted to Governor Carey, would raise the cost from the presnt $3 to $5. Service station operators had requested the increases, it was said, because of rising costs. The increase could go into effect without action by the State Legislature, according to a department spokesman, who said it could be implemented any time if the Governor approves the action.

title: ... and William Steig
description: In a watercolor a young pig sits on the ground. She wears a pink dress and matching bonnet. It is a day in the heart of spring and her face and posture are touched with delight as she declares, I love everything. The watercolor is from THE AMAZING BONE (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $7.95), William Steig's 11th book for children.

title: At 94, Princess Alice Pursues a Regally Active Life
description: LONDON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Princess Alice of Athlone holds the royal record for public engagementsshe has carried out more than 20,000but then she is a vigorous 94yearold and has been at it longer than anyone else in the House of Windsor.

title: G.O.P. Stronger In Bergen County
description: HACKENSACK AFTER three successive years of election defeats, political scandals and internal feuding, Bergen County Republicans have come out of Election Day, 1976, with strong indications that they can be expected to give the Democrats a tough battle for political dominance next year.

title: 76ers 114, Bullets 109
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 13 (AP)Julius Erving scored 10 of his 22 points in the last quarter tonight and led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 114109 victory over the Washington Bullets at the Capital Centre.

title: Pagliaro Gains 125 Yards to Pace Elis
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13It took the Yale team half the game to prove that it was better than Harvard today, but at the end the Elis had convinced everyone in the congealed crowd of 42,000 at Harvard Stadium. Yale won, 217, and thus shared the Ivy League championship with Brown, the only team to beat the Blue this season. That happened hack on Sept. 18 in the opening contest and Yale went on to win eight straight times.

title: One View Insists It Is First Class
description: Maybe the time is right: after all, if a Southerner can win the White House, why can't an Eastern college football team be the best?

title: There's More to Sloth Than Meets the Eye
description: Let's face it. We're up to our turtlenecks in animal books. So how does one decide which are the keepers? My modest proposalthat readers avoid authors of the following species: (1) The Giant Borer, who feeds only on facts and tells more than you want to know; (2) The Bird of Paradise, who chirps out books about wonder of animals and Mother Nature's way; and (3) The Mole, who never saw a real animal and exists on material he digests from other books. Here's a sampling of recent books, none of which were written by any of the above.

title: Study Finds High Commercial Tax Making New Investments Unlikely
description: New studies by the Center for Local Tax Research show that tax burdens on commercial property are heaviest in New York City and some New Jersey cities where fiscal problems are most acute.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE AUTUMN OF THE PATRIARCH, by Gabriel Garca Mrques. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. (Harper & Row, $10.) Surrealistic, Rabelaisian, profligate novel about a largerthanlife dictator of a South American country who stands for the eternal totalitarian figure.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Kids' books. The trouble with children's librarians, Atheneum's Suzanne Glazer once complained about the women who bought threefifths of her books, is that they want to pay $1.95 for a paperback copy, then rebind it at a cost of $3.50 so that it will keep for 400 years after their deaths. If they'd only buy a couple of hardbound copies for the shelves and a dozen paperbacks to circulate. The kids prefer paperbacks!

title: The Region
description: Charges of Medicaid abuse, which have already touched large numbers of physicians, nursing homes, socalled Medicaid mills and pharmacies, now have reached hospitals, both public and private, in New York State. The precise cost of the alleged hospital abuse, which centers on deceptive admissions and billing practices, has not been calculated, but millions of dollars are probably involved.

title: A Farm
description: With this new book of Carl Larsson's pictures, we travel beyond the precincts of his previous volume, A Home, to broader perspectives. In A Farm landscapes alternate with scenes of work and festival. As before, devotees of the print media will be irritated by the curious arrangement of large and small type on the same page and the repetitive nature of the text. But as before, the text (largely a description of Swedish rural life in the 1880's) is of minimal importance.

title: Ancient India: The Mighty Hindu Temples of the South
description: Worshipers crowd the ancient Hindu temple to Siva, God of Destruction, a deity well worth propitiating. The temple elephant rocks from foot to foot in his stall, wearing the sign of Siva on his forehead, three horizontal white stripes. Devotees stream through the courtyard bearing offeringslotus blossoms, jasmine, coconut and rice. A din rises from within the temple, where two drummers and a leatherlunged horn player sound the call to prayer.

title: Weddings
description: BillsGerner

title: The Noble Longfords: Born Writers, Too
description: LONDON, Nov. 10Francis Aungier Pakenham, the seventh Earl of Longford, is a slightly rumpled, outgoing author, social reformer and publisher who is known to virtually every newspaper reader in Britain as Lord Porn, after a lengthy investigation into pornography he led in the House of Lords in 1971. To his delight he is viewed here as a moral crusader, and something of an eccentric.

title: Chimera of State Supreme Court Dies in Crash
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Nov. 13 (UPI) Justice Thomas C. Chimera of the State Supreme Court died today in a onecar accident off the New England Thruway near here, the police reported.

title: DRIVE ON TO REVISE NEW CAMPAIGN LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13A major drive to revise the new Federal campaign law, liberalizing its financial restrictions and promoting more spontaneous local political activity, is already under way in Congress.

title: Rutgers Defense Falters But Tulane Loses, 2920.
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13 (AP)Rutgers' toprated defense awakened late in the game and Bert Kosup scored on a 1yard sneak as the Scarlet Knights beat Tulane, 2920, tonight and kept the nation's longest collegiate victory streak alive.

title: Paddy Chayef sky: TV Will Do Anything for A Rating. Anything!
description: I t all began one autumn night when Paddy Chayefsky was playing poker, six or seven or eight years agohe doesn't remember how many. He was losing he doesn't remember how much. After a while, he and another player, Howard Gottfried, went for a walk down Central Park Westhe doesn't remember how far. They talked about television. Chayefsky hadn't written for TV since the 1950's, but he still watched it a lot. He was still interested. Howard Gottfried had worked for a company that produced TV shows, including Gilligan's Island. Although a lot of people had been calling television a lot of unkind names for a long time, both men felt there was more to be said. Something satirical. Nothing definitive has been written about television, Howard Gottfried said, and the writer agreed somewhat enigmatically. It's a definitive industry, he declared.

title: Margaret Mack To Be the Bride Of David Key
description: The engagement of Margaret Robin Mack to David McKendree Key 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edkard E. Mack of Glencoe, Ill., parents Of the prospective bride. Her fianc is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Key Of Locust Valley, LI., and South Londonderry, Vt. The marriage will take place in January.

title: Article 5  No Title
Letters: Carillons That Truly Ring True
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observer
description: Here is a disagreeable letter from Mrs. T. L. of Flogmere, Pa. Dear Mr. BigShot KnowItAll, she begins, How come we gentle readers still have no explanation of your thundering mistake in forecasting the late unlamented election? I refer to your column of Nov. 2, 1975, in which you predictI have it right here in black and whitethat the Republicans would run Treasury Secretary William E. Simon for President and the Democrats would run Morris Udall, and that Udall would be elected. If this idiotic prediction had turned out to be right, I bet you would already have written six columns congratulating yourself on your wisdom. As things turned out, you now have a splendid pretext for confessing publicly to your stupidity. I daresay, however, that like most of your ilk, you will discreetly ignore the opportunity.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT PHOENIX

title: This Time They Acted
description: LONDONThat splendid architectural creation of Augustus Pugin, the chamber of the House of Lords, seems an unlikely setting for revolt. True enough, the debate is often spiritedI thank the noble Lord for his profoundly disappointing statement is a quite typical sally among membersbut the atmosphere of the second house, with its red leather benches, cathedral windows and bronze statuary, is one of stately and even sleepy contentment. It is also, it should be said, a legislative institution with exceedingly modest powers over the life of the nation.

title: A Case Study Of One Nuclear Deal: France And Pakistan
description: PARISThe ticklish case of the FrancoPakistani atomic deal, still to be resolved, reflects the intricate political rivalries that prevent any broad, effective international agreement to control nuclear proliferation. But the case also reflects a slow change in world opinion: the dangers of nuclear proliferation are beginning to worry the increasing number of countries in a position to supply the equipment and materials others could use surreptitiously to make bombs. The French agreement to sell a $1 billion reprocessing plant to Pakistan showed how atomic energy has become big business, and how commerce, domestic politics and foreign policy often conflict.

title: Lehigh Subdues C. W. Post With Rally in 2d Half, 1710
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 13Lehigh overcame a 100 halftime deficit today and defeated C.W. Post. 1710, before 7,000 fans at Taylor Stadium. The victory was Lehigh's sixth in 10 games, while Post closed its regular season with an 82 record.

title: Births
description: Bernzweig

title: Autumn Harvest Is Bountiful
description: CHATSWORTH FROM the flooded cranberry bogs in the Pine Barrens, where farmhands in hip boots wade the water to coax the red gold to the surface, to the goldentan sweet potato and yellow pumpkinsquash fields, the fall harvest in New Jersey is in full cry.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: The Grassroots Project: Steven R. Wright, Director, The Grassroots Project, Sterling, Craftsbury Common, Vt. 05827.

title: Home Before Dark
description: Reading a first novel is like meeting a strangerone has no idea what to expect. We come prepared to accept the mildest of diversions, though we long for much more. We want to be stirred, involved and enlightened.

title: Football
description: Connecticut

title: Trumbull Gains Its 9th Victory And 6th Shutout
description: Trumbull, the state's topranked team scored its ninth straight victory and sixth shutout yesterday, downing Ridgefield by 150.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT; Who Should Develop Solar Energy?; Many conservation groups are willing to let consumers pay unreasonable prices for solar energy ...
description: WASHINGTONWho shall control solar energy?

title: Yugoslav Court Upholds Challenge To System of Political Favoritism
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 13A Yugoslav constitutional court, ruling in favor of a worker denied an apartment for political reasons, has challenged the party patronage system under which special benefits are reserved for the most active Communists.

title: Senate Facing a Possible Fight by Senior Members Against the Proposed Realignment of Committees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13When the Senate convenes Jan. 4, it may he facing an immediate struggle over a proposal to make the most sweeping changes in the Senate committee structure in 30 years.

title: Six Killed in Georgia Collision
description: STATESBORO, Ga., Nov. 13 (AP)Six persons died early today in the fiery collision of two cars on U.S. Highway 301 near Statesboro, the Georgia State Patrol reported. It said that a car driven by Michael Tippers, 26, of Claxton, ran off the highway and, as it was coming back on the pavement, skidded broadside into another car, killing everyone in both vehicles.

title: Sue Ellen Bedrick Is Married To Samuel Hirschman on L.I.
description: Sue Ellen Bedrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon I. Bedrick of Woodsburgh, L.I., was married last night to Samuel E. Hirschman of Far Rockaway, Queens, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Seymour Hirschman of Lawrence. L.I.

title: Ward Sees Need for Czar To Steer Racing's Future
description: I'm afraid that if I were to speak out, I would have to be very critical of the direction that auto racing is going these days. said Rodger Ward, a twotime Indianapolis 500 champion. The sport is not reaching its fullest potential because there are too many people in co?? who are small and petty, and it just breaks my heart that an organization like USAC [United States Auto Club] isn't taking the lead and doing something about it.

title: Rams' Quarterback, Cards' Injuries Are Factors in Their Game Today
description: The important game in the National Football League today is in Los Angeles, matching the St. Louis Cardinals and the Rams. A defeat for either side will damage the drive to the postseason playoffs and both are in a precarious position as to personnel. The Rams are switching quarterbacks, Pat Haden for James Harris, and when a contending team does that in the 10th week of the season the move hardly reflects confidence.

title: MALAYSIA REPORTS RISE IN TRANSIT DRUG TRAFFIC
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 13 (Reuters)Drug trafficking through Malasia appears to be on the increase.

title: Truth in Advertising Takes on Colleges
description: Under pressure from students, parents, the courts and especially the Federal Government, colleges and universities are being forced to tell prospective applicants much more about themselvesincluding their shortcomingsthan ever before. There is at least a suspicion that some schools may not survive the telling.

title: Elizabeth Simonelli Wed
description: The marriage of Elizabeth M. Simonelli, widow of Peter M. Simonelli, to Robert O. Parker, took place yesterday in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. Msgr. Robert P. Bucciarelli performed the ceremony. Mr. Parker's first wife died.

title: Motor Vehicles Department Maps War on Dishonest Repairs
description: ALBANY (UPI)  The State Motor Vehicles Department says undercover investigations of repair shop operations will begin next month to weed out dishonest businesses.
