description: Incoming

title: Why a 46YearOld Father of 4 Plays College Football
description: I can still recall the look of horror on my wife's face when I told her I would be playing football at Fairleigh Dickinson University. Carrie thought I had gone crazy, that I had completely flipped my lid. She didn't speak to me for a week, that's how angry she was.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: AMONG THE ELEPHANTS, by Iain and Oria DouglasHamilton.(Bantam, $2.25.) An intimate, joyous report by a couple who spent four and onehalf years getting personally acquainted with more than 400 elephants in a Tanzanian national park.

title: College Football Scores
description: Navy 34, Georgia Tech 28

title: U.N. Delegates to Hear the Plans For SouthWest Africa Book Ship
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13A group setting out to sail a cargo of books 7,000 miles to SouthWest Africa has asked for a chance to describe its plans to United Nations delegates,

title: Dog Walkers Consider Park Safe at Night
description: When I first came here six years ago, I was frightened of the park at night, Ken Socha said near midnight recently as he stood in Riverside Park. just off West 76th Street. But not any more.

title: Burns's Warning To Carter
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman's warning to Presidentelect Jimmy Carter to go slow in stimulating the economy by traditional policies was as predictable as the coming of winter. It was only a matter of time.

title: The Port Authority's Sprawling Empire
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is a quasipublic corporation created 55 years ago by the legislatures of both states to develop transportation within a 25mile radius of the Statue of Liberty. It controls not only the region's four airports, but also six interstate tunnels and bridges, two helioports, seven marine terminals, a bus terminal, a bus station, two motor truck terminals, the Port Authority TransHudson Corporation (PATH), the World Trade Center, and a busrail station in Jersey City, N.J.

title: New Synthetic Oil Developed Here
description: TRENTON WITH the price of crude oil fluctuating at about $11.51 a barrel and the oilproducing nations threatening to push it even higher, scientists at a small research laboratory here have helped to move the United States closer to solving its energy needs.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$12,000, pare, mile.

title: Kathryn R. Pasmantier Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Pasmantier of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Rose Pasmantier, to Gordon Colin Oliver of London. Mr. Oliver is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Alister Oliver of Newport, Wales. The couple plan to be married in the spring.

title: Kennedy, at Vatican, Is Doubtful Abortion Amendment Could Pass
description: VATICAN CITY, Nov. 13 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he was committed to fighting abortion but he did not think righttolife advocates could muster enough support to win passage of a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion.

title: American Children Go to Class Soviet Style
description: They don't give A's for initiative in the Soviet Union. During the two years we lived in Moscow and our five children attended Soviet schools, neither they nor their Russian classmates were encouraged to contribute their own views on any subject. Students had no chance to develop reasoning ability by arguing a position in class; the entire pedagogy of the school was directed against individuality.

title: Moments of Being
description: Often when I have been writing one of my socalled novels I have been baffled by this same problem: that is, how to describe what I call in my private shorthand nonbeing. Every day includes much more nonbeing than being. Yesterday for example, Tuesday the 18th of April, was [as] it happened a good day; above the average in being. It was fine; I enjoyed welting these first pages; my head was relieved of the pressure of writing about Roger; I walked over Mount Misery and along the river; and save that the tide was out, the country, which I notice very closely always, was coloured and shaded as I likethere were the willows, I remember, all plumy and soft green and purple against the blue. I also read Chaucer with pleasure; and began a bookthe memoirs of Madame de la Fayettewhich interested me. These separate moments of being were however embedded in many more moments of nonbeing. I have already forgotten what Leonard and I talked about at lunch; and at tea; although it was a good day the goodness was embedded in a kind of nondescript cotton wool. This is always so. A great part of every day is not lived consciously. One walks, eats, sees things, deals with what has to be done; the broken vacuum cleaner; ordering dinner; writing orders to Mabel; washing; cooking dinner; bookbinding. When it is a bad day the proportion of nonbeing is much larger. I had a slight temperature last week; almost the whole day was nonbeing. The real novelist can somehow convey both sorts of being. I think Jane Austen can; and Trollope; perhaps Thackeray and Dickens and Tolstoy. I have never been able to do both. I triedin Nights and Days; and in The Years. But I will leave the literary side alone for the moment.

title: Hospital Mistrustees
description: CAN hospital trustees be trusted? The record shows that in Nassau County, most of them cannot. They cannot distinguish betwen their private and their public interests.

title: Jets, in Unfamiliar Role, Favorites Today Over Bucs
description: At last, the Jets have a must game. This one isn't for the bragging rights to New York, or to prove the American Football League is as strong as the National.

title: A Time For the Fire Brigade
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey United StatesTurkish relationships, damaged by what is regarded here as a proGreek bias in Washington produced by a clever proGreek lobby, and tinged with violent resentment against the Congressional embargo on arms sales to this country, require swift, effective action by American diplomacy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The New York Mets named Arthur Richman yesterday as director of public relations, succeeding Harold Weissman, who has retired.

title: Adults Changing Careers Press the Colleges to Adapt
description: THEY CALL IT boredom, frustration, anger or, often, just a kind of malaise. They may be 28 or 40 or 55. But they all want to leave the careers they had selected for themselves. Both the prospective careerchanger and the school to which he or she turns for help are finding new kinds of problems. For example, colleges may need to adjust hours at which courses are offered or must provide special counseling.

title: Hope for Corporate Bulls Who Become Rabbits in Public
description: The Rotarians are just finishing their roast beef when the guest speaker, the general manager of the local shoe factory, the town's largest employer, gets up to speak. He is outraged by Washington's failure to impose import restrictions on foreign competitors and has spent a long day preparing a fiery speech that he expects will propel his audience to instantly write the White House.

title: Chicagoans in a Stunning Concert
description: The final program by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall this fall was conventional in content if not in the order in which it was played. And of course it was anything but conventional in the perfection with which the orchestra performed.

title: Compensatory Education: Two Views
description: One of the factors leading to the gunsoncampus crisis at Cornell a few years ago was the fact that half the black students there were on some form of academic probation. Yet the average black Cornell student outperformed threequarters of all American students on the College Board examinations. The desperate academic situation those black students faced was due solely to the fact that they were at in institution whose general student body outperformed more than 99 percent of those who took the College Boards.

title: The Mermaid And The Minotaur
description: Hundreds of books are now being written from a feminist perspective by people in every intellectual discipline; some of them are brilliant, some are trash, most are mediocre. Although all claim the right to universal attention, not many earn that right. But every now and then a book comes along that speaks eloquently through feminism to the history of organized human life. When that happens we add it gladly to the small but growing shelf of feminist thought that must take its place beside the thought of every other major perspective that, in this century, seeks to explain us anew to ourselves. Such a book is Dorothy Dinnerstein's The Mermaid and the Minotaur.

title: IRAQIS STILL WARY OF ENEMY INTRIGUE
description: BAGHDAD, IraqWhen Saddam Hussein, the operating head of the Iraqi leadership, went out for strolls here not long ago, Baghdad intellectuals report, he was accompanied at a respectful distance by a halfdozen guards.

title: ...While the Casualties Continue
description: Vernon Evans, a graduating senior at Locke High School in Los Angeles is worried. He has a B average in a collegepreparatory curriculum but fears that he faces a bleak future.

title: To Kill A Cop
description: A dishonest cop undermines the very possibility of civilization, declares one of Robert Daley's police officers. The reader is reassured that civilization will not be undermined. In this novel about white cops and black killers, it seems there are no dishonest cops. Nor cowardly cops, for that matter. There are not even bigoted cops. Though several are butchered by black gunmen, not one word of racism Is spoken, for all the passion implicit in such

title: What's Doing in MILWAUKEE
description: GEMUTLICHKEITMilwaukee is more than a beer townno matter how frothy TV's Laverne, Shirley and even old Fonzie might make it seem. True, you can still hoist a few in your choice of 1,660 taverns that, along with a profusion of old churches, dot the city's multiethnic neighborhoods. But in tact, Milwaukee has in recent decades bloomed into a midwestern educational and cultural center where firstrate ballet coexists peacefully with championship bowling. Many of the city's approximately 700,000 residents joined local industrial barons in financing both an art and a performing arts center, perhaps in an attempt to cast off a sense of being Chicago's northern shadow. And while experiencing the social and financial strains of most old urban areas, Milwaukee is considered a clean, lowcrime city, its recent courtordered voluntary busing scheme a model of civic cooperation. Milwaukee remains basically conservative, especially in its lifestyle, and exudes a traditional feeling of friendliness and welcomeGemtlichkelt.

title: Despite Strikes and Demonstrations, They Seem Eager Not to Displease the Old Right
description: MADRIDAs Spain gingerly picks its way toward new political institutions, the country's illegal labor unions, which led the resistance to the Franco regime, have begun to test their strength.

title: The miracle of Chteau Gloria
description: BORDEAUX, FranceAbout 35 miles north this bustling provincial city, in the heart of the Mdoc peninsula, the great wine chateaus begin. The names are discreetly lettered on gateposts: Chteau Beychevelle, Chteau GruaudLarose, Chteau Branaire, Chteau Talbot, Chteau Ducru Beaucaillou, Chteau Leoville LasCases. And beyond,the gates, lanes lined with flowers slice through seas of vines toward the chateaus themselvesnoble old buildings with turrets and towers and steep slate roofs. Each chateau stands amid trees and formal gardens, its wineaging sheds off to one side. These properties date back centuries. TalbotLord Shrewsburywas an English general killed here in 1453, and part of Chteau Beychevelle was once a feudal fortress. The fame of their wine has existed almost as long. Some individual bottles aging in those sheds may be a hundred years old, perhaps older.

They are either up or down. Diligent financial reporters quickly telephone senior vice presidents and chief economists of leading bond trading houses in search of quotable punditry for Friday's editions. On Friday the financial markets react. On Monday there is a commentary on the reaction.

title: The Only Way to Travel
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13Every now and then along the Canadian Pacific rightofway, a jackrabbit would take off in flight, racing flat out toward the rim of the Alberta plain and throwing in an exuberant leap every few steps like a small boy released from school. In the rugged Northwest, where every Mountie always gets his man, the rabbit is no furry little Easter bunny with a soft white coat and pink eyes. These jacks looked as big as collies, and if you turned them loose at a dog track they would chase the greyhounds.

title: PEOPLE
description: The show is not exactly Bonnie and Clyde, but you must remember that we are on the side of the law, said Richard A. Barone of Paterson, one of five members of the Young Lawyers Committee of the Passaic County Bar Association. He referred to a cabletelevision drama called Law and the Automobile, which was written, produced and performed by Mr. Barone and Mary Delany, Marc Friedman, Tom LaConte and Jan Seigel. The program, which will be available for showing before clubs and civic groups, examines the law as it applies to carowner consumer interests. Miss Seigel said the young lawyers chose the dramatic form to impart information because a roundtable symposium would be too boring, a question and answer session too pat, as well as boring, and a debate format too confusing, as well as too boring and too pat.

title: Albania Defiant
description: As President Ford now surely knows, there are two countries in Eastern Europe that are, indeed, utterly independent of Soviet domination. OneYugoslaviahas been studied assiduously by literally hundreds of Western scholars since World War II and visited during the last decade by millions of Western tourists, who have found it the most open of Communist societies. The other independent Eastern European state is Albania, which in contrast has been the leaststudied and most closed society in Europeand yet whose feat in achieving and maintaining national independence is less remarkable.

title: CHESS
description: HAIFA, ISRAEL WHile there are gambits, such as the Marshall Counterattack in the Ruy Lopez, that perennially defy all attempts at a solution, the life span of the average gambit is quite brief. On its first outing, any reasonable gambit has a great chance of capitalizing its shock value, but thereafter it must reveal solid justification or end up in the lists of the discarded and unsound.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A:FORCING LILIES (Oct. 24) K.E.W., Apple Valley, Pa. asked if anyone had ever tried to force hardy lilies in pots, and if so, how it was done. We consulted Stanley Bulpitt, Brookside Nurseries, Darien, Conn. who won many awards for his outstanding garden displays of forced bulbs and perennials at New York's International Flower Shows. According to Mr. Bulpitt, the trick to forcing lilies is to obtain prechilled bulbs from bulb suppliers specializing in bulbs for forcing. (Prechilling allows bulbs to cure.) Pot lily bulbs individually in compostenriched soil, water and store at temperatures of 32 degrees for four weeks to root. Pots can he stored in a coldframe or buried in the ground and protected so they do not freeze. After roots form, bring into temperatures of 50 degrees for a week or so, then 60 degrees to grow. Lilies planted by the end of this month should bloom around midFebruary. If prechilled lily bulbs are not available, follow the same directions but store pots at near freezing temperatures six to eight weeks for the curing/rooting period.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Margaret Millar is a prolific but not hasty writer, and she obviously refuses to release a manuscript until it is as wellturned as she can make it. She is a precise stylist, and her writing has a good deal in common with that of her husband, the popular Ross Macdonald (creator of the private eye Lew Archer). Her latest book, ASK FOR ME TOMORROW (Random House, $6.95) is  like the Archer mysteriesset on the West Coast. This one moves from San Francisco to Baja California. Again as in the Macdonald books, the Millar novels have a keen sympathy for the human condition. Millar, however, is more of a hater than Macdonald. Her picture of Mexico is anything but flattering; and where. Lew Archer would shrug off bribery and cruelty as part of life, Millar uses a scalpel to peel to the bone.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Every home moviemaker will agree that films taken over the years of children growing up, of memorable vacation trips, or of special family occasions, are priceless possessionsyet if care is not taken in the storing, handling and showing of these films footage taken of a child's first birthday may be all but unusable by the time the youngster's 10th birthday rolls around.

title: Now We Are Fifty
description: WinniethePooh is celebrating its golden anniversary this year, with millions of copies sold in over 18 different languages, including SerboCroatian, Esperanto and Latin. It seems appropriate therefore to ask why this mild story about a group of English toys should have almost instantly become, and remained for 50 years, an international classicprobably the bestloved children's book of the 20th century.

title: Peter Grauer, Miss Watkins Have Wedding
description: The Reformation Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church in Orlando, Fla., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Margaret Carrington Watkins to Peter Thacher Grauer, both of New York. The Rev. Malcom Anderton performed the ceremony.

title: Deaths
description: ATKINMay. Beloved wits of Jullus, Devoted mother of Maurice & Howard, Adored grandmother of Alexandra, Michael and Paler. Deer sister of Nathan Rogin Services Sunday, Nov. 14, 12:45 P.M. at The Riverside 76th St. A Amsterdam Ave.

title: Elizabeth Carrere Is Wed to Oliver H. Havens
description: Elizabeth Lykes Carrre of New Orleans, widow of John F. Carrre, was married yesterday evening to Oliver H. Havens of Paris, formerly of Westfield, N.J. Canon Richard J. Hardman, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: Raisin Is Back To Aid Newark
description: NEWARK FOR a couple of years, those New Jersey theatergoers who wanted to see Raisin, the musical adaptation of Lorraine Hansberry's play about a black family planning to move into a white suburb, had no alternative but its Broadway production.

title: Rangers Tie Loss Mark At Home as Sabres Win
description: The Rangers equaled a record yesterday. They lost their sixth consecutive home game. 62, to the Buffalo Sabres, tying their mark for the longest backward slide before their own fans.

title: BEAME AND SHANKER MEET, DISCUSS PACT DEADLOCK
description: Mayor Beame met with Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, at City Hall on Friday night to discuss new ways of resolving deadlocked contract negotiations, spokesman for both men said yesterday.

title: One View Treats Claim as Illusion
description: If people think The East is coming back in college football, it is fair to ask, back from where, to what, involving whom?

title: Brower and Livingston Roll
description: Livingston's oncebeaten team again won a place in the North Jersey Section 2 Group 4 playoffs yesterday when it struck in the second half for a 220 victory over Mountain at West Orange.

title: They Weren't Riotous Comedies, But RiotProvoking Dramas
description: The arrival of the Abbey Theaterthe national theater of Irelandat the Brooklyn Academy of Music Wednesday night for the start of its first tour of the United States in 38 years comes as a reminder of the fact that possibly the greatest of the famous Abbey Theater riots did not take place in Dublin but here in New York City at the Maxine Elliott Theater on the night of Nov. 27, 1911. The disturbances elsewhere were as prayer meetings in comparison with the reception it got here, wrote a reporter the morning after the Abbey's first opening night in America.

title: Article 1  No Title
Jazz 115, Hawks 86
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 13 (AP)Pete Maravich poured in 30 points as the New Orleans Jazz routed the Atlanta Hawks, 11586, tonight.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Europe in 1776

title: Rhodesia Parley Put Off 48 Hours To Avoid a Clash
description: GENEVA, Nov. 13Ivor Richard, British chairman of the conference on the future of Rhodesia, today postponed for 48 hours a scheduled formal session of all delegations to avoid a headon clash with nationalist leaders over the date of the transfer of rule to the black majority.

title: Bond Deal for the Sawback Turtle
description: David E. Morine, a 33yearold investment banker with a master's degree in business administration from the University of Virginia, recently completed an unusual $13 million deal. He made a tender offer for a Mississippi timber company once eyed covetously by the Masonite Corporation, took control and dissolved it.

title: Drug Marketers Stir Bitter Debate in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13In Colombia, a recent documented study asserted that multinational pharmaceutical companies were marking up their drugs by an average of 155 percent compared with prices for the same medicines on the international market.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: My kitchen cabinets are birch and the finish is stained, marred, and irregularly worn. I don't want to refinish them, but wonder if you can tell me how to prepare them for painting, and what kind of paint to use?Mrs. R.S.S., New York City

title: PARIS EXPERTS SPURN CHARGES ON MUMMY
description: PARIS, Nov. 13French scientists have rejected with indignation allegations published in the United States that they fabricated a threat to the preservation of a royal mummy to get it to Paris for reasons of prestige.

title: For Earl Wild, Music Shouldn't Sound Difficult
description: Because Earl Wild has made playing the piano both look and sound easy, he has been perpetually misunderstood. Looks aren't everything, however, and now Wild, at age 60, is finally attempting to set the record straightthat he is neither a heartless computer capable of nothing but digital prowess nor a feather brain attracted only to frivolous music.

title: The Demon
description: His friends called him Harry the Lover. . . . It had to be . . . a married woman. These solemn words begin Hubert Selby's third novel, by all odds his most ludicrous to date. Ambitious young Harry White is not your ordinary cocksure hero, but possessed of a Major Sexual Urge. These things, as we know, are parceled out unfairly at birth. When Harry exchanges glances with a woman, the game is up. His every seduction is instant, hasslefree and assemblyline dull. In bed of course he outperforms all imaginable husbands. Faithful followers of Playboy will recognize the archetype. But there's a grand surprise in store for the thoughtful reader: Harry becomes the victim of his awesome urge, get it? Poor Harry must leave his baseball game, after scoring what proves to be the winning run, so that his demon can score another in bed. How's that for an original donnee?

title: Angela L. McGoldrick Plans to Marry Dec. 26
description: State Supreme Court Justice Charles G. Tierney and Mrs. Tierney of Pelham, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Tierney's daughter, Angela Lucy McGoldrick, to Stanley A. Robertson of Southsea, England. Plans have been made for a Dec. 26 wedding.

title: An Acting President's Report
description: I became acting president of Bennington College suddenly last January. President Gail Parker had left after a bitter intramural dispute since referred to as one of the most talked about academic flaps in years.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: When the School Gets in the Way of Education
description: Five years ago Rosemarie and I decided school was getting in the way of our son's education. Rob was 11 and attending Jamesville  DeWitt Middle School in DeWitt, N.Y. The school had a fine academic reputation and Rob was doing quite well there. But we felt that he was spending too much time being a student and not enough time being a useful human being in the community. There were other impertant ways and things to learn besides what school offered, we thought.

title: How You Can Make School Easier for Your Child
description: s there anything a parent can do to help a child learn to read? The answer is a resounding Yes!

title: Students Weigh Academic Goals Against Social Ones
description: CHICAGOBlack colleges, long used to struggling, face the paradox of appealing to more top high school graduates at a time of their gravest hour financially.

title: Notes: Controversy Over Giveaway Plans
description: Discounts and giveaways are standard devices in many areas of the economy, but they're a rare and endangered species among travel agents. Last year two New York area agents sought to attract customers with giveaways, but both programs haw since been discontinued; the agents say they gave in to travel industry pressure. Now a New York lawyer has filed a $75million class action suit against the American Society of Travel Agents, the major industry association; a chief target is the A.S.T.A. code of ethics that forbids members to offer discounts, gifts or rebates on commissions to clients.

title: CAMBODIA IS PUTTING PROPAGANDA TO MUSIC
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 13 (AP)the Cambodian Government, which has apparently chosen music as a key propaganda and teaching tool, is broadcasting its revolutionary message in song and rhyme.

title: Dance Festival In New London Seeks New Site
description: The American Dance Festival, an internationally known summer festival that has presented major premieres in contemporary dance by Martha Graham, Pau) Taylor, Twyla Thirp and others since 1948 at Connecticut, College, has announced that it is seeking a new site for its activities.

title: Westfield Dresses Up and Has a Bicentennial Ball
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 14Colonial men and women, American Indians, flappers from the 1920's, a contingent of Keystone Kolas and a couple of sets of the Marx Brothers. These were among the guests at the grand march of the Westfield Bicentennial Costume Ball, held last evening to mark the nation's 200th birthday.

title: Bruins Beat Rockies, 53, On McNab's Key Goals
description: BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP)Peter McNab scored two goals, including the tiebreaker in the third period, and set up another as he led the Boston Bruins to a 53 victory over the Colorado Rockies tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press article yesterday erroneously said that a $500 contribution from Park Tong Sun to Representative John Brademas of Indiana had not been previously reported. Mr. Brademas had reported the campaig?? contribution earlier.

title: Women Legislators to Open Parley in Morristown Today
description: The National Conference of Women Legislators, consisting of elected women officials or former officials of state legislatures in the 50 states, will begin a weeklong annual conference in Morristown today with an address by Governor Byrne and a variety of activities including speeches and field trips.

title: SOME ISRAELIS TELL OF P.L.O. CONTACTS
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 14Palestine Liberation Organization members are becoming more and more willing to talk with Israelis who are close to the mainstream of their country's political life, according to Israelis who have spoken with the Palestinians in over a year of discreet meetings.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 14 (AP)A high official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said yesterday that moderate Palestinian guerrillas were talking with an increasing number of Israeli Jews about making Israel a nonsectarian ArabJewish state.

title: Britain Is AnkleDeep in Water, but Government Says Drought Effects Persist and Curbs Remain
description: LONDON, Nov. 11The great British drought of 1976 is over. But then again, it isn't. It depends on whether one consults one's shoes or the Government.

title: 3 Groups Fight to Keep I78 Out of 2 Watchung Parks
description: SUMMIT, Nov. 14Opponents of state plans to close a gap in Interstate 78 by cutting through a part of Watchung Reservation in Union County will mount another public protest meeting next Friday night in an effort to convince officials that New Jersey cannot afford further loss of unique and irreplaceable woodlands.

title: Rangers Lose 7th in a Row At Garden, 51
description: After seeing their team lose on home ice for tthe seventh consecutive time, a Ranger record, Madison Square Garden spectators were shouting. Reefund! by the end of last night's 51 defeat by the Pittsburgh Penguins. In what now seems a cruel arrangement, the National Hockey League schedule has the Rangers currently on their longest homestand of the season, four games, just when they are playing their worst hockey. They'll take their troubled show on the road for 10 days after playing Chicago here Wednesday night.

title: Eskimos Gain in C.F.L. Playoff
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 14 (AP) The Edmonton Eskimos, with strong kicking by Dave Cutler and Gary Lefebvre, scored a 1412 victory over the Winnipeg Blue Bombers today in the Canadian Football League's Western Conference suddendeath semifinal playoff. Cutler scored all Edmonton's points on four field goals and two singlespunts that go out of the end zone. Lefebvre kept Winnipeg in poor field position with his punting.

title: Jeanne Moreau's 'Lumier' Is Dazzling:Film on Women Written and Directed by the Actress, Who Stars
description: It's a mark of the quality of Jeanne Moreau's "Lumire" that its defects are exaggerations of virtues. There is no fumbling or uncertainty in the first movie that she has written and directed and in which she gives, additionally, a splendid performance.On the contrary, there is great control. Often it leads to marvelous perceptions. Sometimes, in the too-studied dcor of a scene or the overly purposeful marshaling of a character or a dramatic sequence, it gives a sense of contrivance amd airlessness."Lumire," which opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater, is Miss Moreau's own penetrating vision of what it means to be a woman. It is as autobiographical and personal as a first novel, and as deliberately limited in scope. Miss Moreau's women are not farmers or office workers or sociologists. They are four actresses of different ages, inhabiting a particular, affected, high-pressured world.If the narrow focus seems precious, it is made up for by the insight with which we are shown the four women's relations with men, with their careers, with timethe almost visible enemy  and with one another. At its best, "Lumire" is subtle, funny and moving. And its ending is so powerful as to make an extraordinarily good movie seem, for these last minutes, close to a perfect one.The form of the picture is something like one of those traditional tales where four characters come out of a storm and into a quiet inn. In this case the meeting is at the country house of Sarah (Miss Moreau), the eldest of the four and the film's central figure. The women swim, sing snatches of childhood songs, lie in hammocks, fly kites, talk.It is an interval of peace and Miss Moreau uses it to establish her vision of feminine intimacy. It is composed of affection and a simultaneous understanding and restraint. The women see one another's loneliness and tend it with small attentions: presents, caresses, a kind of mutual adornment. They are soldiers resting before setting out for solitary campaigns. All they can do for one another is help with the bandages, not the fighting; and talk around, not through, one another's suffering.The movie then shifts to the four lives. Each is torn in some different way between the traditional feminine needsstability, the nurture of some fixed situationand the compulsion to appear and move in the light. This light, the "lumire" of the title, is limelight, the world's attention, the regard not of one person or family but of a series of strangers. Lovers, an audience: for these actresses they are aspects of the same compulsion. "To dream on the stage and to take your audience with you," says Julienne (Francine Racette), one of the younger women.It is Sarah who is most firmly in the light. Aging  Miss Moreau displays her sagging lines as if they were rewards given for beauty  she is at the height of her career, with a string of younger lovers Yet she clings to a loving friendship with Gregoire, an older man, a medical researcher who lives quietly and could, perhaps, have been her mate. "There is nothing I like so well as talking with you and being silent with you," she tells him. He is the stability she loves and cannot accept.Laura has gone a different way. A successful Italian actress  played by Lucia Bose, she recalls Sophia Loreh  she has married a rich man and thinks of herself mainly as a wife and mother. She has lost the "light" in favor of normality, and the loss gnaws at her strength and serenity.Julienne is a young star, new to success. She seems feather-headed and flighty, but that is largely because she has only recently arrived from the other side, The other side is her estranged husband and child. When she goes to visit, her clothes and her demeanor suddenly recall the young matron she was on the point of becoming.For Caroline, the youngest, the light is still a glimmer. She nibbles at itdinner with a producer, the offer of a bit part without clothesbut is held back by the spoiled young man she lives with. They quarrel continually, but quarreling is a form of stability that she is not prepared to cut away from.The film cuts from life to life. Sarah is discarding a petulant young film worker and acquiring a German writer. The reject is explosive, funny and futile; the writerwell-played by Bruno Ganzis tentative and dreamy. Laura, staying with Sarah, is shaken by the discovery that her husband may leave her. Julienne is comically interviewed by a mawkish woman reporter who asks her about her feelings, and comically seduced by a young American film star.Amid all this, Gregoire discovers he is dying of cancer. He goes to Sarah, possiblyit is only suggestedto ask some act of real if temporary commitment from her. But she is too distracted to give him a chance to talk; he swallows pills and dies quietly.The movie's climax comes when Laura wakes Sarah with breakfast and word of Gregoire's suicide. "I must go there at once," Sarah says, and huddles in bed. "I should take a bath," she says, and then: "There is too much light." She dresses and goesto work. We see her surrounded by technicians, posing, performing, using herself as a photographer uses his camera or a carpenter his tools.At an age when life for most people is cherishing the living and burying the dead, Sarah remains fixed in her world of light. Miss Moreau neither praises the choice nor condemns it, but the achievement of "Lumire"'s extraordinarily moving finale is to make us see its rigor.

title: Scouts Aim to Recruit 10,000 Boys in Week
description: A weeklong recruitment drive for Boy Scouts in New York City will start today, sponsored by the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America.

title: Soviet Freighter Sails From Japan With MIG
description: TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 15 (UPI)A Soviet freighter left a Japanese port for home today, carrying the parts of the MIG25 fighter flown to Japan by a Soviet airman seeking United States asylum.

title: THREE SUSPECTS ARRESTED IN HUDSON GAMBLING RAIDS
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 14 (UPI)Three Hudson County men will face a hearing tomorrow on charges of bookmaking and illegal sports activities.

title: Nursing Home Cuts Protested by Patients' Relatives
description: Sarah Dorfman, a middleaged woman whose mother is a Medicaid patient in a nursing home in New York City, traveled yesterday afternoon from her home in the Bronx to the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden to participate in a special sort of protest.

title: In the Image of God
description: BOSTON, Nov. 14With all its injustice and tension, South Africa is a deeply appealing country. The visitor is moved by the beauty of the land and, especially by a sympathetic emotional quality in the people, white and black.

title: Three Are Elected To the Hall of Fame
description: Clara Barton, Luther Burbank and Andrew Carnegie have been elected to the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, founded in 1900 by New York University.

title: Carter, With a Long List of Campaign Promises, Now Faces the Problem of Making Good on Them
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14  In 1,495 speeches and hundreds of interviews during a 21month Presidential campaign Jimmy Carter promised a wide range of programs, reforms and innovations if elected, often punctuating his words with the phrase, And you can depend on that. His promises range from a complete reorganization of the executive branch of Government to a pledge to place on his Oval Office desk a plaque with President Truman's old motto, The Buck Stops Here.

title: Carter's Church to Admit Blacks and Keep Minister
description: PLAINS, Ga., Nov.14With three Ku Klux Klansmen parading outside and the Rev. Clennon King, a black minister, huddled in a stairwell of an outside entrance, the congregation of Jimmy Carter's church voted today to drop its 11yearold ban on attendance by blacks. It decided to set up a committee to screen all applications for membership, black or white, without regard to race, and to retain its minister, who had opposed its ban on blacks

title: Bus Crash Kills 31 in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14 (AP)A bus moving onto a raft to cross the Urubu River overturned today and 31 of the 35 persons aboard perished, a Brazilian press agency reported. The accident occurred 100 miles east of the northern Brazilian city of Manaus, according to the dispatch.

title: Card of Thanks
description: ROSENTHALDiane. The family of the late Diane Rosenthal thank their many friends for their kind expressions of sympathy during their recent bereavement.

title: 7 GOVERNORS AGREE ON FEDERAL ACTIONS TO HELP NORTHEAST
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Nov. 14The Democratic Governors of seven Northeastern states called today for increased Federal aid, welfare reforms that would give every family a guaranteed in come and the creation of a regional superagency to develop energy sources and revive the economy.

title: Quality of Care Found Inconsistent In New York Municipal Hospitals
description: The man in a bed in Lincoln Hospital almost died because an overworked doctor didn't examine him closely. He lived because a nurse happened by.

title: Pessie Poupko, Talmudic Scholar And Widow of Rabbinical Leader
description: Pessie Poupko, widow of Rabbi Eliezer Poupko, former dean of Orthodox rabbis in Philadelphia, and a Talmudic scholar in her own right, died on Friday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 87 years old and lived in the Borough Park section.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association criticized the 5,000member auxiliary police force as phony cops who were scabbing our jobs. Douglas Weaving, the head of the P.B.A., made this statement in response to the New York City Police Department's call for the unarmed, unpaid volunteer officers to increase their patrols in an effort to stem assaults on the elderly. The auxiliary police do not have the power to make police arrests, only citizens' arrests, and they possibly dissuade wouldbe criminals by their presence on the streets in uniform.

title: Israel Calls Egypt's Bid a Ploy
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 14 (UPI)Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel said today that the latest Egyptian call for peace talks was a diplomatic ploy designed to influence American policy on the Middle East. Israel is ready for immediate dialogue with Egypt if President Sadat is truly interested in a peace agreement with Israel.

title: The Navy Helps Yeshiva Honor Its Fiftieth Year
description: The religious and the military combined with Sunday strolling and socializing in a joyful procession through Brooklyn yesterday marking the 50th anniversary of the Yeshiva of Flatbush.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: To our taste, the greatest preprandial, midday drink ever created in America is a bloody Mary. We have no earthly idea where the cocktail originated, although we have heard numerous claims in that direction.

title: Memorial Services
Market Place
description: The General Motors Corporation took Wall Street and the rest of the auto industry by surprise last week in announcing $200 rebates on subcompact Vegas, Astres and Chevettes.

title: Musk: Songs
description: There are always a considerable number of fine voices around, some attached to people who may legitimately be called singers. Some of these singers, furthermore, are good enough to be identified as musicians, or even artists. Of these, a few have the intelligence, the schooling and the vocal finesse to step forward and make a success as recitalists. Barbara Hendricks showed at Town Hall yesterday that she is to be counted among the few.

title: Dave Anderson
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 14Outside, on the roads leading away from Giants Stadium at sunset, horns were honking in celebration, as if 72,975 relatives had attended an Italian wedding. And in a way, they had. Joseph Peter Danelo, with a grandmother from Cantalup6 and a grandfather from Foggia San Marco, had kicked four field goals today and the Giants, unaccustomed as they are to any offense, needed every one of them. They spoiled their opportunity for a perfect season by defeating the Washington Redskins, 129, on Joe Daneto's 50yard field goal with less than 5 minutes remaining. Historians called it the Giants' most important field goal since Pat Summerall booted a 49  yarder through the snow against the Cleveland Browns at Yankee Stadium nearly two decades ago. And so the Giants finally won a game this season, with the littlest Giant providing all the points. Joe Danelo is only 5 feet 9 inches and 166 pounds, but he has a Giant heritage. Back home in the Minneehaha neighborhood of Spokane, Wash., he was inspired to be a soccerstyle placekicker by Pete Gogolak.

title: Siamese Twins Separated in Spain
description: LA CORUNA, Spain, Nov. 14 (AP) Siamese twin babies were successfully separated in a hospital in this northwestern Spanish city today, the hospital announced. The girls, Marta and Almudena Villar, were born last April joined at the abdomen. A hospital communiqu listed them in satisfactory condition after the one hour and 45minute operation.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1976

title: No Joy in Angola
description: It was not a very joyous occasion when the Popular Movement Government in Angola this week observed the first anniversary of the country's independence from Portugal. In southern Angola, the Government, which says it supports the Marxist tenet of the liquidation of exploitation of man by man, was doing its utmost, using Sovietarmed Cuban troops, to liquidate the stubborn guerrilla remnants of the proWestern movement known as UNITA.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Nov. 14Several hundred thousand New Jersey workers were to receive raises at midnight tonight, when the state's new minimum wage of $2.40 an hour was to go into effect.

title: Executive Changes For Reader's Digest
description: Having reached the retirement age of 65, Hobart Lewis will be leaving the chairmanship of the Reader's Digest Association at the end of the year, allowing for the upward movement of other executives. Kent Rhodes, 64, moves into the slot vacated by Mr. Lewis, leaving the presidency open for John A. O'Hara, 48 and Scottishborn, who has been both director of international operations and director of the Books and Recorded Music Division. He joined the company in England and worked for it in Germany, Canada, Australia and Mexico.

title: Harvard Offering Abortion Aid
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 (AP) Harvard University will now finance abortions under student health insurance. It was among the last Ivy League colleges to adopt this policy, which was described by the health services director, Dr. Warren Wacker, as sensitive. The university will not perform abortions, he said, but will refer women to outside clinics and provide up to $150. The new policy also finances maternity benefits for single women.

title: Music: Berlin's Beautiful Sounds
description: Herbert von Karajan and his Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra gave the first of their five Carnegie Hall concerts a week ago Thursday. But that was a purely orchestral affair. Saturday night and yesterday afternoon they returned for the first two of four concerts that also involve vocal soloists and Vienna's Singverein des Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde, which for this tour numbers over 150; the others in the series are tonight (Mozart and Bruckner) and tomorrow night (Verdi's Requiem).

title: 2 TeenAlters Tell of Climb From the Cellars of Society
description: Lord, you didn't give me a flat piece of of land to run

title: F.D.A. CHARGES FRAUD IN NEWDRUG TESTING ON RESEARCH ANIMALS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14A broad investigation of faults in the testing of new drugs on animals is leading to criminal charges against some research laboratories and will have ripple effects around the world, according to Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of Food and Drugs.

title: Pathologist Studying The Legion Disease Caught a Like Illness
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14More than three months after the mystifying outbreak of legionnaires' disease in Pennsylvania, scores of researchers around the country are still trying to find the cause, and in at least one instance one of them has fallen ill with a disease strikingly similar to the one she was investigating.

title: F.D.A. CHARGES FRAUD IN NEWDRUG TESTING ON RESEARCH ANIMALS
