title: FixedIncome Prices Rise on Eve of Heavy Financing
description: Fixedincome securities prices advanced moderately yesterday as the credit markets readied themselves for the extraordinarily active schedule of financing to he done this week. The Federal Reserve nudged shortterm interest rates

title: 3 Experts Testify at Bronf man Trial
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15Experts called today by the prosecution in the Bronfman kidnapping trial said they were unable to identify positively the typewriter used for the ransom letter and the machine that made certain tapes that figured in the case.

title: Nearly on Time, $21.80, Wins Nashua Stakes at Aqueduct
description: Five 2yearold colts with one major goal provided the theme of yesterday's $36,675 Nashua Stakes at Aqueduct. The big incentive? To register a first stakes victory.

title: Needham Discusses His Views Since Leaving Big Board
description: Thomas E. Mullaney

title: The U.N. Today
Syrian Peace Force Takes Control Of Beirut, Halting the Civil War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 15The Syrian Army took total control of Beirut today, forcing peace on the battleravaged downtown area of the capital and in effect halting a civil war in which at least 35,000 people have been killed. in 19 months.

title: BARNEY RUBINE,87,FOUNDER OF JERSEY METAL CONCERN
description: Barney H. Rubine, who in 1915 founded the Hudson Iron and Metal Company in Bayonne, N.J., died Sunday at the Jewish Hospital and Rehabilitation Center M Jersey City. He was 87 years old and was a lifelong resident of Bayonne, having been brought there as an infant from Russia.

title: ROBERT J. BARR
description: Robert J. Barr, a retired insurance company executive, died Sunday at Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and a resident of South Nyack.

title: Books of The Times
description: The occasional airline crash is inevitably a hideous shocker, even though statistics show that a trip by air is much safer than most other types of travel.

title: Fashion Casts Its Eye on a Gossamer Spring
description: Spring clothes aren't the sort that will strike terror in the hearts of conservatives. The ones that have been parading down the runways of Seventh Avenue in the last two weeks don't play any tricks with hemlines or offer any new, startling types of exposure. When designers want clothes to look provocative, they tend to open up a few buttons of a shirt or make a neckline plunge. These days, that's not enough to make anybody stare.

title: 8 Accused of Running Illegal Lottery Games
description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 15 (UPI) Eight persons were arrested today in Bergen, Hudson and Passaic Counties on charges of operating an illegal lottery, allegedly backed by organized crime.

title: American Distilling Seeks Schenley
description: The American Distilling Company announced yesterday that it had been holding exploratory discussions with the RapidAmerican Corporation to acquire Rapid's Schenley Industries subsidiary for a $355 million package of cash and notes.

title: Pate, Stockton Named To U.S. World Cup Team
description: For the first time since 1971 the World Cup and International Trophy golf championships, which bring together the leading players of countries, will be played in the United States.

title: Waldheim Faces a New Contender From Third World in Election Bid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15Another thirdworld diplomat threw his name into consideration for the post of secretary general today, threatening the chances of the incumbent, Kurt Waldheim of Austria, for election to a second fiveyear term.

title: Associated Press Members of the New Jersey Right to Life Committee picketing the State House in Trenton yesterday in support of Senate Bill 1271.
description: TRENTON, Nov. 15The State Department of Health is preparing a regulation that would close or consolidate on a regional basis hospital maternity wards that deliver fewer than 1,000 babies a year.

title: HEALTH CARE PAYOFFS CALLED RIFE BY HYNES AS 26 ARE INDICTED
description: The state's special nursinghome prosecutor said yesterday that he had found a widespread pattern of kickbacks in the healthcare industry in New York State, with suppliers of goods and services paying up to onethird the value of their contracts to nursinghome operators to obtain the business.

title: American Place Bill Delayed
description: The American Place Theater has postponed the opening of its program of two short plays, Comanche Cafe and Domino Courts, both by Bill Hauptman, to Dec. 2. The delay was caused by the illness of Collard Fowkes, one of the principal performers. The actor was hospitalized on Saturday with a kidney ailment. The two oneact plays have been giving previews since last Tuesday and will continue giving them through Sunday, with Baxter Harris replacing Mr. Fowkes. Mr. Fowkes is expected to be fully recovered by Dec. 2.

title: Giants Not Sure Morton Will Be Ready for Broncos
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 15John McVay, coach of the happiest 19 team in football, began preparations today to get the Giants far enough hack down to play in Denver's Mile High Stadium this Sunday.

title: Israelis Question Sincerity of New Moves by Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 15Israeli Government officials are reluctantly conceding the effectiveness of a recent series of Arab diplomatic and political moves in the complex search for peace in the Middle East.

title: Statements, Made by President Hafez AlAssed
description: The events in Lebanon are a great concern for us; the.atea; and the:entire: World these events concern us and the Arab Nation as ass much as they concein the: they concern the Lebanese people.

title: Bridge: Series of Pair Games Held, Limited to Experts Only
description: One of the paradoxes of bridge is that weak players like to play against strong players, although expecting to lose, while strong players do not enjoy playing against weak players, although expecting to win.

title: World News Briefs; Ambassador Saxbe to Quit Post in India on Saturday
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 15 (AP)Ambassador William B. Saxhe will leave India this Saturday at the end of his diplomatic assignment, the United States Embassy announced today. The announcement said that the 60yearold Mr. Saxbe planned to return to law practice in Ohio after his formal resignation is in effect in early January.

title: Unofficial Count Shows Meeds Washington Victor Over Garner
description: EVERETT, Wash., Nov. 15 (UPI)Representative Lloyd Meeds, Democrat of Washington, has retained his seat in Congress, according to final unofficial returns from Washington's Second Congressional District, ending up with a 372vote margin over John Nance Garner.

title: Friendlier Relations With the Russians Rejected by Chinese
description: PEKING, Nov. 15 (Reuters)China tonight flatly rejected any return to friendly relations with the Soviet Union following the death of Mao Tsetune.

title: Mild Earthquake Strikes Peking; Most Stay Home After First Scare
description: PEKING, Nov. 15 (Reuters)An earthquake quake struck this city today, sending thousands of people fleeing into the streets. There was no immediate sign of damage or casualties.

title: 38 Voters Are Killed In Brazil Bus Plunge
description: MANAUS, Brazil, Nov. 15 (UPI)A bus loaded with voters headed for the tiny river community where they were registered for today's nationwide municipal elections plunged into the Unibu River yesterday killing 38 persons.

title: PLANT IN SIXTH STATE HAS MYSTERY ILLNESS
description: GROVE CITY, Ohio, Nov. 15Katherine Francis, a 33;yearold salvage worker in the Robertshaw Controls Company plant .lere, has been feeling sick since August.

title: New White House Press Chief
description: One of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's oldest, most trusted personal assistants formally named yesterday as the White House press secretary volunteered 10 years ago, after shaking hands with the candidate in a south Georgia shopping center, to work as volunteer in Mr. Carter's unsuccessful campaign for Georgia governorship ... signed on again in the winning 1970 campaign, served as press secretary to Governor and Presidential candidate for the last six years.... A tall, slowspeaking, congenial good old boy, addicted to other people's cigarettes and inclined toward casualness ... His necktie, when he decides to wear one, is invariably loosened ... seemingly imperturbable, maneuvers through difficulties with detachment ... Fiercely loyal to Mr. Carter, with whom he has a fatherson relationship Like the Presidentelect, he comes from a south Georgia farm background and eschews use of his formal name, preferring Jody to Joseph Lester Powell Jr ...Born Sept. 30, 1943, in Cordele, Ga., reared on farm near small town of Vienna ... Dismissed from Air Force. Academy in 1964 for violating honor code, having checked a course notebook in an examination rest break ...Completed studies at Georgia State. University, studying political science... Married to former Nan Jared, has a 9yearold daughter ...Strongly influenced by his mother, a high school teacher, in eclectic love of books ... At ease in public or private company of reporters, who regard him as unusually well versed in lore of Mr. Carter and

title: Car Insurance Rates Found Burdening Some Groups
description: A growing body of evidence suggests that the system used to determine automobile insurance rates is based, in part, cm faulty statistics and unfairly burdens groups of drivers who can least afford. to pay the highest premiums.

title: Fans Are Flocking Away, Causing Concern in N.H.L.
description: The National Hockey League's board of governors is meeting in Key Largo, Fla., today to discuss hockey's most pressing problem, and the subject is not violence. Plummeting attendance figures are the main concern, and all but a few hockey franchises have been affected. The Cleveland Barons, with an average crowd of 5.330 over 10 games, and the Colorado Rockies, who have drawn an average of 5,572 in 11 games, are having the hardest time. But they expected to build fans slowly after moving from Oakland, Calif., and Kansas City, respectively.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A., a unit of the Exxon Corporation, said yesterday that it had taken assignment of contracts for the construction of two 195,000ton tankers by a unit of the Ogden Corporation as part of an expans:on of its tanker fleet. The expansion is designed to handle increased oil shipments from Alaska.

title: ComputerMade Movies Of Heart During Exercise Developed by N.I.H. Team
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15(AP)Scientists have developed a method of making computerreconstructed movies of the heart while a patient vigorously exercises something that the experts say cann9t be done with standard ways of making internal heart pictures.

title: MUNICIPAL LABOR GROUP REJECTS BARGAINING BAN
description: The Municipal Labor Committee, made up of unions representing more than 200,000 New York City workers, voted unanimously yesterday against a suggestion by Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, that collective bargaining be suspended for the duration of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Rhodesians Report 17 Are Killed In Guerrilla Clashes on Border
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 15 (AP)Two black members of the Government's security forces, 11 black guerrillas and five black civilians have been killed in the latest clashes along Rhodesia's borders. security officials said today.

title: Parliament Expels Indian in Exile1
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 15 (AP)Subramaniam Swamy, a rightwing opposition leader who has fled abroad, was expelled from the Indian Parliament today on charges of misconduct and subversive activity. In the first such action in 29 years of independence, the upper house adopted a motion ousting the former Harvard economics lecturer on charges of evading the law, propagandizing against India and traveling on an impounded passport.

title: BUDGET UP SLIGHTLY FOR WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive, requested today a 1977 Westchester budget that included a relatively small increase over the current year, a slight decrease in the countys average property tax and pledge not to increase welfare spending next year by a single cent over this year's figure.

title: Associated Press
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 Chiding those who would compare SovietYugoslav relations with those of the wolf and Little Red Ridinghood, Leonid I. Brezhnev arrived here today for three days of talks with President Tito.

title: Big Board Starts Dismissing 125 In Step Meant to Save $4 Million
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the details of its expected staff reorganization, involving the dismissal of about 125 employees, including nine officers.

title: For a Change, Post Office Says It Had Surplus for Three Months
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The United States Postal Service, which has been running financial deficits since its formation five years ago, announced a milestone today: It had a $15 million surplus for July, August and September.

title: Baron Long's Linden Tree Caper
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14Baron Long was a cheerful rogue whose name is still a legend up and down the Pacific coast. Pe was a professional gambler with money, imagination and a soaring talent for mischief. He loved opera deeply, yet nothing by Verdi or Bizet or Wagner could fill his breast With such exultation as the cries of bookmakers whom had clipped for a bundle. He operated the famous U.S. Grant tiotel in San Diego, raced a string of horses and had a piece of the old Tia Juana track across the Mexican border. After

title: S.E.C. Offers Plan For the Settlement Of Small Disputes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Securities and Exchange Commission outlined today a proposal under which disputes between investors and their brokers involving up to 55,000 could he resolved without resort to expensive and timeconsuming litigation.

title: Petition Drive Is Planned to Urge Carter to Issue Vietnam Amnesty
description: CHICAGO, Nov, 15 (UPDRepresentafives of a dozen religious groups today announced the start of a national drive to obtain one million signatures on petitions urging Jimmy Carter to issue blanket amnesty for all Vietnamera draft resisters and military deserters.

title: FOREIGNERS IN U.S. SELL $3.2 BILLION IN SECURITIES
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Foreigners:Aii tracted by declining interest rates solcLa record $3.2 billion in securities, bends,: and other new financial issues in .thei United States during the third quarter, the Commerce Department said Monday.

title: Berta N. Briggs, Painter And a Writer, Was Head Of Women Artists Group
description: Berta N. Briggs, painter and writer, who had been active in New York City's cultural activities for many years, died Friday at the De Witt Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 92 years old and lived at 40 East 96th Street.

title: U.S. Discloses Shortage of Swine Flu Vaccine for Children 3 to
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The United States Public Health service announced today that there would be no largescale, swine flu immunization effort for Americans in the 3through17yearold age group because only limited supplies of vaccine suitable for children would be available this year.

description: International

title: Brazilians Vote in Local Elections That Will Test the Popularity of the Military Regime
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15Brazilians voted today in municipal elections that are widely viewed here as another step in the slow process of political liberalization promised by the rightwing military dictatorship.

title: Wake for Philadelphia Hotel Booked Solid
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15The Bellevue Stratford Hotel has three days to live, but an autopsy was performed toddy on the 72yearold rococo palace.

title: 2 Moscow Jews Who Faced Prison Up to 5 Years for Protests Are Released as First Offenders and Family Men
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 15The Soviet authorities today released two Jewish dissidents who had faced the possibility of up to five years in prison for protests in downtown Moscow last months

title: Separatist Party Wins in Quebec, Ousting Liberals
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 15The party that seeks to separate Quebec from Canada was swept into power tonight in this predominantly Frenchspeaking province.

title: British Trade Official Scores U.S. For Its Unilateral Curb of Exports
description: The United States is the only developed country to take unilateral action against the exports of its trading partners, Edmund Dell, British Secretary of State for Trade. charged yesterday in an interview.

title: Harvard and Alitz of Army Capture Titles in 1C4 A Cross Country Run
description: It took more time to decide the team champion at the IC4A crosscountry meet yesterday than it did for Curt Alitz of Army to win the individual title. The 21yearold Cadet, the runnerup last year, covered the fivemile course at Van Cortlandt Park in 23 minutes 58.1 seconds and finished 25 yards ahead of John Flora of Northeastern in the University Division.

title: The New York Times/Paul Nosefros A CUSHION OF COATS: A girl dreams away the afternoon in The Sheep Meadow in Central Park, resting on pile of coats left by her schoolmates, playing ball in the field behind her.
CBS's Paley in Soviet To Bid for Olympics
description: William S. Paley, chairman of CBS Inc., and Robert J. Wussler, president of CBSTV, arrived in Moscow yesterday to negotiate the United States television rights to the 1980 summer Olympic Games to be held in the Soviet capital, a CBS spokesman said last night.

title: Korean Lobbyist's Absence May Affect U.S. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15If the Korean businessman Tongsun Park does not return to the United States, that will further complicate an investigation already burdened by questions of diplomatic immunity, access to offshore bank accounts and the legal value of foreign intelligence data, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: United Press International
description: TRENTON, Nov. 15The State Senate Judiciary Committee approved today bill to restore the death penalty for firstdegree murder, overriding objections from one of the state's most respected prosecutors, Joseph C. Woodcockof Bergen County, who said he might resign from office before asking for a death penalty.

title: Advertising; New Wrinkle in Coupon Merchandising
description: Manufacturers use of centsolf coupons, which grew 19.8 percent last year over 1974, are expected to increase 15 to 20 percent this year, according to the A. C. Nielsen Clearing House.

title: 49ersRams Selected As Top Game Sunday
description: The big game in pro football this Sunday will be in San Francisco where the 49ers take on the Los Angeles Rains, whom they defeated earlier, 160. The outcome will go a long way toward deciding the race in the National Con

title: MEDICAID'S LAB FEES BEING CUT UP TO HALF
description: Medicaid reimbursement fees for the most frequently ordered laboratory tests will be reduced by up to onehalf, therely saving the program an estimated total of $3 million a year, New York Cis Medicaid Administration announced terday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times last Saturday on the alleged looting of a teamsters union welfare fund could he read as implying that the Old Security Life Insurance Company was a defendant in a civil suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The suit charges that. Old Security was used as a front for transferring union premiums to companies controlled by alleged conspirators, but it clues not name Old Security as a defendant or ask that its assets be frozen.

title: Inauguration Will Be Informal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15  About 300,000 to 400,000 of those Americans Who worked hard for the election of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter will be invited to Washington for his inauguration that is planned to be informal, inexpensive and to include lots of parties, says Ken Kieves, executive director of the inaugural committee.

title: Notes on People
description: Daniel Schorr, who tangled with Congress over making public the secret report on the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency and eventually resigned as a CBS News correspondent, signed a contract yesterday to do book that should disclose some of his problems. Called Final Assignment, the book is to be published next fall by Houghton Mifflin. Mr. Schorr says. The book will be personal but I will not be satisfied to have it simply personal. I want to try to illuminate what goes on in government and what goes on in television and what goes on between and television.

title: Suffolk Legislature Approves $578 Million Budget
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI, Nov. 15The Suffolk County Legislature, adding. $1.7 million to the budget of the County Executive, John V. N. Klein, adopted today $578 million budget for 1977. the new budget will result in a property tax rate of about $3.06 per $100 of assessed valuationan increase for homeowners of as much as 79 cents over last year. The county tax accounts for about only 10 percent of the total tax bill for residents, with the remainder consisting of school, town and special district taxes.

title: On Beating Grandmother
description: Another problem we have in New York is children beating up grandmothers. Sometimes they kill them, although the usual thing is just robbery. Sometimes the children are quite young. Ten, twelve, thirteen years old. Sometimes the grandmothers are old enough to be greatgrandmothers. The other day two pubescent boys did a streetmugging job on a woman who later told policemen she was 103.

title: Newspaper Group Elects Chief
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP)Jack W. Tarver, president of Cox Enterprises Inc., which publishes The Atlanta Constitution and Journal, was elected president of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday.

title: Stage: Claw
description: CLAW at the Manhattan Theater Club is about a Michael CaineAlfie type of opportunist, enmeshed ii, an 0 Lucky Me life journey, who ends as disastrously as the protagonist of A Clockwork Orange. That the play's ancestors and influences are cinematic rather than dramatic is one indication of its lapses as theater.

title: U.S, GRANTING LISBON $300 MILLION LOAN TO BOLSTER REGIME
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Ford Administration has quietly approved an emergency loan of $300 million to Portu. gal and has decided to seek Congressional approval to join in a longterm $1.5 billion consortium to help the newly formed, Government of Mario Soares stay ,in, power.

title: $122.5 MILLION BUDGET PROPOSED FOR ROCKLAND
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 16The Rockland County Legislature was presented with a preliminary $122.5 million budget last night by the county budget officer, George Rene.

title: Albert M. Kahn, Manufacturer, Headed Philanthropic Drives
description: Albert M. Kahn, a retired rubber manufacturer, died Monday at a hospital in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Thousand Oaks.

title: Car Insurance Plan Opposed by Brokers
description: Representatives of insurance broker associations warned yesterday that large numbers of motorists would start driving without insurance if the state approved proposed increases in automobile assigned risk rates. In some cases the rates would more than double.

title: New Carafes for Old Wine
description: So widespread has wine drinking become today that a dinner table lacking something deep red, rosy pink or pale white on it looks almost inhospitable, as if some understood pleasure was about to be withheld.

title: Associated Press A PARTING GIFT: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, trying out new Yugoslav Zastava 101 passenger car given to him by President Tito.
A.M.C. Sets Rebates On'76 and 77 Pacers
description: DETROIT, Nov. 16The American Motors Corporation announced today $253 rebates on its 197677 Pacers in an effort to spur sagging sales and reduce high inventories of the small car.

title: S.E.C. Cites Royal As Concealing Data In Monogram's Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16In a rare intervention in a still undecided tender offer, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Royal Industries had issued incomplete and inaccurate statements in connection with a hotly contested takeover bid against it by Monogram Industries.

title: Thai Business Chiefs Still Uneasy in Wake of Military Coup
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 16Many industrial and financial leaders are apprehensive in the wake of the military takeover of a month ago.

title: TV Fires Salvos In Ratings War
description: SUDDENLY, primetime television is a feast, its usually sparse bill of fare lush with more enticements than a gluttonous viewer could possibly consume.

title: Now, About Food at the Movies....
description: Movie Moguls are twitchy because folks aren't running to the movies anymore. They say there aren't enough of the right movies, that people only want to see blockbusters, that admission Prices are too high and that television, the perennial blackhatted villain, is why movies are closing.

title: Deaths
1,199 Bombings in Nine Months
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI)  TheFederal Bureau of Investigation reports: that 1,199 bombing incidents occurred in the United States and Puerto Rico during. the first nine months of 1976, killing 3'9 persons, injuring 179 and causing $9.5: million damage. Eight of the dead and 44 of the injured were perpetrators themselves, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: Diet: Not Me
description: There are, of course, the cognoscenti who know gracious dining, impeccable service, the cuisine customcooked to give the palate a fleeting if unforgettable thrill. And then there are the rest of us who are less than knowledgeable on dining but can tell the world a thing or two about eating.

title: Rev.Dr.Cyril Richardson, Scholar Of Early Church History, 67, Dead
description: The Rev. Dr. Cyril Charles Richardson, internationally known church historian and Washburn professor emeritus of church history at Union Theological Seminary in New York, died yesterday morning in his home after a heart attack, He was 67 years old and lived at Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street in Manhattan.

title: TV for ColgateRutgers
description: Rutgers, which finally achieved.. ranking among the nation's top 20 college football teams will meet oncebeaten Colgate Thanksgiving night in Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N. J. The game, which will be televised regionally by ABC, will start at 8:30. It originally was scheduled for this Saturday at New Brunswick, N. J.

title: I.C.C. TO LET RAILROADS RAISE FREIGHT RATES 4%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission agreed Tuesday to let the nation's railroads raise their general freight rates by 4 percent on Jan. 7, 1977.

title: Tenace Goes to Padres, Baylor Gets Angel Pact
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 16 (AP)Gene Tenace and Don Baylor officially left the Oakland A's today, signing multiyear contracts as free agents. Their contracts were negotiated by Jerry Kapstein, their agent. Tenace went to the San Diego Padres and Baylor to the California Angels.

title: Toy Makers Battling Toward a Record Year
description: Santa's workshops they are not. No ndlolly elves dancing round the work tables; no cutesy curtains tied back with ropes of jingle bells.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Plea Entered in Fatal Robbery
description: NEWARK, Nov. 16 (AP)An Irvington youth who pleaded no defense to a felony murder charge in the death of a candy store owner will be sentenced Jan. 5.1 Raymond Zyas, 19 years old, who entered the plea in Superior Court here yesterday, faces a maximum term of life imprisonment. The authorities said that Walter Borowyk, 65, of Irvington scuffled with the youth during a robbery attempt by the teenager outside Mr. Borowyk's store. During the scuffle, the authorities said, Mr. Borowyk fell and struck his head on the curb. He died six days later.

title: TORONTO PONDERS FUTURE OF CANADA
description: TORONTO, NOV, 16In the aftershock, of the separatist election in Quebec., Robert Stewart stood at the long bar in the Sheraton Centre Hotel, where lunctime patrons from Toronto's financial and governmental district gazed solemnly out a huge plateglass window, peering across City Hall Plaza to where the red;andwhite maple leaf flag of Canada flapped in the breeze.

title: Regular Insurance Tough to Buy For Auto Owners in South Bronx
description: The situation with auto insurance today is the same as it was with drugs years ago, said William Vargas bitterly. As long as it was only the blacks and the Puerto Ricans who were shooting up, no one cared. But as soon as the white kids got involved, then they started strike forces and everything else.

title: Broodmare Brings A Record $1 Million
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 16 (AP)Queen Sucree, the dam of the 1974 Kentucky Derby winner, Cannonade, brought a world broodmare record price of $1 million at the fourth session of the 33d Keeneland November breeding stock sale tonight.

title: On Digesting Music (and Dinner, Too)
description: When the new Avery Fisher Hall opened last month, there were those whbquite literally  breathed easier. The downstairs restaurant had been eliminated and with it the smell of cooking oil that occasionally would rush upstairs and mingle with the strains of Brahms and Stravinsky. It was not a palatable mixture. Only the bar remains in Fisher Hall. Experience has shown that it is necessary for some music lovers 10 build up their courage during intermissions.

title: On Ice: Twyla Tharp Twirls a Champion
description: THE mutual attraction between stage choreographers and ice skaters has taken several forms over the years. In 1947, Pauline Koner, one of modern dance's most prominent figures, choreographed for Holiday on Ice. At the other extreme, there have been ballets such as Frederick Ashton's Les Patineurs in which dancers pretend to be skaters. Usually, it is the other way around.

title: Exxon Borrows Money Directly From Public; Saskatchewan Is Selling $125 Million Issue
description: In a move that could have longrange impact on the ways by Which companies raise capital, the Exxon Corporation went directly to the public yesterday to borrow money.

title: Court Gives State Writ to Attach Hollander's Assets of $3 Million
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Albany issued a warrant yesterday allowing the state to attach $3 million of the property of Eugene Hollander, the nursinghome operator, and said the state could attempt to collect punitive damages as well.

title: Reenactment to Follow Washington's Footsteps
description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 16The loss of Fort Washington in Harlem Heights on Nov. 16, 1776, and the British thrust across the Hudson River and up the Palisades four days later left Fort Lee exposed and undefendable. At the alarm that 5,000 British and Hessian troops under Lord Cornwallis were six miles away and advancing south toward Fort Lee, General Washington raced from his headquarters at the Peter Zabriskie House in Hackensack (now the Von Steuben House) to the jeopardized clifftop bastion.

title: State YearEnd Fete Will Reenact Washington Crossing of Delaware
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16Opening with a reenactment by 500 uniformed troops of General Washington's Delaware River crossing on Christmas Eve 1776, New Jer. sey will celebrate 10 crucial days of the nation's revolutionary .birth with ,a lavish cultural and historical festival begidning Dec. 25.

description: RESULTS

description: Music

title: Kennedy High Relay Victor
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 16John F. Kennedy High of Bellmore, L.1., the New York State intersectional crosscountry champion, won a scholastic fiveman, 10mile relay today at the New York Institute of Technology track. Kennedy was clocked in 49 minutes 14.9 seconds and was led by the individual winner, Ira Meyers, sophomore, who ran 9:26 for two miles,

title: Consumer Spending Rise Seen
description: Consumer spending will strengthen in the period immediately ahead, A. Deah Swift, president of Sears Roebuck & Company, predicted yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times last Friday stated incorrectly that Mego International had acquired the Tinker Toy and Child Guidance lines from the Questor Corporation. Mego was actually negotiating to acquire these and other lines of the Questor Education Fmclucts unit.

title: Sweet And Sour Talks in Belgrade
description: PARISThis week's BrezhnevTito colloquy in Belgrade is a most important dialogue and also one about which little, apart from formal statements, will he knownat least for months to come. President Tito, the first man to thumb his nose at Stalin and get away with it, is now 84 and unwell, despite occasional displays of remarkable vitality.

title: ELEANOR BROWN DOWLING
description: Eleanor Brown Dowling, a former magazine editor, died Monday at the Glen. Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: Gifts to United Way Up $37 Million in 76
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 16 (UPI)Pledges and money reported by United Way campaigns in the United States and Canada are 8.8 percent higher than those reported at this time last year, the United Way of America headquarters said today.

title: Private Lives
description: John Leonard

title: Miss Rutherford Bowls a 300
description: TULSA, Okla., Nov. 16 (AP)Tam Rutherford of Oroville, Calif., became the second bowler in two days to record a perfect game in the Professional Women's Bowlers Association $35,000 national championships today. The lefthanded Miss Rutherford shot her first career 300 in the opening round of the matchplay finals. She finished her last three games with a 776 scratch series and totaled 1,485 over all.

title: Steinerius Duo: Fine Rapport
description: Myron Kartman, violinist, and William Henderson, pianist, who form the Steinerius Duo of the University of Alabama, made amuch admired debut in Town Hall five years ago. On Monday night, reappearing here in Alice Tully Hall, they played very well but had trouble adjusting the balance between them at the start of the program.

title: Mets Give Matlack a 3Year Pact
description: Jon Matlack, the lefthander who reached a personal sixyear high with 17 victories this year, has signed threeyear contract with the New York Mets for an estimated $100,000 a year, the club announced yesterday.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Enid Nemy

title: Knicks Survive Errors And Top Hawks, 10097
description: Twentyfour second violations, threesecond violations, a zone defense, shabby foul shooting, an ejected coach and a rulebook full of other mistakes were all present last night in the Knicks 10097 victory over the Atlanta Hawks. The Madison Square Garden revival of The Comedy of Errors was staged before an audience of 12,917, the smallest of the season at the Garden.

title: From Traditional Origins, an UptoDate Thanksgiving
description: If Benjamin Franklin had had his way the Thanksgiving bird would have been our national emblem today. It was his contention that the bald eagle . . . Is a bird of had moral character; he does not get his living honestly and you may have seen him perched on some dead tree, where, too lazy to fish for himself, he watches the labor of the fishinghawk; and when that diligent bird has at length taken a fish . . . the bald eagle pursues him and takes it from him.

title: Nessen Angered in White House At Unexpected Powell Interview
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16President Ford's press secretary, Ron Nessen, exploded with anger today while reporters interviewed Presidentelect .Timmy Carter's chief spokesman, Jody Powell, in the White House press office.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Syntex Corporation made questionable overseas payments totaling well over $200,000 during the five years ended last July, according to a 6K filing by the Panamanianbased drug company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: United Press International NEW U.S. ARMY HELMET: A Model wears the new helmet, to be distributed to U.S. troops in 1980. Made of a bulletproof and heatresistant plastic, it is lighter and more comfortable than steel helmet now in use. It also provides better protection for head and neck.
Agency Backs Move to a Hotel Of Center for Mentally Disabled
description: New York City's Department of Mental Health and its consultants heartily recommend that the Brewster Hotel be used as a socialrehabilitation center for the mentally disabled. West Side residents were told at a public hearing last night.

title: SIMON LAZARUS JR.
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 (UPI)Simon Lazarus Jr., a lawyer, community worker and greatgrandson of department store developer, Simon Lazarus, died yesterday at Jewish Hospital. He was 64 years old. Mr. Lazarus, who was hospitalized Oct. 19 for treatment of leukemia, suffered a heart attack Saturday. His greatgrandfather was the founder of the Lazarus store in Columbus, from which Federated Department Stores, now the largest department store chain in the nation, was built.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times last Friday stated incorrectly that Mego International had acquired the Tinker Toy and Child Guidance lines from the Questor Corporation. Mego was actually negotiating to acquire these and other lines of the Questor Education Products unit.

title: About Education
description: Imagine the stress felt by a student who knows that his or her failure to learn what is being taught may some day result in someone's death.

title: Dance: City Ballet Comes Home
description: How do you keep em down on the farm, after they've seen Paree? Well, one hardly knows. New York must do its best, but undoubtedly our own New York City Ballet has just had one of the triumphs of its still young life in Paris, France. Mind you, Paris, France, or its critics, do not see too much great ballet nowadays, but it was nice to be noticed, and a triumph is a triumph is a triumph.

title: Move Follows Province's Potash Takeover Step
description: Saskatchewan, the Canadian prairie province that angered United States fertilizer companies this year by moving to take over by purchase or expropriation at least half of the output of the agriculturally, important potash industry, came to Wall Street yesterday to borrow $125 million to help finance telephone and electric power expansion.

title: Bronf man, on Stand for First Time, Tells About Threat Against His Life
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 16Samuel Bronfman 2d, making his first appearance at the trial of his two alleged kidnappers, testified today that his life had repeatedly been threatened by the armed and masked man who allegedly seized him in August of 1975 at the garage of his mother's estate in Purchase.

title: Quebec Separatist Victor Pressed To Keep Province Within Canada
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 16In the wake of the stunning election victory won yesterday by the separatist party of Quebec Province, strong pressure was being brought today by local and national federalists against any attempt by the new provincial government to break away from Canada.

title: Upstate Teachers' Strike Leaders Fined, Given 10Day Jail Terms
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 16 (UPI)A State Supreme Court justice today fined :six leaders of the North Syracuse teachers union $250 apiece and ordered them: to begin 10day jail terms for a twoweek strike that ended yesterday.

title: It Must Be Something They Ate
description: When Mrs. Jack Gardner, the clown of proper Boston, invited the haute monde to the housewarming of her Venetian palazzo, Fenway Court, she served doughnuts and champagne.

title: Empire Built on Beer Nourishes 3 Generations of a Thai Family
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 16A small noodle shop marks one corner or Soi 41 off Sukhumvit Road, and a burnedout theater marks the other corner.

title: SON OF ASTRONAUT CLEARED OF CHARGE
description: Lieut. Frederick P. Borman, a 1974 West Point graduate and a son of a former astronaut, Col. Frank Borman, was cleared by the Army yesterday of an allegation that he had taken a $1,200 bribe. The charges alleged that he received the money to fix a case involving two cadets who had been accused of cheating at the United States Military Academy.

title: Personal Health
description: PEOPLE generally think of cancer as a capricious disease, one that usually strikes without warning or regard for the particular particular characteristics of individuals. In the case of certain leading types of Cancer, this is not entirely true. There are individuals who can be distinguished ahead of time as facing a high risk of developing the disease.

title: Regents Urge Giving New York City, More Aid at the Suburbs
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16A major change in New York State's aidtoeducation program, which would give New York City. $92.19 million in additional funds by sharply reducing assistance to wealthier suburban districts in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties, was proposed today by the State Board of Regents.

title: Canton Newspaper Strike Ends
description: CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP)Employrees of The Canton Repository returned to work today after negotiators for!the newspaper and Local 219 of the International Typographers Union reached tentative agreement on a contract andended a 15day strike.

title: N.F.L. Standings
In Memoriam
description: LIPSCHITZHarris. Dearest father who left us 11 years ago today to be with mother. Your modesty, your Intelligent ways, and sense of humor will never be forgotten. You are always In our thoughts and hearts.

title: Bob Lemon Named Pilot Of White Sox
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP)Bob Lemon, a hard  throwing right  hander who pitched his way into baseball's Hall of Fame, was named today to manage the Chicago White Sox. The White Sox president, Bill Veeck, made the announcement while propped in a wheelchair at Illinois Masonic Medical Center where he will undergo cervical surgery Thursday to relieve pressure on his neck nerves. Veeck said Lemon would succeed Paul Richards. who managed the team last season, which marked Veeck's return to baseball when he formed a syn

title: 1976: The Living Section
description: Sandy Huffaker

title: Living Abroad: Rome
description: When my wife came home after shopping he other day, she unpacked six potatoes, even carrots, a head of lettuce and four rapes. The grapes were her change. Sometimes change comes as a stick of chewing gum, a mint, a postage stamp, a telephone token, an egg, or, from the butcher, one or two chicken livers. No one is ever quite sure what he'll get except that he won't get any 50 lira (six cents) or 100 lira coins when he breaks a bill.

title: Paris Counts 45,085 Abortions In First Year After Change in Law
description: PARIS, Nov. 16 (AP)There were 45,085 reported abortions in France in 1975, the first year in which abortion on demand was legal, the National Assembly has been told.

description: It is now more than a year since New Yorkers voted decisively for sweeping changes in the city charter. Progressor lack of progresstoward implementing these changes is the timely topic of a series of State Charter Revision Commission hearings that opened yesterday at City Hall.

title: NEW BOND ISSUES UP DESPITE NIGH SALES
description: The credit markets, which had viewed this week's huge volume of new bond issues with more than a little apprehension, breezed through the first round yesterday. New issues generally sold readily enough, and bond prices moved high

title: Payton Expected to Be Even Bigger Star
description: It is just a figure, 1,000 yards, but in pro football it has not only significance but also prestige and exclusivity. Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears running back, joined the 1,000yard club last Sunday more or less on schedule and thus justified the views of all the scouts who, when they saw him in college at Jackson State, nodded sagely to one another and said collectively, Can't miss. Payton has gained 1,008 yards rushing this season and leads the league as the only runner over 1,000. With four games to go Payton could wind up with around 1,500 yards, which would put him in a class with 0. J. Simpson and Jim Brown.

title: Bridge:
description: Most followers of the game would be surprised to learn that Argentina has the world's best bridge team at this moment, demonstrably.

title: Advertising

title: Venezuelan Gives U.N .'s Assembly A Warning on Oil
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16The President of Venezuela, Carlos Andres Perez, warned today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would gauge an oil price increase directly to the measure of agreement achieved in talks under way between the rich and poor nations.

title: Mrozambique Says Rhodesian Forces paid Border Again
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 16 (AP)Mozambique charged today that Rliddesian forces searching for guerrillas used jets, bombers and helicopters as 010 crossed the border and attacked a Mozambique army base. There was no comment from Rhodesian officials on the report.

title: Rohaytn Said to Seek Candidate To Run Against Beanie Next Year
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, is seeking to line up a good government candidate to run against Mayor Beame in next year's Democratic primary, according to party politicians.

title: TV: Case of the Disappearing Evangelist
description: THE Disappearance of Aimee, Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on NBC this evening at 8, is an exceptionally attractive production looking desperately and unsuccessfully for a dramatic focus. Aimee, played by Faye Dunaway, is Aimee Semple McPherson, the Canadaborn evangelist who, while based in California, became an international figure in the 20's and survived into the 40's.

description: Robert M. Burns, a retired chemical engineer, died Sunday at his Concord, mass home. He was 86 years old.

description: Woody Herman started his career as a band leader 40 years ago in the old Brooklyn Roseland and, after years of practice, practice, he will play Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Mr. Herman and the Young Thundering Herd will appear in the tribute to his 40 years on the bandstand under the auspices of New Audiences and radio station WRVR.

description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Nov. 16The only thing officials of this Middlesex County community wanted to do was bring the tax rolls up to date. They never expected the process to bring them a cemetery. But it did, and now they aren't quite sure how to handle the new possession.

title: Wrong Veto
description: For the third time, the United States has used its veto to block the admission of Vietnam to the United Nations. William W. Scranton, the chief United States delegate, cited as the reason for the negative votethe only one among the Council membersVietnam's refusal to provide a fuller accounting for the 800 M.I.A.'s, Amercan servicemen still listed as missing in action in the Vietnam war.

title: Reuss Urges Acceleration in MoneySupply Growth
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss, the chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency, today called on the Federal Reserve Board to accelerate the growth of the nation's basic money supply to a little over 7 percent a year by the end of 1976 to stimulate the flagging economic recovery.

title: Young and Single In a Party Mood
description: One of my jobs, when 1 was little, was passing the trays of hors d'oeuvres at my parents cocktail parties. My specialty was arranging Wheat Thin borders, and folding the napkins in fancy ways, with crackers on the plate in flower and star designs, with Triscuit and silverware tucked inside like campers in sleeping bags. When I'd exhausted all the possibilities of napkin folding, I took to making place cards and radish roses and carved potato centerpieces and colored ice cubes, for the drinks. I didn't concern myself much with the taste of the food. (I was almost irritated, in fact, when a guest sampled a cracker and spoiled the symmetry of the tray.) To me, a party was much like a junior prom held in a house instead of a school gymnasium. And I couldn't wait to have parties of my own.

title: Wife of Witness Reported Kidnapped After a Jury Convicts 3 in Drug Case
description: The prosecutor hi a Federal heroinsmuggling trial reported yesterday that the wife of the Government's chief witness had apparently been kidnapped in an attempt to prevent the witness from testifying.

title: GILMORE, GIRLFRIEND TAKE DRUG OVERDOSE
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 16Gary Mark Gilmore, the condemned man who tried to expedite his own execution, was hospitalized today after taking an overdose of barbiturates in an apparent suicide pact with his girlfriend.

title: CARTER FACING CURB ON USE OF PATRONAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's patronage powers, and those of seven newly elected governors whose parties had been out of power, could be seriously impaired by a Supreme Court decision handed down last June, according to Federal officials and others familiar with the case.

title: Cold Spring Harbor Wins
description: GARDEN CITY, L.J., Nov. 16Cold Spring Harbor defeated Calhoun High School of. Merrick, 32, tonight and won the Nassau County scholastic soccer championship at the Garden City Pool field. Jeff Walker scored the winning goal for the Seahawks at 4:15"of the final period. Cold Spring Harb will meet North Babylon Friday night at Garden City for the Long Island championship.

title: P. S. Widens Lead In Toronto Show
description: TORONTO, Nov. 16The United State Equestrian Team strengthened its hold on first place in the race for the team championship when Dennis Murphy rode Tuscaloosa to victory in the international class tonight at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

title: Chile Will Release All But 20 Jailed Under State of Siege
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 16 (UPI)The military Government announced today that it was releasing more than 300 political prisoners, all but 20 held under the nation's state of siege.

title: AMERICAN NEWSMAN TOLD TO QUIT BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Nov. 16The British Government today ordered an American investigative reporter for a London newspaper to leave the country on the ground that he was a threat to national security. British and American officials here could recall no precedent for such an action against a foreignborn journalist.

title: Argentine Guerrillas Lose 10 in Raid
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16About 40 leftwing guerrillas attacked a suburban police station near La Plata, the capital of Buenos Aires Province, before dawn today but were driven off after 10 had been killed, according to security sources. Four policemen were reported wounded,

title: Carter Striving For Fast Action On His Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Presidentelect Jimmy Carter, evidently intent on a rapid takeover of the reins of government after his inauguration, has set Feb. 15 as a target date for presenting Congress his own budgetinbrief for the 1978 fiscal year, one of his principal aides said today.

description: CHICAGO. Nov. 16Lloyd McBride and Ed Sadlowski, the opposing candidates for the presidency of the United Steel Workers of America, attacked each other today in the first official debate of the union's election campaign.

description: Once, a raincoat was just that, coat to be worn in the rain, surfacing into higher consciousness only when it, was worn by Greta Garbo, say, in Anna Christie,  or Vivien Leigh in Waterloo Bridge, or, best of all, by Ingrid Bergman in Arch of Triumph. Miss Bergman wore a beret with her raincoat, which gave it cachet. Otherwise, of course, raincoats were for men.

description: Representatives of insurance broker associations warned yesterday that large numbers of motorists would start driving without insurance if the state approved proposed increases in automobile assigned risk rates. In some cases the rates would more than double.

title: New York Still Tops in Capital
description: Despite its problems, New York City remains the world's largest capital market and this has been the busiest week of the year, so far, for new financings. An outpouring of $3.5 billion in corporate, municipal and foreign bond offerings has coincided with $2.5 billion in Government notes and another $1.4 billion in Government agency obligations, for a total of $7.4 billion. Two issues of unusual interest yesterday were the direct offering by the Exxon Corporation and the moneyraising efforts by Canada's Province of Saskatchewan after taking over American assets in that province.

description: A solarpowered microwave relay tower, the first of its type for commercial service, will soon bring dial telephone service to the Navajo settlement of Medicine Hat on the San Juan River east of Lake Powell in southeastern Utah.

title: Rebel Who Found a Cause
description: What in the world would impel teenage girl in Hartford some 20 years ago to decide she simply had to be composer of serious music? Well, to some extent, as Barbara Kolb tells it, the same motive that impels any teenager to do anything weird: Parental opposition.

title: Flyers Top Wings On Late Goals, 20
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (AP)Orest Kindrachuk snapped a scoreless tie with just over two minutes remaining and Mel Bridgman scored into an open net in the final 7 seconds to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 2.0 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: DEBATE TRIGGERED ON JUVENILE CASES
description: CHERRY HILL, Nov. 16Reformers andjudges clashed today over a proposal to litnit juvenile court jurisdiction to criminal cases.

title: GOODMAN CHARGES CHARTER PLAN LAGS
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday that the Beame administration had failed to implement half of the revisions in the City Charter that were supposed to be in place by next Jan. 1.

title: AMERIGO F. CAPRIO
description: Amerigo F. Caprio, a chemist, who held more than 30 patents, died Monday at Madison, N.J., nursing home. He was 81 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: Firemen's Strike in Sixth Day
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 16 (UPI)A citywide firemen's strike, which has landed four union leaders in jail, entered its sixth day today without any negotiating sessions scheduled between the city and the union. Attorneys for the city and Local 37 of the International Association of Firefighters failed to turn up agreeable guidelines for negotiations during allday talks yesterday.

title: 4 Faces of Ellen Burstyn
description: Last year Ellen Burstyn was often asked, Why are there no roles for women? Her answer: Don't ask me. Ask the guys in Hollywood.

title: Luxurious Fruits of Fall
description: Seekers of gastronomic exotica should waste no time in getting to some of the city's more ambitious produce markets, there to obtain three of autumn's most interesting and least known fruitspersimmons, pomegranates and quince. All will continue to be available until about the first of the year.

title: College Football
Regents Urge Giving New York City More Aid at the Suburbs
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16A major change in New York State's aidtoeducation program, which would give New York City $42.19 million in additional funds by sharply reducing assistance to wealthier suburban districts in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties, was proposed today by the State Board of Regents.

title: Sony of Japan Seeks Westinghouse Plant
description: The Sony Corporation of Japan announced in Tokyo yesterday that it was negotiating to buy the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's television plant in Horseheads, N. Y. Terms were not disclosed.

title: JAPAN'S STEEL EXPORTS TO U.S. CLIMB SHARPLY
description: TOKYO, Nov. 16Japanese steel exports to the United States climbed sharply to 5,655,000 tons during the first nine months, an increase of 44.1 percent from a year earlier, a statistical survey issued by the Japan Iron and Steel Federation showed.

title: Separatist Who Will Govern Quebec

title: Music: Von Karaian's Verdi Requiem
description: ANOTHER of those living legends, Herbert von Karajan, concluded his current New York appearances with the Verdi Requiem last night in Carnegie Hall. In the last few days he and the Berlin Philharmonic, with the Vienna Singverein, have been presenting some of the masterpieces of the choral literature, and this was the grand finale.

title: WORLD JEWISH CONGRESS TO SEEK MOSCOW TALKS
description: GENEVA, Nov. 16The World Jewish Congress announced today that it was responding to overtures from Jews inside the Soviet Union by seeking exploratory talks with Moscow on the possibilities of Soviet Jewish relations with the World Jewish Congress.

title: GROUP OF BANKS LENDING $800 MILLION TO MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 16The Mexican Government signed an $800 million loan accord today with a consortium of international banks as part of its effort to bolster reserves after the recent outflow of capital and devaluation of the peso.

title: Recital: Miller at Piano
description: Works by John Cage and Milton Babbitt concluded the first and second halves of Robert Miller's piano recital at the Manhattan School Monday night, a concert sponsored by the Group for Contemporary Music. Perhaps this strategic location on the program was intentional, for these pieces were by some distance the most substantial of the evening.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An investment group headed by the First National State Bank of New Jersey and BacheHalsey Stuart Inc.. of New York was the successful bidder at an interest rate of 6.55 percent for $16.9 million in school bonds offered by the Newark City Council. Dennis Sullivan, the City Finance Director, said the sale represented an upward turn in the financial status of New Jersey's largest city, which twice last year rejected bads because the interest rate .offered exceeded 9 percent, and last December was unable to attract any bidders to a third bond sale. Mr. Sullivan attributed the success of the sale to the announcement yesterday that the Moody's Investors Services has raised the city's bond rating from a Baa grade to a grade of A.

title: Birds Hinted as Air Crash Cause
description: NAPLES, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP)Parts of birds have been found in an engine of the private jet that crashed on takeoff Friday from Naples Airport, injuring 11 persons, officials said today. We found beaks, claws and parts of birds in the right engine, said Henry Moyers, an air safety investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  President Ford has declared the Sudan eligible for the purchase of American military equipment. The move was described tonight by a State Department official as part of normalizing relationships with Sudan.

title: High Tides Around New York
A Korean Lobbyist With Global Links
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16At the center of the Justice Department's Investigation into South Korean efforts to influence United States policy is a wealthy businessman whose worldwide interests and operations are as difficult to penetrate as the carefully guarded findings of Federal investigators on the possible effects of his lavish giftgiving.

title: Hartwick Gains Final In Soccer
description: Hartwick, Howard and Clemson won their soccer matches yesterday to reach regional finals in the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs. St. Francis of New York and Philadelphia Textile also have advanced and three other regional finalists in the University Division will be determined today.

title: Notes on People
description: THE Miss World beauty contest in London is faced with a depleting list of candidates. Miss India, 18yearold Naina Balsaver, yesterday became the fourth contestant to walk out of the competition. Miss Balsaver withdrew at the request of her government in protest over South Africa's apartheid policies. South Africa is sending two candidates one black and one white. Contestants from Mauritius, Swaziland and Liberia already have quit the contest in protest.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16  Housing starts dipped in October but were still at the highest levels in more than..two years except for September the Commerce Department reported today.

The Bobcats had been ranked third the last two weeks.

title: General Motors Resisting U.A.W. On Organizing of Southern Plants
description: MONROE, La., Nov. 16Unlike many of his predecessors and some of his friends, Ronald G. Littleberry did not have to go North to find a good job. One that he never dreamed of came to him.

title: Film: After the Prom, the Horror
description: CARRIE is an elegant box lunch that got dropped. The wine is all over the rolls. Caviar is embedded in the turkey, and there is lettuce in the mousse. It is a mess, with bits of salvage floating usefully around in it.The newest film by Brian de Palma, who is often wrong but not dull, "Carrie" is billed as a horror movie. But it is sometimes funny in a puzzling kind of way, it is generally overwrought in an irritating kind of way, and once in a while it is inappropriately touching. It isn't frightening at all until the very end, and then it is briefly and extremely frightening.CarrieSissy Spacekis a Charles Addams-like teen-ager who lives with her mother in a Charles Addams-like house. The mother, played as a cracked belle by Piper Laurie, is a religious maniac. She hangs a picture of "The Last Supper" over the dining room table, and fills the house with candles and hysterical prayers.Carrie turns out friendly but strange. Her schoolmates loathe her strangeness. When she menstruates for the first time in the locker room and becomes hystericalthe only advice she gets from her mother is that menstruation is a sign of sexual impuritythe other girls shriek and mock her and pelt her with Tampax. They turn hysteria into something close to an epileptic seizure.In the process, however, Carrie discovers that, by concentrating, she can break ashtrays, make people fall off bicycles and worse. It's telekinesis, the movie explains.Well, this changes things. In a pretty funny scene, Carrie tells her mother, who had been shutting her in closets and tries to slop her from going to the prom, that she's in charge now. To underline the point, she makes all the windows in the house hang shut.The prom is a trick, however. Carrie's classmates have been punished for harassing her; to get even, they make a grisly plan whereby shethe wallfloweris taken to the prom by the class football star, elected beauty queen and then doused in pigs' blood. Her reprisals, via telekinesis, are as violent and devastating as an air raid. And there is one final bitthe movie's one real frightwhen she gets even with one of the girls who instigated the prom trick.Until this last bit, our reactions are in a constant state of short-circuitry. Mr. de Palma is our only pre-Raphaelite director. His apocalyptic scenes, bloody as they theoretically are, are too mannered and elegantly draped to be scary. It's Burne-Jones illustrating Dracula, and the result hovers between being ridiculous and making us smile because it is ridiculous.Mr. de Palma has ordered universal overacting. Piper Laurie does it with considerable gracethe wicked witch in a children's pantomime. The marvel, though, is Sissy Spacek. She makes us perfectly aware that she is overacting, and yet she is very effective. Her hysteria is far too hysterical. Her delight in being taken to the prom is far too radiant. But it moves us; and, in truth, the main horror in Carrie isn't the real bloodshed but our apprehension that her pleasure as well as her dress will be ruined by that bucket of pig blood."Carrie" opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters.

title: Quebec Votes Separatist
description: It all depends on my showing, said Robert Bourassa after leading the Liberal Party back to power in Quebec in 1970 and taking office as Premier of the largely Frenchspeaking province. If my Government can find jobs for all our people, they will see it is to their advantage to stay In Canada, and the separatists will lose strength.

title: Carter Striving For Fast Action On His Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16Presidentelect Jimmy Carter, evidently intent on a rapid takeover of the reins of government after his inauguration, has set Feb. 15 as a target date for presenting Congress his own budgetinbrief': for the 1978 fiscal year, one of his principal aides said today.

description: PEKING, Nov. 16 (Reuters)China's northern earthquake zone was recovering today from a severe jolt that rocked major cities almost 400 miles apart.

title: Memory Of the Best of All Feast.
description: It was, perhaps, the best Thanksgiving of my life. There:was a late Indian summer in the. Napa. Valley, about 25 years ago, and the vineyards had blazed with color:. And then instead of letting the leaves drop, the vines had held on to most of them. If you walked among them they crackled like cold fire. The light was brilliant from all the red, yellow and gold, and from a sky that, at noon, was more an October's bright blue than the softer haziness of late November.

title: Liner Carrying Pilgrims Sinks
description: TRIESTE, Italy, Nov. 16 (UPI)The liner Blue Sea burned and sank Sunday in the harbor of Jidda, Saudi Arabia, where it had arrived with about 1,000 pilgrims bound for Mecca, reports reaching here said today. They said there were no casualties on the ship,

title: Newsweek Barred by Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 16 (Reuters)  The Indonesian Government has banned Newsweek magazine from the country indefinitely, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office said today. Its action followed the banning of the magazine's Nov. 8 issue, which carried an article described by the Foreign Ministry as hostile to President Suharto and his wife.

title: Congressional Watergate?
description: For the last several years, a mysterious Korean businessman known as Tongsun Park has been exceptionally active in Washington political and social circles. He was the chief organizer of a luxurious private club in Georgetown where, according to one informed estimate, about 300 members of Congress were entertained at parties at one time or another. But entertainment was only the beginning of Mr. Park's activities.

description: TRENTON, Nov. 16 (AP)A 55,yearold seamstress from Manhattan, who said she was out of work, won $50,000 a year for 20 years, or $1 million, the New Jersey Lottery today.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)Personal income increased 0.7 percent in October as pay raises for Federal workers helped offset cuts in factory employment, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: The BankAmerica Corporationthe nation's largest banking concern  announced here yesterday that it would publish a substantial amount of previously confidential information about its operations under the terms of a new disclosure code it has adopted.

description: The New York City Police Department plans to audit the books on about 360 vending machines that dispense coffee, soda, cigarettes and other items at police stations and other police buildings to determine the amount of profits they produce and what is being done with that money.

title: Connors Defeats Riessen, Orantes Is Upset by Okker
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 (UPI)Topseeded Jimmy Connors scored a 63, 63 victory over Marty Riessen today and reached the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Benson and Hedges Griicl Prix tennis tournament at Wembley. Connors's 65minute victory earned him a match against Stan Smith, who crushed Haroon Rahim of Pakistan, 61, 60.

title: 2 Acorns In Peanutsville

She treated us like we were her old friends from Plains, I was really surprised when we asked her about the issuesshe said 'Oh, I don't know about the issues  and she seemed like such a smart person up to that point. description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17Samuel Bronfman 2d testified today that Dominic P. Byrne, one of his two alleged kidnappers, had offered to free him midway into his nine days of captivity in August 1975 but that he had rejected the bid at that point.

title: SUPERHEAVY ELEMENT CALLED NONEXISTENT
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Nov. 17Dr. Albert Ghiorso, the leader of the American quest for superheavy elements, said today that he was convinced they did not exist, adding that he was greatly relieved because they might have been used to make miniature atomic bombs.

title: TV: Compelling Drama Tonight
description: The impression of authenticity in Liza's Pioneer Diary, the presentation on public television's Visions series tonight at 9, is hardly an accident. The orinal drama was written, produced and directed by Nell Cox, whose apprenticeship for this project, the first featurelength film she has directed, includes many years as an editor for LeacockPennebaker Productions, prominent documentary makers. Liza's Pioneer Diary is completely fictional, but the treatment is carefully larded with details that convey an uncanny realism.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The latest signs of slowdown in the economy, notably Monday's report of an October dip in industrial production, have triggered fresh talk about a quick antirecession tax cut in 1977. However, some Democrats and some labor leaders, particularly those in the building trades, would prefer publicservice employment or public works projects.

title: The New Presidentialese
description: WASHINGTONAt a longplanned news conference, which has replaced the hastily called press conference, the late Frank Sullivan's clich expert, Dr. Arbuthnot, revealed the parameters of the new Presidentialese to the official translators.

title: The Mars Experiment
description: Mars went behind the sun earlier this month, thus interrupting for a time communications between Earth and the instruments landed on the Martian surface by the successful Viking 1 and 2 rockets. The temporary halt in the receipt of new data permits a preliminary evaluation of what has been accomplished since last summer's historic landings.

title: Unilever Group Reports Advance Of 29% in Its 3dQuarter Earnings

This continued the recovery in earnings shown in the first two quarters this year, after a fluctuating pattern in the last two years.

title: 'Tycoon' Echoes 30's Hollywood
description: "Not half a dozen men have been able to keep the whole equation of pictures in their heads," says the narrator of F. Scott Fitzgerald's "The Last Tycoon."For a brief period in the late 20's and 30's, Irving Thalberg could. Thalberg, the production chief at M-G-M, a "boy genius" until his death at the age of 37 in 1936, appeared to be able to divine successful films as mysteriously as other people found water with a forked stick of witch hazel.The equation he held in his head told him how much a certain kind of picture would gross, which, in turn, told him how much could be profitably spent on its production. He knew whose brains to rent. The capacities of directors, writers and actors were as apparent to him as labeled contents. He could cut four minutes from a dreary 100-minute movie in such a way to make it seem a single, breathless experience of 60 minutes. In those days, moviespicturesdidn't waste time getting to points.Thalberg was responsible for good films and bad. Though his genius was made possible by the period, when Hollywood and its public were one, he was regarded with awe, as if he possessed not simply a knack for pictures but the secret of life.All of these things are contained in the muted and thoughtful, sad but unsentimental film version of "The Last Tycoon" about Fitzgerald's Thalberg-like hero named Monroe Stahr. Written by Harold Pinter, and directed by Elia Kazan, the movie attempts to take Hollywood seriously, without hoopla and grotesqueries, and especially to take Thalberg-Stahr seriously.Fitzgerald didn't live to finish "The Last Tycoon," so that the version published in 1941, edited by Edmund Wilson with Fitzgerald's notes, is technically a fragment, yet it's a very complete satisfying fragment, a quality that the film preserves through an abrupt kind of editing style and a narrative that's without conventional shape.Thalberg died before being overtaken by defeat. In the film, Monroe Stahr does not. Stahr, who is played with reticent passion by Robert De Niro, whose lean, dark good looks seem an idealization of Thalberg's, becomes a casualty of the "new" Hollywood of Wall Street investors, bankers and union organizers that Fitzgerald could see in the future."The Last Tycoon," which opened yesterday at the Cinema I, is a very low-key movie, and so full of associationsto Thalberg, to the stories one knows of Hollywood in the 30's, to Fitzgerald's own life and careerthat it's difficult to differentiate between what one is seeing on the screen and what one is bringing to it."The Last Tycoon" doesn't really build to any climax. We follow it horizontally, as if it were a landscape being surveyed by a camera in a long pan-shot. The background is Hollywood in the Golden Thirties, when studios turned out 30 to 40 pictures a year and every backlot could simultaneously contain pictures set in New York, Africa, the South Pole and Montmartre.In the foreground are scenes from the curious life of Monroe Stahr as he edits several films at once, deals with neurotic actors and directors, maneuvers in corporate battles, and carries on an affair with a mysterious English girl whom he loves and loses.In one of his final notes for "The Last Tycoon," Fitzgerald wrote in capital letters, "Action Is Character." It is one of the achievements of Messrs. Kazan, Pinter and De Niro that so much of Monroe Stahr succeeds in coming through in the film. Other characters that are so vivid in the book simply don't have enough time on screen, though both Robert Mitchumas Stahr's studio adversaryand Jack Nicholsonas the union organizerare extremely effective. Jeanne Moreau and Tony Curtis make brief, flashy appearances as idols of the old-time silver screen.Ingrid Boulting, who plays Stahr's mysterious English love, is beautiful in an eccentrically large-eyed way, and there are times when she doesn't seem to know how to read a line or where to put her hands. At other moments she is totally, serenely sure of herself, which may or may not be acting but does suggest the odd quality that drew Stahr to her. I also liked another new actress, Theresa Russell, who plays the Hollywood-born, Bennington-educated girl who narrates the novel but is simply a supporting character in the film.None of the changes that Mr. Pinter has made in the novel seem to me to damage the style or mood of the book. More than any other screen adaptation of a Fitzgerald workwith the exception of Joan Micklin Silver's fine adaptation of the short story "Bernice Bobs Her Hair""The Last Tycoon" preserves original feeling and intelligence. The movie is full of echoes. We watch it as if at a far remove from what's happening, but that too is appropriate: Fitzgerald was writing history as it happened.

title: British Union Leaders Unhurt
description: MADRID, Nov. 17 (Reuters)Two of Britain's top tradeunion leaders were shaken but uninjured in Spain today when their car left a mountain road and stopped just short of a precipice after striking a pile of earth. The two menLionel Murray, General Secretary of the Trades Union Congress, and Jack Jones, leader of the powerful Transport and General Workers Union, were in Spain as part of a British factfinding mission visiting at the invitation of the illegal Spanish General Union of Workers.

title: Lortogs Seeking Reorganization Under Chapter XI Bankruptcy
description: Lortogs Inc., a producer of children's and girls apparel, filed yesterday for financial reorganization under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, NOV. 17New Jersey banking and law enforcement officials clashed today with the United States Attorney over who should get credit for the recent indictment of bank officials accused of misusing bank funds to finance gambling and loanshark operations.

title: Macy Net Up 3% on 10% Sales Gain
description: R. H. Macy & Company, New York's largest retailer and an operator of leading department stores in other areas as well, had a 3 percent increase in its net income in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 30. Sales rose 10.2 percent over the yearearlier period.

title: Roosevelt and LI OTB Display Spirit of Detente
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 17In a distinct atmosphere of togetherness, George Morton Levy, president of Roosevelt Raceway, met today with the heads of the offtrack betting corporations of Nassau and Suffolk Counties to super vise the selection of post At the positions for Saturday Race night's $50,000 Silver Spoon pacing final. The drawing, Tracks held at a luncheon at the Island Inn, underlined the spirit of cooperation among Levy and Easa Ease and Syd Askoff, presidents of Nassau and Suffolk OTB, respectively. The two OTT corporations have contributed more than $15,000 apiece in promotion of the Silver Spoon series, which carried an overall value of $150,000 when it began on Nov. 4.

title: Gabon Closes Northern Border
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Nov. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)President AlbertBernard Bongo today ordered Gabon's northern frontiers closed arter a rocket attack yesterday on a police border post. Mr. Bongo, who was speaking at Lambarene, in the West African nation, said that uniformed men had fired rockets and thrown explosives at the newly constructed Meyokye Sud border post, largely destroying it. He added that the attack, by men arriving in two vehicles, occurred shortly after a meeting on the frontier between senior officers of the Cameroon and Gabon national police forces.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN TRIAL OF MANDEL
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 17The prosecution has finally rested its complex corruption oase against Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, 10 weeks after the trial began Sept. 8.

title: McDonnell to Meet Taxi Owners And Drivers in Separate Talks

He met with both sides in the dispute yesterday, but did not report any progress toward settlement of their contract dispute.

title: Beginnings of Power Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17There is saying in Washington that a President's Itrm begins not on the date of his inougura.tion but on the day of his election, find in some sense this is already true of the FordCarter transition in spite of the repeated disclaimers from the Presidentelect. News When he decided to stage Analysis his transition to the Presidency from Plains, Ga., rather than set himself up in Washington, the private explanation came from his aides that he did not want to Crowd President Ford in his final weeks in office or poach on his Presidential domain.

description: The New York Mets said last night that Jerry Grote, their No. 1 catcher for 10 years, was intent: on retiring because of a chronic back ailment.
