description: MIAMI, Nov. 7 (UPI)A suit to foreclose on the Fontainebleau Hotel at Miami Beach has been withdrawn because Ben Novack, the owner, came up with $250,000 in back payments.

title: City College Senate Votes To Suspend Newspaper For Journalistic Abuses
description: Charging journalistic abuses by the editors of The Campus, the 96yearold student newspaper of the College of the City of New York, the student senate voted yesterday afternoon to suspend the weekly's charter. The senate will decide, meanwhile, whether to revoke the charter altogether.

title: Survey of Coast Saving Institutions Finds Wide Range of Interest Paid
description: A survey of savings institutions by a California consumer group found a 45 percent difference in interest paid by the topranked savings and loan association and the lowestrated commerical bank.

title: Nuggets Overwhelm Nets, 11278, For 10th Victory in 11 Outings
description: DENVER, Nov. 17 (AP)Dan Issel scored 9 points to pace an awesome secondquarter Denver splurge tonight that paced the Nuggets to a 11278 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets.

description: PEKING, Nov. 17 (Reuters)Teng Yingchao, the 73yearold widow of Prime Minister Chou Enlai, has , returned to public life in the wake of the purge of socalled radicals.

title: 60 MINUTEMAN MISSILES ARE ORDERED BY PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The Administration, concerned over the lack of progess in negotiations with the Soviet Union, for a new strategic arms limitation agreement, has decided to build 60 more Minuteman III longrange ballistic missiles, Pentagon, spokesmen said today.

title: Hynes Calls for a Federal Battle Against Fraud in Health Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17New York State's special nursinghome prosecutor called today for the creation of a new Justice Department unit to combat fraud in health care programs and to finance state investigations of abuses in public programsinvestigations such as the one that led to the indictment Monday of 26 home owners, operators and suppliers alleged to have engaged in Medicaid kickback schemes.

title: Mrs. Carter Planning Active Role in Capitol
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) Rosalynn Carter plans to hold frequent news conferences, will have an active role as a policy adviser and will pursue her interests with the mentally retarded and the problems of the aged in the new Jimmy Carter Administration, her press secretary said today.

title: Municipal Officials Are Concerned By 5 Percent Ceiling on Budgets
description: ATLANTIC CITY, NOV. 17Local concerns over budget restrictions included in the new state income tax package were cited today at the 61st annual conference of the State League of Municipalities.

title: Black Rhodesian Leader Accuses 2 Others of Cheap Power Politics
description: GENEVA, Nov. 17Bishop Abel Muzorewa, leader of one of the black nationalist factions at the conference on the future of Rhodesia, accused two other black leaders today of resorting to cheap power politics.

title: Abdul Bhashani, Bengali Leader And Moslem Guru, Is Dead at 97
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov. 17 (Reuters) Abdul Hamid Bhashani, a Bengali politician and Moslem leader, died in Dacca's Medical College Hospital tonight. He was believed to he 97 years old. He was admitted to the hospital three weeks ago with a heart condition and acute bronchitis.

title: NC Agrees to Settle Suit by U.S.; Will Curb Financial Stake in Shows
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The National Broadcasting Company agreed today to a settlement of the Government's antitrust suit against it on terms that will severely restrict both the number of networkowned entertainment programs that NBC may broadcast and the financial interests it may have in entertainment programs owned by others.

title: F5's Crash in Morocco
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Nov. 17 (Reuters)Two F5 jet fighters collided and crashed here today while flying past an independence day parade being reviewed by iKng Hassan H. One pilot died, and two persons were killed on the ground, when one of the planes crashed in a cemetery near the city. The other pilot ejected and landed safely.

title: Iranian Linked to Killing Of 3 Americans Is Slain In Exchange With Police
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 17 (UPI)  A terrorist who allegedly masterminded the murder of three Americans on a Teheran street last August has been killed by his own grenade during a clash with the police, officials here announced today.

description: Dorothy Sara, a graphologist, author, former editor and faculty member for many years of the Henry George School of Social Science, died Tuesday in Columbus Hospital in New York City after a heart attack. She lived at 10 Park Avenue and was 79 years old.

title: Navy Reserve Pilot Lost off Carrier
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 17 (AP)A civilian pilot on Navy Reserve duty was reported lost at sea today after his Corsair 11 jet attack plane slid off the carrier Ranger during a landing attempt. He was identified only as a member of Reserve Attack Squadron 305 based at Point Mugu near Oxnard. As the plane approached the carrier last night to land, it hit the flight deck and slid off into the ocean.

title: ACCOUNTING BOARD HEAD REJECTS REASSESSMENT
description: Marshall S. Armstrong, chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, rejected yesterday recent urging that a special committee be reconvened to assess the hoard's performance.

title: U.S. Homes Said to Waste Fuel
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP)New American homes waste energy, a panel of research and building specialists said today. William Graves of Brookhaven National Laboratories in New York said, Thirty percent of the energy we use is used in buildings and half the heat now produced in a furnace goes up the stack.

title: Nonsectarian Hospitals in Jersey Are Ordered to Permit Abortions
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that nonprofit, nonsectarian hospitals could not prohibit the use of their facilities for abortions.

description: GOODALLDr. Ralph E. He left will% out even saying goodbye on NOV. 18, 1974. So unlike him. A good friend, who has been deeply missed.

title: Park Plan for Staten Island Is Killed
description: The proposal for a $40 million, 146acre Staten Island amusement parkwhich for months has pitted Mayor Beanie against the angry opposition of hundreds of Staten Island residents and all of their elected representativeswas in effect killed last night when the Mayor's representative on the Board of Estimate announced the Mr. Beame would no longer support it.

title: New York Follows Beame Into Jerusalem's City Hall
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 16  Sixteen American mayors, sonic of them showing signs of jet lag, sat with the Jerusalem City Council yesterday and talked of areana dear to themcapital developments, sewage, rates of indebtedness and the like.

title: Radio
Other Companies List Their Earnings Results
Stronger U S. Civil Defense Effort Urged by an Industry Study Group
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16The Joint Congressional Committee on Defense Production was told by an industry study group today that the United States must increase its civil defense efforts to maintain the nuclear deterrent balance with the Soviet Union.

title: REPORT ON CONRAD CASE FOR RCA STILL NOT READY
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that a report on Aanthony L. Conrad's resignation as chairman two months ago was not yet complete. The company said a month ago that a final report was expected within a few weeks:

title: SLAVERY IN THE EMPIRE SUBJECT OF A TV SERIES
description: The battle to abolish slavery and the slave trade in the British Empire is the subject of a sixpart British Broadcasting Corporation television series, The Fight Against Slavery, which will first appear in the United States for six consecutive Mondays beginning Nov. 29 at 9 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13. The episodes will be rebroadcast the following Saturday evening.

title: FOREIGN SERVICE GROUP VOTES TO OUST PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UN)  The career diplomats in the State Department have voted overwhelmingly to oust the president of their professional organization, it was announced today.

title: ANNEMARIE SNELLMAN
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 17 (AP)AnneMarie Snellman, a former Associated Press correspondent in Helsinki, died today after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

title: U.A.W. Members Approve Contract With Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17  Rankandfile members of the United Automobile Workers have narrowly approved a threeyear labor contract with the Chrysler Corporationthereby relieving the fears of union officials that skilled workers would veto the agreement.

title: City College Medal to Giardino For His Service to New York
description: Alfred A. Giardino, former chairman of the Board of Higher Education, received City College's 1976 John H. Finley Medal for distinguished service to the City of New York at the 96th annual dinner of the college's Alumni Association in the Roosevelt Hotel last night.

title: Zoning Out the Porn
description: The cleanup efforts that come and go like Times Square's dingy snows have proved to he an exercise in redundant futility. Neither missionary zeal, nor economic outrage, nor political opportunism, nor transient law enforcement, can stop the completion of the pimp's or prostitute's appointed rounds or the efflorescence of seedy sex establishments.

title: Campaign Against Waste
description: The reforms of the distribution of state aid to the schools proposed by the Board of Regents aim at correcting present scandalous inequities. The existing approach to the disbursement of approximately $3 billion in state aid has the effect of steadily widening the gap between poor and rich districts, with special penalties for the hardpressed cities,

title: Study Finds No Evidence to Support Contention That HighFiber Diet Can Prevent Heart Disease
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 17A carefully designed study has found no evidence to support the popular contention that a highfiber diet can prevent heart disease.

title: Syrian Troops Search Cars to Keep Guns Out of Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 17 (AP)Syrian troops serving in a peacekeeping mission here today searched cars entering Beirbt in an effort to keep weapons out of the capital, now quiet after 19 months Of civil war.

title: Galt MacDermot Singing And Playing Show Tunes On Piano at the Ballroom
description: Most of the composers and lyricists who have appeared so far in the Broadway at the Ballroom series at the Ballroom, 458 West Broadway, have depended on a singing style that made up in enthusiasm or personal involvement for whatever it might lack in polish. Their piano playing has been, at best, serviceable. But this week, with Galt MacDermot, composer of Hair, Two Gentlemen of Verona, Dude, Via Galactica and a number of lesserknown efforts, on the stand, the tables are being turned.

title: Soap Box Derby Set for Aug. 20
description: AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 17 (AP)The directors of the AllAmerican Soap Box Derby have set Aug. 20 as the date for next year's 40th running of the gravity classic. Derby officials said that they expected 200 contestants, up from about 160 this year.

title: Mr. Carter And Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Two months before he becomes President, Jimmy Carter is being importuned to play a quasiofficial role on this issue and that. The British want him in on plans for support of the pound. The State Department would like him to send a tough private message to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries warning against an oil price increase.

title: Investment Firms Buy 90% of Bonds In Exxon Auction
description: More than 90 percent of the bonds sold publicly by Exxon Tuesday were purchased by six investment hankers or groups of investment bankers for resale.

title: KISSINGER IS WILLING TO HELP ON MIDEAST; ? and Aides Believe That Carter Will Have Good Opportunity to Achieve Peace in Area
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger says the Carter Administration will inherit an unprecedented opportunity to help achieve peace in the Middle East, and he is willing to lend advice on how to accomplish it.

title: Ghanaian Poet Who Taught in U.S. Is Out of Jail and Back in African University Post
description: CAPE COAST, Ghana, Nov. 14Kofi Awoonor, the internationally known poet who was released from prison last month after a trial that found him guilty of helping an accused antiGovernment plotter to escape, has resumed his teaching position at this sunbleached university town On the sea..

title: I.M.F., in Shift, to Sell Gold Dec. 3 At the Average of Acceptable Bids
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The International Monetary Fund announced today that the 780,000 ounces of gold it will sell at its fifth auction on Dec. 8 will be offered at the average price of acceptable bids. Gold will be delivered to successful bidders through the Bank of England.

title: Books of The Times
description: Just as the United States 20year war in Southeast Asia was only superficially about Communism, so the Thirty Years War of 1618.48 was only tangentially about religion, even though creedal fanaticisms might deceive the unwary. It was a tangled, sinistrous conflict that was fought over issues of economic and political power. At its end, in the Peace of Westphalia, the Holy Roman Empire was in shards, Germany lay in ruins from which it took at least a century to recover and France emerged as a nationstate in the West, albeit to face a civil war.

title: U.S. GIVES THREE STATES $124 MILLION IN JOB AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Treasury Department today mailed checks totaling $124 million to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to help state and local governments pay for employee services that they might otherwise have curtailed.

title: Canine Carriers Presents Advice On Flying Pet Safely and Quickly
description: It's as safe to ship a dog today as it is to transport a person, if you follow the rules, said Robert Bronner, president of Canine Carriers, with headquarters in Darien, Conn. You should get the dog to the airport on time, be certain he is picked New s up on arrival, that he has the proper crate and is in of good health. Bronner Dogs speaks with authority for his company ships from 20 to 25 pets a week in the tristate area. A crate should be large enough so the dog can stand, turn and lie down, he added. However, the dog isn't wearing a seat belt, so it shouldn't be too large.

title: Staten Island Amusement Park Plan Is Killed as Beame Ends His Support
description: The proposal for a 40 million, 146acre Staten Island amusement parkwhich for months has pitted Mayor Beanie against the angry opposition of hundreds of Staten Island residents and all of their elected representativeswas killed last n1ght when the Mayor's representative on the Board of Estimate announced he would no longer support it.

title: Army Puts Over for 90 Days Action on Closing Arsenal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 (UPI)The Army had decided to postpone for 90 days any actions on the closing of the Frankford Arsenal, which is scheduled to shut down in September 1977.

title: Poll Finds Meditation, Mysticisrri And Yoga Growing in Popularity
description: Some meditate privately before breakfast, others join a weekend yoga retreat or sing lustilly with Pentecostals. But whatever the form and style, Americans in growing numbers are trying spiritual or mindexpanding disciplines that were little known in this country a few years ago.

title: Deaths
PREMIER IN LISBON HAILS U.S. APPROVAL OF A LOAN
description: LISBON, Nov. 17  Prime Minister Mario Soares declared today that the Ford Administration's approval of a $300 million loan to Portugal was a demonstration of confidence in Portuguese democracy and the first constitutional government.

title: REGENTS MEET TO WEICP THE STATUS OF NYQUIST
description: The New York State Board of Regents met in executive session yesterday to consider the future status of Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner, whose resignation had been requested by a majority of the board.

title: Pitt Team Chooses Sugar Bowl Berth
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 17 (UPI)In a rote by seniors and starters, the topranked Pittsburgh football team chose the Sugar Bowl over the Orange and Cotton Bowls as the postseason game in which it would most like to play, but Coach Johnny Majors said today the final decision would be made by the school administration.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)China set off its largest nuclear explosion today, prompting United States officials to activate a nationwide network to monitor radioactive fallout from the blast.

title: Dallas Cancels Kennedy Memorial
description: DALLAS, Nov. 17 (UPI) The city where President Kennedy was assassinated 13 years ago next Monday has canceled this year's public memorial service at the downtown assassination site because of declining local interest, the mayor's office said today. Mayor Robert Folsom wrote the Greater Dallas Council of Churches, traditional sponsor of the event, and said, It was getting so we had more organizers than participants. We thought we could reach more people through their individual houses of worship rather than asking people to journey to the site,

title: ANOTHER AMERICAN TOLD TO QUIT BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Nov. 17Philip Agee, a former Central Intelligence Agency employee who has exposed some of the agency's secrets, has been served deportation papers here, the British Government said today.

title: Joseph Block, 82, Dies
description: Joseph Block, an importer of china and cookware, died yesterday at his home. He was 82 years old and lived at 25 East 86th Street.

title: Holdups for Narcotics and Money Peril the Neighborhood Druggist
description: The neighborhood druggist, once a fixture in every part of the city, has become an endangered species.

title: Newspaper Upheld in Libel Suit When Lack of Malice Is Shown
description: DENVER, Nov. 17 (AP)A $1.1 million libel suit against The Rocky Mountain News was dismissed on the ground that the newspaper had not acted with malice since it had not known its articles about an undertaker's alleged mishandling of body were erroneous,

title: OILPRICE HOPES LIFT DOW 2.74 TO 938M8
description: The stock market advanced yesterday. buoyed by hopes of a postponement of an increase in world oil prices.

title: Bronfman Says One Captor Offered to Free Him
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov, 17Samuel Bronfman 2d testified today that Dominic P. Byrne, one of his two alleged kidnappens, had offered to free him midway into his nine days of captivity in August 1975 but that he had rejected the bid at that point.

title: 3 Teachers Charged With Fixing Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The Justice Department today charged three motor carrier organizations with conspiring illegally to fix intrastate truck rates in Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina and Tennessee.

title: Cozza Expresses Regrets at Having to Relinquish Yale Coaching Post
description: Carmen Cozza did not want to relinquish the Yale head football coaching job just yet. He had hoped to remain in that post for at least two more seasons because of personal goals and the simple desire to stay in coaching. But the most successCollege ful Eli football coach did Sports not go kicking and screaming when it became clear Notes on Monday the Yale Corporation wanted him to step down. He went quietly into the fulltime work as Yale's director of ath

title: Connally Doubts Carter's Ability To Reorganize the Government
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally has predicted that Presidentelect Jimmy Carter will have little success in reorganizing the Federal Government.

title: Bello Again Testifies He Saw Rubin Carter and Artis at Slaying Scene
description: PATERSON, N. J., Nov: 17  Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Ards, their second trial for a triple murder here 10 years ago, were identified today as the gunmen seen by the same witness, Alfred P. Bello, who had testified against them in their first trial and who testified again today, in front of the jury.

title: Con Ed Picks 2 MidHudson Areas As Possible Sites for a Power Plant
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. l7Consolidated Edison announced today that had selected two areas in the midHudson Valley as possible sites for a gigantic new generating station to provide power for the metropolitan area in the 1990's.

title: U.S. Calls on Business to Help Shape Technical Aid to Developing Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Ford Administration invited business, labor and educational leaders to help plan a United States policy for transferring technology to developing countries at a daylong conference here today.

title: 2 Die in Carolina Hotel Blaze
description: LEXINGTON, N.C., Aug. 17 (UPI)Two persons were killed and six others injured last night in a fire that swept through the old twostory Lexington Hotel. The two dead persons were trapped on the top floor of the building, where firemen believe the blaze began about 10 P.M. The cause of the fire was not known.

title: Chrysler Tank Contract Is Seen Helping Connecticut
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Nov. 17The Army's choice last week of the Chrysler Corporation as the primary contractor for its proposed new generation of battle tanks may help fuel this hardhit industrial state's economic, recovery 18 to 24 months from now and may help assure relative prosperity for the state in the 1980's.

title: A Subway Elongatomus? Why, It's Preposterous!
description: Ever hear of a Thesaurus Rex, the dinosaur that had a vocabulary of a thousand words? Or Elongatomus, an elongated critter that stretched from coast to coast whose pelvic remains support a highway interchange in Missouri?

title: Jury Bribery in Narcotics Acquittal Is Alleged in Federal Investigation
description: A charge that jurors may have been bribed to acquit the defendants in a major narcotics trial last year is under investigation by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan.

description: Pouring King Kong Off to a Start

title: Bullets Inflict a 11197 Defeat on Knicks
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 17While standing outside the Washington locker room after the Bullets 11197 victory over the New York Knicks tonight, Elvin Hayes said he was planning no special celebration for his 31st birthday. He appeared fully satisfied that the Bullets had just taken the Knicks apart like a piece of cake.

title: High Grain Executive Is Sentenced To Three Months in Cheating Plot
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17A Federal judge imposed today a threemonth prison term on a Greenwich, Conn., man who is the highest ranking grain company executive convicted so far in the continuing investigation of corruption in the grain export industry.

title: Young Doctor Repairs Injured Birds of Prey
description: ST. PAULDr. Patrick Redig held the large Xray film up to the window of his office, and the crooked bone of the right wing of the redtail hawk showed up clearly.

title: Prices Are Firm in Credit Markets; Reception Excellent for New Issues
description: Active trading and a firm price tone prevailed yesterday in the Government securities and corporate bond markets. New issues, heavily weighted with international offerings, met with an excellent receation on the part of buyers. Saskatchewan, the Canadian province, came south of the Credit border to Wall Street and Markets saw a sellout of its $125 million of 30year debentures priced to yield 8.70 percent. The issue is rated doubleA.

title: Israel Sees No Sign That Syria Seeks .Confrontation
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 17Israel, which has been warily monitoring developments during the long months of war in Lebanon, views that country as likely in the long run to become a more hostile neighbor now that it is under Syrian domination.

Rudi, Campaneris, Dave Cash Signed
description: Like tenpins in a bowling alley, three more of baseball's free agents fell into linethe contract signing lineyesterday while at least one more stood poised with pen in hand and another learned that his novel proposal's were not as acceptable to owners as pure money.

title: UTILITY RATE INCREASES ARE OPPOSED BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that he had directed Corporation Counsel W. Bernard Richland to oppose the requests filed by the New York Telephone Company and Consolidated Edison with the Public Service Commission for higher phone and natural gas rates.

title: 7 ARE NAMED TO SHARE 5 ROCKEFELLER AWARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP)Seven persons have been named to share the 1976 Rockefeller Awards for outstanding public service.

title: FUNERAL FOR JEAN GABIN: Crowd at the Pere Lachaise Cemetery in Paris waits for body of Jean Gabin, the actor, to be taken into the crematorium, at right. His ashes will be scattered in the Atlantic Ocean, off Brittany. Mr.,Gabin died Monday at the age of 72.

title: Election Divisions in Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 17  Quebec Province's momentous election on Monday has left this metropolis geographically divided into federalist and separtist camps. A casual look at the latest electoral map

description: LOS ANGELESWhen the wife of Jim Nelson, a 39yearold electrical contractor, decided recently that she wanted new draperies for their home here, the family got the draperies without spending a cent.

description: International

title: Recital: Boris Bloch in Piano Debut
description: In the second half of his debut recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night, Boris Bloch turned to Prokofiev's Four Pieces (Op. 4), Busoni's Carmen Fantasy and Liszt's Spanish Rhapsody. Most Of these are fingerbreakers, but they seemed like simple exercises to the 25yearold pianist, who was horn in Odessa, studied there and in Moscow and now lives in this country.

title: New York Tightens Regulations For Obtaining Property Tax Cuts
description: Property owners seeking reductions in their assessed valuations will be required from now on to submit more precise and detailed information to the New York City Tax Commission.

title: CARTER ASKS LEADERS OF CONGRESS TO HELP IN A REORGANIZATION
description: LOVEJOY, Ga., Nov. 17Presidentelect Jimmy Carter asked 15 Democratic Congressional leaders today to have Congress restore early next year the President's power to propose Government reorganization plans, subject to the veto of Congress.

title: Maritime Fruit Carrier Files Suit Against Bankers Trust Group
description: The Maritime Fruit Carriers Company, an Israelbased shipping corporation, said yesterday in New York that it sued a group of banks and individuals, alleging that they acted to the company's detriment.

description: Braniff and British Airways Plan Dallas Concorde Flights

title: Utah Killer Is Recovering After an Overdose of Drugs
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 17Gary Mark Gilmore, angry and abusive, appeared on the road to recovery today after the condemned murderer took an overdose of barbiturates in an attempt to fulfill his wish to die.

title: CARTER DRIVE'S COST IS PUT AT $35 MILLION
description: PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 17Jimmy Carter spent $35 million in his successful, twoyear run for the Presidency, with signalCant contributions coming from fellow Georgians, Carter campaign officials disclosed today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Julia, the Central Park Zoo's unruly, 30yearold elephant, survived a medical examination under anesthesia yesterday afternoon, according to zoo officials. They said it had been conducted by Dr. Michael H. Milts, the zoo's. veterinarian, to determine if a physical ailment was causing Julia's uncharacteristic recent rampages.

title: Meadowlands Results
Around the Nation
description: HARRISONBURG, Va., Nov. 17 (upt)Mary .Baldwin College has signed an agreement to pay $1.12 million for Staunton Military Academy, which at one time was one of the most prestigious schools for young men in the South.

title: BIRTH PILL SURVEY CITES BENIGN LIVER TUMOR RISE
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 17 (UPI)A new study indicates that there may be a link between the use of birth control pills and the increasing number of benign liver tumors in women.

title: Mother of 3 Is Charged With Murder and Arson In Death of Her Children
description: SOMERS, N. Y., Nov. 17The 42yearold mother of three young children who died in a fire at their home here early Monday morning was arrested today and charged with three counts of seconddegree murder and one of arson.

title: Notes on People
description: At least three lameduck CongressMen are off on factfinding trips in vitrious parts of the world at government expense. Rep. William S. Randall, Democrat of Missouri, is on a 16day tour of Rumania, Yugoslavia, France and West Germany. An aide said that Mr. Randall, who is chairman of the Select Committee on Aging, is studying among other things, cell regeneration projects in Belgrade and Bucharest clinics. Rep. Edward Hutchinson, Republican of Michigan, is on a House Judiciary Committee tour of Africa, studying problems of terrorism, and Rep. Thomas Morgan, Democrat of Pennsylvania, is on an 18day tour of the Far East.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The Knicks were trying to protect what would be a 10097 victory over the Atlanta Hawks and now, in the closing seconds Tuesday night, Lonnie Shelton hurried into the backcourt and took Walt Frazier's inbounds pass. Look at him, Eddie Donovan, the Knicks general manager, was saying at courtside. Look at him come hack to help outa rookie center coming hack to handle the ball. Some guys go into the stands to avoid the ball in that situation. And most Knick rookies aren't on the floor in that situation; most

description: A 16yearold Brooklyn youth was arrested late yesterday and charged with the stabbing deaths yesterday afternoon of two men in separate robberies in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, the police reported.

title: Associated Press TRENTON WAREHOUSE DESTROYED: A warehouse of the Novagard Company burning early yesterday in Trenton. Firemen were unable to get near the building because 55gallon drums of chemicals used in the manufacture of caulking compounds exploded as the flames reached them. Police were not yet able yesterday to determine the fire's cause. No one was injured.
House Panel Issues Subpoenas in Inquiry On 2 Assassinations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The House Select Committee on Assassinations began today serving about 10 subpoenas in search of new information on the murders of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: An Authority on Juvenile Justice Questions Community Treatment
description: CHERRY HILL. Nov. 17One of the country's leading authorities on juvenile justice said today that the concept of treating delinquents in communitybased social service agencies had been oversold and discredited.

title: Chy Davidson, Commodores Star Halfback: On and Off Field, a Leader at Bayside High
description: His odd first name is a derivative of the Greek Letter, Chi, but Chy Davidson seems to be a derivative of Jack Armstrong with a dash of 0. J. Simpson. Davidson plays at Bayside and he'll be the most significent player on the field Saturday when High the Commodores play DeWitt Clinton for the Public School Schools Athletic League S?orts football championship. Davidson is a 5foot11inch halfback who runs 100 yards in less than 10 *seconds; he has scored 19 touchdowns and 118 points in this his senior season; he is a cocaptain who commands respect from his teammates, and he is president of the student organization at the Queens school.

title: Sheets and Towels That Are Fit for a Pharaoh
description: For centuries, designers have shaped new chairs and sketched innovative prints based on the major discoveries made in archeological excavations.

title: Tiny Saskatchewan Town Reflects Rising Affluence in Canada's West
description: NORTH BATTLEFORD, Saskatchewan A motorist passing quickly through here might remember his small prairie settlement, if at all, as only one of dozens of small cities and towns in rural Western Canadawith a grain elevator by the railroad tracks as the most notable feature.

title: Brezhnev Ends Talks With Tito; Ties Emphasized
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17Leonid I, Brezhnev concluded three days of talks with President Tito today, leaving the impression that their two countries were on the closest terms they have been in many years.

title: Banks in New York Are Charged With`Dumping
description: A state Assembly committee yesterday began investigation into charges that major New York City banks were aware of the city's coming fiscal crisis as early as late 1974 and dumped billions in city securities without telling prospective buyers of the crisis they knew was imminent.

title: USING IUD'S IN PREGNANCY SAID TO RAISE DEATH RISK

description: According to the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, 5 million people have a hand in administering the nation's 1.5 million employee benefit plans, commanding more than $400 billion in assets.

title: What makes Friday more fun? Weekend Friday in The New York Times
Levi Hints Laxity on Past Wiretaps
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (UPI)Attorney General Edward H. Levi suggested today that previous heads of the Justice Department may have made quick decisions in approving Federal Bureau of Investigation requests for warrantless national security wiretaps.

title: East Germany in New Crackdown Against Dissidents and Emigration
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 18East Germany, faced by new stirrings of discontent among its 17 million people, has taken action to clamp down on dissidents and institute new restrictive rules on emigration to the West.

title: Iranians Said to Buy Missiles From British; With Payment in Oil
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 18  British sources here report that the Iranian Government has agreed to buy Britishmade antiaircraft missiles at a cost of about the equivalent of $660 million.

title: Reporters Right to Gather News Facing Increasing Tests in Court
description: Only a very few years ago, no one thought of raising the question of whether reporters had a constitutional right to go out and gather news. The general assumption, to the extent that anyone thought about it, was that they did.

title: SPAIN'S PARLIAMENT APPROVES ELECTION AND ITS OWN DEMISE
description: MADRID, Nov. 15Spain took a major step tonight toward elective democracy as the largely appointed Parliament left by Franco approved general elections for next year and voted itself out of exist. ence.

title: Art: Steinberg's Lines on Life
description: SAUL STEINBERG is his own archivist. Questioned about a drawing that was published no matter how long ago, he will pad across the room and return with the original.

title: Cash Sings Gospel of Old Values
description: Sometimes, when he's on stage singing, Johnny Cash will swivel around and point the neck of his guitar toward the audience, almost as if it were a gun. He may be singing one of his humorous songs, when he does this, and he may be smiling. But standing 6 foot 2 inches in his black, swallowtail suitcoat, with furrows in his face you could very nearly plant cotton in, and coalcolored eyes and that curiously offkey voice, deep as a mine shaft, Johnny Cash cuts a faintly ominous figure, and he means to.

title: Art People
description: PERHAPS IT IS MERELY taste, or perhaps it is something greater, like an urge to control all of the physical environment that the eye can see, but for one reason or another, many architects like to work on the taps of buildings. Bankers or lawyers may be content with a mere horizontal slice of space, so long as it is above the right address; architects, on the other hand, seem desirous of special places that are not merely unconventional, but spectacularly so.

title: Article 16  No Title
Carter Said to Plan a Food Reserve
description: PARIS, Nov. 18Economic advisers of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter have told West European officials to expect American initiatives early in the new year aimed at improving the world food situation.

title: U.S. Airlines Get Timetable to Cut Noise of Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Depart ment of Transportation issued today an antinoise timetable giving the nation's airlines four to eight years to replace or muffle 1,600 planes whose noise exceeds legal limits established after they were built.

title: Sympatico Winner In Puissance Class
description: TORONTO, Nov. 18Jim Day of the Canadian Equestrian Team piloted Sympatico to victory in the international open jumper puissance (high jump) class tonight at the Royal Winter Fair horse show, but the United States remained in the lead for the team championship.

title: Kissinger Sees U.S. Limited in Ability To Stem Oil Prices
description: There is little that the United States can do to prevent an oil price increase this year, or for that matter in the future, until steps are taken to conserve energy and to develop alternative sources of energy, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said yesterday.

title: Deaths
The New York Times Controls tlw tides of the nation's money and credit. (Dr. Burns at the Hilton yesterday.)
description: But if economic conditions did justify new stimulatory measures next year, Dr. Burns said that he would favor a permanent broadly based tax reduction for individuals and businesses of the kind enacted by the Democrats in 1964, rather than temporary or selective cuts aimed at particular sections of the population and interests.

title: Pop Music: Sweet Papa Stovepipe
description: Sweet Papa Stovepipe may be a fanciful stage name, but McKinley Peebles, the singer and guitarist who uses it, is as tall and straight as a stovepipe, as patriarchal and ready with advice and parables as anyone's father and, in his stage manner guilelessly sweet.

title: Bridge:
description: PITTSBURGH. Nov. 18The advance guard of some 5,000 tournament enthusiasts arrived here tonight, ready to do battle in the fall national championships of the American Contract Bridge League starting tomorrow afternoon at the William Penn Hotel and the Hilton Hotel. The major events in the first week of the 10day tournament will be the mixed pairs,.the life master men's and women's pairs, and the blue ribbon pairs.

title: Knicks Bradley, Hurt Again, To Miss at Least One Game
description: Bill Bradley sat early yesterday morning on the plane ride from Baltimore to New York, his right hand inserted in his shirt to ease the pain in his right shoulder.

title: Gottfried Ousts Cox at Net,
description: WEMBLEY, England, Nov. 18 (AP)Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., moved into the quarterfinals of the $125,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament tonight when he beat Mark Cox, Britain's No. 1 hope, 16, 61, 64. The loss to Gottfried ended the best run of Cox's career, which included victories over Jimmy Connors, Eddie Dibbs and Manuel Orantes en route to the Swedish open championship last Sunday.

title: Defense Dept. to Stress Investment In New Plan on Contractor Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 The Defense Department described to Congress today a new profit policy designed to encourage defense contractors to increase their productivity by basing their profits in part on their investment in plant and equipment.

title: Key Witness Against Carter and A rtis Admits Lies
description: PATERSON, Nov. 15The jury in the second murder trail of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis today heard a key prosecution witnesswho has identified the defendants as the armed men he saw at the murder sceneadmit to having lied when he testified under oath in several prior proceedings related to the case.

title: Hanging Clock Signals It's SkiShow Time at Coliseum
description: Freestyle skiers were doing somersaults from a moving ski deck, models were displaying the latest in ski wear to the musical strains of the Broadway production A Chorus Line, and devotees were examining the advantages of a shockabsorbing ski pole as winter arrived at the New York Coliseum last night.

title: ADVANCE IS ON A BROAD FRONT Buoyancy Apparently Derives From Possibility of a Tax Cut and Easing of Fed's Credit Policy
description: A renewed sense of optimism on Wall Street sent stock prices surging yesterday across a broad front. The Dow Jones industrial average, closing at its best level of a busy session, rose 12.05 points to 950.13.

title: Reds to Open Season April
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 (UPI)  The world champion Cincinnati Reds, traditional hosts for the National League opener, announced today that Opening Day 1977 would be Wednesday, April 6, against the San Diego Padres. The 2:30 P.M. game at Riverfront Stadium will mark the first time the Padres have been in Cincinnati for Opening Day.

title: The Old Soldier Returns For Farewell to the Point
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 18In an eerily convincing evocation by Gregory Peck, Douglas A. MacArthur returned here today.

title: People and Business
description: Venezuela's President, Carlo Andres Perez, told Italian officials in Rome yesterday that any increase in the cost of oil might be spread over a period of time.

title: The Now York Times/Don Hogan Charles
description: YANKEES SIGN GULLETT: Don Gullett, in his new Yankee cap, with Thurman Munson, team's catcher, after Gullett signed with Yanks. Page A19.

title: SPAIN'S PARLIAMENT APPROVES ELECTION AND ITS OWN DEMISE
description: MADRID, Nov. 18Spain took a major step tonight toward elective democracy as the largely appointed Parliament left by Franco approved general elections for next year and voted itself out of existence.

title: Screen::James Dean Dimly Seen
description: "He remains as relevant today as 20 years ago," says the portentous narrator at the end of "James DeanThe First American Teenager." These patchwork sequences from Dean's three movies and interviews with acquaintances make no case for his relevance, then or now.If anything, the film excerpts from "East of Eden," "Rebel Without a Cause" and "Giant" leave one to wonder what the fuss was about. The aura has left the image, and only the pout remains.The interviews amount to a number of people saying that actually they didn't know him all that well. Among the unrevealing reminiscences are contributions from Carroll Baker, Natalie Wood, Sammy Davis Jr., Dennis Hopper and an unwell-looking Nicholas Ray. "James Dean" opened yesterday at the RKO 59th Street Theater; but why?

title: VENEZUELAN JUDGE DROPS. OCCIDENTAL CASE CHARGE
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 18 (AP) A judge has dismissed charges against six persons accused of being involved in payoffs of Venezuelan officials by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The: Times last Wednesday that reservations were required at the Top of the Met restaurant. Seating is on a firstcome, firstserved basis.

title: Holdup Man Is Slain By a Bronx Merchant
description: A Bronx merchant disarmed one of two holdup men in his store last night and shot one of them to death, the police reported.

title: Red Smith
description: On Page 16 of The New York Times for Jan. 6, 1920, eightcolumn streamer announced: Ruth Bought By New York Americans for $125,000, Highest Price in Baseball Annals. It was the lead story in the sports section, taking precedence over a wrestling match in the 71st Regiment Armory where Jimmy Londos won the heavyweight championship of Greece from William Demetral, Willie Hoppe's victory over Charley Peterson at billiards, Princeton's 1920 football schedule and the result of the Sir Barton Purse at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans. The unsigned story read:

title: BRITISH CURBS SPUR INCREASES IN POUND
description: LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Britain took action tonight to curb the amount of money circulating at home, causing an immediate rise in the pound on foreign exchanges.

title: Tax Cut Possible, Burns Says Publicly
description: ??? the Federal Reserve Board, yesterday said in public what he apparently had been saying in private about the case for a tax cut when the Cartel Administration takes office in Jan uary.

title: Kelley Deposition Raises Confusion Over Whe: Jr He Received the Reports on Recent F .B.I. Burglaries:
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Confusion arose today over whether Clarence M. Kelley, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, had been given information about the findings of a Justice Department inquiry into recent burglaries by some F.B.I. agents in the New York City area.

title: Obituary 11  No Title
MISERICORDIA LIKELY TO ADD TO AFFILIATION
description: An effort by the Beame administration to have a $10 million medical affiliation contract at a municipal hospital in the South Bronx awarded to a Roman Catholic hospital at the expense of a Jewish medical school apparently is succeeding.

title: Gunman Who Survived Jordan Hotel Raid Links Action to a Fatah Group
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 18 (UPI)  A guerrilla attack on the InterContinental Hotel here yesterday was by a Pelestinian splinter group angered by the Syrian invasion of Lebanon, a lone surviving gunman has reportedly told Jordanian authorities.

title: Dunne May Battle Faso in the Primary For Executive Post
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 18State Senator John R. Dunne announced today that he was seriously considering entering primary for the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive in 1977.

title: Deaths
UNESCO Panel Condemns Israel For Its Policies in Occupied Lands
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 18 (AP)Delegates at a United Nations conference voted today to condemn Israel's policies in occupied Arab territories, despite protests from the United States and other Western countries.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: CARTER URGES AIDES TO FIND A BROAD MIX FOR POSTS IN CABINET
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Presidentelect Jimmy Carter has instructed his talent scouts to provide him with the names of at least one experienced Washington insider, someone from outside the capital, a woman and a black for each position in his Cabinet to give it what a senior aide termed today a representative mix.

title: 2 HEARST RELATIVES POST $500,000 BAIL
description: LOS ANGELES Nov 18 (AP)Patricia Hearst's father and uncle today posted $500,000 bail, which could free her from prison while she awaits trial on state changes.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times last Wednesday that reservations were required at the Top of the Met restaurant. Seating is on a firstcome, first, served basis.

title: Pro Football Statistics
Animal Drug Test Guidelines
description: F. D. A. Proposals to Be the First Substantial Effort To Insure Data Reliability in Such Experimentation

title: Music: Chung Family Trio
description: The ChungsKyung Wha, violinist; MyuhgWha, cellist; and MyungWhun, pianistare giving joint concerts this fall in Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington and New York, and, Wednesday night, they filled the local date by appearing at Avery Fisher Hall. All the concerts are being given under the auspices of the AmericanKorean Cultural Society.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: P.L.O. SHOWING SIGNS OF FACTIONAL RIFT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization and their Arab government sponsors are maneuvering to avoid factional rivalries inside the organization that could hamper renewed diplomatic efforts in the next few months.

title: NADJARI IS ACCUSED OF LEAKS TO PRESS
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the former special stare prosecutor for corruption cases, and his former chief assistant, Joseph A. Phillips, were accused yesterday by the New York State Commission of Investigation of having deliberately disclosed, or leaked, information to the press that improperly tarnished numerous officials.

title: Louis Cowan. Killed With Wife in a Fire; Created Quiz Shows
description: Louis G. Cowan. former president of the. CBS television network, and his wife, Pauline, were killed yesterday in a fire that swept through their apartment in the Westbury Hotel. Mr. Cowan was a major innovator in broadcasting, having created the Quiz Kids radio program and The S64,000 Question for television. Mrs. Cowan was one of the early civilrights organizers in the South in the 1960's.

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: PLOTS 811 and 315. TOTAL CRAVES, KNOLIAV000 PARK CEMETERY, IIROOK 1.1'N. I.INIITED TO JEWISH, HIGHEST OFFER TAKES ALL v7028 Tim Es

title: Friedgood Maid Rebuts State Testimony on Time Of Death of Doctor's Wife
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 18A housemaid testified today that she heard Sophie Friedgood walking overhead in her bedroom on the morning of June 18, 1975some eight hours after the prosecution contends that Mrs. Friedgood was murdered.

title: Englewood Proceeds With Plan for Major Renovation of MacKay Park
description: ENGLEWOOD, Nov. 18Elated city officials pressed forward today with plans for a major refurbishing of MacKay Park after the state agreed to provide a $984,000 grant for the project.

title: An Award Cites Doublespeaking By U.S. Agency
description: The Committee on Public doublespeak of the National Council of Teachers of English has decided to give its Doublespeak Award to the State Department. Daniel P. Moynihan, the Democratic Senatorelect from New York. was runnerup.

title: 3 Youths Slay Driver With Bat Alter Accident
description: Three youths beat a motorist to death with a baseball bat in the Elmhurst section of Queens shortly after midnight this morning and then sped from the scene in their car, the police reported.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Cheryl Dunsker is a sophomore now, but she remembers well the first time, as a freshman of a few weeks' standMg, she returned from Kirkland College near Utica, N.Y., to her home in South Orange, N.J.

title: 2,500 Attend Funeral of Policeman
description: MERRICK, LI., Nov. 15George R Kempen, a Nassau County police office! who was accidentally shot and killed by another police officer last Sunday night, was buried today after ceremonies attended by more than 2,500 policemen from the metropolitan New York area and as far away as Chicago.

title: U.S. Aides Outline Stable Food and Agriculture Outlook for 1977
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 A stable food and agriculture outlook for the coming year was outlined by the Agriculture Departments top economists and researchers at a fourday national conference that ended here today, but the prospects appeared generally more favorable for consumers than for producers.

title: South A Inca Curbs Nine Labor Activists In Drive on Unions
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 18The South African Government, continuing its clampdown on black trade union activities, has issued banning orders to nine more labor activists, bringing the total under restriction to 13.

title: Yankees Sign Gullett to 6Year Pact Worth a Reported $2 Million
description: Jumping checkbook first into the freeagent market, the Yankees added Don Gullett yesterday to their already starstudded pitching staff.

title: About Real Estate
description: RIVER EDGE, N.J.As its present officers would be the first to admit, the now renowned Prel Corporation reached a high level of unpopularity among local communities, subcontractors and other creditors a few years ago. It was a publicly listed building organization, with stock trading on the American Stock Exchange, which operated largely in New Jersey. In 1975 it elected to reorganize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: The Day After Mideast Peace ...
description: WASHINGTONGenerals, it has been said, always refight the last war. As for the Middle East, this is increasingly true with regard to the diplomats and their advisers. Innumerable conferences, speeches and position papers deal with the future of the region, but most of them labor under the delusion that peace in the Middle East is a synonym for the resolution of the ArabIsraeli conflict. The tragic case of Lebanon has apparently not sufficed to enlighten these wellmeaning people that there is not one Middle East crisis but many crises.

title: Events and Openings
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA BALLET ENSEMBLE, Quaerig College, Co!den Auditorium, 8:30.

title: Deaths
Tickets, Schedule
description: Tickets for Mr. Richardson's reading ($6.50, $5 and $4) can be purchased at the Y box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue at 92d Street (which will be closed from 4 P.M. today until 5:30 P.M. tomorrow). For ticket information, call 4276000.

title: Jazz:
description: The normally ebullient atmosphere of Jack Kleinsinger's Highlights in Jazz series was uncommonly subdued Wednesday evening when Mr. Kleinsinger presented A Jazz Portrait of Hoagy Carmichael at New York University's Loeb Auditorium.

title: A Strong Start, on Erratic Past
description: The Reluctant. King (Le Roi malgr lui) was the last of the few stage works completed by Emmanuel Chabrier (184194). Based on a French comedy of 1836, it was given its premiere at the OperaComique in Paris on May 18, 1887. It was received with enthusiasm by the public and press, but the theater burned down on May 23 after the new opera had had only three performances.

title: The Herds Gather For a Herman Reunion
description: On election night, 1936, when Franklin D. Roosevelt was sweeping to his second term by wiping out Gov. Alf Landon of Kansas, a band built around five young musicians from Isham Jones's orchestra made its debut at the Roseland Ballroom in Brooklyn. The leader was a 23yearold saxophonist and singer, Woody Herman. They called themselves the Band That Plays the Blues. Later it became the Herman Herd, a constantly changing organization that is still rolling relentlessly back and forth across the country on an endless series of onenight stands.

title: Company Profits Rise in Quarter; G.N.P. Gain Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Corporate profits rose modestly in the third quarter although the original estimate for the gross national product was revised downward, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Utah Killer Is Returned to Prison Infirmary to Recover
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 18 (AP)Gary Gilmore, pale but defiant, returned to state prison and was cheered by fellow inmates today after two days at a hospital following his suicide attempt.

title: Pacers Win and Snap 7Game Piston String,
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (AP)Billy Knight's 23 points led a balanced Indiana attack that carried the Pacers to a 104.99 basketball victory over Detroit tonight, ending the Pistons sevengame winning string.

title: A Welcome Invasion of Pianists
description: Pianists come in all shapes and sizes (several of them small), a variety of temperaments and at different stages in their careers (beginning, middle and end). Of ability, even greatness, there is no lack of them this weekend, which promises to he particularly rewarding.

title: Strong Man Fighting to Keep Fed Independent
description: Arthur F. Burns, the avuncular, pipesmoking chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is an endangered species fighting for survival. Alone among the central bank governors of the Western industrial world, Dr. Burns has real control over the supply of new money and credit entering the economy, which just about everyone now admits has an important effect on the strength of business activity in the country and the level of prices.

title: Carvings Wrought in a Swedish Village Woodshop
description: Inge Friberg, who treated New York to an exhibition of his Swedish wood crafts three years ago, is back in town. This time he is accompanied by his wife, Neta, and a new collection of the fine wooden objects they produce in their workshop in the village of Landvetter.

title: Most Black Power Inside Soweto Now Held by One Student Group
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 18An elusive student group has emerged as the single most powerful group in the black township of Soweto except for the police, who are busy jailing most of the student activists they find.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHENEVER Dorothea Straus hears a certain Mozart symphony, she smells wood shavings, turpentine and paint. T his is because, for her, the senses, storage houses for the past, are more faithful than the emotions, and that symphony recalls the studio of a muralist friend whose favorite piece of music it happened to be. And this why her third book of memoirs is called Palaces and Prisonsthe earlier ones having been Thresholds and Showcases: For Mrs. Straus the memories of people from the past are almost literally stored in houses; so it is to houses she returns in her thoughts to summon the images of certain people who were dear to her or important in a painful way.

title: NBC Is Seen Giving Up Little in Settling Antitrust Suit
description: NBC gave little away in its agreement with the Department of Justice to settle a twoyearold antitrust suit against the networks. The prohibitions detailed in the agreement scarcely alter present business practices and are expected to have no significant economic impact on the network itself or on the television production industryif and when the restrictions go into effect.

title: House Panel on Assassinations Denies Planning Visit to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  An official spokesman for the House Select Committee on Assassinations today denied as absolutely false a report that the panel was sending investigators to Cuba in connection with the killing of President Kennedy.

title: CEMETERIES
GROWTH RATE EASES IN SUPPLY OF MONEY
description: The rate of growth in the nation's money supply slowed slightly in the last few weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Rare Revival
WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: $2.5 Billion of 2Year U.S. Notes Sold at an Average Rate of 5.86%
description: The United States Treasury sold $2.5 billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average rate of 5.86 percent, well above the 5.70 percent that had been expected as recently as Wednesday afternoon. There was an unusually wide range of bids accepted by the Government's debt managers and a relatively small number of orders for securities as demand for the issue cooled. The Government securities market yesterday apparently was disappointed that the Federal Reserve did not give a more overt signal that it had decided this week to push shortterm interest rates down slightly, and the disappointment was reflected in the light demand for the new twoyear notes.

title: Opera:
description: Chabrier's The Reluctant King

title: Former H.U.D. Official Sentenced
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18 (AP)A former regional official of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development has been sentenced to 60 days in prison by a Federal court judge on bribery and tax evasion charges. Clay T. McClain, former head of the mortgage credit section of the H.U.D. office in Kansas City, Kan., was sentenced Tuesday by Judge William H. Becker. The prison sentence is to be followed by 18 months of probation.

title: Sadat Urging U.S. To Take Initiative For Mideast Peace
description: CAIRO, Nov. 18President Anwar elSadat, apparently with the blessing of other leading Arabs, is once more propounding the theme that only the United States can bring peace to the Middle East.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: ALBERTIJules, beloved husband of Maybelie. Services today, 1:30, The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave New York City.

title: New Music for Old Custom House
description: Jack Mitchell

title: Argonauts Dismiss Coach
description: TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP)  Coach Russ Jackson, who feuded with Anthony Davis, the running back, has been dismissed, the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League said today. Jackson took the coach's job in 1975.

title: Soviet, Retaliating, Bars a U.S. Diplomat From Post
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18The Soviet Union has revoked the visa of a senior American Embassy officer, apparently in retaliation for similar action against a Soviet diplomat posted in the mission to the United Nations.

title: Publishing: Master Builder
description: BEN RAEBURN, head of Horizon Press, said, We are his exclusive publishers,'referring to the late innovative architect Frank Lloyd Wright. Mr. Raeburn made his remark without emphasis, but that he takes his role seriously can be gathered from the fact that since 1951, when Horizon was founded, he has published 16 books by Wright and five by Wright's wife, Olgivanna. Coming early next year will be another volume, the autobiography of the master builder.

title: Man Ray Is Dead in Paris at 86; Dadaist Painter and Photographer
description: Man Ray, the American painter and photographer who helped create the Dadaist movement more than 60 years ago, died in his sleep early yesterday at his Paris studio. He was 86 years old and was treated for a lung infection at a Paris hospital last week.

title: Carter and Congress
description: The growing public recognition of the importance of having a President and Congress working constructively together was a major factor in the victory of the CarterMondale ticket. The first meeting between Presidentelect Carter and the Democratic leaders of the House and Senate offered evidence that this goal can be realized.

title: Why I Cried, Help!
description: Wednesday was not a good day at Julia Richman High School. The cold kept most of our 3,600 students (1,000 of them freshmen, 500 more total population than last year) and all of our 160 teachers (30 fewer than last year) in the school. It did not keep the hundred rovers in the classes, only in the halls. Teachers also took to the halls, voluntarily giving up one of their free preparation or lunch periods.

title: Article 3  No Title
Price Moves Are Narrow For Soybeans and Grain; Tax Spreading Is Factor
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) Soybeans and grain traded in fairly narrow ranges on the Chicago Board of Trade today and closed mostly uneven.

title: Deaths
Legislative Panel Will Reconsider State's Purchase of Pingry School
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18A highly controversial proposal under which the state would purchase the Hillside facilities of the Pingry School for use as an educational institution for handicapped children will be considered once again tomorrow by the Joint Legislative Oversight Committee on Bonds, also known as the watchdog committee.

title: Lefkowitz Aide Goes on Leave Amid Allegations Against Him
description: A top assistant to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday took a leave of absence without pay amid allegations that he had accepted payment of a Las Vegas gambling debt in exchange for advising the owners of a statelicensed school or, their dealings with the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: Agency's Input, Thruput, Output Get a Downput
description: The Committee on Public Doublespeak of the National Council of Teachers of English has decided to give its Doublespeak Award to the State Department. Daniel P. Moynihan, the Democratic Senatorelect from New York, was runnerup.

title: Municipal League Doubts Coexistence With Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18Gambling Casinos. which are expected to attract new convention business and revitalize this resort city, might chase out the New Jersey League of .Municipalities Conference, which annually adds more than $1.5 million to the local economy.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1976

title: Judge Bars Contact With Jurors During and Alter the Carter Trial
description: The judge presiding over the second murder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis issued an order yesterday prohibiting anyone from getting in touch with the jurors, or their families or friends, about the case either during or after the trial.

title: PAVEL SATYUKOV, HEADED PRAVDA FOR KHRUSHCHEV
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (Renters)Pavel A. Satyukov, a Soviet journalist who served as editor of the Communist Party daily Prayda in the Khrushchev era, died yesterday after an illness, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported today. He was 65.

title: Edward Bellande, 78, Dies
description: Edward A. Bellande, a former airmail and test pilot who became a leader in the aerospace industry, died Wednesday in Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 78 years old.

title: Canonizing Pork
description: WASHINGTON  When the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that provides funds for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and a handful of independent agencies met in the Capitol, Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, the chairman, banged his gavel to open the meeting. It was called to vote on the H.U.D.Independent Agencies Appropriations bill. Let's start with the money for NASA while the exofficio members are here, he said.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: By MEL GUSSOW

title: Brezhnev in Belgrade
description: Yugoslavia is not a helpless Little Red Ridinghoocl and the Soviet Union is not the terrible and bloodthirsty wolf. No less an interpreter of fairy tales than Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Leonid I. Brezhnev is responsible for these assertions, proclaimed at an official dinner given for him in Belgrade by President Tito. The point Mr. Brezhnev clearly intended to make was that only the peddlers of children's stories would suggest that the Soviet Union constitutes a threat to Yugoslav independence after Titonow 84 and ailinghas passed from the scene.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets to Sunday night's concert are priced at $3.50, $4.50, $5.50 and $7.50. Remaining tickets to Monday night's concert are $3.50 and $4.50. The box office is open Monday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. For information, call CI 77459.

title: Japan Acts to Reduce Surplus In Trade With Common Market
description: TOKYO, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Officials from six ministries today met for emergency talks on demands by the European Common Market for measures to cut Japan's huge trade surplus with the community.

title: Evidence Is Lacking in Six Murders Linked to Narcotics Trial That Acquitted
description: Although at least six murders, including those of several potential witnesses, have been linked to a major narcotics trial, law enforcement authorities have failed to find enough evidence to prosecute anyone for the killings.

title: Deaths
Market Place
description: The Canadian stock market has been in a trough for more than a year as Government controls have squeezed profits. Prices have slipped even further following the sweep to power of Rene Levesque and his separatist party in Quebec Province this week.

title: Union Strikes 16 Key G.M. Plants, But Talks Continue After Deadline
description: DETROIT, Friday, Nov. 19The United Automobile Workers struck 16 key plants of the General Motors Corporation at midnight last night after company and union bargainers failed to agree on a new threeyear national contract.

title: C.C.N.Y. Senate Chided for Ban On Newspaper
description: The City College administration told its Student Senate yesterday that the senators violated due process requirements of the New York City Board of Higher Education when they voted Wednesday night to suspend The Campus, a college weekly, for alleged violations of journalistic ethics.

title: Farewell, Mr. Scrooge
description: In setting salaries for judges and toplevel officials the executive branch, Congress in recent years has given a good imitation of Ebenezer Scrooge. Since 1969, salaries have risen only 5 percent while the Consumer Price Index has gone up by more than 60 percent. This means that judges and executives have suffered a drastic cut in their real incomes as inflation has steadily advanced.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: BLOCKJoseph. Park Avenue Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of Its loyal and devoted member and expressos deepest sympathy to the bereaved family.

title: Todd's Birthday Present: A Visit From Father
description: Richard Todd will be 23 years old today, and his father will he coming from Mobile, Ala., for the first time to watch him start at quarterback for the New York Jets on Sunday,

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The car show will be open from 6 to 11 P.M. today and noon to 11 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Tickets are $4.50 tonight and tomorrow afternoon, $5 after 5 P.M. tomorrow and all day Sunday. For children under 12, tickets are $2.50 at all times.

title: Private Hospitals to Decide Soon Whether to Challenge Abortion Ruling
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18Lawyers for private nonsectarian hospitals said today that a decision would be made within a few weeks whether to challenge a ruling yesterday by the New Jersey Supreme Court that the hospitals could not prohibit the use of their facilities for elective abortions.

title: From Accordions to Zithers
description: One of the nicest things about Musical Instruments of the World, a new encyclopedia produced by the Diagram Group, is that you don't have to be a musician to love it. It is a browser's delight. A picture book containing more than 4,000 illustrations, it shows almost every kind of musical instrument man has devised, and the variety of the instruments shapes, designs and materials makes for an eyefilling and mindboggling volume.

title: U.S. Airlines Get Timetable to Cut Noise of Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Department of Transportation issued today an antinoise timetable giving the nation's airlines four to eight years to replace or muffle 1,600 planes whose noise exceeds legal limits established after they were built.

title: Broadway
description: IF ALL GOES well in other places, Kirk Douglas will return to Broadway in the spring or fall Citizen Toni Paine, a oneman play by Howard Fast. It will be produced by those two expatriate impresarios of the oneman play, Don Gregory and Mike Merrick, and directed by Arvin Brown. Mr. Douglas was first on Broadway in Spring Again 1941, when he was calling himself George Spelvin Jr., and last on Broadway in 1964, when he was McMurphy in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. He will begin rehearsing Citizen Tom Paine in Los Angeles on Dec. 6, and then open in it in Wilmington, Del., on Jan. 11. The play is then scheduled for Memphis, Cleveland, Boston and Philadelphia, where it is hooked until March 12. The New York opening would be sometime after that.

title: In Memoriam
Hyman and Friends at Church Concert
description: Dick Hyman and Friends will present a concert Sunday at 5 P.M. in the Church of the , Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. The jazz musician will be joined by Bob Wilber, sopranosaxophone player, ?? W?? Erwin, cornetist, Mitt Hinton, bassist and Bob Rosengarden, drummer.

title: State Aide Expects Casinos to Bring A Real Boom in Tourist Industry
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Nov. 18 The state's tourist industry is expecting real tourism boom because of casino gambling in Atlantic City, John J. Horn, the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, said here today.

title: Children Romp at Dedication Of a Playground in Central Park
description: An old abandoned playground in Central Park at West 86th Street has been transformed, through community efforts, into an allwood playground with exciting waterworks and junglegym mazes for children of all ages.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Morning

title: Women Take the Stage in Crab Quadrille
description: Myrna Lamb's new play, Crab Quadrille, opens its rehearsals to the public tonight at the Interart Theater at 549 West 52d Street. The play is aboutamong other thingssurvival. The theme is painfully close to the heart of both playwright and theater. The theater is part of the Women's Interart Center, a sixyearold venture that traded a nomadic existence for the 10th floor of an industrial budding in an odd corner of the city in July 1971. It now occupies four floors and the basement.

title: Britain Refuses to Disclose Details Of Deportation of 2 U.S. Writers
description: LONDON, Nov. 18Britain's Home Secretary, Merlyn Rees, was called before the House of Commons today to explain why he intends to deport two American writersPhilip Agee, a prominent critic of the Central Intelligence Agency, and Mark Hosenball, a journalist who has written extensively about the C.I.A. and British intelligence services.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: QUEBEC LIBERAL CHIEF IS REPORTED QUITTING
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 18Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec, whose Liberal Party was decisively defeated Monday by the French speaking province's separatist movement, was reliably reported today Ito have bowed out of politics.

title: Notes on People
description: Saul Bellow, winner of the 1976 Nobel Prize in Literature and the Pulitzer Prize for fiction, has been chosen to deliver the 1977 Jefferson lecture of the National Endowment for the Humanities. Art: 30 Years Of American Prints
description: THE ART of printmaking has undergone so many changes in recent years that even quite knowledgeable observers of the art scene have reason to be genuinely bewildered nowadays about exactly what is going on in this busy field. New methods and new materials, new technologies and new ideas have been added to the traditional printmaking mediums of etching, engraving, lithography, et al., and these traditional mediums also continue to flourish. Xerox images, reliefs in paper and lead, collage combinations of fabric and plastics these, too, now constitute vital areas of the printmaker's art, and still newer and ever more startling devices seem to turn up every season.

description: Music

title: Music:
description: BARTOK'S Music for Strings, Percussion and Celesta is one of those 20thcentury works that should be ideally suited for the new Avery Fisher Hall, with its lively and lucid acoustics. In Carnegie Hall, where the Boston Symphony played the Bartok Wednesday night under Seiji Ozawa's firm guidance, the score was heard in a softer focus that cost it some of its customary brilliance. Mr. Ozawa also underplayed the febrile, clangorous style that often is identified with Bartok, in favor of smooth, flowing performance that threw the score into interesting perspectives. There was less cutting edge to the strings, for instance, than in performances by such Bartok specialists as Fritz Reiner, and little hint of the visceral excitement that can be generated in a fiercer interpretation. Nevertheless, Mr. Ozawa made the work go, and his way emphasized a lyrical side of Bartok that often is overlooked by those who think of him essentially as a percussionist.

title: Opera Had Premiere in 1887
description: The Reluctant King (Le Roi malgre lui) was the last of the few stage works completed by Emmanuel Chabrier (184194). Based on French comedy of 1836, it was given its premiere at the OperaComique in Paris on May 18, 1887. It was received with enthusiasm by the public and press, but unfortunately the theater burned down on May 25 after the new opera had had only three performances. It was remounted the following November at the Theatre Lyrique and at the end of its run the following year had been given 17 times, a relatively small number. The work was championed in Germany by the conductor Felix Mottl.

Then they discovered that among the cosponsors were groups such as the Revolutionary Communist Party and the Revolutionary Student Brigade, so they withdrew from sponsorship, leaving today's conference in Manhattan to proceed under different auspices.

title: Mrs. Rankin, Miss Post Lead on 143's

title: Harvard Freshman, 63 Years Old, Has an Advantage in History Class
description: Harry Gersh is the second generation in his family to go to Harvard. The first was his son.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19A Brooklyn dentist has invented an apparatus designed to restore breathing to anyone whose throat is blocked by food or other obstructions. The instrument, which is about the size of a cigarette lighter, has a blade that pierces the throat and permits the springoperated insertion of an air tube.

title: Television
description: Claudio Arrau is piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic; Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M.

title: Fed's Action Seen as Response to Lag.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction in its discount rate to 5% percent from 51/2 percent.

title: Sir Basil Spence, Coventry Cathedral Architect, Dies
description: LONDON, Nov. 19  Sir Basil Spence, the architect, whose bestknown building was Coventry Cathedral, died last night at his home in Eye, Suffolk. He was 69 years old.

title: PANEL REBUFFS MOVE TO EXPAND THE SALE OF BIG BOARD SEATS
description: A New York Stock Exchange Committee backed away yesterday from an earlier proposal that the Big Board be permitted to expand its permanent membership by selling more seats.

title: 6 Concerns Indicted In CoalFraud Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) A Federal grand jury today indicted six Pennsylvania companies and three of their present and former executives on charges of conspiring to fix prices of anthracite coal sold throughout the nation.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 19 (AP)A key Commission of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted today to reaffirm its condemnation of Israeli excavations and building projects in Jerusalem.

title: U.S. BELIEVES DAMASCUS WILL EXTEND U.N. FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)In the opinion of State Department experts, Syria will extend the sixmonth mandate of the United Nations peacekeeping force on the Golan Heights between Israel and Syria.

title: Neophyte Black. Collectors Learn Some of the Art World's Secrets
description: For the small but growing number of black people who want to see in their own homes some of the art they admire, the process of buying involves the usual newcomer's questions: How do I choose? How much should pay? and Five years fro mnow, will still be glad I bought it?
