title: U.S. Businessmen's Study Tells Egypt Why Foreign Investment Lags
description: CAIRO, Nov. 25Unrealistic exchange rates, vague investment laws and confusing bureaucracy are preventing significant foreign investment in Egypt, a task force of American businessmen has concluded in a special report presented to the Egyptian Government.

title: Dave Cowens: Basketball's Different Star
description: Pete Maravich dreamed of it, but Dave Cowens did it. Maravich spoke of leaving pro basketball for lack of motivation but instead returned to his $400,000ayear job in the New Orleans Jazz backcourt. Cowens invoked a rare clause in an athlete's contract and took an unpaid leave of absence of indefinite duration from the Boston Celtics.

title: Hill of Acid Mine Refuse Is Being Leveled to End the Pollution of Creek
description: ARGONNE, III., Nov. 23For the last three months earthmoving machines have been slicing away at an ugly hill of coalmine refuse that has dominated the southwest Illinois village of Staunton for the last 50 years.

title: Tennessee Train Wreck Hurts 30
description: DYERSBURG, Tenn. Nov. 25 (UPI)An Amtrak passenger train carrying 250 travelers derailed in this west Tennessee town early today. Thirty passengers were hospitalized with minor injuries.

title: Metropolitan. Briefs
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice in Albany has temporarily barred enforcement of Governor Carey's latest financial disclosure order affecting 6,000 state employees. Financialdisclosure forms were to be returned to the State Board of Public Disclosure by next Wednesday. But Justice Ellis Staley signed a temporary restraining order on Wednesday barring enforcement until arguments are heard on the court challenge by a group of newly affected state workers.

title: Goldin Says Banking Procedures Of Sheriff Are Costly to the City
description: The New York City sheriff's office keeps more than $9 million on deposit in noninterest hearing checking accounts, costing the city an estimated $350,000 a year, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: Cal Poly Wins Finale, 3410
description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif. Nov. 25 (AP)Bob Ansari threw touchdown passes of 51 yards to Bob Trudoau and 54 to Jimmy Childs to lead Cal Poly of San Luis Obispo to a 3410 victory over Sacamento State today.

title: SHIFT IN FARM POLICY UNDER CARTER IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Under Presldenteitct Jimmy Carter the Agriculture Department is almost certain to make more gystematic attpmpt to manage the ?? economy than the last two Republican Administrations did.

title: Port, Carey Get Breaks And Titles
description: Port Washington and Carey took advantage of some bad breaks by their opponents yesterday and marched to Nassau County interconference championships. Port won the AAA title, defeating West Hempstead, 139, while Carey sent Seaford to defeat, 276, in AA play.

title: Landlords in Westchester Charged With Violating Codes on Air Pollution
description: TONKS Nov. 25 (AP)The owners CI 30 Westchester County apartment ldings Lave been charged with violatng state irpollution ?? by using substandard incinerators. Thirteen of the 30 are in Yonkers.

title: Farm Seizure Poses Problems for Mexico
description: CIUDAD OBREGON, Mexico, Nov. 21The expropriation or private farms near here last week has eased the pressure for land from thousands of peasants, but it has created agrarian problems for the incoming Government of Presidentelect Jose Lopez Portillo.

title: Campaigning by Debate
description: This week's cordial and cooperative discussions between President Ford and Presidentelect Carter were in pleasant contrast to the edgy antagonism dispidyed in the famous television debates that were the focus of the recent campaign. Indeed those debates told little about the real nature of the two candidates, even less about what they believed and least of about what they would do if elected.

title: Holiday Parade: Giant Balloons, Chilly Children
description: The coldest people at Macy's 50th Thanksgiving Day parade yesterday were almost certainly the 110 alohashifted musicians and a dozen hula dancers from a Honolulu high school. Temperatures in the 30's had other musicians blowing on their hands, too, and even the Rockettes shivering.

title: Shift by Rainbow Girls Expected
description: DES MOINES, Nov. 25 (AP)The International Order of Rainbow Girls may drop its unwritten whites only policy under pressure from state affiliates. L. Ray Chamberlin, an Iowa Rainbow official says. The dispute arose in October when the international suspended all of Iowa's chapters after Michelle Palmer, whose mother is black, was voted into the Rainbow Chapter in the town of Indianola. Mr. Chamberlin said he thought the international was coming around.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES WEST ON UNESCO NEWS ISSUE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 25 The Soviet Union denounced the United States and other Western nations today on the ground that they were blocking the will of the majority at the UNESCO conference here by refusing to negotiate on a controversial resolution on the mass media.

title: Syrians Say They Strive to Avoid A Conflict With Israel in Lebanon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 24 Syria is eager to avoid giving Israel any pretext for military action in southern Lebanon and it wants to deal with the situation there by political and diplomatic means, Damascus sources said today.

title: A Meeting on SouthWest Africa In Pretoria Makes No Progress
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 25 (Reuters)A sevenhour meeting here today between delegates to the deadlocked conference on SouthWest Africa and South Africa's Prime Minister, John Vorster, produced no major decisions, conference sources said.

title: About Real Estate
description: A Federal task force has gone to work here on a request for Government insurance of a $65 million mortgage for the first phase of housing construction at Battery Park City. It is the largest insurance request ever submitted to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Hot Holiday Meals Delivered to the Homebound Elderly
description: PATERSON, Nov. 25It was all there todayturkey and all the trimmingsmade available through the Passaic County Office on Aging and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Paterson. But many elderly people in the Paterson area couldn't get to the meal at the Father English. Community Center, so the meal came to them.

title: Ohio City's Police Strike Expands
description: LORAIN, Ohio, Nov. 25 (UPI)Police Chief John Malinvosky said today that he was worried about his department's inability to cope with any major emergencies this holiday weekend as more policemen and firemen in this city near Cleveland called in sick in a contract protest. The dispute centers on the city council's demand that negotiations be reopened on a wage package already accepted by policemen and firemen. City officials said new figures indicated the city would suffer a $1.6 million deficit it the wage proposal became effective.

title: TRBEAU MAY BACK A VOTE ON QUEBEC
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 25Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau declared today that a national referendum on the separation of Quebec from Canada might be held if a sufficient majority of Quebecers indicated that they favored independence for the Frenchspeaking province.

title: Affirmative Action, a Heroic Measure
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.The 1964 Civil Rights Act's ban on employment discrimination was adopted in an atmosphere of monumental naivet. Over a decade later, minorities are still twice as likely as whites not to have jobs. The median family income of blacks is only about 60 percent that of whites. The employment situation of women is similarly bleak.

title: News Summary
description: Turkish troops and civilian relief workers struggled through snow and freezing temperatures to reach isolated regions of eastern Turkey where, officials feared, more than 3,000 persons had been killed in an earthquake. Governmeet estimates of the number of homeless reached 200,000, and there were fears that up to 5,000 persons had perished in 109 villages. President Ford offered American aid. [Page A1, Col. 6.1]

title: A New Lease on Life
description: I am 28 years old and I have cancer. Anger comes before anything else. There are times that the anger becomes overwhelming, turns to frustrated rage, because there is no one to be angry at. I can curse God, which I've done many times, but it is unsatisfying because God doesn't shout back. Crying helps.

title: Art: From Paris In the Age of Ingres
description: ONE OF THE THINGS that Europeans most miss in this city is the kind of miscellaneous exhibition of old master drawings that in London and to a lesser extent in Paris is taken for granted. The exhibitions in question may include one or two masterpieces, but their first object is to satisfy a panoramic curiosity; for every sheet by Leonardo or Rembrandt cr Watteau there are 50 by lesser names that tease our fancy, test our general knowledge and excite our cupidity without costing a fortune.

title: Weekend Gardening: It's the Berries
description: There I am curled up in a comfortable chair after Thanksgiving dinner, and the annual phantasm of growing my own cranberries rises momentarily to the fore. We named our big pond Cranberry Pond after discovering that in the late 1800's it was flooded and drained each year to provide the boggy creature comforts for those big tart berries that make their preserved way to the holiday table.

title: Soccer Title to Clinton
description: Clinton downed Lafayette, Wednesday afternoon at Baker Field and won the Public Schools Athletic League soccer title. Colleth Roland scored in the first half for the Governors. Charles Carollo, the Frenchies goalkeeper, stopped a Clinton penalty shot in the second half, but his teammates were unable to score a tying goal against Clinton's Mike Lue.

title: Passenger Group Says M.T.A. Plans Slashes in Service
description: The Committee for Better Transit, one of the most active transitrider groups, accused the Metropolitan Transportation Atuhority yesterday of planning further draconian cuts in service.

title: Auto Manufacturers Try Lighter Materials to Increase Gasoline Mileage
description: An extra mile can be squeezed from a gallon of gasoline for every 400 pounds cut from the weight of a car; Detroit says. So it has gone on a more rigorous dietmore aluminum and plastic and less steelto take more guzzle out of its cars.

title: Youth Accused in Fire Killing 4
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 (UPI)A 17yearold boy has been charged with setting a blaze that killed four members of his family, including his crippled mother. William Kelly was arrested today and chafed with involuntary manslaughter in connection with the fire yesterday. The dead were his mother, Florence Hanson, 45; his stepsister, Mary, 14; his aunt, Ann Kelly, 65. who was blind, and her son from a previous marriage, William McNecce, 33.

title: Music: Bernstein Art Songs
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN returned to the podium of the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night with some new songs of his own to introduce, an anniversary to acknowledge and a death to commemorate.

title: Unbeaten Rutgers Wins, 179
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 25Rutgers concluded its 108th and finest football season tonight with an exciting 179 victory over Colgate that extended the longest current majorcollege winning streak to 18 games over two years.

title: 3 F.B.I. Men in Stakeout Were Shot, Apparently by Their Fellow Agents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25A team of inspectors from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's headquarters is trying to reconstruct a shootout in which three bureau agents were wounded last week, apparently by other agents, while trying to avert a robbery at a New Jersey bank.

title: Broadway
description: SPOTLIGHT, A MUSICAL that is supposed to reach Broadway next season, is part of that growing genre of Broadway musicals that are about show business itself. Spotlight tells of a famous performer and his two children, one a rock star and the other a Broadway stage star, and if this makes you think about the Fondas, say, or the Sinatras or Judy Garland and Liza Minnelli, then you will be thinking exactly what the people connected with Spotlight want you to think.

title: Trial in Reporter's Murder Tangled In Plots, Rivalries and Political Rifts
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 23Almost six months after a bomb killed Don Bolles, a Phoenix reporter, the man accused of murdering him has yet to go on trial, and prosecution of the case has become entangled in plots, rivalries and bureaucratic strife.

title: TURKISH QUAKE TOLL PASSES 3,000 MARK; SNOW SLOWS RELIEF
description: DIYADIN, Turkey, Nov. 25Hampered by snow and cold, Turkish troops and civilian relief workers struggled today to reach the isolated rugged reaches of eastern Turkey, where officials feared, more than 3,000 people had been killed in an earthquake yesterday.

title: McGovern Endorses Humphrey For Senate Majority Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)Senator George McGovern endorsed Hubert Humphrey of Minnesota for Senate majority leader today, calling him the logical choice for the job.

title: Lost Double ets Spell Double Trouble at OTB
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation has begun an investigation into a mixup earlier this week that reportedly cost it $600.000.

title: Northern Highlands Captures 9th in Row
description: Northern Highlands, looking ahead to its Group 3 playoff title game with Ridgefield Park on Dec. 4, earned its ninth straight success, 216, yesterday over Old Tappan at the loser's field.

title: Around the Nation
description: SCRANTON, Pa. Nov. 25Chief Federal District Judge William J. Nealon yesterday set next Tuesday at 10 A.M. as the time for two men involved in an investigation of the harboring of Patricia. Hearst and three other Federal fugitives to surrender to the Federal authorities here.

title: U. N. Events Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. to discuss Security Council report and Vietnam application and Legal Committee report.

title: 33 Reported Killed in Clashes Between Rival Rhodesian Blacks
description: LUSAKA, Zambla, Nov. 25 (UPI)Thirtythree Rhodesian guerrillas were killed and 14 wounded last week in clashes between rival black factions in Mozambique, sources from the Zimbabwe African National Union said today.

title: Spanish Socialists Plan to Hold Open Party Congress Next Month
description: MADRID, Nov. 25Apparently with Government approval, the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, which is still illegal, plans to hold its first open congress since the end of the civil war next month.

title: Ferry Service to Resume Sunday Between Portland and Yarmouth
description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 25Ferry service between Portland and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, will resume Sunday after a threeweek lapse when the 370foot Marine Cruiser begins a schedule of two round trips a week.

title: Trenton Releases Its Plan to Cope With a NuclearPlant Emergency
description: TRENTON, Nov. 25The state today released its longawaited plan for handling emergencies that would arise if a nuclear power plant blew up. However, the emergency plans for the slate police and the State Bureau of Radiationwhich would be in chargewere not disclosed.

title: Ballet: Magic Returns With Coppelia
description: The New York City Ballet's holiday offering Wednesday night at the New York State Theater took the form of the season's first performance of Coppelia, led exuberantly and joyfully by Helgi Tomasson and Patricia McBride.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Texas A. & M. Sends Texas to a 273 Loss
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 25 (AP)George Woodard and Curtis Dickey punched out three touchdowns tonight as 11thranked Texas A. and M. whipped Texas, 273, and kept its chances alive for a Southwest Conference cochampionship. Both Houston and Texas Tech must lose Saturday to give A. & M. share of the title. The Aggies, however, already have accepted a bid to play Florida in the Sun Bowl at El Paso, Tex., Jan. 2.

title: Mexicans Using U. S. As Haven for Dollars
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 25  Apprehensive Mexicans carried hundreds of millions of dollars over the border into Texas before the Central Bank of Mexico moved Monday to curb the flow, according to Texas hankers.

title: Peking Sends Army To Area of Clashes
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 25Chinese troops have been sent into cities, villages, schools and factories in Fukien, the southeast coastal province opposite Taiwan, after extremely important instructions from Chairman Hua Kuofeng, apparently designed to stop factional fighting, according to Fukien radio broadcasts.

title: Stockholm Museum Burglarized
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 25 (Reuters) Thieves who apparently hid inside the National Museum of Fine Arts last night got away with at least $100,000 in valuable objects, the police reported today. Among articles reported missing were a diamondencrusted gold casque, two 17thcentury pocket watches and seven other old timepieces.

title: Imperial Chemical Posts a Rise In Net and Sales for 3d Quarter
description: Imperial Chemical Industries reported yesterday in London thirdquarter sales of $1.7 billion, compared with $1.28 billion in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1975. Net income rose to $132 million, or 24 cents a share, from $76 million, or 15 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Books of The Times
description: IF I'VE ONLY one life, let me live it as awhat? The original line, by a copywriter for Clairol, read as a blonde but Tom Wolfe finds the members of what he calls the Me Decade trying to recolor their very souls. They are going to live their lives, he says, as Emma Bovary or Erica Jong or, if they are men, as Casanova or Henry VIII. The notion that you can take your pick has arrived, and perhaps this is the rough beast, its hour come round at last, that Yeats say?. slouching towards Bethlehem to be born.

title: Mrs. Grasso Appoints 6 to Panel That Weighs Technology's Impact
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 25 (AP)Gov. Ella T. Grasso has named six persons to the Commission on Connecticut's Future. The panel was created by the 1976 General Assembly to help the state anticipate the impact of changing technology on its citizens.

title: Australia Buys Capt. Bligh's Log For Display in National Museum
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 25 (UPI) The Australian Government said today that it had bought the logbook kept by Capt. William Bligh during his 45day voyage to safety in this region after being cast adrift from the Bounty by mutineers.

title: The City Game: Bayside Outscored by St. Francis
description: Defense took the holiday off yesterday as two Queens schools met for the unofficial football championship of New York City. St. Francis Prep, the Catholic Schools champion, defeated its host, Bayside, the Public Schools champion, 28.23, before about 6,000 fans.

title: Naples Coalition Council Resigns
description: NAPLES, Nov. 25 (UPI)The CommunistSocialist city council of Naples resigned early today after a disagreement in a nightlong debate.

title: Islanders Bow To Red Wings, Giacomin, 31
description: UNIONDALE, L.T., Nov. 25Looking for drumsticks, the Islanders got Wings instead tonight as they dropped a lackluster 31 verdict to Detroit at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Foreign Relations Council Appoints Panel to Choose a Murrow Fellow
description: The fellowship, named for the late CBS correspondent, provides for nine months of research at the council's headquarters at 58 East 68th Street. The competition is open to newsmen specializing in international relations. Applications will be accepted until March 1 and the winner will be announced on June 1.

title: 50th Thanksgiving Parade: A Cornucopia of Bands, Balloons and Children
description: The coldest people at Macy's 50th Thanksgiving Day parade yesterday were almost certainly the 110 alohashifted musicians and a dozen hula dancers from a Honolulu high school. Temperatures in the 30's had other musicians blowing on their hands, too, and even the Rockettes shivering.

title: Should Washington Guarantee Municipal Loans?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26  When Presidentelect Jimmy Carter met the other day with Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon to discuss New York City's fiscal problems, one of the options they talked about was a Federal loanguarantee program.

title: Miss Schattner Has Nuptials to Mark Pachman, a Lawyer
description: Susan Naomi Schattner, daughter of Mrs. I. J. Ditzian of Delhi, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Mark Alan Pachman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Pachman of North Bergen, N.J., and Boca Raton. Fla.

title: Management
description: Sooner or later, the ownermanagers of a small company must pass control to their younger successors. Adding an issue of preferred shares can help bridge that generation gap.

title: Subways Are For Shopping
description: In 1908, four years after the first subway train rumbled under streets of New York City, small bubbleshaped machines began appearing in stations from City Hall to 145th Street. For a penny, the machine would send a stream of salted peanuts or a huge gumball down a chute into a hand cupped under the small opening.

title: Notes on People
description: A color guard of United States Marines took the American flag to London's Westminster Abbey yesterday and, to a fanfare of trumpets, it was placed on the high altar by the Dean of Westminster. The United States Ambassador, Anne Armstrong, stepped in front of the congregation and began reading from William Bradford's History of Plymouth Plantation: Being thus arrived in good harbor and brought safe to land, they fell upon their knees and blessed the God of heaven.

title: EDWARD T. FOLLIARD, 77, REPORTER WON PULITZER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP)Edward T. fliard, a Pulitzer Prizewinning reporter who covered Presidents from Calin Coolidge to Lyndon B. Johnson for The Washington Post, died today of cancer at his home here. He was 77 years Id.

title: A Pop Music Feast For the Holiday
description: WHEN ONE LOOKS over the list of pop, rock and folk events cascading into the metropolitan New York area this weekend, it might he assumed that Thanksgiving is the source of it all. Thanksgiving is a principal migratory time for students, after all, and this weekend the town is full of themoff from school or back home, and burning for something to do.

title: Joy Ungerleider Bride Of Dr. Philip Mayerson
description: Joy G. Ungerleider, widow of Samuel Ungerleider Jr., was married yesterday at her home in Larchmont, N.Y., to Dr. Philip Mayerson, dean of the College of Arts and Science and professor of classics at New York University. The bride is director of the Jewish Museum of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York. Rabbi Jules Harlow performed the ceremony.

title: Antiques
description: THE LARGEST AUCTION of period European tapestries held here or anywhere in recent years takes place today at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet. The 35 weavings for sale date from the early 16th century through the late 18th century and represent a capsule history of the development and decline of the flat woven art form.

title: Advertising
description: Most Colgate toothpaste advertising describes the product as a cavity fighter. But, to the Spanishspeaking segment of the population, the pitch is toward a nice smile.

title: LINE IN A MOVIE SCRIPT HITS U.S.SOVIET AMITY
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25Last June, after an:American production team finished filming a documentary on the Kirov Ballet's renowned school in Leningrad, an ebullient reception was held at a Moscow hotelall champagne and brotherly love.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: The Chinese Acrobats of Taiwan will perform at the Minskoff Theater today and tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. and on Sunday at 3 P.M. They will perform nightly Tuesday through next Saturday at 8, with a 2 P.M. Saturday matinee. On Sunday, Dec. 5, performances will be at 2:30 P.M. and 6 P.M. For tickets, call the box office, 8690550; Ticketron, 5417290, Or Chargit, 2397177. Prices are $7 to $10, except Friday and Saturday nights, when they are $7 to $12.

title: For Children
description: ANNUAL CHRISTMAS TREE EXHIBITION, with 25toot high balsam fir decorated with 1,580 ornaments, including natural objects, such as mammals, cherries, pears, stars and dogs, complete with fires, on view at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West on 79th Street, In Roode. volt Hall on the second floor. 873.1300. The annual baroque Christmas tree and creche display, with collection of 180 figures that make up the 18th. century Neapolitan creche, will 90 on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 82d Street and Fifth Avenue, Dec. 4. 879.5500.

title: Yankee Hopes for Jackson Brighten As Padres Drop Out, Sign Fingers
description: The bidding for Reggie Jackson, slugger and outspoken star, has soared past the $3 million mark, and more than one source concluded yesterday that the Yankees had the best shot at winning the auction.

title: Patricia Hearst Eats Holiday Meal at Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 (UPI)Patricia Hearst, free on bail while her bank robbery conviction is appealed, spent the Thanksgiving holiday with her family for the first time since she was kidnapped in February 1974.

title: L.I. MinisterPsychotherapist Slain In Office and a Patient Is Accused
description: Dr. J. Schoeberg Setzer, a Lutheran minister and practicing psychotherapist, was stabbed to death yesterday in his office in North Babylon, L. I., by one of his patients, according to the Suffolk County police.

title: Ex Dr. Kildare DissectsI Iguana
description: While Richard Chamberlain, the movie star, slipper in hand, has been pursuing Cinderella across the Radio City Music Hall screen to the delight of holiday audiences, two blocks west at the Circle in the Square, Richard Chamberlain, the stage star, has been working his way deeper and deeper into the exhausting character of the former minister T. Lawrence Shannon in Tennessee Williams's Night of the Iguana. The play begins previews tonight.

title: Big Peru Copper Mine Opened By AsarcoLed Joint Venture
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 25Peru's President, Francisco Morales Bermudez, triggered a dynamite blast today that loosened a million tons of orebearing rock at the terraced, openpit Cuajone copper mine 550 miles south of here near Moquegua.

title: Watts Plays for the Millions
description: Andre Watts is only 30, but anniversaries are already cropping up in his career, and a significant one is at hand. On Sunday afternoon he makes his 10th consecutive appearance in Lincoln Center's Great Performers Series at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Orthodox Jewish Leaders Begin FourDay Session in Washington
description: More than 1,000 lay and rabbinic leaders from the United States and Canada gathered in Washington for the opening last night of the biennial convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America at the L'Enfant Plaza Hotel.

title: Gail Katherine Gavigan Married to Robert Dwyer
description: Gail Katherine Gavigan, who teaches at St. Thomas the Apostle School in West Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Joseph Dwyer, a teacher at St. Agnes High School in Rockville Centre, L. I. The ceremony was performed in St. Dominic's Ronian Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L. I., by Msgr. David Fitzpatrick, chancellor of the Diocese of Maine.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Rockland Center for the Arts was founded 30 years ago in West Nyack, N.Y., with the active support of artists, actors and writers (among them, Helen Hayes and Lotte Lenya). It has lived up to its name and aspirations and now has two galleries for exhibition. One of them is filled with Herman Rosse: 18871965: Designs for Stage, Film, Interiors, Architectural Themes. Mr. Rosse, among other things, designed the sets for such films as The Emperor Jones and Frankenstein. Also Murders in the Rue Morgue, made with Bela Lugosi in 1932, which will be seen tonight at 8 P.M. as an adjunct to the exhibition. Admission to the film is $1.50; $1 for students and over65's. Admission to the show and the center, free; the exhibition is open today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Sunday, the last day, from 1 to 4. There is also a oneman show by Michael Zansky, and Sunday at 5 P.M., you can sit in on a jazz concert by the Steve Lampert Quintet; admission: $2.50. The center is at 2729 Old Greenbush Road, in West Nyack. At the intersection of Routes 59 and 303. Information: (914) 3580877.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, LI., 8 P.M. (Television Channel 10 (Manhattan Cable), 8 P.M.) (RadioWMCA, 8 P.M., WGBB, 9 P.M., delayed broadcast)

title: U.S. Judge Facing Bar Inquiry for Silence
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 (UPI)Federal District Judge Herbert A. Fogel has come under investigation by the Philadelphia Bar Association because he refused to answer questions for a Federal grand iurv.

title: Warfare in Space?
description: Science fiction fans will find the idea of warfare in space with death beams and other exotic weapons rather old hat. But recent reports about both Soviet and United States preparations for possible warfare in space bring fiction into the realm of reality.

title: W. EARL DYSART
description: W. Earl Dysart, a retired drug industry executive, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He was 66; years old and a resident of Montclair.

title: Three Touchdowns Put Blackwell Near Record
description: NEW PROVIDENCE, N.J., Nov. 25Ted Blackwell moved within 6 points of the New Jersey high school season scoring record as he registered three touchdowns on runs of 28, 2 and 4 yards today in leading unbeaten New Providence to a 206 victory over previously undefeated Summit before 10,517 for the Suburban Conference championship.

title: Canadian Dollar Slips
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (Reuters)The value of the Canadian dollar fell here today to oneforone with the United States dollar, the cheapest it has been for 11 months.

title: SIMON WILL TRAVEL WITH 49 TO MOSCOW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon la leaving tomorrow for Moscow with a party of 49 in an Air Force jet on, a trip whose primary purpose is a 15minute speech in the Soviet capital, Administration officials said today.

title: New York Using Medicaid Funds To Board Well Babies at Hospitals
description: Hundreds of children are being kept in hospitals in New York City at an annual cost of millions in Medicaid funds even though almost none of them require hospitalization, a legislative committee reported yesterday.

title: Borg Defeats Fibak, but They Both Gain Tennis Final
description: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 25 (AP)Bjorn Borg of Sweden advanced to the final of a $70,000 roundrobin invitation tennis tournament today after defeating Wojtek Fihak of Poland, 46, 63, 62.

title: Children's Books, Long Ago, Far Away and Now, in 2 Shows
description: The children who learned their table manners by reading Les Contenances de la Table (circa 1487) cannot have been so different from those poring over Gustav the Gourmet Giant today, but the literature written for. them has changed and proliferated over the 500 years young people have had their own books.

title: TROOPS IN LEBANON TO MOVE SOUTHWARD
description: FRIEIRUT, Lebanon, No. 25 Officials o of the Arab League today confirmed newspaper reports that contingents of the Arab peacekeeping force would be sent to the southern port city of Tyre and to the strategic Khardaly Bridge spanning the Litani River between Nabatiyeh and Meri Uyun.

title: Drawing From the American Mainstream
description: JUST WHEN it seemed certain that the great wave of Bicentennial exhibitions surveying American art had come to an endthat, indeed, there could scarcely be anything Ica in the storerooms to dust off and hart on the walls  the Whitney Museum of American Art has come up with a show that can take its place beside the best of the Bicentennial events. it is called American Master Drawings and Watercolors, and it is a show of superb quality. Even for people who think they know this field pretty well, there will be some delightful surprses.

title: CASTIELLA, 69, DIES; A HIGH FRANCO AIDE
description: MADRID, Nov. 25 (UMFormer Foreign Minister Fernando Maria Castiella of Spain died of a heart attack today. He was 69 years old.

title: Lebanon Factions Said to Agree On Syrian Control of Artillery
description: Lebanon Factions Said to Agree On Syrian Control of Artillery; BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 (Reuters) Lebanon's leftistMoslem and Christian rightist factions agreed in principle tonight on a plan to put their artillery under Syrian supervision, informed sources reported.

title: Jewish Defense League Official Convicted of AntiSoviet Action
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (UPI)The head of the Washington area Jewish Defense League has been convicted of conspiring to shoot out the windows in the apartments of two Soviet embassy officials to protest the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Mauritius Stamp Gets $80,000
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 (UPI)A onepenny Mauritius stamp of 1874, expected to fetch $32,000, was sold in two minutes today for $80,000 at an auction staged by Stanley Gibbons International Ltd. The orange and red stamp, which bears the head of Queen Victoria, was bought by Rene Berlingen, a private collector from Liechtenstein. There are only 14 of these stamps in the world, and Berlingin now owns four of them.

title: 3 Given Prison Terms in Theft Of $5 Million in Antique Coins
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 (AP)Three men convicted of the theft of $5 million worth of antique coins from Harvard University have been sentenced to prison. The theft occurred Dec. 2, 1973, at the Fogg Museum.

title: Huge Zinc Find Troubles Crandon, Wis.
description: CRANDON, Wis.The approach of winter in this section of clean water and clear air has brought a dull, monotonous grayness to the countryside, save for the green of the spruce, fir, red pine and aspen nestled among the tall, leafless birch trees, whose white bark form background for the evergreens. The scene is complemented by an overcast sky as the north woods area awaits the icy brasts from Canada that will soon paint the landscape a snowy white.

title: Dallas Wins, 1914, Foiling Late Rally
description: DALLAS, Nov. 25  The Cardiac Cardinals, so named for their lastminute victories, suffered their second stroke within four days today as they just missed beating the Dallas Cowboys. The same was true last Sunday when they just missed beating the Washiiigon Redskins. The score today was 1914 for the Cowboys; the score on Sunday. 1610. for the Redskins.

title: Chinese Wizardry For the Family
description: The Chinese Acrobats of Taiwan at the Minskoff Theater make up what is easily the most spectacular family show around this weekend. This is a troupe of tumblers, Jugglers, acrobats, dancers, trick cyclists, martialarts experts and musicians, and they are unlike any Western entertainment.

title: The Last Americans
description: Legend has it that on the first Thanksgiving, when the Pilgrims celebrated the good harvest of 1621, their neighborhood Indians witnessed the proceedings and even shared the victuals. If they didn't, they should have, since they had taught the settlers how to plant corn. Thanksgiving Day, 1976, therefore is a reasonable occasion for reminding the wellfed majority that the first Americans have become the last Americans.

title: Brokerage Data Expert Advising On a Proposed National Market
description: Who is Norman Epstein and why are people on Wall Street talking about him?

title: Nancy Mason, Rick Hauser of Boston TV Station Wed
description: Nancy Sandra Mason, dance coordinator and associate producer at public television station WGBH, Boston, and Rick Hauser, a producer and director for WGBH, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Dr. Harry Mason, in Middletown, N.Y. Rabbi Kurt Metzger of the Monroe (N.Y.) Temple of Liberal Judaism performed the ceremony.

title: HOWLAND H. PELL JR.
description: Howland H. Pell Jr., 79 years old, former vice president of the Columbia Gas Company, died Tuesday at Norwalk Hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He lived at 7 Hills Lane in Westport.

title: Mike Nichols For the Fun of It
description: COMEDIANS is serious about being funny, said Mike Nichols, director of the new Trevor Griffiths play, which opens Sunoay at the Music Box Theater. Serious funny is a familiar role for Mr. Nichols. There has been humor in all of his previous work not only in the Neil Simon plays lie directed, but even in David Rabe's drama Streamers. The difference between his other work and Comedians is that this time the subject itself is comedy.

title: The Battle of the Warsaw Ghetto
description: On Passover Eve, 1943. the Nazis, abetted by Eastern European minions, began what was to have been an easy. final liquidation of the Warsaw Ghetto. But young Jews, resolved to kill Nazis as they themselves were slaughtered, fought an actionwearisome, hopeless, but inspiredthat tied down German troops. Nobody really seemed to care. The Poles themselvesantiGerman but also antiJewishlooked on with quiet satisfaction, and worse, as the Nazis solved Poland's Jewish problem. Oh, there were magnificent, conscientious exceptionsone can never disregard men such as Capt. Henryk Ivanski, who led a Polish unit in aid of the Jews in the Ghetto battle and lost two sons and two brothers who went with himbut the Jews were dying in a land that didn't care, at the hands of enemies who did malevolently.

title: U.S. Bases on Guam Deplored
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 25 (AP) The United States and 20 other nations voted in the negative today as a General Assembly committee adopted a resolution that strongly deprecates the establishment of military installations on Guam as being incompatible with the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter. The Decolonization Committee adopted the resolution with 60 yes votes and 42 abstentions. Last year a similar measure cleared the Assembly by a vote of 89 to 6, with 32 abstentions.

title: The Sweet Science in Small Sizes
description: Ask any reader of Eastern sports pages to name the world's outstanding fistfighters and he will start with Muhammad Ali, hesitate, and then if he is more knowledgeable than most, add the names of George Foreman, Ken Norton and perhaps Joe Frazier, who has retired. Almost 13 years have passed since Ali first succeeded to the heavyweight championship, which means that few people under 25 can remember champions who preceded him and, if some do remember, they certainly never saw any of them. A whole generation has grown up believing that All invented boxing and that the game will die when and if he retires for the last time. Most letters to the editor describing Ali positively as the greatest fighter of all time turn out to be from undergraduates. Anyhow, the point this paragraph set out to make is that the average fan in the East, called upon to name fighters off the top of his head, will mention only heavyweights. This isn't true in places like Southern California, where the large MexicanAmerican population makes boxoffice idols of little guys like Alfonso Zamora, Carlos Zarate, Rafael Limon and Danny Lopez, but on the Atlantic Seaboard if you tell somebody about great fights between little fellows you encounter expectant silence as he waits for the laugh.

title: Local Fans to Miss Big Games Sunday as Giants and Jets Get TV Spots
description: If there are any television fans who have not seen enough of the Giants or Jets this season they will have another chance on Sunday. Channel 2 will show the Giants game against the Seattle Seahawks from the Meadow.

title: Texan Jailed in Slaying of Two Seeks Daily Release for Work
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 25 (UPI)T.Cul len Davis, a businessman who is awaiting trial on two counts of murder, has promised to pay the cost of stringent security if a Federal judge rules he can go back to work each day.

title: BLACK MARINES ACCUSED OF ASSAULTING WHITES
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif. Nov. 25 (AP) The Marine Corps has charged eight black Marines with assault and conspiracy in a Nov. 13 commandolike raid on a barracks of white Marines.

title: Publishing: The Fist That Weeps
description: ARARITY in today's publishing, a work of fiction from East Germany, is on George Braziller's list for release next April. The book Is Reiner Kunze's satirically titled The Wonderful Years, a spare, cooltoned series of vignettes depicting life in East Germany with its contradictions, absurdities, smallmindedness and Catch22 patterns of existence. A slim book done in fictional form, it could not, from all accounts, be more realistic.

title: FRANK A. M'HUGH
description: Frank A. McHugh, a former manger of the Brook Club of New York City and assistant manager at the Plaza Hotel, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and lived at 176 East 71st Street.

title: News Summary
description: Turkish troops and civilian relief workers struggled through snow and freezing temperatures to reach isolated regions of eastern Turkey where, officials feared, more than 3,000 persons had been killed in an earthquake. Government estimates of the number of homeless reached 200,000, and there were fears that up to 5,000 persons had perished in 109 villages. President Ford offered American aid. [Page A1, Col. 6.]

title: Waiting for Bullwinkle and Bird Worthwhile Trial for 2 Children
description: Oscar the Groud.

title: Livingston Blunts W. Essex
description: Livingston stopped a 2point conversion run with 8 minutes 28 seconds remaining yesterday and handed West Essex its first defeat, 2221, at Livingston.

title: Utilities Continue Fight For Utah Coal Project
description: More than seven months ago, as pressure from environmentalists mounted, a controversial plan to build a coalburning power plant atop the scenic Kaiparowits Plateau in southern Utah was abandoned.

title: Bills Beaten as Star Gains 273 Yards
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 25 (AP)Greg Landry, the Detroit quarterback, threw two touchdown passes to David Hill today that more than offset the recordsetting running of O.J. Simpson as the Detroit Lions crushed the Buffalo Bills, 2714, in a National Football League game.

title: How to Get There
description: The historic hamlet of Oyster Bay is less than an hour away from the city by train or by car. Take the Long Island Rail Road to the end of the Oyster Bay Line, or take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 41 North and follow Route 106 to the harbor area. After touring the hamlet follow East Main Street a mile and a half to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt. From there follow Cove Neck Road another mile and a half to the Roosevelt mansion, Sagamore Hill.

title: Dr. Joost Meerloo Is Dead at 73; Was Authority on Brainwashing
description: Dr. Joost A. M. Meerloo, a psychiatrist and a prolific writer best known during the cold war years for his studies on the effects of brainwashing, died Nov. 17 in Amsterdam. He was 73 years old.

title: European and Arab News Chiefs End 3Day Conference in Tunis
description: TUNIS, Nov. 25 (UPI)A EuropeanArab conference of news agency directors today created three committees and published a list of recommendations aimed at bringing about a new information order.

title: Screen: A Surprise From Germany
description: ONE OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL, moving and exhilarating films available in New York this weekend and next is most certainly Werner Herzog's "The Great Ecstasy of the Sculptor Steiner," a 45-minute documentary on Walter Steiner, the champion German ski jumper who describes what he does as ski-flying, which it is.The film occupies the major part of the current program at the Film Forum, 15 Vandam Street, where it may be seen tonight through Sunday evening at 7:30, and at the same time next week, Thursday through Sunday. Making up the rest of the program are two other shorts by Mr. Herzog, "Precautions Against Fanatics" and "Last Words" (each 12 minutes) and Jean-Marie Straub's "Introduction to an Accompaniment to a Cinematic Scene by Arnold Schoenberg" (15 minutes), which was first shown at the 1975 New York Film Festival with Mr. Straub's screen adaptation of Schoenberg's "Moses and Aaron."On the evidence of such feature films as "Signs of Life," "Even Dwarfs Started Small" and "Every Man for Himself and God Against All" (titled "The Mystery of Kaspar Hauser" for its commercial release here), Werner Herzog is one of West Germany's most vital young film makers. Yet as original as those films have been, they've also suffered from acute over-intellectualism, a disease that has denatured so many young European film makers.Ideas are all very well and good, but a film maker who doesn't also have an instinctive passion, something not quite understood or predictable, might as successfully write textbooks."The Great Ecstacy of the Sculptor Steiner," made in 1974, reveals for the first time that passion in Mr. Herzog, and in so doing it becomes a kind of key to the three feature films that have already been seen here. Mr. Steiner, who sculpts wood part-time and most of the time is obsessed by ski jumping, is a real-life Herzog hero, a fellow whose particular circumstances set him apart from everyone else.Most of Mr. Herzog's heroes appear to have been gifted by being deprived of somethingnormal height or intelligence, for examplethe rest of us take for granted. Mr. Steiner is deprived of an ordinary man's peace of mind by being possessed by his talent the demonstrations of which in this film are as spectacular as anything I've seen on the screen."The Great Ecstasy of the Sculptor Steiner" has the shape and manner of a sport film as it records the preparations that Mr. Steiner makes for a competition in Yugoslavia, and then records the competition itself. The things that separate it from other films are the personality of the ski jumper himself and Mr. Herzog's extraordinary slow-motion footage of the ski jumper at work. You have the feeling that on any one of these jumps. Mr. Steiner is going to take off and never again set foot on earth. At least, not alive.As a ski jumper, Mr. Setiner is an artist, and though specific jumps can be measured, those measurements have as little to do with his art as do the measurements of a painter's canvas. "The Great Ecstasy of the Sculptor Steiner" is, like "Edvard Munch," really concerned with the mystery of the creative impulse.The two other Herzog shorts on the Film Forum program are the kind of avant-garde practice films that look as if they had been made for the principal appreciation of the film maker's friends and associates.

title: Exchanges Closed for Holiday
description: Securities and commodities exchanges, banks, government and businesses were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving Day.

title: Subways Are For Shopping
description: In 1908, four years after the first subway train rumbled under streets of New York City, small bubbleshaped machines began appearing in stations from City Hall to 145th Street. For a penny, the machine would send a stream of salted peanuts or a huge gumball down a chute into a hand cupped under the small opening.

title: CAMPAIGN IS OPENED TO BAR RELIEF CUTS
description: A group of 18 leaders of New York City's major social agencies yesterday announced a highestpriority campaign to keep welfare grants at their current levels and to fight potential cuts by the State Legislature.

title: Parents/Children
description: As a parent perhaps there's something really troubling you. You'd like to ask the pediatrician about it, but for one reason or another you've been reluctant to speak up. You berate yourself for not getting the problem out in the Open.

title: Market Place
description: Despite optimism in the municipal bond market over last week's decision by the State Court of Appeals declaring the moratorium on $ 1 billion of New York City notes unconstitutional, there are mixed feelings among the experts regarding the future.

title: Fire in Brooklyn Kills a Woman, 63, and 2 Children
description: A 63yearold tvoman and her two grandchildren died of smoke inhalation in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday morning in a fire apparently set with a flammable liquid, the Fire Department said.

title: The Need for More Powder
description: SEATTLEWe all live with nuclear Weapons, and hope nut to die by them. I??? ago, we tired of thinking about themterrible beyond belief, but so remote from daily life.

title: Fire Control in Top Shape For a Shot at Colonial Cup
description: CAMDEN, S. C.. Nov. 26 Dr. John Fisher, a veterinarian by profession, a trainer by desire and an optimist by nature, gazed out over the bucolic setting of the Springdale Course today. He had just finished sending Woodcrest's (that's Mrs. Charles Norris Jr.) Fire Control through his final workout in preparation for tomorrow's Colonial Cup, the nation's richest steeplechase. You know, said the 40yearold Dr. Fisher, who by his own admission works very little in the veterinarian field these days, I bought Fire Control for Woodcrest in France, and for while T was mighty sorry. But now I'm glad I bought hint.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Syria and Iraq Reach an Accord To Pull Back Troops on Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 26 Syria and Iraq, bitter enemies for years, have made a significant step to reduce tensions by withdrawing most military forces from their border.

title: Books of The Times
description: According to the Random House Dictionary of the English Language, college edition, a polonaise is a slow dance of Polish origin, in triple meter, consisting chiefly of a march or promenade in couples. And that's a fair, if superficial, description of Piers Paul Read's sixth novel. He is also the author of Alive: The Story of the Andes Survivors, which probably sold more copies than all of his intelligent fictions put together. Polonaise originates in Poland and spends most of its time there. It is slow: In following the Kornowskis from 1924 to 1958, it occasionally even dawdles. It is divided into three parts, and obsessed with couples: Stefan and Krystyna, Krystyna and Bruno, Stefan and Rachel, Rachel and Krystyna, Bruno and Stefan, and Annabel and Teofil. The march is to war, and the promenade is of art. Meanwhile, God is waiting in ambush.

title: Retail Stores Sales Rise 8%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 The Department of Commerce said today that total retail store sales for the week ended Nov. 20 were estimated at $12.6 billion, up 8 percent from a year ago when sales were $11.8 billion. Department store sales for the same period were estimated at $1.6 billion, up 12 percent from $1.5 billion a year earlier.

title: YAMANI WARNS AGAINST COUNTERING EMBARGOES
description: LONDON, Nov. 26 Sheikh Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Petroleum Minister, warned the West today against trying to counter Arab oil embargoes with any oilsharing plan. This lie said could lead to the destruction of everyone.

title: For Children Who Make Magic, Advice From a Master Magician
description: Doug Henning, the most exciting magician since Houdini, doesn't look at all like a sorcerer. At age 29 he looks dike a flower child in his sneakers and jeans, with his rippling hair, floppy mustache and bright, amazed eyes. He is short and so skinny that Walter Kerr thought at first glance that he had been sawed in half vertically.

title: JOHN N. ALLMAN
description: John N. Allman, vice president of the insurance firm of Marsh & McLennan of 1221 Avenue of the Americas, died in Chappaqua, N.Y., on Thursday. He was 48 years old.

title: Mary Evans Married To Richard L. Rhodes
description: Mary Magdalene Evans, daughter of Mrs. Charles E. Evans of St. Joseph, Mo., and the late Mr. Evans, was married at the Carriage Club in Kansas City, Mo., last evening to Richard Lee Rhodes, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rhodes of Kansas City, Kan. Judge Harry A. Hall of the Jackson County (Mo.) Circuit Court performed the ceremony.

title: Futures in Wheat, Corn And Soybeans Show Drop Of 2c to 8.5c a Bushel
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP)Soybean and grain futures fell by about 2 to 8 cents in slow postholiday dealings on the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: Business  Nomads  Set  Their  Sights On South Korea's Lush Pastures
description: SEOUL, South Korea Their briefcases are scarred. Their passports are faded. Their suitcase handles carry the torn tags of many a flight.

title: All That Glitters Is Not GemsTrade Show Has Minerals, Too
description: In 1968 an old opal prospector in Sydney, Australia, told a brash young American student named Kenneth Helfand that a milliondollar fortune in opals lay in a mountain 450 miles to the northwest.

title: Lawyer for Antoine And WABC Aides Will Meet Monday
description: WABCTV officials and a lawyer representing Tex Antoine will meet Monday to discuss the fate of the television weatherman who made what he called a human error in an ontheair remark about what women should do when threatened with rape.

title: Avery's Show On Architecture Wide Ranging
description: Columbia's Avery Architectural Library is not merely one of that university's great treasures, it is also one of the city's. Under the guidance of the gracious and erudite Adolf K. Plac??ek, Avery has become not just the finest architectural library in the country, but, in the opinion of many scholars, even the finest in the world.

title: DETECTIVE TESTIFIES Al CARTER'S RETRIAL
description: PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 26 The prosecution in the triplemurder retrial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis today continued its effort to bolster the testimony of its key witness, Alfred P. Bello, with corroborative testimony from other witnesses.

title: Pounding the Beat Is Not a Pedestrian Job
description: Frank Cohen has delivered nine babies, searched for scores of missing children and survived two major race riots, a stationhouse corruption purge and the mysterious enmity of a small, deformed, malnourished looking exconvict who haunts the doorways of upper Broadway and hates the police with passionate intensity.

title: Gov. Grasso Asks for an Inquiry Into Reilly Murder Prosecution
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 26Gov. Ella T. Grasso today ordered a new investigation into the 1973 murder of Barbara Gibbons and requested an inquiry into the prosecution of murder charges against Mrs. Gibbons's son, Peter A. Reilly.

title: The Band Ends Era With Last Waltz
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Nov. 26 The last waltz is always a bittersweet affair. There is the joy of completion and the poignancy of the coda.

title: Article 8    No Title
Mosque Trial Jury Is Told to Continue To Try for Verdict
description: Jurors at the Harlem mosque trial, in their ninth day of deliberations, said yesterday that they still had hopes of reaching a verdict, and the presiding judge ordered the deliberations to continue.

title: Virginia Beardshaw Is Bride of Andrew Cahn
description: Virginia Zachry Beardshaw and Andrew Thomas Cahn were married yesterday afternoon at the Westover School in Middlebury, Conn., by the Rev, Robert. Lee Hammett, an Episcopal priest..

title: France's Retail Prices Up 0.9%
description: PARIS, Nov. 26 (UPI)France's retail prices rose by 0.9 percent in October under the Government's new austerity plan and price freeze, a drop from 1.1 percent in September, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: U.S. Failure to Tax Limousine Services For Officials Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)  The Treasury's failure to collect taxes on the value of limousine service that has been provided for ineligible Government officials is costing taxpayers up to $4.8 million a year, Senator William Proxmire charged today.

title: Ruffled U.S. Raises Brandy Import Duty
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) Presidnt. Ford raised import duties on some Enropean brandies today in the latest. round of a trade dispute between the United States and the Common Market. The duty increases partially restored tariff levels reduced in 1974. But the increases were less than some American farm groups had been demanding and left levies on some European brandies untouched.

title: Unusual Penalty Call on Colgate Keeps Rutgers on Unbeaten Path
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 26 Just a little bit of luck can go a long way toward helping a good football team keep alive a long winning streak.

title: Santa, Too Popular, Loses His Telephone
description: WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 26 (UPI) The telephone company has disconnected Santa Claus's phone. It says he was lust. too popular.

title: maurice villency designs rooms that enhance your own style and taste
description: NEW YORK CITY 200 Madison Avenue Corner 35th Street 7254840 Daily to 6, Thurs. to 9

title: Yugoslavs Affirm Independent Line
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 President Tito and his aides reaffirmed today that Yugoslavia would never join any political, military or state community.

title: BRONFMAN JURY TOLD OF TELEPHONE CALL
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 26 A brotherinlaw of Mel Patrick Lynch, one of the two men on trial for the alleged kidnapping of Samuel Bronfman 2d in August 1975, corroborated today the defendant's testimony that Mr. Lynch received a telephone call from someone named Sam a year before the alleged abduction.

title: Boy, 15, Shot to Death Point Blank; Officer Arrested in East New York
description: A 31yearold policeman with an unblemished record during his eight years on the force was arrested early yesterday and charged with murder in the pointblank shooting of a 15yearold youth in the East New York section of Brooklyn Thursday night.

title: Article 5    No Title
Fighting Westway
description: Opponents of a new Federal interstate highway along Manhattan's West SideWestwayhave argued that the proposed artery could increase air, noise and visual pollution in adjoining neighborhoods. If these environmental problems are their real concern, it is difficult to understand why these same Westway foes have now gone to court to try to block demolition of the crumbling old West Side Highway, which they say they want rebuilt.

title: A 60Degree Day Greets Shoppers And StreetCorner Santa Clauses
description: On a day that seemed designed for Turkey sandwich picnics, vanguard Christmas shoppers turned out in droves yesterday and found New York City to be a 60degree Indiansummer festival.

title: Rutgers Has Its Day After a Good Night
description: TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 26 (UPI)Governor Byrne declared today Hooray for Rutgers Day to ceIebrat.e the State University's 110 season football record.

title: ITALIANS AND VATICAN CONCUR ON REVISIONS IN CHURCHSTATE TIES
description: ROME, Nov. 26 The Italian Government and the Vatican have reached agreement on proposals for major revisions in the concordat that has governed churchstate relations since 1929.

title: Schmidt Tells World Socialists Bad Management Has Hurt Economy
description: GENEVA, Nov 26 Leaders of Socialist movements of the nonCommunist world were told by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today that bad management by governments, not ideology, was to blame for a general economic crisis.

title: Most of a Townin Nevada Wants To Buy Southern Pacific's Part
description: MONTELLO, Nev.. Nov. 26 (AP) Residents of Montello cannot call this tiny northeastern Nevada community their own because the Southern Pacific Railroad owns a third of it. But they are hoping to buy the railroad out with a $20.196 loan from Elko County.

title: FINAL TURKISH TOLL OF 4,000 IS EXPECTED
description: ERZURUM, Turkey, Nov. 26Turkish and foreign efforts to aid victims of the earthquake in eastern Turkey continued to grow today, and informed Turkish sources predicted that the final death toll would be about 4,000.

title: Help of Banks and Pension Funds Held Key to New York's Recovery
description: New York City and State officials said yesterday that the help of the city's banks and pension funds was crucial to solving the problem of paying off $1 billion in shortterm city notes.

title: Athens Staggering Under the Weight of Rural Migration
description: ATHENS, Nov. 26 The Frangos brothers, Tassos and Elias, moved to Athens 10 years ago from Assea, a small village in southern Greece. Over the years they went to school, found good jobs as hotel clerks, and brought their five brothers and sisters and their aged mother to join them.

title: Official Jewish Leaders in Soviet Seek Link to International Groups
description: PARIS, Nov. 26 With apparent Soviet encouragement, a move is under way to establish a formal link between the official Soviet Jewish community and international Jewish bodies.

title: Market Climbs; Energy Stocks Up in Slow Day
description: Energyrelated issues helped send stock prices higher yesterday as the market advanced on a broad front in reduced semiholiday trading.

title: Soviet Bloc Seeks FirstStrike Curb On Nuclear Arms
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 26The Sovietled Warsaw Pact proposed today that the West join in an accord to prohibit the first use of nuclear weapons by either side in a conflict.

title: Huang Said to Be Leaving U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.. Nov. 26 Huang Hua will give up his post soon and return home, delegation sources said today. He is reported to be suffering from a liver ailment.

title: Equity Funding Accord Is Reported
description: The private classaction lawsuits growing out of the Equity Funding scandal are about to be settled for $50 million to $60 million, the New York Law Journal reported yesterday.

title: Jersey's Slump Is DownRated
description: TRENTON, Nov. 26.The State Labor and Industry Department says that while the recession has hit New Jersey the hardest among the states, the economic damage may not be as severe as statistics indicate.

title: A 60Degree Day Greets Shoppers And StreetCorner Santa Clauses
description: On a day that seemed designed for turkey sandwich picnics, vanguard Christmas shoppers turned out in droves yesterday and found New York City to be a 60degree Indiansummer festival.

title: FourthPeriod Spree Wins, 114103
Subpoenas Issued in Paper Inquiry
description: The American Paper Institute acknowledged yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the Department of Justice in connection with a grand jury Investigation of possible price fixing in the industry.

title: With Only U.S. Opposed, Assembly Urges Restudy Of Admission of Vietnam
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26 The General Assembly voted over the lone opposition of the United States tonight for favorable reconsideration of Vietnam's request for admission to the United Nations.

title: TEAMSTERS CONSENT TO DISCUSS PENSIONS
description: The trustees of the major pension fund of the teamsters union have agreed to begin negotiations with the Federal Government concerning the handling and management of the fund's $1.4 billion in assets, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday.

title: Veteran Singer at Hopper's
description: Thelma Carpenter makes it all seem so easy as she sings her songs at Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street, where she is appearing through next Saturday. She simply sings, with no tricks, no coy toying with words or melody. She concentrates on the song and the sense of a song.

title: For 215 Black Youths, New Ark Symbolizes New Life
description: NEWARK, Nov. 26Two years ago, Arthur was found guilty of breaking and entering, and faced time in a juvenile detention center. Instead, the authorities referred him to the New Ark School here, and the I5yearold youth says the experience has made me want to be somebody, to do something.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Korvette Extends Shopping on Sunday for Christmas
description: The Korvette stores, which became the first major retailer in the metropolitan area to start Sunday hours last August, will extend them this Sunday from 6 to 11 hours in 20 of its stores in the area.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Thin Lizzy Cancels Concert
description: The Thin LizzyGasolin rock concert at the Palladium scheduled for tomorrow night has been canceled, because of an injury to Brian Robertson, a member of Thin Lizzy. No new date has been set.

title: Voight Named Top Player
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 26 (AP) Mike Voight, the North Carolina tail. back, who came back strong after a slow start ?? this season, waS named Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year today for the second straight season. He received 51 of the 114 votes in the balloting that included seven other players. Maryland's quarterback, Mark Manges, was second with 20 votes.

title: SHOOTING OF AGENTS IS CONFIRMED BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed today that bureau agents had wounded at least two and perhaps three fellow agents with shotgun fire in a stakeout that thwarted an attempted bank robbery in New Jersey. But a spokesman said that some of the wounds might have been caused by ricochets.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BINGO Muggsthat's the name is a pleasant dropin tavern on the night scene along upper First Avenue, with informal atmosphere, spicandspan rustic decor and bracing music from Marty Tocci's keyboard. Outside, near 62d Street, there's a brightly lighted banner over a compact dining veranda with hanging plants. It's even more cheerful inside, as you perch at the bar amid yellow lamps and wood paneling that widens into a rear table

title: McFall Got $1,000 In Second Payment From South Korean
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) John J. McFall, the majority whip in the House of Representatives, said today that he received $1,000 in cash from the South Korean businessman Park Tong Sun in 1972 in addition to the $3,000 he earlier reported receiving from Mr. Park in 1974.

title: Army and Navy Clash in Football Today
Answers to Quiz
description: Questions on Page 21.

title: St. John's Five And Fairfield Win Openers
description: Glen Williams was sitting in the St. John's locker room last night with both his thumbs stuck in an ice bucket. Those thumbs had just helped the Redmen pull out a plum of a victory, 7965 over Brown, in the opener of the second Joe Lapchiek Memorial basketball tournament.

title: Weekly News Quiz
Taking a Gander at U. N.'s Geese
description: PARIS  One never ceases to be amazed at the medley of moral and political standards prevalent at the United Nations. In the name of international decency and human justice I am delighted that a majority of countries represented in the General Assembly votes overwhelmingly on each occasion presented to condemn the evil practice of. apartheid or racial segregation in South Africaor, for that matter, in Rhodesia and Namibia.

title: Invalid Robbed, 4 Chase Suspect
description: A 22yearold man who allegedly snatched a purse from a woman in a wheelchair yesterday afternoon was caught after being chased into Central Park by the victim's 66yearold husband and three sanitationmen, the police reported.

title: About New York
description: Contrary to the city's official boosterism, you don't have to be crazy to love New York. But you have to fantasize a lot.

title: Westway Decision By U.S. Seems Left To Carter Officials
description: The Federal decision on the controversial Westway Interstate System highway project apparently will be lett for the new Carter Administration despite President Ford's indorsement of the roadway during the recent campaign.

title: Injuries Are Making Jets and Giants Weaker Still
description: In their most troubled areas the Jets and the Giants will be hobbled tomorrow.

title: Henry D. Phelps Is Dead at 74; Among Last of Newport Old Guard
description: Henry Delafield Phelps, an investment banker in Providence, R. I., one of the last surviving members of Newport society's Old Guard, died Thursday at Newport Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at Sunnyfield in Middletown, R. I., which adjoins Newport.

title: Banker, Set for CabinetLevel Job, Will Work on Transitional Budget
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Nov. 26 Thomas Bertram Lance, the first person publicly assured of a Cabinetlevel job in Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's administration, will soon go to Washington to work on transitional budgetary matters, a Cartspokesman said today. It was a further indication that the millionaire banker may become director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Personal Investing
description: lf the strategic approach of three of the best performing mutual funds is any criterion, making money in the stock market these days means concentrating on such traditional basics as undervalued earnings, clean balance sheets, liquidity, and conservative management,

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26Apparatus developed at RCX Laboratories in Princeton monitors human breathing without any physical contact with the subject, who could be an;nfant. The monitoring is done with a special form of radarhighfrequency radio having what is called a Doppler effect.

title: The Filthy Rich
description: CHICAGOIs there a difference between filthy lucre and windfall profits"? Four hundred years.

title: Venezuela and Soviet Union Sign Agreement on Oil Cooperation
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 26 (AP)Venezuela and the Soviet Union signed agreement today on oil and on economic cooperation after what visiting President Carlos Andres Perez called frank and sometimes tough negotiations with his Kremlin counterpart, Nikolai V. Podgorny.

title: Solution for Injection Into Burned Patients
description: Mr. Charles L. Fox Jr., a professor of Surgery at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, was granted Patent 3,993,750 this week for a solution to be injected in seriously burned patients or those recovering from surgery or injuries. It is a blood fluid or plasma substitute designed to compensate for sodium loss.

title: Town Fears Occidental Will Wreck It
description: MIAMI, Ariz., Nov. 24 Katie Weimer looked out from her office at Jesse's Used Car Lot, across the row of automobiles facing Live Oak Street, and she mused about this town's past and her fears for its future.

title: Tito Gives Amnesty to Hundreds To Mark Yugoslavia Anniversary
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 In observance of Yugoslavia's national day on Monday, President Tito has granted the customary holiday amnesty to several hundred prisoners, tinder this year's amnesty decree, 532 prisoners are to have their sentences reduced, and 163 are to receive pardons.

title: Less Joy Is More
description: The things you can rent these days! You can rent a butler, a car, an island, a tuxedo, a painting, a policeman, a sixcourse dinner for 30. You can even rent a killer to dispose of somebody who is inconveniencing you. Before long, if the pound sterling doesn't get hold of itself, you will probably be able to rent England for a weekend.

title: Trapped
description: Many otherwise sensitive persons in late 20thcentury America wear the skins of tortured animals. While the most popular fur is mink, which is usually ranchgrown under relatively humane conditions, approximately onehalf of all furs sold are derived from raccoon, lynx, fox, squirrel and other wild animals.

title: LLOYD GRIFFIN
description: Lloyd Griffin, chairman of the executive committee of Peters Griffin Woodward Inc. ,a television sales concern, died Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: RHODESIAN DEADLOCK OVERCOME AS BLACKS ACCEPT BRITISH PLAN
description: GENEVA, Nov. 26The deadlock that has prevailed at the monthlong conference on Rhodesia's future was overcome tonight when two black nationalist holdouts accepted a British formula fixing March 1, 1978, as the date for independence under black control.

title: Mrs. Grasso Seeks New Inquiries In Reilly Case and Its Prosecution
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 26Gov. Ella T. Grasso today ordered a new investigation into the 1973 murder of Barbara Gibbons and requested an inquiry into the prosecution of murder charges against Mrs. Gibbons's son, Peter A. Reilly.

title: The Issue: Canada Itself
description: It was an incongruous installation ceremony that the Lieutenant Governor presided over in Quebec City on Thanksgiving Day; but it was heavy with significance for the future of Canada. Here were the new Quebec Premier, Rene Levesque and his Parti Quebecois colleagues, all dedicated to an independent Quebec and the dismemberment of Canada, swearing allegiance to Elizabeth II, the Queen of Canada as of Britain.

title: Uncertainty Growing in EastWest Trade Relations
description: VIENNA, Nov. 26 Signs of uncertainty are characterizing the economic relations between freemarket countries and the Communistgoverned nations of Eastern Europe after some years of improved prospects.

title: Open Interest
Trudeau Produces 73 Report Alleging Official Kickbacks
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 26Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau presented to Parliament today a 1973 report charging that Governmentowned chemical company had paid nearly $2 million in kickbacks to foreign customers. He conceded under questioning that there was no record of any action on the matter in the three and a half years since he first heard of it.

title: Grain Executive Admits Guilt in Shortweighting Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 An executive of Cook Industries Inc. who once said he would be completely vindicated on charges of conspiring to shortweight grain export shipments for Cook's benefit pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor described in the indictment against him.

title: A RHODESIA DEADLOCK OVERCOME AS BLACKS ACCEPT BRITISH PLAN
description: GENEVA, Nov. 26The deadlock that has prevailed at the monthlong conference on Rhodesia's future was overcome tonight when two black nationalist holdouts accepted a British formula fixing March 1, 1978, as the date for independence under black control.

title: Drew Paces Hawks With 33 Points
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 26 At long last the Atlanta Hawks won a game on the road. After 28 successive setbacks away from the Omni in Atlanta (seven this season), the Hawks posted a 109105 victory over the New York Nets tonight. John Drew, with 33 points, led their offense before a crowd of 7,269 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: A Community Takes to Heart a Patrolman Afoot
Soviet Bloc Seeks FirstStrike Curb On Nuclear Arms
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 26The Sovietled Warsaw Pact proposed today that the West join in an accord to prohibit the first use of nuclear weapons by either side in a conflict.

title: U.S. and Soviet Clash In U.N. Over Rights
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26 The Soviet Union and the United States clashed so heatedly today during a human rights debate that an Asian onlooker left the General Assembly's Social Committee muttering, Whatever happened to detente?

title: Group Saves 200YearOld Homestead From Bulldozer
description: FAIR LAWN, Nov. 26The chill of late autumn fills the rooms of the 38thcentury farmhouse of dull maroon sandstone and wooden shingles. Outside, an 1810 black kettle hangs suspended from a tilted tripod. Out back, the worn brown siding boards of the carriage house are curling from the ravages of 200 years of wind, rain and sun. The aging cherry tree still towers above the henhouse, its black branches stark against the sky.

title: Citibank Keeps the Interest Rate On Its Corporate Loans at 6%
description: Citibank kept its minimum interest rate on corporate loans unchanged at 6 percent yesterday, the rale most banks are posting on loans to their most creditworthy customers.

title: 10 Die as Gas Line Explodes in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 (AP) A gas line exploded today in Barrientos, a northern, suburb cf Mexico City, and spewed flames that killed at least 10 persons, most of them children, the Red Cross reported. Seventysix people were injured.

title: Upstate Town Reconstructed After Devastation of 72 Flood
description: PAINTED POST, N.Y.The night they scraped the mud off their boots and went into the firehouse to take a look at the master plan taped up on one of the fire trucks, the last thing the people of Painted Post had on their minds was winning some award. They just wanted their town back and quick.

title: Notes on People
description: The 21 secondgraders at the Aspen Elementary School have a new parttime French teacher. She is Claudine Longet, the singer who is awaiting trial in that Colorado resort town for the killing of Vladimir Sabich, the professional skier who was slain by a single bullet last March 21 In the $250,000 home he had shared with Miss Longet for more than a year.

title: MAJOR BUSINESSMEN IN BRITAIN OPPOSED TO DEFLATION MOVES
description: LONDON, Nov. 26 The Confederation of British Industry came out unexpectedly today against the narsh deflationary measures that the Government is expected to take soon so as to qualify for a loan from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Bridge:
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 Two players from Philadelphia who were unknown to fans swept to victory here last night in the blueribbon pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Dollar Generally Steady In Transactions Abroad; Gold Price Is Off a Bit
description: LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP)Major currencies were little changed in slow European trading while gold closed at $130.50 in Zurich, down 50 cents from the previous day, and at $130.625 in London, down from $130.875.

title: Shadow Over Connecticut
description: Though the charges that Peter Reilly murdered his mother, Barbara Gibbons, have finally been dropped, questions about this case and the distortions in Connecticut's criminal justice system still abound. Not the least of the questions is: Who actually did kill Barbara Gibbons?

title: The Socialist International
description: History  The Socialist International, a loose organization of democratic socialist parties from around the world with headquarters in London, was founded in Frankfurt, West Germany, in July 1951. The founders said that they were reestablishing the Labor and Socialist International, which had ceased functioning after the fall of France in World War II. That organization, formed in Hamburg in 1923, had succeeded the Second International, established in Paris in 1889.

title: Johnson Antipoverty Aides Look to Possible Roles Under Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 They might be called the class of HIM, for they are the social engineers who toiled over the blueprints of Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society, which promised nothing less than the elimination of poverty from an affluent society.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Armin Corporation announced yesterday that operations of its computedtime, lightemitting diode watch manufacturing subsidiary in Arlington, Tex., have been discontinued. Competitive conditions in the form of lowpriced electronic watches and the continued softness in the lightemitting diode watch sales made it uneconomical to continue making such watches, the concern said.

title: Alaina Reed Sings Gospel Style
