description: Alaina Reed has touched most of the bases on the local cabaret circuit, she has toured in Hair and has gone as far afield as Australia in Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band on the Road. Now she's appearing for four nights, ending tomorrow, at the Bijou Theater on West 45th Street with a sevenpiece band and two backup singers.

title: Quebec Premier Angrily Rejects Trudeau's Charges of Tribalism
description: QUEBEC. Nov. 26  Ren Lvesque, Quebec's new separatist Premier, declared today that the Canadian federal system no longer answered his province's aspirations and angrily rejected charges that he sought to return to a form of tribalism.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Any day now the Madison Square Garden boxing promoters will announce that Muhammad Ali, who never has been the retiring type, will resume his role as the world heavyweight champion. Ali will defend the title against. Duane Bobick at the Garden in a Feb. 28 closedcircuit TV doubleheader that will include a Ken NortonRon Lyle bout from Las Vegas, For ending his leave of absence, Ali will receive $2.5 million and Bobick will collet $400,000 as a white hope. For agreeing to put aside his contract for a Bobick match, Norton will be consoled with $500,000 and Lyle will receive $100,000 despite a loss to Jimmy Young recently. The money reflects the motive hehind All's return to the ring less than two months after he announced his retirement in Istanbul. Because of his high tax bracket, All can always use $2,5 million for pocket money.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Basic reserve position, 8 malor New York bads

title: Thomas James McKee Weds Ann P. P. Sperber
description: In the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday, Ann Pinckney Proctor Sperber, a member of the public relations staff at Sears, Roebuck & Company, was married to Thomas James McKee, who is a lawyer with Colt Industries. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren performed the ceremony.

title: A 2D VICTIM OF BLAST IN QUEENS, 34, DIES
description: A second worker died yesterday as a result of last Sunday's explosion in a Queens chewinggum factory, and the Queens District Attorney's Office moved to reopen the question of criminal negligence.

title: TEAPSTERS CONSENT TO DISCUSS PENSIONS
description: The trustees of the major pension fund of the teamsters union have agreed to begin negotiations with the Federal Government concerning the handling and management of the fund's $1.4 billion in assets, the Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday.

title: Lots of Books on Magic
description: Here are Doug Henning's suggestions for a library of magic for children 12 years of age and older. Mr. Henning has read all the books and keeps copies of them in his own library.

title: Police Don't Know if 10th Ave. Sniper Is a Vigilante
description: The police said yesterday that they did not know if the two women and a man who were shot early this week at 46th Street and 10th Avenue had been hit by a vigilante determined to clear out the prostitutes and pimps whose presence has incensed residents of the poor neighborhood for many months.

title: Portable Sleep Inducer With Pillow Speaker
description: A portable sleep inducer has a speaker that sits under the pillow and emits a pleasant sound, in tone and strength selected by the user. Trademarked SleepaTone, the equipment is delivered in a case that will fit in a handbag.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions

title: Pitt Wins, 247, and Finishes Unbeaten As Dorsett Breaks Five More Records
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 Tony Dorsett finished his regularseason career as Pittsburgh's tailback tonight with all the flair and skills that have put him alone as possibly the greatestand definitely the most productiverunner in the 108year history of college football.

title: EFFORT IS ON TO SHIFT THE BOARDER BABIES
description: The Human Resources Administration said yesterday that it would attempt to identify the socalled boarder babies in hospitals in New York City so that renewed attempts could be made to place them in appropriate rehabilitative programs and institutions.

title: People in Sports
description: Don Read, head football coach of the University of Oregon Ducks, was dismissed yesterday after his third straight losing season. His wonlost record for 1976 was 47: in three years his record was 924. In that period his teams had won only three Pacific8 Conference games, and two of those were against Oregon State, the team that shared the conference cellar with the Ducks this season. Read's contract for $30,000 a year still had one year to go.

title: 3 ACCUSED IN LOOTING OF STORE IN THE BRONX
description: Two police officers who broke up a store looting in the Bronx last night; stumbled onto a cache of drugs and arms in a bar where the three alleged looters, including the store's security guard, were arrested. The loot included 10 ounces of cocaine with an estimated street. value of up to $10,000, 10 ounces of marijuana, a machine gun and a shotgun.

title: Marsh Ahead By Two Shots In Dunlop Golf
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan., Nov. 26 (AP) Graham Marsh of Australia shot a threeunderpar 60 today for a 135 total and gained a. twostroke lead after the second round of the $200,000 Dunlop Phoenix golf tournament. Marsh, 32 years old, birdied three of his first four holes and never trailed.

title: Elizabeth MacDonald Manning, Publisher of Finance Magazine
description: Elizabeth MacDonald Manning, a magazine publisher, died Thursday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. She was 57 years old and lived at 5 East 75th Street.

title: City Ballet in Other Dances, Robbins Duet
description: It takes all ways to make a ballet. The origins of Jerome Robbins's Other Dances are almost unexpected. It was created as a piece d'occasion for James Lipton's gala evening for the benefit of the New York Public Library on May 19 of this year. But the piece has outlived, triumphantly, the occasion.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions on Page 21,

title: Unit Votes to Permit 2 Schools to Join Pac8
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 26 (AP) An Arizona Board of Regents committee agreed today to recommend that Arizona and Arizona State be allowed to join the Pacific8 Conference. Four of the five members of the policy committee voted to make the recommendation to the full Board of Regents, which tneets tomorrow. The motion is expected to carry.

title: 17 AT U.N. URGE TREATY AGAINST HOSTAGETAKING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26 Seventeen countries called today for an international treaty against the taking of hostages.

title: Article 2    No Title
House Study Urged in Black Panther Death
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 26 (UPI)  A House committee was asked today to investigate the 1969 killing of Fred Hampton, a Chicago Black Panther Party leader, on the ground that he had been set up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation through an informer and murdered in a raid carried out by a special force of the Chicago police.

title: Kerr Wissler Becomes Bride
description: Kerr L. T. Wissler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland H. Wissler of San Bernardino, Calif., was married there last night to William Everett Low, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Low of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. James C. Huffstutler performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: U.S. Signs Fishing Agreements With Soviet Union and Mexico
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)The United States signed agreements with Mexico and the Soviet Union today governing fishing zones off the United States and Mexican coasts.

title: End of Long, Long Snail
description: BRIGHTON, England, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Geronimo, the world's longest known snail, died in his sleep here today, aged 6. Geronimo is listed in the Guinness book of World Records as being 13 inches long. He had appeared on British television 52 times.

title: ITALIANS AND VATICAN CONCUR ON REVISIONS IN CHURCHSTATE TIES
description: ROME, Nov. 26The Italian Government and the Vatican have reached agreement on proposals for major revisions In the concordat that has governed churchstate relations since 1929.

title: British Jail 3 in Liner Plot
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 26 (AP) Three men were convicted today of conspiracy to contravene the Explosive Substance Act in what the prosecution said was to have been an Irish Republican Army attempt to blow up the liner Queen Elizabeth 2. William Baker and James Bennett were given the maximum sentence of 20 years in prison and Bernard McCaffery received a 16year sentence.

title: Chris Evert and Sue Barker Reach Tokyo Tennis Final
Toyota Will Introduce Vehicle Designed for the Asian Market
description: TOKYO, Nov. 26 (Reuters) The Toyota Motor Company of Japan has announced that it will shortly introduce a new low. priced vehicle specially designed for the Asian market.

title: Robert Dodds, 62; An EngineerEditor For McGrawHill
description: Robert H. Dodds, a civil engineer and a senior editor of Engineering NewsRecord, a McGrawHill publication, died Thursday at Rosary Hill in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 62 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: A Dose of Applied Psychology Draws Diners and Feeds an Ego
description: Many restaurant proprietors insist that they are amateur psychologists, hut Arthur Weider, the man cajoling customers on First Avenue, is a professional.

title: Unemployment Up in E.E.C.
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 26 (Reuters)Unemployment is increasing again among European Economic Community nationsnotably in West Germany, France, Belgiurn and Denmarkafter falling slightly during the summer, according to the figures released today by the European Economic Community Commission.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Nassau County police announced the arrest of a 27yearold unemployed carpenter on charges of having offered up to $5,000 for the murder of his fatherinlaw. The suspect, John Whirl Jr. of 346 Yale Road, Garden City South, L. I., was charged with three counts of firstdgree criminal solicitation. The police still are searching for the killer of Mr. Whirl's fatherinlaw, Herbert Bunora, 75, who was gunned down outside his home at 1263 Cambria Street, Uniondale, L. I., last Dec. 31.

title: A 60Degree Day Helps Shopping And Sunbathing
description: On a day that seemed designed for turkey  sandwich picnics, vanguard Christmas shoppers turned out in droves yesterday and found New York City to he a 60degree Indiansummer festival.

title: Kuchar Wins Florida Golf
description: JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla., Nov 26 (AP) Wally Kuchar of Erdenhein, Pa., posted a twounderpar 70 today to win the 54hole Jacksonville Beach open of the Florida Professional Golfers' Associatien with a. 207. Jim King of. Miami and Bob Erickson of San Antonio, Tex., tied for second with 208's.

title: Oklahoma Downs Nebraska OnTouchdown in Final0:38
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 20 (AP) Two pass plays set up a 2yard scoring run by Elvis Peacock, a halfback. with 38 seconds left in the game today to give eighthranked Oklahoma a 2017 Big Eight. Conference football victory over Nebraska. No. 10.

title: Groundbreaking Today At Track and Field Hall
description: CHARLESTON, W. VA., Nov. 26 (AP)  This year's United States track and field Olympic medalists and members of past Olympic teams will participate tomorrow in groundbreaking ceremonies for the National Track and Field Hall of Fame.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Peking Purge May Have Claimed New Victims
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 26 There are indications that Chino Kuanhua, China's urbane Foreign Minister, may be the latest victim of the spreading campaign against Chiang Ching, Mao Tsetung's widow, and three other disgraced members of the Politburo.

title: Flames Rout Blues; Maintain Hot Streak
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 26 (AP) David Shand's 40toot slap shot snapped a 22 first period tie, sparking the Atlanta Flames to a 52 National Hockey League victory tonight over the St. Louis Blues.

title: ... Won't Clear the Air
description: For the second time in less than a year, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has gone to court to try to force local officials to carry out one of the 28 transportation control strategies that the city and state themselves proposed more than three years ago.

title: World News Briefs
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 26 (Reuters) Robert Havemann, a physicist who is a persistent critic of the East German Communist Party, was arrested today, friends of the dissident reported.

title: Balanchine and Larchmont
description: I think it can be agreed among us that, in large measure, the woes of New York flow from problems engendered by social changes in the country at large; that in Washington there has been a considered policy these past 10 or 15 years of favoring the Sunbelt regions, small towns, and suburbs at the expense of Northeastern cities stained by wickedness, permissiveness, and liberalism; that the financial waste alleged against New York, while troubling, is Lilliputian compared with that which marks, say, the Pentagon and its satellite corporations; that our true sin, in the eyes of Philistine skinflints and neoconservative ideologues, has been the decencyif not sufficient, still impressive  with which New York has treated its poor; that two or three pieces of enlightened legislation like federalization of welfare and national health insurance, worthy in their own right and hardly a threat to any hierarchies of power, could soon ease the plight of the city; and that only a fresh national policy emphasizing the social goals of the welfare state, which right now means measures designed to save our cities from collapse, can yield a remedy.

title: Constructing Houses With Extrudable Plastic
description: A New York contractor and designer believes his extrudable plastic construction forms promise mass housing without the need for skilled labor.

title: A Man Is Sought in Shootings Of 2 TeenAge Girls in Queens
description: Two teenage girls were shot in a usually quiet section of Bel'erase, Queens, by a young man early this morning, the police reported. One girl was later described by the police as in critical condition and the other as in serious condition in Long Island Jewish Hospital.

title: Number Is Chosen For $980,000 Lottery
description: The New York State Lottery director, John D. Quinn, announced winning numbers last night for the Colossal YearEnd Bonus Drawing, with a $980000 top prize, and for the Holiday Lottery.

title: Dow Chemical, in a Slow Start, Builds Market in East Germany
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 26  The Dow Chemical Company, a pioneer in trade with Eastern Europe, has entered a new market in East Germany with a longterm agreement with this Communist country. As in most pioneer work, the beginning has not. been easy for Dow, the first American company to set up an office in East Berlin, or for Robert Marshall, the company's 30yearold representative, who is from Baltimore.

title: Federal Funds Average Rate Hits 4.90%, Low for Last Seven Months
description: The average rate on overnight loans of Federal funds, the basic shortterm interest rate of the money market and the rate most directly under the control of the Federal Reserve, dropped to 4.90 percent in the week ended Wednesdayits lowest level in seven months  in the wake of the central bank's new easier monetary policy.

title: Beirut's Delegate to U.N. Is Active Again After War
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 26 Edouard Ghorra, the delegate of Lebanon, is eagerly preparing for a long telephone call to the Foreign Ministry in Beirut.

title: Trudeau Produces '73 Report Alleging Official Kickbacks
description: OTTAWA. Nov. 26 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau presented to Parliament today a 1973 report charging that a Governmentowned chemical company had paid nearly $2 million in kickbacks to foreign customers. He conceded under questioning that there was no record of any action on the matter in the three and a half years since he first heard of it.

title: Louisiana Coast Is Patrolled for Smugglers
description: BELLE CHASE, La., Nov. 26 (UPI)United States Customs officials, housed in a new $400,000 command post, are attempting to protect. Louisiana's marshy coast from smugglers of Colombian cocaine.

title: Parents and Neighbors Shocked; Little Sister Doesn't Understand
description: Annie Brannon carried a Crumpled tissue in her hand as she walked slowly around her seventhfloor apartment at 515 Fountain Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn. Occasionally she would stop and stare vacantly, but she said little to the two dozen relatives and neighbors who had gathered to mourn the death of her 15yearold son, Randolph Evans.

title: Boy, 15, Shot to Death PointBlank; Officer Arrested in East New York
description: A 31yearold policeman with an unblemished record during his eight. years on the force was arrested early yesterday and charged with murder in the pointblank shooting of a 15yearold youth in the East. New York section of Brooklyn Thursday night.

title: A Decade Old, ConsciousnessRaising Develops a New Look
description: Consciousnessraising groups, formed in the 1960's to heighten women's awareness of sex discrimination through the sharing of personal experiences, have evolved into nonprofessional therapy groups in which women explore personal problems such as loneliness land low selfesteem.

title: XEROX PUBLISHES A LIST OF FOREIGN, U.S. PATENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26The Xerox Corporation published this week in the Offical Gazette of the Patent and Trademark Office a long list of American and foreign patents offered for license under a consent order reached with the Federal Trade Commission on July 29, 1975.

title: Puerto Rico Stirred by Charges Of Wiretaps by Phone Company
description: SAN JUAN, P. R. In a complex case that has liven compared to the Watergate scandal. Federal and Commonwealth authorities are investigating charges that the Governmentowned Puerto Rico Telephone Company violated the rights of hundreds of citizens and engaged in political espionage, through extensive and illegal wiretapping of private telephone conversations.

title: SHEET STEEL PRICES tiLL BE RAISED 6% BY 4 MORE MAKERS
description: Four more of the nation's top 10 steelmakers said yesterday they planned to raise prices of sheet steel by 6 percent Dec. 1, They were the Armco Steel Corporation, Inland Steel Company, Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation.

description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 26 Wealthy farmers eased tensions in rural areas, of northwestern Mexico today by donating 30,000 acres of their property to landless peasants who for the past week have been pressing their demands for plots of their own by invading private farmlands.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) Corporations,unions and Government contractors can legally contribute to the committee that will foot the bill for Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's inaugural festivities. the Federal Election.. Commission. said today.

title: Article 4    No Title

description: MOSCOW. Nov. 26 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today launched its 868th Cosmos research satellite into earth orbit to continue studies of outer space, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

description: LIVINGSTON, Nov. 26New Jersey will have its first specially constructed medical unit for victims of severe burns within 90 days, officials of St. Barnabas Medical Center said today.

description: ERZURUM, Turkey, Nov. 26Turkish and foreign efforts to aid victims of the earthquake in eastern Turkey continued to grow today, and informed Turkish sources predicted that the final death toll would be about 4,000.

They just wanted their town back and quick.

description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) Don (Duck) Williams hit an 18foot jumper with IS seconds to play in an overtime period today to give Notre Dame an 8079 basketball victory over highly ranked Maryland.

description: MADRID, Nov. 27 (Reuters)  Spanish opposition leaders demanded legal status tonight for all political parties and an equal share of press and broadcast coverage before a referendum is held next month on Government plans to make Spain more democratic.

title: Yesterday's Folkies Are Today's Cabaret Singers
Women of Courage
description: Margaret Truman has written a book that will delight the feminist heart, and will also nourish feminist stirrings in many American women who are only now beginning to feel differently about themselves and who want to know more about the extraordinary women of this country's past. This is not a hook by an accomplished historian. There are no startling insights or subtle character studies. It is rather a simple narrative by an admitted patriot (this in itself is refreshing!) who happens to be the daughter of a former President of the United States. That is why one cares about her choices for great American heroines. She has, after all, a personal attachment to the history of this country.

title: Mary Jo Janak Married To Richard Marin on L.I.
description: Mary Jo Janak and Richard A. Marin were married yesterday morning in St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hempstead, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas J. Reynolds.

Last week shells were fired from Lebanon into Israel. Nobody was hurt and the event itself lacked military significance, but it did serve to emphasize the political importance of who controls southernmost Lebanon.

Richard Gardner Fabian performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Branford Memorial Chapel at Yale University, from which Mr. Macgill graduated in 1965.

Va., Nov. 27The Federal Bureau of investigation monitored editorial criticism of its activities made by West Virginia's leading daily newspaper, The Charleston Gazette, conducted criminal record checks of its owners and editors and, on orders from J. Edgar Hoover, the late F.B.I. director, denied the newspaper any information or assistance.

Something always does; he seems to he on Marvin daylight time, which is often days behind everyone else. The only time he respects is the one on the 24second clock.

title: Massachusetts Concern to Gild West Virginia Capitol's Dome
Bergen to Provide

The program will offer therapeutically oriented social, recreational and health services for 25 elderly persons a day, with the initial registration limited to 100.

title: Remembered Laughter
description: Protean is not a large enough, or even a long enough, word to describe the abundant talents of Noel Coward. He was a playwright, actor, songwriter, singer, director, novelist, shortstory writer, poet and autobiographer. His early memoir, Present Indicative, is one of the most buoyant, euphoric books ever written about a life in the theater. The plays, Private Lives and Design for Living, the movie, Brief Encounter, and such songs as Mad Dogs and Englishmen, also imperishable.

description: ALAWYER from New Jersey plays a prominent role in unearthing a scandal that leads to the downfall of a leader in government. Watergate? Not quite.

title: Setting Precedents
A WOMAN IN REVOLT
description: Flora Tristan, the grandmother of Gauguin, was France's first feminist who might have been forgotten in the rush of history had it not been for Professor Dominique Desanti's sensitive, brilliant, and masterful biography. This is surely one of the must read books of the year, which will still be read decades from now.  SUZANNE HENIG, PH.D. San Diego State University

description: Five hundred patients were evacuated safely from a fire in a large mental hospital in Montreal last night.

description: A mistrial was declared yesterday al the murder trial of Lewis 17X Dupree, charged with killing a policeman four vears non inside a Harlem mosque.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
Changing Profile of Turtle Bay
description: You can see it on old maps: a little cove off the East River between 45th and 48th Streets. It doesn't look much like a turtle, but they called it Turtle Bay, perhaps because turtles inhabited it. One theory is that the name was an Anglicized version of deutal, Dutch for a slightly bent blade, but the bay doesn't really look like that, either.

The protesters said that 35,000 people were still living in tents, campers and shacks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Girl Next Door

title: CHESS
description: The problem that a hypermodern defense poses for the attacker is how far and how quickly he can throw his center pawns forward before they crumble under a sharp counterattack. In the opening, moves spent building a central pawn phalanx subtract from the time that could be used getting pieces into play. Consequently, the advantage of a spacecontrolling pawn center has to be weighed against the disadvantage of retarded development.

title: Miracles for What?
description: Cures are now being achieved in about 47 percent of all cancer cases in this country, Dr. J. Herbert Dietz of the MemorialSloanKettering Cancer Institute reported at a recent meeting. But, he added, the miracles being worked by medical science are often negated by the Catch22 situation in which many of the cancer victims find themselves.

description: PEKING, Nov. 27 (Reuters)The chief Soviet negotiator at the stalled border talks received an unusually warm welcome when he returned today after an 18month break.

description: The season gets into full swing, starting with City College at Columbia, 116th Street and Broadway, Tuesday night. On Wednesday night, Yale is at Fordham, Navy at Princeton and Scranton at %St. Francis in Brooklyn. Thursday night, Columbia is at. Rutgers and Hofstra plays at Temple. Saturday, Manhattan visits Fairfield, Columbia meets Iona in New Rochelle and Vanderbilt is at St. John's, Grand Central and Utopia Parkway in Jamaica, Queens. All are 8 P.M. games. City College is at Hofstra 2 P.M. Saturday.

description: Bob Trumpy, Cincinnati Bengals' tight end, on today's key game with the Pittsburgh Steelers: We're not afraid of Pittsburgh. We're absolutely going to win.

title: In Summary
description: There will be an early test of strength in the contest between moderates and conservatives for control of the Republican Party, and it will occur because the chairman of the Republican National Committee has decided to resign, instead of completing two more years of her term, to let the party get the fighting over with long before the next national elections.

title: P.L.O. REJECTS CALL TO SURRENDER ARMS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 27Officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization, in an open challenge to Syria, announced today that they had rejected a demand for the surrender of heavy weapons still in their hands in the Palestinian refugee camps and in the southern part of Lebanon.

title: 100,000 Elderly Residents in a Plan To Give Early Warnings of Trouble
description: Most people find only bills in the mailbox, but 100,000 elderly Manhattan and I Bronx residents find security there. They are registered with the city's Early Alert Program, which works with the Post Office to detect and rescue citizens in trouble.

title: American Folk Song Is Tinged With The Bizarre
description: Buddy Doyle was a blind dwarf who sang for his living on the streets of Memphis, Tennessee, Dewey Segura, a Cajun accordionist, ran moonshine liquor between Louisiana and Texas, while his children feigned sleep atop the 50gallon tank in the rear of his sedan. Jimmie Strothers, a bigvoiced man with an apparently inexhaustible repertory of reels, rags, blues, and gospel songs, was incarcerated at Virginia's State Prison Farm for having murdered his wife with an axe.

title: Hedy Hartman, Art Aide, Bride
description: Hedy Hartman and Jon Abbott Mersereau, both of whom graduated cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania last year, were married yesterday afternoon at the Carlyle. Criminal Court Judge Harold Mayer performed the ceremony.

title: Childwold
description: By Joyce Carol Oates. 295 pp. New York: The Vanguard Press. $8.95.

title: SAMUEL ZAHN DEAD
description: Samuel Zahn, who had been a principal dress manufacturer in New York City and a leader in its dress industry until his retirement in 1955, died Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and also lived at the Sherry Netherland Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Jackson Decides to Play for the Yankees
description: Reggie Jackson, the most glamorous member of the first freeagent family in baseball's revolution, has agreed to play for the Yankees.

title: Desegregation Struggle for Balance
description: A DOZEN of New Jersey's 607 publicschool districts must develop a plan for desegration before January. Orders to alter their classroom structure were handed down eight years ago. It isn't always a case of segregation, said Nida E. Thomas, director of the Office of Equal Education Opportunity, which oversees enforcement of desegregation programs for the state's Department of Education. Sometimes, there is a question of resegregation, implementation or updating. We must always be alert to achieving a balance.

title: Article 2  No Title
Vince Lombardi's Son
description: His name is Vince Lombardi, his title is administrative assistant to the general manager of the Seattle Seahawks, and his heritage is obvious. But he probably would not be with a club in the National Football League if his father were still alive.

title: Headliners
description: After a stormy career that made him one of the 20th century's more influential literary figures and one of France's more prominent political figures, Andre Malraux died last week. Mr. Malraux first gained international prominence with his 1933 novel, Man's Fate, an examination of Chinese revolutionaries belief that their selfsacrifice would lead to a happier society. His proclivity for personal adventureas a pilot for the Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War and as an underground fighter during the Nazi occupation of Franceadded to his fame as an opponent of Fascism. His World War II associations also brought him into close association with Charles de Gaulle and into a new governmental career that merged literature, art and politics. When President de Gaulle resigned in 1969, Mr. Malraux returned to his writing. He was now in poor health, however, and last week, after a brief hospitalization for pulmonary congestion, he died.

title: Weakness of Peso Hurting Businesses on U.S. Border
Jewish Life in Legend
description: Of these seven books on Jewish themes, one, Isaac Bashevis Singer's A TALE OF THREE WISHES (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $4.95), is told as naturally as breathing and outshines the others as the Sabbath does the workdays of the week.

title: Australia's Bacon Favorite Of the Equestrian Crowd
description: Kevin Bacon's eyes twinkled at the question. He pondered for several seconds and then broke into a broad grin.

title: Sometimes It Is Helpful, and Sometimes Not
description: The ability of radio, television and the press to sell everything from toothpaste that brightens the sex life to cigarettes that liberate women is well known to the commercial interests that market the products and the public who buys them.

title: A Play About A Most Unlikely Messiah A Most Unlikely Messiah
Walt Disney
description: An American Original. By Bob Thomas. Illustrated. 379 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $9.95.

title: PEOPLE
description: There may be some irony in the fact that New York City's financial fate may be somewhat in the hands of a New Jerseyan. He is Orin Kramer of South Orange, who last spring quit his $25,000ayear job as a special assistant to Richard C. Leone. the State Treasurer, to campaign for Jimmy Carter. When New York officials asked last week to be able to plea the city's new crisis with the Presidentelect, Mr. Carter sent Mr. Kramer to represent him. Known in New Jersey as a talented young economist, Mr. Kramer may end up in the Carter Administratien either as a White House assistant or as an Official of the Treasury Department.

title: Miss Moran Has Nuptials
description: Victoria Mary Moran, daughter of M. Frances Moran of Ridgefield, Conn., and the late George Bernard Moran Jr., was married in New York yesterday to Bruce Malcolm Gras, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon W. Gras of Washington. The Rev. Dr. Terence A. Finlay performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. A reception was given at the York Club.

title: Seaford Takes a Road to the Past
description: RESIDENTS of Seaford have convinced their merchants to make the business district more attractive by recapturing some of the flavor of the village's nautical past.

title: The Life and Times Of The Merry Widow
description: For a widow of 71, Hanna Glawari certainly gets around. Never long away from New York the eponymous heroine of Franz Lehar's The Merry Widow returns on Wednesday night to take up residence at the Light Opera of Manhattan.

title: DR. DAVID MARINE, 96, FOUND GOITER'S CURE
description: Dr. David Marine, a pathologist who. discovered the iodine treatment for goiter and other thyroid disorders almost 70 years ago, died Friday at Beebe Hospital in Lewes, Del. He was 96 years old and had lived in Rehoboth Beach, Del.. since his retirement in 1945.

title: It's Still Harry's Company
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.Henry F. Fischbach emigrated to this country from Rumania in 1903, at age 12. His possessions were in a bale and the bale was on his back. I was the porter, and I gave myself the tip, he said.

title: DINING OUT
When Prices Go Up, Up, Up
description: It took Buzzie Bavasi and Jerry Kapstein three minutes to agree that for Rollie Fingers the future was a seat in the bullpen of the San Diego Padres. The relief pitcher with the most elegantly waxed mustache in baseball was the 10th and last of Kapstein's clients to sell his services to a new employer after working out his contract and achieving free agency. The Dodgers, Cardinals, Pirates and especially the San Francisco Giants had been romancing him, but nobody met his price until Bavasi agreed to go into the pocket of Ray Kroc, the McDonald hamburger potentate who owns the Padres.

title: The World
description: In Summary

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: In Europe nobody is going to put up much of an argument against the proposition that Herbert von Karajan is the world's preeminent conductor. Especially in Germany and Austria the man is an untouchablethe criterion to which all conductors must aspire. But in England and America, Karajan is greeted with more reservation. Indeed, Karajan's recently concluded series in Carnegie Hall with the Berlin Philharmonic did not evoke a rapturous press. Quite the contrary. There were comments about Karajan's coolness and objectivity, and the feeling was that Karajan was too concerned with the outward rather than the inner aspects of music, ending up with perfect but lifeless interpretations.

title: The Cloud That Won't Go Away
description: ALFRED J. SCOTTI, whose decades in law enforcement have made him cautious in his public statements, says that his new job as special state prosecutor for Suffolk County speaks for itself.

title: Seahawks Evans Is an Original Again
description: Norm Evans, an original Miami Dolphin in 1966 and an original Seattle Seahawk in 1976, has written a book, On The Line, trying to show people what it's like inside the head of the average offensive lineman.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Brotherhood

title: Bryan Dixon Weds Jean Marie Lown
description: Jean Marie Lown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Freer Lown of Kingston, N. Y., was married yesterday morning to Bryan Dixon, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Aubrey Dixon Jr. of Frederick, Md. The Rev. Robert Zimmerli performed the ceremony in the chapel of Calvary United Methodist church in Frederick.

title: Florida Urges Army Corps to Put Dredged Sand on Eroding Beaches
description: NAPLES, Fla.Officials in Florida are backing a plan to have the United States Army Corps of Engineeis place quality sand dredged from Federal inlets and channels onto Florida's seriously eroding !beaches, rather than dump it at sea.

title: The Mixed Reasons for New, U.S. NaziHunt
description: Thirtyfive years and more have passed since the shootings echoed. World War II has been over for more than 31 years, the Nuremberg trials for more than 30.

title: Soviet Boxers Capture 6 of 10 Bouts With U.S.
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 27 (AP)The Soviet Union boxing program regained sonic of the stature it lost at the Montreal Olympics last summer as the Soviet heavyweight team defeated a United States team, 6 bouts to 4, tonight.

title: Klan Held Active in Marine Base
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Nov. 27 (AP)The executive director of the San Diego Urban League says there is an active Ku Klux Klan chapter at Camp Pendleton and the Marine Corps knows all about it. The allegation was made yesterday by Clarence Pendleton Jr. who said that. the presence of white supremacist groups might have been the motivation for a group of black marines making a commandostyle raid on a white barracks two weeks ago.

title: Lucille Ball Looks Back On 25 Years Of Laughs
Studentless Schools Take a New Course
description: THE gymnasium of the abandoned Newhridge Road Elementary School in East Meadow no longer echoes to the shouts of excited gradeschool gym classes. But it will soon hear instead the clink of silverware and the applause of a theater audience.

title: Cotton Bowl Berth Won By Houston
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 27 (AP)Seventhranked Houston, playing its first season in the Southwest Conference, got five touchdown runs from Alois Blackwell and Daryl Thomas and routed Rice, 4220, today.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT RULES CURFEW LAW IS UNCLEAR
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has declared a curfew law for children under 17 in Norwich, N. Y., unconstitutional because it set no morning hour at which the curfew should end.

New Lawyers Find Job Prospects Rise Despite Predictions
Gottfried, Solomon Reach South Africa Tennis Final
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 27 (UPI)Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., upset topseeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 46, 63, 75, today and reached the final of the South African open tennis championships.

title: Rocky Isn't Based on Me, Says Stallone, But We Both Went the Distance We Both Went the Distance, Says Stallone
ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: DALLAS This city willed itself into being. According to the local historian A. C. Greene, It did not come about by historical accident or through natural advantage, There was no real reason for its existence; like so much else in Texas it was promoted into reality by one man, John Neely Bryan, who picked a spot and announced from a promontory on a sometimes river, in Moseslike fashion, that the city was born. Lacking rationale or assets, Dallas made things happen that had no reason to happen, like bending the railroad to go through town, This stubborn, willful ingenuity, or making something out of nothing, is the basis of its character and style.

title: Dorothy Van Kennen Is Wed
description: The marriage of Dorothy Duncan Van Kennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fisher Van Kennen of Ponte Vedra, Fla., and Winnetka, Ill., to Richard Rodgers Beaty took place in White Plains yesterday. The bridegroom, son of Julian B. Beaty Jr. and Mrs. Henry Arthur Guettel, both of New York, was named for his grandfather, Richard Rodgers, the composer. He is known, however, as Tod.

description: GENEVA, Nov. 27Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel called today for a renewed Geneva peace conference for the Middle East, modeled on the European security conference at Helsinki in 1975.

title: The Light Makes All the Difference
Book Ends
Beame, Meet Carey, But Don't Ask For Money
description: When Mayor Beame faced the cameras recently to report that the court order to pay investors back $1 billion was indeed a problem of some gravity, he said reassuringly that he was confident something could be worked out. He explained: Everybody wants to help.

title: Dental Study on Brushing Styles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (Reuters)The American Journal of Public Health reports in its November issue that a monthlong study of 311 children 10 and 11 years old has shown that it did not make any difference to dental health whether they brush their teeth with upanddown strokes or in little circles.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Several years ago Patricia Hearst was removed from her apartment against her will and some months later convicted of a bankrobbery that everyone seems to agree she would never have participated in if she hadn't been kidnapped in the first place. People who get mugged in the park shouldn't have been walking there. They were asking for it. So do rape victimseveryone knows that. At one time or another in their history, all religions have. managed to suggest that the successful man has been smiled upon by God, meaning, of course, that the poor wretch with nine children, no income and a terminal disease is being suitably punished. Sometimes it's called the Protestant ethic: Victims are guilty. Lewis Carroll put it this way:

title: THOUSANDS IN LISBON DENOUNCE AUSTERITY
To Get and Hold Industry
description: NASSAU COUNTY can no longer rely on automatic development and automatic growth. More and more industrial concerns are pulling up roots and resettling in other parts of the country, and many others went out of business during the recent downturn in the economy. The longsoughtafter peace in the world has resulted in a decline in the county's defenseoriented industries.

title: Manila Presses Its Drive on Liberal Catholics With Arrests and Closing of Radio Stations
These Women Can Speak for Themselves
Guilty Conscience Costs $1,000
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Nov. 27 (AP)An electricity thief with a guilty conscience is the likely source of $1,000 sent anonymously to the Massachusetts Electric Company here, according to Donald A. Graves, district manager. A note inside an envelope containing ten $100 bills said, For service not paid for. For guilty conscience.

title: SHOP TALK
description: COMMUTER trains still stop at the Oradell station, but most people who go inside these days aren't buying tickets. Three years ago, four women leased the station from the Bergen County town and turned it into the Cricket Gift Shop.

title: Kathie Frankel Engaged To Gilbert Michel Claret
description: Kathie Dana Frankel, a lawyer living in Paris, plans to be married in May to Gilbert Michel Claret, a lawyer with the Paris firm of Lepaulle & Jeantet.

title: Pamela Hope Arnold Is Bride of Alan Schiz
description: Pamela Hope Arnold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Emerson Arnold of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Alan Michael Schiz in Temple Sinai in Stamford, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Schiz of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Samuel M. Silver performed the ceremony.

title: Rojas Takes A.A.U. Run
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27  Rick Rojas, a 24yearold Harvard graduate from Boulder, Colo., won the Amateur Athletic Union national crosscountry title today with a recordbreaking run over 10,000 meters at hilly Fairmont Park.

title: Hofstra Five Reaches Final Against Dowling
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 27Hofstra and Dowling advanced to the final of the first Hofstra Tipoff basketball tournament today. Hofstra defeated C. W. Post, 10082, in the first game and Dowling beat Adelphi, 6867.

title: Columbia Observatory in Rockland County Ruled Exempt From Local Property Taxes
description: In a potential landmark decision, a New York State Supreme Court, justice has ruled that Columbia's LamontDoherty Geological Observatory is exempt from local property taxes even though it is engaged mainly in research rather than teaching.

title: LEGISLATORS TESTIFY ON MANDEL'S BEHALF
Article 1  No Title

description: VASHON ISLAND, Wash.Seattle's skyline recedes as one of. the 35 daily ferries lurches to a landing at this small island of cottages, estates and evergreensa haven for 7,000 residents who like being close to the city but not too close.

title: Communities' Pleas Bring Back Patrolmen
description: The Police Department has been getting so many complaints from community residents who miss their fa. miliar beat patrolmen, that it has quietly, selectively, begun shifting some of them back to their old schedules. Officer Cohen said yesterday that he been told by his captain he would officially resume his regular Deal and regular daily schedule next Monday.

title: Top Navy Runner Follows His Father's Path to Glory
Heather M. Campbell Married to John M. Hill
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Heather Mowatt Campbell, dauahter of Col. William Reginald Campbell, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Campbell of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Newport. to John Michael Hill. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hill of Cazenovia N.Y.

title: Another Day of Hunger for the Aged
description: BY the standards of our youthoriented society, the couple is old: He is 66 and blind, she is 65 and suffers from heart disease and chronic arthritis. They live in the large, twostory house in which they reared their six children, each of whom has long since left to begin a family and build a career. And last Thursday the old couple was trapped alone on the Island, enduring the pangs of hunger, on our national day of thanks.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ONE worthwhile way to spend a winter afternoon indoors is to label all valves and plumbing lines in the basement or attic. All too often when an emergency develops that calls for the quick shutting off of a water, gas or hotwater valve, time is lost looking for the right one.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Formal Protest Lodged Over a Bit of Informality

title: Christopher and His Kind
description: Revisionism is the fashionable word for it, but the impulse to revise the definitive version of an epoch or an episode is as old as history. New evidence fuels new interpretations; perhaps even more important, changes in the spirit of the age and in the nature of the life we live have their effect upon our view of the past. To take a single instance, highly relevant to Christopher Isherwood's new DOOK, Christopher and His Kind, there is our gradually relaxing and more sensible attitude toward homosexuality. In the 1930's, the years of the Isherwood legend, it was no longer the love that dares not speak its name, but it was still a subject to be treated with A maximum of discretion and a minimum of candor. A book such as this one, in which the selfdeclared homosexuality of the author is made an essential, if not the essential, element in his recollection of the decade, might have been written then; its publication would have been thought unwise.

title: Celtics Trample Knicks
Berkeley Likely to Reject Plan To Charge Motorists for Entry
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 27 (UPI)The suggestion that motorists be charged admission to this university city has received an adverse response and will probably be rejected.

title: Correction
description: In the article A Critical Guide to Ballet Recordings [Nov. 21], the music for Symphony in C should have been attributed to Bizet, rather than Stravinsky, whose Symphony in C was used by John Clifford for a ballet called Stravinsky: Symphony in C. Recommended recordings of Bizet's score are Marriner's on Argo ZRG719, and Beecham's budget version on Seraphim S60192.

title: CLASSY TRANSITION IS GOAL OF COLEMAN
Briton's Classic I.Q. Data Now Viewed as Fraudulent
